column2: A 58-year-old apartment house superintendent in Harlem who allegedly ran a gun-rental business for worried residents of the area was arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court and held in $15,000 bail.

A labor dispute involving union printers and Variety has resulted in the setting up of picket lines at the office of the theatrical weekly, 156 West 46th Street, and its print shop in the Bronx and Valley Stream, L. I.
Four opposition political parties agreed here today to make a joint attempt in the October parliamentary elections to unseat Golda Meir's Labor partydominated Government.
ROME, Sept. 5--Apostolic nuncios and other papal diplomats started a three-day conference today to reassess their role, problems and working methods.

Auto contract talks, which had been stalled for a week, showed signs of significant movement today when negotiators for the United Auto Workers announced the start of secret bargaining sessions with Chrysler Corporation on key economic issues.

The holders of three tickets numbered 939800 and three tickets numbered 302635 won chances at a top prize of $50,000 a year for life in the preliminary drawing yesterday for the New York State Lottery's "million-dollar summer special."
A new agency, charged with insuring that one governmental department knows what the other is doing, held its organizational meeting today in Governor Cahill's office.
President Nixon, declaring that he would veto the minimum wage bill, challenged Congress today to improve upon a "disappointing" record by enacting his "bipartisan" legislative proposals.
The Nixon Administration, in response to a request by industry, will propose tomorrow new regulations relaxing antipollution requirements.

Seven months after he was shot during a holdup in front of his home, Senator John C. Stennis came back to the Senate today. After the 72-year-old Mr. Stennis entered the chamber shortly after noon to a standing ovation, accompanied by his senior Democratic colleague from Mississippi,

The above - 90 - degree - heat wave ended yesterday for much of the metropolitan area as a cold front moved down from New England faster than expected. But temperatures remained uncomfortably high and no real relief was forecast until tomorrow.

Relatives of alleged members of the Black Liberation Army here yesterday protested what they said was "harassment" by law-enforcement authorities. Mrs. Patricia Green Moore, whose husband, Richard, was convicted in April of
A tractor struck a land mine today, killing an Ulster farmer on the border with the Irish Republic.

Any assessment of "Sasuke Against the Wind" distills itself inevitably into a balancing of the movie's magnificent black and white photography, its spectacle and its sense of period against the utter chaos of its plot.

How to da handle the trial of his chief political opponent on charges of subversion, murder and illegal possession of firearms has developed into the most awkward procedural problem President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

West Germany's equivalent of the Watergate hearings resumed today with an admission from a high Government official that he had withdrawn about $25,000 from a special political fund the day before a former member of Parliament claims he was bribed with the same amount.
When the field pulled up after the finish of the $29,350 Astarita at Belmont Park yesterday, Ron Turcotte on Raisela drew up beside Eddie Maple on Nancy G. and asked, "Wanna settle for a dead heat?"
The Sudanese Government proclaimed a state of emergency today in the wake of student demonstations and a strike threat by six major trade unions.

Smiling, even applauding, as Ken Rosewall's stinging backhanders went by him, Vijay Amritraj of India was eliminated yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $227,000 United States Open tennis championships, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3.

Ice dealers and manufacturers in the city are sadly watching potential profits melt away as the demand for ice during !the heat wave far outstrips the capacity of plants in the area to manufacture it.

Tons of New York City garbage have been dumped in the Hackensack Meadowlands in defiance of a five-day ban on out-of-state dumping, officials charged today. Five New York carters poured about 35 tons of garbage into three Kearny landfill sites yesterday despite threats of court action, according to William D. McDowell, executive director of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Corporation.
President Nixon said today that he was giving "highest priority" to achieving a Middle East settlement that would put an end to Arab threats to curtail future oil deliveries to Western countries.

The Federal grand jury investigating corruption in Maryland is expected to resume meetings next week, with indications that more indictments of local figures will be handed up before any action is taken on Vice President Agnew's case, sources close to the investigation said today.

President Nixon acted yesterday to reassure the country that it has a functioning President-not one so sunk in Watergate that he has neither time nor appetite for leadership on the urgent business of government.

Hundreds of thousands of pupils got an extended summer vacation today as teachers struck in cities and towns around the country. In Detroit, the nation's fifthlargest school district, officials had hoped to open schools for at least half a day tor the 280,000 pupils there despite a walkout by the 10,500 teachers.
John D. Ehrlichman and three other former White House aides have been named defendants in the secret indictments for the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former.
Aficionados of the recent wave of martial-arts movies can take comfort in the knowledge that the latest arrival, "Lady Kung-Fu," displays adequate reverence for the form they first knew and loved.

The height requirement will be dropped from the physical test and questions regarded by some as culturally biased will be screened out of the written test in a new Police Department qualifying examination in an effort to end bias against women and against members of racial minority groups.
The most comprehensive Picasso show since the master's death last spring was officially opened tonight in the unusual setting of the French Communist party's giant annual country fair here.

The City Planning Commission set the stage yesterday for the city's acceptance of a controversial $150,000 gift from Bloomingdale's department store for alterations in the area around the Naumberg Bandshell in Central Park.

Three Black Muslims were arrested today on charges of kidnapping a policeman as they conducted their own investigation into the slaying of their leader, James Shabazz, who was shot to death in the driveway of his home yesterday.
The Bowmar Instrument Corporation introduced yesterday a "pocket-sized" calculator priced at $59 and aimed specifically at housewives and students at about the junior high school level.

Teachers went on strike today in two Westchester County suburban areas, the wealthy white Harrison School District and the poorer integrated Greenburgh Central 7 District outside the city of White Plains.
The nude body of a young woman found floating in South River here yesterday with her hands bound behind her back was identified today as that of a 28-year-old teacher from Lakewood.
Cape May placed liens today on six city blocks owned by its largest property owner and taxpayer, the Rev. Carl McIntire.

Roy S. Durstine Jr., formerly vice president of Roy S. Dur?ine, Inc., an advertising agency, and president and publisher of Who's Who in Advertising, Inc., died yesterday of Hodgkin's disease at his home, 226 East Sixth Street. He was 38 years old.

Dr, Michael T. McNichols, a physician specializing in rheumatology who had practiced here, died Wednesday after a heart attack in the South Shore division in Rockaway of Long Island Jewish Medical Center.
A Federal Court judge dismissed a suit here yesterday that had alleged fraud in the sale of apartments in the Coop City housing development in the Bronx.

A mystery woman, so beautiful she made heads turn in shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, helped call attention to the questionable wagering patterns that touched off a Federal investigation of the superfecta here.
G. D. Searle Co. has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Will Ross, Inc., in an exchange of stock valued at $215.9-million, the two makers of health-care products announced yesterday.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass.--In the big, pale yellow living room, with the tall rose bushes and the ocean outside it, nothing speaks of what Lillian Hellman calls the "fat, loose, wild" years of her life.
John Schroeder and Grier Jones tied for the lead with four others, all with three- under- par 67's, after the first round today of the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.

On the eve of his debut as a college football coach, Joe Morrison displayed the cautious pessimism he picked up from his coaches during 14 years with the football Giants. His team, the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, opens against Eastern Kentucky, but then goes on to play such schools as Vanderbilt and Auburn.
Plans to build condominium apartments on a 26-acre site owned by Robert H. Abplanalp, the millionaire industrialist, were presented here tonight at a meeting of the Planning Board in Village Hall.

Television went to the Museum of Modern Art last night in the form of a preview screening of a new 13week series called "A for Art." The project will be seen, beginning this Sunday, not on commercial television or even public TV, but on cable television.

Two gunmen tried to hold up a massage parlor known as the Tender Touch at 136 East 58th Street, near Lexington Avenue, but they found it wasn't an easy touch. They fired three shots at Pio Matos, a uniformed guard, without hitting him and then fled when the guard returned the fire. He told the police he thought he had wounded one of the gunmen. .... A taxicab company mechanic was

Peter G. Peterson, the former Secretary of Commerce, said today that the United States could protect its future oil supplies and the value of the dollar by helping Middle Eastern countries "restructure their societies."

The Consumers Power Company said today it would close its Palisades nuclear power plant near South Haven, Mich., for about three months while the company conducts tests and cleaning of the steam generating system.

A panel of three judges was named yesterday to hear an appeal by defense lawyers seeking to delay the obstruction-of-justice trial of former. Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.

Six persons were rescued yesterday after being lost at sea for three days. William Carlton, 23 years old, a Nantucket policeman, and five relatives were picked up by a Coast Guard helicopter yesterday and flown to Nantucket Cottage Hospital where they were examined and released.
John M. Steinmuller, a planning consultant for Allied Stores, Inc., who had been a mechanical engineer for the concern, died Friday at his home here. He was 79 years old. old.

The city is beginning a 10week crash medical screening program for welfare clients receiving aid to dependent children, hoping to be able to reclassify thousands as "disabled" and thus save the city and state up to $12.5-million each next year.
The 35th annual standardbred horse sales concluded its three-day session today with a record average price of $12,423. Reports

Carol Hofmann, former United States Equestrian Team star, rode two jumper winners and almost captured a third class today at the opening session of the fourday North Shore Horse Show at the Oldfield Club.
Several of the country's largest retail chains reported yesterday increased sales in August over the same 1972 month, following similar reports by other retail concerns last week.
Chrysler Corporation's proposals on working conditions look "more sour," now than they did when first presented, Douglas Fraser, vice president of the United Auto Workers Union, said today.

United States business plans a strong increase in investment in plant and equipment in the final two quarters of this year after only a modest growth in actual investment in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Senate watergate committee has asked about 100 corporations, selected at random, to tell whether they made illegal contributions during the 1972 Presidential campaign.

SWEETNESS AND LIGHT Next week the evenings on Christopher Street in Greenwich Village will brighten up considerably, not a moment too soon for James Caras. Mr. Caras is co-owner of the Li-Lac Candy Store - the oldest candy store in the city, he says-just across the

Two weeks of intensive investigation by a pair of Bronx detectives led to the arrest last night of a man who will be arraigned this morning on a charge of murdering a 23-yearold psychotherapist with a sword.
A White House official said today that the next round of Soviet-American talks on limitation of strategic arms would begin on Sept. 24 in Geneva.

Mrs. Sheila Krinsky, a graduate student in counseling at Columbia University, and Henry Ebel, an associate professor in the Division of Humanities at Richmond College of the City University of New York, were married, at the Municipal Building here this afternoon by Mayor Burt Ross.

Rick deMont, who had to return a gold medal he won last year, won another one tonight in the world swimming championships and broke a world record in doing it. His feat was the first of four world marks bettered tonight.

District Attorney Jim Garrison listened intently in Federal District Court today to tape recordings purportedly linking him to an alleged bribery scheme involving New Orleans policemen and pinball machine owners.

Prime Minister Heath will go to Ireland on Sept. 17 for a day's talk with Liam Cosgrave, the Irish Prime Minister. It will be the first official visit of a British leader to the Republic since it was founded 51 years ago.
Winning numbers drawn on Sept. 6 were: NEW YORK 030860 Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000.

The Federal Reserve System intervened repeatedly in the New York foreign-exchange market in July, selling the equivalent of $273-million in foreign exchange acquired through swap drawings on the central banks of West Germany, France and Belgium, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

Business loans at New York City banks, after declining for three weeks in a row, increased during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday in a preliminary report.

Governor Rockefeller intends to use public-opinion polling on an international basis and hold public hearings throughout the United States and possibly abroad as part of an ambitious study of the nation's future.

Energy officials in the Nixon Administration disclosed today that the Government might have to restrict the amount of oil that could be burned by individual consumers, including that used in private homes.

On the eve of his debut as a college football coach, Joe Morrison displayed the cautious pessimism he picked up from his coaches during 14 years with the football Giants. His team, the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, opens against Eastern Kentucky, but then goes on to play such schools as Vanderbilt and Auburn.

The Senate Watergate committee apparently lost today its last chance to gain access to President Nixon's White House tape recordings in time for its final series of hearings to reflect any secrets the tapes contain.

Temperatures continued to moderate over the metro. politan area yesterday and, for the first time since the heat wave began early last week, Consolidated Edison reported virtually no heat-related problems.

The Yankees helped two title-contending teams last night by trading Felipe and Matty Alou, then helped their own cause by defeating the Milwaukee Brewers, 8-6. The decisive hit was a three-run homer by Mike Hegan.

The City Planning Commission unanimously approved the creation of a special interim preservation district in the Clinton area of Manhattan where the new convention center is to be built. The special district,
Sotheby Parke Bernet will initiate in mid-September an unprecedented policy of guaranteeing the authenticity of the art works it sells, a spokesman said yesterday.

Richard J. Sullivan, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, today forecast that $3.3 billion, including Federal funds, would have to be spent on public water-pollution-control facilities by 1977 on the basis of an anticipated 50 per cent rise in the state's population.
A band of Palestinian gunmen who had occupied the Saudi Arabian Embassy here since Wednesday morning left yesterday on a Syrian airliner, taking with them five Saudi hostages tied hand and foot.

John McKay, the Uniyersity of Southern California football coach, may have done a big favor for an alumnus of San Diego State. The alumnus is a linebacker, Bill Ferguson, the New York Jets' fourth-round draft choice this year.

A special report to the State Commission of Correction says that the atmosphere at the state prison at Napanoch "is extremely tense and an incident of almost any proportion could cause an explosive situation."

William D. Eberle, President Nixon's chief trade envoy, said yesterday in Washington that next week's ministeriallevel trade talks in Tokyo would give a "political impetus" to detailed negotiations in 1974.
When the baseball experts were making their predictions of the 1973 pennant races, the Houston Astros, a 1962 expansion club, was mentioned prominently.

A family fun tournament, known as the Eastern States Industrial Recreation Association softball championships, opens here Saturday on 12 fields and will run, with a short break for sleep, for the next 30 hours or so.

The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 5.5 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. Truck tonnage last week was 1.8 per cent above the immediately preceding week.

Douglas G. MacAgy, who as curator of exhibitions at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden of the Smithsonian Institution was preparing for the opening of its collection of h modern sculpture next spring,
W. A. Boyle, the deposed former president of the United Mine Workers of America, was arrested and charged with murder today in the 1969 killing of Joseph A. Yablonski.

SAN MATEO, Calif.--Since most of the Watergate testimony is now in, and the President has again stated his case, perhaps it is time for an additional perspective. My own frame of reference is built on long friendship with Mr. Nixon and whatever insight and understanding of his character I have gained from my association with him.

Five men have been indicted and 10 other persons have been arrested in connection with the Federal investigation of alleged fixed superfecta harness horse races at New York tracks, according to Federal court records in Brooklyn.

The Senate Watergate committee apparently lost today its last chance to gain access to President Nixon's White House tape recordings in time for its final series of hearings to reflect any secrets the tapes contain.

The Boston Edison Company yesterday said it planned to sell 1 million additional shares of common stock with a $10 par value and 400,000 shares of a fourth series of cumulative preferred with a $100 par value. The offerings are planned,
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 196.6 from 205.1 last week.

When President Nixon's lawyers, appealing Judge John J. Sirica's demand for the Presidential tapes, argue their case next week, they will appear before a court whose reputation for liberalism and innovation is unmatched by any in the country.

Arthur Loewengart, a leather manufacturer who founded Loewengart Co, in Germany in 1925 and re-established his business here in 1937, died Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla. Since his retirement, he had lived there and in Shavei Zion, Israel. He was 74 years old.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 196.6 from 205.1 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 122.4 on Sept. 5, 1972.
With tainted shellfish being blamed as the main source of Italy's cholera outbreak, the destruction of mussel beds was begun today in the bay of Naples.

Because of the considerable popularity of Secretariat, the habit-forming properties of television and the enduring charm of a quarter of a million dollars, the biggest horse race still on the calendar for 1973 is the invitation handicap in which Secretariat and Riva Ridge are expected to oppose other winners like Key to the Mint, Cougar II, Onion, Tentam and Annibilate 'Fm at Belmont a week from tomorrow.

The United Paperworkers International Union said today that a "major breakthrough" had been achieved in the labortroubled Eastern Canadian paper industry with a tentative two-year agreement reached yesterday between the Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd.
Several of the country's largest retail, chains reported yesterday increased sales in August over the same 1972 month, following similar reports by other retail concerns last week.

Mrs. Brenda Huff of New York and Dr. William Henry Everett, an internist here and chief of the department of medicine at the North Adams Regional Hospital, were married this afternoon at the home of Prof. and Mrs. Dudley W. R. Bahlman. Professor Bahlman is dean of the faculty and professor of history at Williams College.

The Skylab 2 astronauts, delving into the mysteries of the sun's energy, photographed today the aftermath of a solar explosion more than 100 million times as powerful as the San Francisco earthquake of 1906.

Some new evidence on familiar questions: On Sept. 9, 1971, the four-day uprising at, Attica prison began. The fifteen minutes of state police shotgun and rifle fire that ended it on Sept. 13 took 39 lives, including those of nine corrections workers, and wounded more than eighty others.
When Gordie Howe went recently for a check-up to see whether, at the age of 45, he could return to hockey, the doctor told Howe everything was fine.
Dr. Lucile Kohn, a retired teacher who was formerly chairman of the American Labor Education Service, died Wednesday at her home, 1138 Madison Avenue. She was 90 years old.

The Watergate grand jury is investigating a secret $100,000 donation to President Nixon's political campaign made by officials of a Cleveland ship company while the concern was trying, without success, to win payment of a $5-million overrun on a Government contract.
East New York School District 19 in Brooklyn has lost $965,000 in Federal aid because it refused to set up separate math and reading tests for black and Puerto Rican children.
The state Supreme, Court, citing the Federal Government's "constitutional authority over interstate commerce," ruled unconstitutional yesterday the city's $3 tax on departing airline passengers.

A State Superior Court judge today enjoined picketing firemen against disrupting the Miss America Pageant at Convention Hall, and soon after the injunction was served the firemen packed up their placards and left the site.
W. A. Boyle, the deposed former president of the United Mine Workers of America, was arrested and charged with murder today in the 1969

Prime Minister Heath is often clumsy in dealing with the agony of Northern Ireland; but he is on target with his warning that delay in setting Ulster's new political machinery in motion can only jeopardize its effectiveness, play into the hands of both Protestant and Catholic extremists and result in "more lives lost, more maimed and more wounded."

City Council President Sanford D. Garelik's disclosure that a New York City drug treatment program has been recruiting narcotics addicts from out of state underscores the total inadequacy of present record-keeping and auditing procedures. This outreach practice should never have been allowed. It would not have been if the Addiction Services Agency had adequately performed its task of reviewing on-going drug programs.

Peters Eglits, a former president of the bar in his native Latvia and president emeritus of the Latvian Lutheran Church in this country, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 203 East 82nd Street.

OTTAWA -- H. Anthony Hampson, the soft-spoken chief executive officer of the Canada Development Corporation, talking to businessmen not too long ago, remarked that the staff of C.D.C. was small-15 in all.
Attorney General Frank J. Kelley said today that he had filed a petition with the Supreme Court asking for an immediate review of the Detroit school desegregation case.

The White House said today that if the Secret Service had wiretapped the telephone of F. Donald Nixon, the President's brother, it would have been "related to the protectivefunction of the Secret Service."

Despite President Nixon's assertion that he was giving "highest priority" to a Middle East settlement, Administration officials and diplomats said today that they saw little likelihood of any break soon in the ArabIsrael impasse.
Senator Harold E. Hughes, 51 -year-old Iowa Democrat, said today that he would leave the Senate when his first term expires next year to accept a "'compelling commitment" to do religious work.
The Pittsburgh Pirates relieved Bill Virdon as manager today and brought Danny Murtaugh back from the front office to finish the season in Virdon's place.
The Japanese police today intensified their public allegations that South Korean officials abducted a Korean opposition leader here last month.

A mystery woman, so beautiful she made heads turn in shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, helped call attention to the questionable wagering patterns that touched off a Federal investigation of the superfecta here.

Louis H. Wilson, an aide to Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, died last night at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 65 years old. Mr. Wilson joined the Agriculture Department two years ago as a special assistant to the then Secretary Clifford M. Hardin. Before joining the department Mr. Wilson was for nearly 25 years an executive with the Fertilizer Institute, a trade organization.
The recent upturn in corporate bond prices faltered a bit in early trading yesterday but seasoned issues recovered before the end of the day and closedd firm.
A retired san Francisco accountant was said this week to have won $65,093 in what Harolds Club officials call the world's largest slot machine Dayoff.
A panel of prominent lawyers recommended today that the District of Columbia legalize the numbers game to serve as a model for the nation.
Prices rose yesterday in moderately active trading on the American Stock Exchange. The over-the-counter market also was firmer on substantially higher volume.
Cape May placed liens today on six city blocks owned by its largest property owner and taxpayer, the Rev. Carl McIntire.

Ten guards held hostage by inmates at the Stateville Penitentiary for more than nine hours today were released tonight when Illinois state policemen threatened to enter the inmates' cellblock with tear gas.

Government and Communist troops battled for 19 hours along the defense perimeter protecting the provincial capital of Kontum yesterday and more heavy fighting was reported 75 miles to the east on the central coast.

The new television season that gets under way Monday will be replete with the usual meat-and-potatoes fare such as "Marcus Welby," Archie Bunker, and "Ironside," but it also shows promise of giving hefty servings of truly special "specials."

State Senaor John J. Marchi's mayoral campaign coordinator resigned yesterday in a disagreement with Senator Marchi over strategy, finances and the influence of United States Senator James L. Buckley's aides in the campaign.
Warren J. Martin, a partner in the admiralty law firm of Martin Ryan, died of cancer Wednesday at his home, 18 Walworth Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 54 years old.

Egil Krogh Jr., former White House aide, entered a plea of, not guilty immediately after his surrender today in Los Angeles for arraignment on charges stemming from his alleged participation in a burglary scheme to obtain Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatric files.
" Tamu-Tamu," a two-act chamber opera composed, written and directed by Gian Carlo Menotti, had its world premiere at the Studebaker Theater here last night.
Senator Harold E. Hughes, 51-year-old Iowa Democrat, said today that he would leave the Senate when his first term expires next year to accept a "compelling commitment" to do religious work.

Television station WABC will inaugurate an hour-long Sunday evening "Eyewitness News" program, beginning at 6 P.M. on Sept. 16. It will be the city's only hour-long early evening news report on Sundays.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., showed a sharp recovery in the three and six months ended June 30, lifting sales and profits to records for the periods, according to midyear results announced yesterday.

Because the transcript of a television interview was misinterpreted, The New York Times erred yesterday in describing a disagreement between an informer who testified at the Gainsville Eight trial and a woman who accused him of having been an agent provacateur.

President Nixon's decision to veto the bill for an overdue increase in the Federal minimum wage imposes on the country's working poor the grossly unfair burden of having to wait - no one knows how long - for statutory relief from the huge bite inflation is taking out of their already depressed living standards.
A squadron of F105 jets whose sophisticated radar once sought out North Vietnamese missile sites left today to begin the second phase of American withdrawals from Thailand.

It's the normal and prudent rule of power and politics that you never try to fight more than one battle at a time, even when you're fighting from a position of strength; but President Nixon is back in Washington, weak, breathless and defiant, fighting on three fronts at the same time.

Savings Bond redemptions hit a new high in August, the Treasury Department said today, as bond holders apparently cashed in their Government securities in favor of competing investments offering higher interest rates.

When the Giants' orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Anthony Pisani, gave Larry Jacobson the good news that his injured foot would be healed in time for the regular-season opener Sept. 16, the defensive tackle wasn't at all satisfied.
International joint - venture projects that might require outlays in excess of $1-billion were announced yesterday. The projects are envisioned for South Korea and Saudi Arabia.
The dispute between President Nixon and Congress intensified today. While Mr. Nixon vetoed the minimum wage bill and sought the support of Republican leaders for his legislation,
After 23 years, the United Nations Commission on Unification of Korea recommended its own liquidation today in a report to Secretary General Waldheim.
Garret S. Nagle, who retired in 1961 as assistant vice president of the Reynolds Metals Company, died Wednesday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 79 years old.
The public recantation by two Soviet dissidents has renewed the issue of political confessions that was dramatized by Arthur Koestler in his 1940 novel "Darkness at Noon."

The board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday authorized its chairman, James J. Needham, to continue discussions with the Pacific Stock Exchange about a possible affiliation between the two groups.

The dispute between President Nixon and Congress intensified today. While Mr. Nixon vetoed the minimum wage bill and sought the support of Republican leaders for his legislation, the Democratic leadership issued- a statement taking sharp issue with his assertion yesterday that Congress so far this year had turned in "a very disappointing performance."
The arrival of seasonably cool weather will, if it persists, do much to improve inshore marine angling.

Fresh sualls in the currency markets, touched off by heavy selling of the pound, were at least temporarily halted today as the major Western nations declared their willingness to guarantee London deposits of sterling area countries for six more months.

The Exxon Company U.S.A. raised its wholesale gasoline prices yesterday by one cent a gallon. However, most service station owners will have to absorb the increased cost because retail gasoline prices are frozen through today and then become subject to ceiling prices already established under Phase 4.
The warn wings from Soviet intellectuals against mounting internal re pression amid the improvement in East-West relations have provoked embarrassment and concern in the French Communist party.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Egg rolls Walnut chicken* Fried rice Almond cookies and sherbet
The K.G.B. is celebrating a victory over an exhausted man-Pyotr Yakir. This man has been exhausted by almost fifteen years in Stalin's labor camps; he was first confined when he was fourteen.

With few exceptions, cities all across this country are witnessing a familiar, but no less vicious, cycle in the fortunes of their mass transit systems: rising costs and fares, loss of passengers, reduced net income, deterioration, loss of more passengers and finally a slide into hopeless decay.

Controller Abraham D. Beame, observing with no apparent sign of real concern that "overconfidence" could cripple his mayoral campaign, spelled out with considerable precision yesterday the first three things he would do if he is elected as New York City's 104th Mayor.
Government sources said that President Nixon would nominate John R. Bartels Jr. as permanent administrator of the recently created Drug Enforcement Administration.

The record for the biggest tournament was held by Chicago for eight years. The 1965 total of 14,511 tables stood until a month ago, when the Summer Nationals in Washington came up with a staggering figure of 16,044 tables.

The State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had granted $164.5million of the $183-million increase in electricity rates requested by the Consolidated Edison Company. This is $69.2million above the temporarily increased rates now in effect.

Dairy leaders estimated yesterday that a sharp, Federally ordered increase in milk prices to be paid to farmers would require a 2-cent-a-quart rise for consumers in the New YorkNorthern New Jersey' area.

Representatives of the New York City Opera and its striking musicians made some progress yesterday in their first bargaining since the walkout began seven days ago, a mediator named by Mayor Lindsay reported last night.
The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 5.5 per cent above the corresponding week of last year.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

THE ONION FIELD. By Joseph Wambaugh. 427 pages. Delacorte. $8.95 Perhaps there are readers out there who will be able to race through Joseph Wambaugh's "The Onion Field" completely caught up by its narrative drive and utterly vulnerable to its shocks and twists.

The novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn asserted today that a Leningrad woman had been driven to suicide after five days of continuous questioning by the secret police concerning the whereabouts of a major underground manuscript he wrote.

The faculty of Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., has approved a three-year contract that provides a 5.5 per cent across-the-board increase in the firs year. The contract, which would be retroactive to Seit. 1, is expected to be approved by the Board of Trustees next Wednesday.

The State Commission of Investigation will begin public hearings Wednesday on complaints official mishandling of Federal surplus property, violations of state bidding laws and the conversion of public property and services for private use.
The Senate passed a bill today to authorize continued Federal financing of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty. The 76-to-10 vote sent the hill to the House of Representatives.

The White House said today that if the Secret Service had wiretapped the telephone of F. Donald Nixon, the President's brother, it would have been "related to the protectivefunction of the Secret Service."
The Agriculture Department will soon begin disclosing information on 1974 crop prospects under a new policy aimed at giving farmers an even break with big commodity traders.
A band of Palestinian gunmen who had occupied the Saudi Arabian Embassy here since Wednesday morning left yesterday on a Syrian airliner, taking with them five Saudi hostages tied hand and foot.

The State Racing and Wagering Board will by the end of this month appoint an over-all director of security for the state's race tracks, Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., chairman of the two-monthold board, said yesterday.
Despite repeated announcements to Congress that a sweeping new Federal housing program would be submitted today, the Nixon Administration postponed disclosing the proposal until next week.
The Dow-Jones industrial average forged back above the 900 level yesterday with a 1.96 point advance that stretched the rally from this year's Aug. 22 low to nearly 50 points.

With enemy troops pouring into the provincial capital of Kompong Cham, the Phnom Penh Government mounted an emergency helicopter lift of reinforcements to the embattled city today but the situation was reported to be growing more serious by the hour.

One song can do it. The singer Gilbert O'Sullivan, who arrives for his first American concert at Philharmonic Hall on Sept. 21, wrote "Alone Again (Naturally)." Recording the song, O'Sullivan had a big hit single and a big hit album.
The Senate voted today to forbid television blackouts of professional sports events that are sold out 72 hours in advance.

The Knicks opened their rookie training camp today with the unwelcome news that Earl Monroe had entered St. Anthony's Hospital in Oklahoma City and would undergo surgery tomorrow for the removal of bone spurs in his

Edgar Winter brought an immediate hyperthyroid, chair-standing, overexcited response from the sell-out audience at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Wednesday--it expressed neatly the cliff-hanging joy of rock 'n' roll, good times but a short fuse.

It was a hot-and-cold day at the United States Open tennis championship in Forest Hills yesterday. Advancing to the semifinals of the men's singles were a hot Stan Smith over a cold Onny Parun, 6-3, 6-3, 6-2, and Jan Kodes over a cold-and-hot Nikki Pilic, 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 3-6, 7-5.

John McKay, the University of Southern California football coach, may have done a big favor for, an alumnus of San Diego State. The alumnus is a linebacker, Bill Ferguson, the New York Jets' fourth-round draft choice this year.

The American Basketball Association has picked Mike Storen as its new commissioner and will announce the action at a news conference here today, The Associated Press learned last night. Robert Carlson announced his resignation earlier yesterday as A.B.A. commissioner after a meeting of the league's trustees in Chicago.

Ladies, if you are heavy users of decaffeinated coffee and upset-stomach remedies you might well be drudges. If, however, you are big purchasers of paper towels you might be entitled to classify yourselves as striving suburbanites.
The Nixon Administration joined Senate liberals today in calling for repeal of 1971 legislation exempting Rhodesia's chrome industry from a United States trade embargo.

Miss Ellen Gail Cohen was married here last evening to David F. Stein, a vice president in the international deapartment of Kuhn, Loeb Co. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

The Consumers Power Company said today it would close its Palisades nuclear power plant near South Haven, Mich., for about three month while the company conduct. tests and cleaning of the steam generating system.

To the Editor: There is not enough gasoline in all the world to feed the appetite for power in oversized cars. There never will be enough. If your car consumes a gallon of gasoline every eight, ten, twelve, fourteen, etc., miles, it's a subversive, unpatriotic machine, dedicated to the economic overthrow of this great country.
The House passed yesterday a greatly expanded flood insurance plan that gives the Federal Government more power in getting communities to conform to safe zoning laws.

The Environmental Protection Agency issued its revised air pollution plans today and insisted that the proposal would not cause widespread power blackouts in the country, as had been charged by environmentalists.
The New York State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had granted $164.5-million of the $183-million increase in electricity rates the Consolidated Edison Company had sought.

Military officials said that a rocket body from a Soviet satellite burned on re-entry into the earth's atmosphere last night causing star gazers in Texas, New Mexico and Colorado to report seeing a fireball streaking across the sky.
Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.
After dropping the permissible daily limits for the previous two sessions, prices of agricultural commodity futures ranged widely yesterday.
The Agriculture Department will soon begin disclosing information on 1974 crop prospects under a new policy aimed at giving farmers an even break with big commodity traders.

The nude body of a young woman found floating in South River here yesterday with her hands bound behind her back was identified today as that of a 28-year-old teacher from Lakewood.

The heart of it all is the land. The rolling green hills, the centuries-old Maryland farms, the seashores, the suburban escape from the concrete and brick reality of Baltimore and Washington - it is land that has made millionaires of skillful real estate developers.
Many of the old people who shop at the A. P. at First Avenue and 90th Street stand in front of the meat cases for long periods of time, like children gazing through a toy store window.
An authoritative study reported today that despite the Soviet-American agreement on arms limitation there is little evidence that the superpower arms race has slackened.

The Court of Claims judges appointed by Governor Rockefeller to handle narcotics trials under the state's stringent new drug law will undergo close' scrutiny by the State Senate's' Judiciary Committee before they are formally confirmed, Senator Bernard G. Gordon, chairman of the committee, said yesterday.
A political scientist from the Pacific Northwest has told the American Political Science Association here that integrated schools may retard the political growth of blacks.

Mrs. Edward (Laura) Hubbard of South Natick, Mass. grand. father of Renee, Carolina Gillian Amory of N.Y.C. The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company said today that it signed formal contracts with Sonatrach, the Algerian national petroleum company, for importation of 3.3 trillion cubic feet of liquefied natural gas from Algeria over a 20-year period.

The basic story line of President Nixon's new scenario, as revealed at his Wednesday news conference, is that he has put Watergate behind him and is turning his full attention to "the business of the people." Welcome as is the President's decision to come alive again on his day-to-day responsibilities, his script contains one major flaw. It treats as either/or propositions two quite distinct issues confronting the Presidency.
A 39-year-old Canadian minister on a visit here was stabbed four times, punched, kicked, thrown to the ground and robbed of $30 as he walked yesterday through Morningside Park.

Hunter College decided to hold freshman orientation--usually a notoriously ho-hum affair held at the school--aboard a Staten Island ferry boat yesterday. More than half of the 2,000 entering students turned out.

The occupation of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Paris ended as five Palestinian commandos accompanied by five Saudi hostages bound hand and foot were put on a Syrian airliner for a negotiated escape. The French Government softened its policy against submitting to terrorist blackmail after the commandos released three French women and a Tunisian. [Page 1, Column 1.]
The two-millionmember New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. gave its support today to the $3.5-billion transportation bond issue that will go before the state's voters in the November election.

An earthquake was felt in Valdez and Anchorage early today, but no damage was immediately reported, according to the Palmer Observatory. An observatory spokesman said the quake registered 5.5 on the Richter scale and "was felt very strongly in Valdez."

All Fires the Fire, by Julio Cortazar, translated by Susanne Jill Levine (Pantheon Books, $5.95). Eight short stories. American Atlas, by Dan Gerber (Prentice-Hall, $5.95). Satiric novel about a man's efforts to become a poet.
The Government today devalued the piaster - for the fifth time this Near - to 510 to the dollar, from 500.

Former Representative J. Vaughan Gary, Democrat of Virginia, died today at a hospital here. He was 81 years old. Mr. Gary represented the Third District, which includes Richmond and a surrounding area, for 20 years. He retired in 1965 and returned to private law practice.

WASHINGTON--It is an appealing vision-an "open" foreign policy, supported by a new bipartisan consensus, As he testifies at his confirmation hearings, Henry Kissinger will try to forge the new consensus he is now promoting in public and private conversations. He wants to save foreign policy from Watergate. by rallying liberals as well as conservatives to the President's foreign policy banner.
An attorney for the widow of Senator Edward V. Long said today that a series of suits and countersuits had been settled out of court.
In Rumania, the wolf of Rome suckling Romulus and Remus is now a more relevant symbol of the country's independent spirit and nationalist ambitions than the hammer and sickle.
A State Supreme Court justice extended yesterday a temporary restraining order barring work stoppages by printers at The New York Times.
Lester Lane, who became basketball coach at Oklahoma University last spring, died yesterday after playing in a faculty basketball game. He was 41 years old.

In OTB parlors around town yesterday, the reaction to the allegations that harness-racing, superfectas had been fixed ran the gamut from ambivalence to admiration, from anger to "who the hell cares." But mostly hte frustrated bettor was simply envious.
A surprise awaited President Nixon on his return to the White House last Saturday-his bedroom had been completely redecorated.
Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, charged his Republican opponent, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., with political extremism here tonight.
Leftist guerrillas captured a military supply center today and held it in the face of a police and army siege for five hours, killing one officer and wounding two men before surrendering at dawn.

Toni Fritsch kicked a 22-yard field goal with three seconds left tonight to highlight a 20-point Dallas rally and give the Cowboys a 26-23 preseason victory over Miami in their first meeting since Super Bowl VI.
The Ford Motor Company reported today that it sold 194,615 new cars in August, off 7.9 per cent from 211,204 in the same month last year.

Sam Yorty, the former Mayor of Los Angeles, is expected to become a Republican. The conservative Democrat, who was defeated in June by Thomas Bradley, is expected to announce his decision by tomorrow. Both his wife and Gordon Luce, the G.O.P. state chairman, were quoted as saying Mr. Yorty would switch.

New Jersey's Department of Community Affairs has come to the aid of a day-care program for the children of farm workers just as the last four centers in the program were preparing to close for lack of funds.

For Daniel Safford Parker, a man born with a silver pen in his hand, his nomination yesterday to be administrator of the Agency for International Development is a natural fusing of his interests in business and in international affairs.
The House passed yesterday an Amtrak financial aid bill that would require all existing passenger train service to be continued on the basic Government-backed rail system until at least next July 1.

Miss Andrea Jean Bess, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bess of New York and South Orange, was married here today to Kevin Thomas Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Francis Hughes of South Orange and Sea Girt. The National Association of Manufacturers, stung by increasing hostility toward big business by many segments of society, is studying the possibility of initiating an Institute of American Industry, which would educate business executives on broad social, political and ethical matters.

John Schroeder, bursting into prominence after 4 1/2 years of virtual obscurity on the pro tour, shook off a double bogey on the 15th hole, a par 4, and finished with a 65 today for a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.

John D. Ehrlichman, the former Presidential adviser on domestic affairs, pleaded not guilty today to charges of burglary, conspiracy and perjury in the 1971 break-in at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

Four Americans advanced and one was eliminated today in the free-style competition at the world wrestling championships. Ben Peterson of Madison, Wis., an Olympic champion, defeated Boris Karloy of Hungary by a fall in a lightweight match. Peterson's brother, John, tied with Edbeg Abilov of Bulgaria in a middleweight contest.
The Abitibi Paper Company and the United Paper Workers International Union reached agreement today to end a strike and partly ease the supply of newsprint for United States newspapers.

A explosion in farm prices follow ing the end of the brief sum mer price freeze sent the Government's Wholesale Price In dex for August up by 5.8 percent, the Labor Department re ported today.

Chief Judge Irving R. Kaufman declared yesterday that it was "nothing less than a disgrace" that the Nixon Administration had failed to fill a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

Coxson, and a possible drug war between gangs in South Jersey and Philadelphia.

Emerging victorious after extraordinarily tense contests were the familiar names of Mrs. Margaret Court and Evonne Goolagong, both of Australia. They'll meat today in the final.

George Meany, angered by soaring prices and President Nixon's veto of the minimum wage bill, said today that the Nixon Administration had created "one of the most depressing spectacles I've ever seen."

South Vietnamese artillery opened fire before dawn today on a company of about 100 Vietcong soldiers assembling 12 miles west of Saigon, the Government announced.

Willard Marriott Jr., president, said yesterday while in Los Angeles for the opening of the company's newest hotel.

After suffering their 20th shutout last night, 5-0, to Milwaukee, the Yankees had one less game to play, which should gladden their hearts because that's how it looked like they were playing-just running out the schedule.
A cooperative of 280 kosher butcher shops has invested more than $2.5-million to buy more than 5,000 cattle since Aug. 2 to provide beef for con summers here.

Four horses jumped cleanly over all 17 fences today in the opening of the $25,000 American Gold Cup at John F. Kennedy Stadium here.
Monetary reform negotiations remained deadlocked today after a conference of high financial officials of the major Western powers failed to resolve major differences.

Archibald Cox, the Justice Deapartment's special prosecutor, asked the United States Court of Appeals today to order President Nixon to deliver White House tape recordings directly to the Watergate grand jury, without any prior judicial screening.
A Japanese district court ruled today that the nation's maintenance of military forces is unconstitutional. It was a landmark decision in the deepest and longest-running controversy in postwar Japan.

Dr. John R. Kernodle, chairman of the American Medical Association's board of trustees, and five North Carolina businessmen were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of bank fraud involving over $1.7-million.
Ernest L. Montanye, the superintendent of Attica-prison, said today that he was leaving his post to take a promotion in Albany.

Mrs. Ethel G. McAdie, who in a career of nearly 50 years advanced from secretary to vice president of a large New York advertising and publicrelations agency, died yesterday in Fort Pierce (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. She was 80 years old.
Louis F. Hanke executive vice president of Dreher Advertising in New York, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home 9 Bradford Avenue. He was 56 years old.

Canada's 1973 wheat crop, estimated at 604.4 million bushels, will be 13 per cent larger than last year's 533.3 million bushels, Statistics Canada reported today in its first estimate of this year's principal field crops.
Gil Orlovitz, prolific writer of avant-garde poetry, plays and novels, died July 10 at Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 55 years old and had lived alone in a single room at 235 West 107th Street.
Richard V. Bonomo, chairman of the board of the Schiavone-Bonomo Corporation of Jersey City, died today in Mountainside Hospital in Montclair. He was 78 years old and lived here at 40 Club Road.
Agreement on a new contract for Western Airlines pilots was reached last night minutes before a midnight strike deadline, the Air Line Pilots Association announced early today.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal urged the city yesterday to step up its programs for the preservation and maintenance of basically sound residential structures.

A six-hour negotiating session between the New York City Opera and the musicians' union that struck the opera a week ago brought what the city's mediator called "substantial progress" yesterday, but the talks broke off with no date set for their resumption and no immediate prospects for an end to the strike.

Ernest Scott, a former chancellor of the Philadelphia Bar Association, who retired a year ago as senior partner of the law firm of Pepper, Hamilton Scheetz, died today at his home in Berwyn. He was 69 years old.
The astronauts aboard Skylab 2 photographed today a sun explosion that scientists estimated was 10 times the size of the earth. The scientists called it "the brightest and biggest this year."

To the Editor: Twice in two weeks, subway trains have stalled for long periods in the sweltering East River tubes. First it was a derailment, then a cave-in.

Chauncey Depew Steele, a former hotel executive who managed the Algonquin Hotel in New York in the early nineteen-twenties and thirties, died yesterday at Mount Auburn Hospital. His age was 83, and he lived here.

The outbreak in Italy of what at the moment looks like a mini-epidemic of cholera, including a score of deaths, has had wide repercussions. Tourists are avoiding the affected areas; a mass campaign to vaccinate millions ot Italians against this disease is under way; and at all international borders, ports and airports sharp watch is being kept against the entry of travelers who might be bringing cholera infection with them from Italy.

The Soviet Union's discus star, Faina Melnik, and East Germany's javelin queen, Ruth Fuchs, broke their own world records with mighty throws tonight in the finals of the women's Europa Cup track meet.

Enric Madriguera, onetime concert violinist and a dance-orchestra leader, died today at Danbury Hospital. He was 71 years old. A native of Barcelona Spain, Mr. Madriguera graduated from that city's Liceo Conservatorie in 1915, coming to the United States a year later.

Brendan Foster of Britain won the 5,000-meter run today at the European track and field championships .as Lasse Viren of Finland, a double Olympic gold medal winner, finished fifth. Bertha Hertz registered as a new voter today at the age of 100. Mrs. Hertz, a widow, is certain she voted before, but is not certain how many years ago she cast her last vote.
Brian Kelley, a 14th-round draft choice who was born in Dallas and thought he would play pro football there, made it officially with the New York Giants yesterday.

The credit squeeze has caused a crisis in the home financing industry, the House Banking Committee was told today. "Our country is once again--for the third time in seven years--in the midst of an interest rate crisis,"
TASTES The inflationary spiral has hit many restaurants, forcing closings and the scaling down of ambitions. None has been hit harder than the Library.
Many of you ardent television viewers and some of you intense magazine readers are now aware that there is a way to take care of that suddenly remembered birthday of beloved but far-off Aunt Tillie.
Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today that he thought the nation had weathered the worst part of Watergate and the issue now had "diminished importance."

A Westinghouse scientist announced yesterday success in manufacturing a compound that becomes superconducting loses all electrical resistance--at a higher temperature than any previously developed substance.

Some 10,000 South Jersey bus riders were without their usual transportation because of a srike of the Amalgamated Transit Workers Union Local 1358 (A.F.L.-C.I.O.), whose 165 men walked off their jobs at the Atlantic City Transportation Company.

In light trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange, after opening higher, gave ground throughout most of the rest of the session yesterday to close off slightly. Prices in the overthe-counter market also were off.
G. Gordon Liddy, a convicted Watergate conspirator, was cited for contempt today by the House for refusing to take an oath as a witness before a House subcommittee.

Survived by wife Frieda, daughter Betty Booth and granddaughter Amy Booth. Services Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2:15 P.M., Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Sergei K. Tumansky, a designer of aircraft jet engines, died here yesterday. Mr. Tumansky is believed to have been responsible for the large after-burning turbojet engines installed in the MIG-23, one of the world's most advanced fighter planes.

An alternative route, to stem opposition, has been proposed by the State Urban Development Corporation for an aerial cable-car system to connect Manhattan with the new "town being developed on Roosevelt Island, formerly Welfare Island.
Three persons were killed yesterday and two others were overcome by poisonous fumes while cleaning a septic tank.Two more were hospitalized.

Benny Borgmann, a resident of this suburban area of Paterson, insists that, contrary to popular 'belief, a would-be professional athlete doesn't have to get an early starting baseball or basketball to become a star.

The Coast Guard this afternoon abandoned its search for David Post Rumbough, the 23-year-old son of Dina Merrill, the actress, and her first hushand, Stanley M. Rumbough Jr., a New York industrialist.
The world heavy-weight champion, George Foreman, indicated tonight he would make his next title defense against Jerry Quarry in the first week of November.
Talks between Czechoslovakia and the United States about the settlement of mutual financial claims opened in Prague today, C.T.K., the official press agency, reported.
Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is expected to travel to the Aspen Institute for .Humanistic Studies in Colorado this month to accept the Institute's Statesman-Humanist Award.
Diplomats say China has been pressing Western European countries to strengthen their ties with one another and to man their defenses against the Russians.

Contract negotiations aimed at averting a threatened shutdown Thursday of the Radio City Music Hall will be held at 2 P.M. today at the offices of the. State Mediation Board in the World Trade Center.

A few hours after President Nixon's latest "state of the union" message arrived in Congress, Senate Democraticleaders met today to begin drawing up their own list of "must" legislation to be passed in the next few weeks.
Teachers manned picket lines instead of classrooms yesterday in strikes in the metropolitan area and around the country that have kept about 800,000 pupils from starting their fall school terms.
A group of papal diplomats concluded in a three-day conference last week that Peking was emerging as an international power center much more rapidly than Vatican assessments had foreseen.

In the five-day meeting of a major part of the underdeveloped world that ended here yesterday, the industrial nations were repeatedly denounced as economic imperialists and pillagers of-the resources of the poor.

The Zapata Corporation directors authorized yesterday a cash tender offer for 1,500,000 shares, about 29 per cent of outstanding shares, of the company's common stock at $25 a share. The offer will expire on Sept. 26.

Federal District Judge Vincent P. Biunno today rejected a move by the Passaic County Technical and Vocational High School to bar hearings by the State Commission of Investigation into allegations of corruption and improprieties in the operation of the institution.

William A. Keegan, a former member of the Hudson County Park Commission, was severed as a defendant today in the trial of John J. Kenny and five other county officials or private citizens on charges of conspiracy to permit use of county parkland as a landfill operation for private profit.
Hank Aaron hit his 710th career home run tonight, moving within four of Babe Ruth's record 714, as the Atlanta Braves defeated the San Francisco Giants, 10-4.
In the first day of trading after meat ceilings were removed there was no change in live cattle ales at stockyards in the Middle West today, but the wholesale price of choice beef here rose sharply.

The Genuine Parts Company, an independent distributor of automotive replacement parts, is making an offer to acquire Acklands, Ltd., Canada, for stock valued at about $75-million, it was disclosed yesterday. Acklands distributes automotive parts and industrial and consumer goods.

The Defense Department acknowledged today that United States fighter-bombers flew air strikes in support of the Cambodian Government in 1970 and 1971, with the attacks kept secret through a system of dual reports.

The more credit-worthy developing countries may have raised as much as $8-billion in loans on the Eurodollar and other "Eurocurrency" markets last year, the International Finance corporation reported today.
The Foreign Ministry said today that it had received official confirmation of Cuba's diplomatic break with Israel, and expressed regrets at the mole.

More than any other group of men and women, scientists live with the terrifying knowledge of humanity's precarious balance on the edge of self-destruction. An awareness of awesome risks, together with their own responsibility in creating them, leads scientists at times to reach across national boundaries to appeal to the conscience of men of power.
A plan to increase the Police Department's effectiveness with $3.5-million in overtime and to expand fivefold the use of crime-prevention devices in stores was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

One of the most devastating schemes ever advanced for a national park now looms ominously over Grand Teton, Wyo., in the form of a proposed $2.2-million jetport. Last year Congress appropriated funds which may but do not have to be used to expand an existing small airport within the park.

Three-month Treasury bills sold yesterday at a rate slightly above 9 per cent, a record high, in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's action on Friday increasing reserve requirements on large certificates of deposit.
On the eve of his sentencing for embezzling more than $1.2million from his client, Allen Funt, creator of Candid Camera, Seymour Goldes, an accountant, apparently committed suicide.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines pardoned 249 convicts today, the eve of his 56th birthday, and urged Filipinos to help him build a new society.

The House Ways and Means Committee, acting on President Nixon's trade bill, agreed tentatively today to give the President temporary authority to lower barriers to imports as a means of combating inflation. Under the committee's formula, the President could reduce tariffs or enlarge quotas for up to 150 days during times of rapidly rising prices.
The nation's airlines in July registered a 22 per cent increase in domestic air freight revenue ton miles compared with the same month in 1972, the Air Transport Association said today.
Rod Laver has agreed to play for Australia against Czechoslovakia in the Davis Cup semifinal at Melbourne in November.

Shoppers found beef prices generally unchanged here and throughout the country yesterday on the first day Federal price ceilings were removed. However, many retailers remained uncertain on what would happen next.

Tom Weiskopf, fresh from victory in the World Series of Golf, in Akron, Ohio, now is looking eagerly to the Ryder Cup matches in Muirfield, Scotland, Sept. 20-22. Weiskopf, on Sunday, shot a 66 for a 36-hole total of 137 to beat Jack Nicklaus and Johnny Miller by three strokes. Tommy Aaron was 12 strokes-back.
The Skylab 2 astronauts melted two crystals in space today in an experiment that scientists said might help man to use solar power, build nearly pollution-free engines and make steel stronger.
President Nixon's re-election campaign had a cash balance on Aug. 31 of $4-million, the Finance Committee to Re-Elect the President reported today.
The Government authorized the steel industry today to make a two-stage, $400-million-a-year increase in prices of sheet and strip steel.

The overly long exhibition season has finally ended for the football mercenaries, and they will begin playing for keeps this weekend. The preliminary head-knocking has lent itself to all sorts of interpretations over the years, and some of the speculation even has the ring of validity to it. For the most part, though, it's like reading tea leaves. The coaches-and maybe even the fans-see in them whatever they want to see.

Since the English Stage Company took over the Royal Court Theater in the mid-nineteen fifties, it has been the seedbed for some of the most exhilarating offerings of the British theater.

Bruno Morpurgo Morel, president of Distillerie Stock U. S. A. of New York, distributors of brandy and vermouth, died Saturday at his summer home on Fire Island. He was 63 years old and lived at 860 Fifth Avenue.

Officials of the various striped-bass fishing derbies held annually in the fall along the East Coast could perform a public service this year by asking participants to cooperate with a Striped Bass Fund research project now under way.

The Old Stone Savings Bank, Rhode Island's largest savings bank, with assets of $653-million, received permission yesterday from the state's Board of Bank Incorporation to convert into a stockholder-owned commercial bank.
Peter Brook and members of his company from the International Center for Theater Research, which is based in Paris, will open a five-week work period today at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
A stunt pilot practicing maneuvers for the National Aerobatic Championships was killed yesterday when he lost control of his single-engine plane and it smashed into a field, the authorities said.
A tightly deadlocked election threatened to perpetuate the political instability that has prevailed in Norway ever since she rejected entry into the Common Market last year.
Mrs. Billie Jean King was taken to a hospital in Hilton Head, S. C., for blood tests yesterday after complaining of feeling ill.
Hundreds of millions of dollars were slashed off share prices in Australia and New Zealand today as stock markets reacted to yesterday's upward revaluation of the two countries' dollars.

The issue of busing to achieve school integration, which has been lying dormant in the halls of Congress during the last few months, was raised again today by President Nixon in his second "state of the union" message.
Six African nations just south of the Sahara estimated today that their immediate and long-range aid requirements as a result of five years of drought and famine would cost $827-million.

President Nixon gives pride of place in his message to his recommendations concerning inflation and the energy problem. This is audacious strategy because in both instances he is exploiting visible problems to promote actions that will not solve the problems but will achieve objectives he has long desired on other grounds.

John Conteh of Britain wore down the former World Boxing Association champion, Vicente Rondon of Venezuela, tonight and stopped him at 1:20 of the ninth round of a scheduled 10-round lightheavyweight bout. Conteh, the European champion, staggered Rondon with a hard right to the jaw in the eighth round. Conteh dropped Rondon for a count of 7 with a left hook to the head in the ninth. Conteh waded in after Rondon regained his feet.
