At the United Nations these days much of the debate concerns Namibia, Guinea Bissau and Zimbabwe. Most Americans do not know what the disputes are about or even where Namibia, Guinea Bissau and Zimbabwe are.
The House passed and sent to President Nixon today a bill to bar advertisements of little cigars from television and radio. The measure, if signed by the President, as sponsors expect,

The Philadelphia Orchestra left today on a trip to China, where it will play seven concerts. Mayor Frank Rizzo was at International Airport to see off the musicians and their director, Eugene Ormandy.

Pontiac's general manager, Martin J. Caserio, said today the division was ready to build a sub-compact car as soon as General Motors has the extra capacity to handle it. He indicated this would be 1975.

If today was Yogi Berra's birthday and the spunky New York Mets' manager was asked what he would like most in this closing month of the pennant race, there's no doubt that he would ask for a few .300 hitters.

Can a player change his style once it has jelled? It is not to the point to cite the case of Salo Flohr, the Czech grandmaster, who gave up the wild sacrifical orgies in which he indulged himself as a youngster for the driest of dry positional strategy in maturity.

Testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in closed session today indicated that the genesis of a program of wiretaps of 13 Government officials and four newsmen-lay in the concern of Henry A. Kissinger over repeated leaks in the press of classified information relating to his work as the President's national security adviser.

President Nixon told applauding members of the Republican National Committee today that he planned to campaign personally for Republican candidates in Congressional races next year and the Presidential election in 1976.

Leigh Anne Brautigam cried quietly and Scott Finder was afraid to talk to his classmates as a sunny kindergarten room in Public School 95 filled with wistfullooking mothers and their frightened or excited children yesterday morning.
The United States and Canada reached an agreement today for a new package of air routes and an expanded system to clear passengers through customs.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal party Government won a confidence vote in the House of Commons tonight, apparently ending for the present a political crisis that has beset it for the last several weeks.
Dr. Arthur S. W. Touroff, director emeritus of surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital, died yesterday at his home, 333 East 79th Street. He was 73 years old.
A study sponsored by the Department of Labor indicates that after blacks are hired as professionals in private industry their chances of advancement are poor.

The European allies of the United States approved a declaration tonight designed to answer Washington's appeal for improved trans-Atlantic relations and to clear the way for a visit to Europe by President Nixon. But no documents were released.
The Senate Interior Committee approved a strip mine regulation bill today, but a key environmental question remained undecided. At issue were highwalls--vertical cuts made when a surface mine is dug.
Dr. George Gilbert Deaver, a pioneer in clinical rehabilitation and a specialist in physical disabilities, died here today at the Cupola Retirement Village. His age was 83.

Herman Bell, 25 years old, the last of five Black Liberation Army militants sought in the killing of two New York City policemen, was delivered from New Orleans to a heavily guarded courtroom in Manhattan. Assistant District Attorney Robert Tanenbaum of the Manhattan District Attorney's Homicide Bureau brought Bell back under a writ of habeas corpus for an appearance before Supreme Court Justice George Postel, who had signed the order here last Wednesday.

Vice President Agnew appeared to be at his alliterative apogee the other night when he told a Republican audience that "we have reached the watershed of Watergate" (although that could be taken to mean that everything will be downhill from here on).

Retail sales held steady in August after a sizable increase in July, the Commerce Department reported today. Given the sharply higher food prices last month, it is probable that the physical volume of sales declined.

The Defense Department acknowledged that United States fighter-bombers flew air strikes in support of the Cambodian Government in 1970 and 1971, with the attacks kept secret through a system of dual reports. From July, 1970 to February, 1971, according to a Pentagon paper, United States planes conducted 3,634 tactical air strikes to help support Cambodian Government forces.
Governor Cahill and the State Legislature combined today to approve a bill providing up to 13 additional weeks of unemployment benefits.
A bill to protect student athletes will not be considered by the House Education Committee this week as scheduled.
Governor Cahill and the State Legislature combined today to approve a bill providing up to 13 additional weeks of unemployment benefits.
A bill to protect student athletes will not be considered by the House Education Committee this week as scheduled.

Don Maynard, the scrawny castoff who wound up gaining more yardage and catching more passes than any other receiver in pro football history, was traded yesterday from the Jets to the St. Loius Cardinals for a 1974 draft choice.

Cambodian Government troops made an amphibious landing behind enemy lines inside the provincial capital of Kompong Chain early today and a spokesman reported that the enemy was swept from a large area with little opposition.

The Senate passed a bill today that would provide Federal operating subsidies to mass transit systems for the first time. The measure, which now goes to the House, would authorize $400-million in subsidies for the current fiscal year
Four hundred tons of gold, worth $1.5billion at current market prices, may have been sold in recent months by a seller whose identity is shrouded in mystery.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the world's largest brokerage house, disclosed here yesterday that it would start a major new mutual fund next month. The fund, which will be known as the Lionel D. Edie Capital Fund, Inc.,

Officials of the various striped-bass fishing derbiesheld annually in the fall along the East Coast could perform a public service this year by asking participants to cooperate with a Striped Bass Fund research project now under way.

David F. Price, an attorney for the defense in several wellknown criminal cases in Brooklyn, died yesterday in North Miami Beach, Fla., where he had been living since his retirement. He was 85 years old.

Superseding indictments have been handed up against Abbie Hoffman, the former Yippie leader, and three others, accusing them of selling three pounds of cocaine to police undercover agents in a midtown hotel.

According to Henry Kissinger this was supposed to be The Year of Europe for U.S. policy but the chances of real success are modest. Not that it isn't high time to check the erosion of trans-Atlantic relationships; it is simply that too many unforeseen frustrations have occurred.

An old psychological principle says you can't get one worry out of your mind until you get a different one into it. President Nixon has seized the news that the nation is more worried about inflation than Watergate as a tremendous opportunity.
A bomb scare shut down a London railway station and badly disrupted commuter services this morning in the aftermath of explosions in two stations yesterday.

The City Health Department has cited 29 more restaurants and other food establishments for having failed their second health-code inspections and has warned them that violations must be corrected before a third and final inspection this month or they could be closed.
The Justice Department-moved today to facilitate the confirmation of Henry A. Kissinger as Secretary of State by bowing to Senate pressure and allowing two Senators to read
An interruption of campus services was averted today at the University of Massachusetts When a strike by 1,000 nonprofessional employes ended the day it began.

United States officials were not surprised by the Chilean armed forces' revolt today, but they declined to comment for the record, to avoid even a hint of commitment to the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens or involvement in it.
A first report today to the state Public Utilities Commission on the condition of passenger railroad tracks in New Jersey showed some good and some bad.
The Government told a Federal Court jury today it would prove that the General Motors Corporation and the. Ford Motor Company had an "unspoken" agreement" to fix prices illegally in auto-fleet sales.
Eugene L. Mullaney, a retired senior director of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, who practiced law in New York for over 50 years, died yesterday at his home. His age was 83.

The Best American Short Stories 1973"--when you stop to think of it, that's a, pretty brave title. Martha Foley, the editor of this volume, is taking quite a lot on herself. But then she's been doing it, and getting away with it, for a long time--almost it seems, for the entire 58 years of the annual's history.

Siing with the Nixon Administration, the House of Representatives today rejected Senate proposals aimed at obtaining freer access to State Department information and requiring Congressional approval of military-base, agreements with foreign countries.

Most of the Mets were here tonight. trying to enhance the team's chances of pulling a pennant out of this bizarre season. Willie Mays wasn't here, though, so he didn't see his team stumble and lose under a barrage of four Phillie homers, 6-4.

The Rev. E. Jerome Johanson of West Hartford, Conn., and Brunswick, a retired professor of theology and Christian ethics at the Hartford Seminary Foundation, died yesterday in the Regional Memorial Hospital. He was 75 years old.

James B, Carey, founder and first president of the 285,000-member International Union of Electrical Workers, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home ini suburban Silver Spring, Md. He was 62 years old.

Jerry Lucas reported to training camp with a torn muscle in his lower back. "I have had back problems before," said Lucas, "but it's never been this painful before. I can't bend or make any quick moves, The injury occurred two weeks ago, soon after I began working out.

Commissioner Robert O. Lowery, the first black to head the 14,000-man Fire Departmenl and the first cabinet member appointed by Mayor Lindsay, resigned yesterday to campaign for Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.
The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal of the New York Stock Exchange for an increase in brokers' commissions on securities trades.

Detectives posing as Consolidated Edison workmen arrested a 73-year-old woman at her Harlem apartment yesterday on charges of selling narcotics and possessing numbers policy slips and two ounces of cocaine.

Three years ago, shortly before the end of Salvador Allende Gossens's fourth campaign for the presidency of Chile, he reflected on his three previous failures and said: "If I lose this time too I'll just keep trying until the day I die.

At least 12 officers in the Cambodian Army were put to death Friday for ordering their troops to retreat before a rebel attack near the besieged city of Kompong Chain, reliable sources reported today.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner endorsed Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor yesterday and urged "the biggest vote possible" for his fellow Democrat "to give him the kind of mandate needed to run this city."

Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally ended a twoday visit to Washington today, more than ever an emerging national leader in the Republican party he joined last May. There was heightened speculation, which Mr. Connally did riot discourage, that he is a leading contender for the Presidency in 1976.
President Nixon told a conference of judges, prosecutors, educators and law enforcement officers today that "we've turned the corner on drug addiction in the United States."
A criminal warrant was issued yesterday against a Lit Brothers department store here, charging it with using illegal strikebreaking tactics.

A man who was forced to stand on a crowded Penn Central train from Grand Central Terminal to White Plains two years ago won a jury verdict yesterday awarding him a refund of his $1.80 fare plus $10 damages for "discomfort." The case, believed to be the first in which a passenger of a commuter railroad has been reimbursed for a ride in which no seats were available,

The state administration sought an order in Superior Court today to roll back price increases in gasoline and other fuels im. posed by the Exxon Corporation last week in defiance of ,onnecticut's new Petroleum Products Control Commission.

WASHINGTON-Like most public scandals of great magnitude, Watergate has spawned many collateral vices, not the least of which is the offense which has become known to the American public as McCarthyism.

Angela Davis blamed the United States Government last night for bringing about the military overthrow of President Salvadore Allende Gossens in Chile "I don't think it's a defeat, it's a setback of course," Miss Davis said at a rally of nearly 300 pro-Allende leftists at United Nations Plaza.
Top price in today's session of the Keeneland fall sale of yearling horses was $130,000 for a gray filly by Crimson Satan out of Our Jackie.

The three biggest American auto makers and eight major foreign car manufactures -- together representing 90 per cent of the new cars sold in this country--have agreed to start telling buyers how much gasoline the cars will use, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it had asked the nation's airlines to place "no smoking" signs in the lavatories of all commercial airliners. It also said that it would make a special inspection of all airliner lavatories for potential fire hazards.

Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican nominee for Governor, and 'his wife have become grandparents for the first time. The 51-year-old Mr. Sandman announced that a son was born yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. Steven A. Wade of Wildwood Crest.
Top-seeded Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia was upset tonight in the opening round of the $37,500 national hard court tennis championships at the aptos Seascape Racket Club.

The senate Foreign Relations Committee seems determined to find out Henry Kissinger's role in wiretapping his own officials and newspaper reporters a few years ago but less determined to get at the main thing, which is to get hold of this wiretapping mania in the future.

President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile was deposed in a violent military coup, and the Santiago police said that he had committed suicide rather than surrender to the attackers. Dr Allende, a Marxist who was elected President in 1970, reportedly had shot himself in the presidential palace.

Before his name was picked at random out of a revolving drum last May to preside at one of the most important trials of the year, few New Yorkers outside the sphere of the Federal Courthouse in Foley Square had ever heard of Judge Lee Parsons Gagliardi.

The Govennie decidedtoday I to appeal directly to the Supreme Court, rather than a high court, against a decision by a district court judge last week that the Japanese defense forces were unconstitutional.

Charging that Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, was attempting to avoil televised campaign debates, the campaign manager for Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic nominee, warned today that Mr. Byrne would appear by himself, even if it meant debating an empty chair.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal of the New York Stock Exchange for an increase in brokers' commissions on securities trades. It also announced that a fixed schedule of commission rates would be abolished altogether by April 1, 1975.
A coroner's jury, ruling today that an accused former prisoner of war had committed suicide, criticized the military service for its handling of the case.

Comes the new season, comes another deluge of made-for-TV movies, those curious arrangements of mini-climaxes signaling a commercial break. Basically, so far at least, the' form is a substitute for the Grade B products that used to be palmed off as second features in movie houses.

Harlem Prep, a six-year-old school serving 600 students, has apparently been overtaken by its perennial financial crisis, according to administrators who said yesterday that the school had not resumed classes this week because of a lack of funds.
The Cost of Living Council reported today that large corporations had notified it of their intentions to raise prices on more than a thousand products and groups of products.

The city went back yesterday to buying beef from wholesalers after the Purchase Commissioner, Marvin Gersten, estirqated that the latest bids by wholesalers would lead to an average cost of $1.06 a pound, cut up and delivered.

While Henry A. Kissinger's nomination as Secretary of State has aroused little opposition in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, mail from the public received by the committee in' the last week has been overwhelmingly against Senate approval of Mr. Kissinger.

When two decorators marry, whose taste dominates? "Neither one, it's a merger," insisted Barbara D'Arcy But in her case, at least at the outset, she hastened to ex plain, "most of the furniture was Kirk's."

Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday an agreement by the United States Lines to move its huge cargo container operations from Elizabethport, N. J., to Howland Hook on Staten Island. The company moved its operations out of New York four years ago.

Miss Margy-Ruth Greenbaum was married here last evening to Perry Davis, an assistant to Mayor Lindsay. Rabbis Bernard Rosenzweig and Steven Riskin performed the ceremony in the Lincoln Square Synagogue.
John Riggins, the reluctant holdout, entered into a third round of contract negotiations with Weeb Ewbank, wearing the cap of the Jets general manager, at Shea Stadium yesterday.

The novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has accused Western liberals of dual standards of morality in what he described as their quick readiness to denounce oppression in rightist countries but reluctance to r criticize the Soviet Union.
Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys named Roger Staubach his No. 1 quarterback today and Craig Morton promptly asked to be traded.

Patrick J. Cullen, assistant treasurer and general service banking officer of the Times Square branch of' the Chase Manhattan Bank, died in Polyclinic Hospital yesterday after being taken ill at work. He was 62 years old and lived at 145-27 231st Street in the Rosedale section of Queens.

Members of the faithful in the small crowd of 5,637 at Yankee Stadium last night who watched the Indians conclude a two-game set with the Yankees hardly could have been blamed had they wondered which of the two teams was in last place.
Larry Evans has been defeated by Andrew Karklins of Chicago in the second round of the 1973 United States Chess Tournament. Karklins won on the 27th move of his game with Evans on Monday night.

Leaders of five big corporations went before a United Nations panel today to insist their concerns behave as good guests abroad, contribute to the prosperity of the countries in which they do business and do not meddle in politics.

King Hussein of Jordan and Presidents Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Hafez al-Assad of Syria today continued their talks aimed at ending the isolation of Jordan within the Arab world and peremitting the, reopening of the so-called Arab eastern front against Israel.
Max Falk advertising director of The New York Times, will retire Oct. 1, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times, announced yesterday.
The French Socialist leader, Frangois Mitterrand, said tonight that President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile told him two years ago that he would commit suicide if he were overthrown.

In other years, after other fights, Muhammad Ali liked to touch his face and preen. "Look at this face, ain't a mark on it," he would shout. "No other fighter ever looked this way. I am The Greatest." But now he's The Tiredest, his eyes weary, his voice a whisper. And his body is betraying him.

The appointment of Frank G. Frederiksen, senior vice president of the Chemical Bank, as general chairman of the 1974 March of Dimes in New York City was announced yesterday by R. Jennings Mangum, chairman of the New York Chapter of the National FoundationMarch of Dimes.

Members of the South Jersey Board of Women's Officials, a group which has been supplying basketball referees for 18 high schools in four South Jersey counties for six years, have found themselves with no contracts for the 1973-74 season. And according to Mrs. Carol Pesiri, chairwoman of the board, it is because of their efforts to get equal pav.

Negotiations for a rematch between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier are close to being completed, according to Bob Arum, one of Ali's attorneys and the president of Top Rank, Inc., the closed circuit TV company.

Cutbacks of home heating nil to 80 per cent of customers' purchases last year and turbine fuel for airlines to 70 per cent of normal were made known yesterday by the Cities Service Company Milton Musicos, chairman of Mayor Lindsay's Pubilc Utilities, renewed a call for mandatory Federal allocations.

The active December copper futures contract hit bottom again on traders' charts early yesterday of 74 cents a pound. Then came reports that the Government of President Allende of Chile had been ousted.

The American Civil Liberties Union filed a $300,000 damage suit in Federal Court today, contending that White House advance men violated the constitutional rights of five demonstrators during a speeech by President Nixon.

The close of every art season brings a warning that the age of major loan exhibitions may be drawing to a close, yet each new season somehow manages to bring us an undiminished roster of sparkling exhibitions still culled, for the most part, from collections not otherwise available to the general public.

The Pentagon's paper yesterday on the bombing of Cambodia provided more details but - to the disappointment of some Senators - did not answer the crucial questions left over from the Senate Armed Services Committee hearings last month into the secret air war.
Termination of the proposed $750-million merger agreement between the United Aircraft Corporation and the Signal Companies, Inc., was announced jointly yesterday.

Customs agents yesterday removed most of a cache of about 150 pounds of hashish discovered by drug-detecting dogs in a camper vehicle that arrived here last week aboard the France.

The "young professionals"--read advanced students--of the New Dance Group studio presented a brief and mildly intriguing program of works Monday evening at St. Clement's Church-Theater, 423 West 46 Street.

Enlistments in the volunteer Army were 19 per cent below the goal set for August, and those in all four services were 11 per cent short of the goal, Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger announced today.

John B. Connally, who until recently was one of President Nixon's special advisers, has volunteered an extraordinary piece of special advice. He has suggested that Mr. Nixon may well be justified in ignoring the Supreme Court if it were to order the Presidential tapes of the Watergate conversations to be turned over to the special prosecutor.
A Yugoslav airliner crashed into a mountain peak near here today while preparing to land. All 42 persons aboard were believed killed, officials reported.

MANHASSET, L.I. -- At Herman Jackson's little grocery store on Spinney Hill, you can buy Railroad Mills Sweet Snuff or canned hogmaws or many varieties of canned greens, all favorites of the small black community here.
The Bank of England said today it had asked all banks to pay an. interest rate no higher than 9 1/2 per cent on deposits of less than [Pound]10,000. The measure is effective immediately.

After four months of study, a Superior Court judge yesterday ordered a Maryland publishing house to return the money it got from college students during a 1971 sales campaign at California State Polytechnic College here.

A major group of Orthodox rabbis asserted yesterday that there was "no justification for the continued existence of the Conservative movement" as it of assailed the Conservative decision to allow women to be counted in a minyan.

The Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, appeared today to have assembled a fairly solid bloc within his Government and army in favor of signing the completed agreement for a coalition government with the Pathet Lao.

The active December copper futures contract hit bottom again on traders' charts early yesterday of 74 cents a pound. Then came reports that the Government of. President Allende of Chile had been ousted.

At least three types diagnostic X-ray procedures could expose a pregnant woman to enough radiation to be a serious danger to the fetus, two scientists reported today to an international meeting on radiation protection.
Senate Democratic leaders agreed today to a Nixon Administration proposal for a series of meetings with key Senators to discuss next year's budget outlook.
District Attorney. Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan underwent chest surgery at St. Luke's Hospital last Friday, Mr. Hogan's chief assistant announced yesterday.

The controversy over grand jury access to secret White House tape recordings was very nearly submerged in legal confusion today as the case was argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
A group of California farm workers, some with their families, picketed a food wholesaler for Shop-Rite supermarkets here today to protest marketing of nonunion grapes and lettuce.
W. R. Grace Co. has signed an agreement with the General Motors Corporation to supply automobile emission - control catalysts, it was announced last night.

District Attorney Michael F. Armstrong of Queens, who is serving an interim term following the indictment and resignation of Thomas J. Mackell, announced yesterday that he was not a candidate for a full four-year term.

At least 12 officers in the Cambodian Army were put to death Friday for ordering their troops to retreat before a rebel attack near the besieged, city of Kompong Chain, reliable sources reported today.

The American Psychiatric Association asked today for a meeting with Soviet psychiatrists to discuss charges that political dissidents have been improperly confined in mental institutions in the Soviet Union.
Policemen shot 10 black miners to death during disturbances at the Western Deep Levels Gold Mine here last night, the mine owners said today.
In continued light trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange fell shortly after the opening, recovered slightly in mid-afternoon but still closed sharply lower.
Ground was broken in Chinatown yesterday for Confucius Plaza, a $45-million, six-acre school, housing and community complex just south of the foot of the Manhattan Bridge on the Bowery.

The House of Representatives is expected to vote tomorrow on a bill that would prohibit the National Football League from continuing its television blackouts of. the teams' home games provided all tickets had been sold 72 hours in adyance.

The General Federation of Labor held elections throughout Israel today amid reports that the Government was hoping that the list of candidates headed by Premier Golda Meir would again win control but by a smaller margin than las time.

To the Editor: It is gratifying that the concern about the nation's misuse of its limited and irreplaceable land resources, which was once shared-by only a few conservationists and planners, has now proliferated to the point that the nation may be about to embrace a new land ethic rejecting the concept of land as a commodity and asserting the interests of all of the nation's citizens in the manner of its use.

NEW ORLEANS--Acquired Jerry Moore, safety, from Chicago for future draft choice. Acquired Odell Lawson, running back, from San Francisco on waivers. Placed Dous Wyatt, safety, and Ron Billingsley, defensive tackle, on injured reserve list. Waived Ray Jones, safety; Adrian Young, linebacker, and Charley Brown, wide receiver.

The United States and South Vietnam have issued parallel protests over reports that North Vietnam is repairing and improving 12 formerly American airfields now in Vietcong territory.

The Singer Company signed a wide-ranging agreement in Moscow yesterday providing for scientific and technical cooperation and the possible manufacture Of Singer products in the Soviet Union.
Firefighters aided by ocean fog and dipping temperatures got the upper hand yesterday on two timber blazes that charred 20,000 acres in northern California, United Press International reported.

The Internal Revenue Service announced today that Kansas Beef Industries of Philadelphia, Inc., would refund $101,000 as a result of violations stemming from sales above Federal price ceilings set last March.

McGill University recently awarded the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws to Charles Goren. This was unrelated to his membership on the National Laws Commission; it was a tribute to the remarkable role he has played in the history of the game, as player, teacher, lecturer and writer.
Bernard Edward McGuire, for three decades a newspaper telegrapher and teletypist with the North American Newspaper Alliance, died Sunday in St. Elizabeth's division of St. Clare's Hospital.

The Coastal States Gas Corporation and the Securities and Exchange Commission approved yesterday a consent decree settlement of a civil complaint filed by the S.E.C. alleging that Coastal States had violated S.E.C. regulations and provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
The stock market tried hard late yesterday at least to break even but finally closed with a loss of 5.57 points in the DowJones industrial average.

The mediator in the negotiations between Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the New York City Opera Company said yesterday that prospects for settling the 12-day-old musicians' strike were "bleak."

John Cheney Glidden, vice president of Stone Webster Securities Corporation, New York, died today at his home, 139 Chestnut Street. He was 55 years old.

Police Commissioner John F. Nichols, a conservative lawand-order candidate, and State Senator Coleman Young, a black liberal, appeared this morning to have qualified as the two candidates for Mayor in the general election Nov. 6.

When Gay Clement of 229 West 22d Street stepped up to one of the box-office windows at the Times Square Theater Center in Duffy Square yesterday afternoon to buy a pair of tickets to last night's performance of "A Little Night Music," she was informed that she was the winner of a bonanza.

A preliminary injunction enjoining members of Typographical Union 6 from engaging in illegal slowdowns or work stoppages at The New York Times was granted yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Sarafite.

The American Farm Bureau Federation urged an end today to all Federal price controls. The federation's board of directors said in a statement that, "if consumers are to be assured of ample meat supplies, it will be necessary to remove all price controls."

Because of a major change in audience-measurement methods instituted by the A. C. Nielsen Company, television executives will know this morning exactly how well their new Monday night shows fared with viewers.

J., with a field of 104 professionals and 12 amateurs. After 18 holes today and tomorrow, the field will be reduced to the low 40 scorers and ties for the final 36 holes on Friday. Don Massengale is the defending champion.

A last-minute court move to stay the eviction of eight families in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn failed yesterday and the city prepared to remove them this morning.

Governor Rockefeller delared today that if the Legislature passed a bill reinstating the death penalty, he would sign it. The Governor, speaking before 400 business and civic leaders here, said that he personally preferred to deal with the crime problem "without going to the death penaltyy"

John Preston Davis, former national secretary of the National Negroes Congress, who edited the well-known reference volume, "The American Negro Reference Book," died on Monday at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center.

President and Mrs. Nixon may have claimed enough tax deductions in 1971 as possibly in 1971 as well, to have wiped out all of their taxable income for Federal income tax purposes, according to figures published by the White House and other official sources.

A Superior Court judge in Somerville yesterday refused to halt a State Commission of Investigation hearing scheduled to begin today in Paterson on charges of corruption in the management of surplus Federal equipment. Judge George Y. Schoch, after a private hearing with attorneys representing the employes and governing board of the Passaic County Technical and Vocational School, said there would be "no irreparable harm" to those mentioned at the hearing.
The Susquehanna Corporation announced in Los Angeles yesterday that it had suspended payment of dividends on its Class A cumulative convertible preferred stock for an indefinite period.

Iceland declared today that she would break diplomatic ties with Britain if British ships "continue ramming Icelandic ships." The seven-man Cabinet made the decision unanimously, accepting a proposal put forward by Premier Olafur Johannesson.

Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 7:30 P.M. (Radio--WMCA, 7:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. (Television--Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) (Radio-- WHN, 7:30 P.M.)
Three of the four mayoral candidates are so short of campaign funds that their campaigns may be severely handicapped.

Bertha Rosenthal Farmer was 17 years old when she received a diploma in 1907 from High School No. 147 on the Lower East Side. She vowed that "Someday I'm going to go to college," even though she had to seek a job as a typist and bookkeeper to help support a widowed mother.

Melvin R. Laird, the President's chief domestic adviser, said yesterday that the nation's inflation was "a good problem, not a bad problem," because it was the result of "pent-up dollars" abroad being spent on American food.

Henry A. Kissinger says the Nixon Administration is willing at least to consult other members of the Organization of American States about the possibility of relaxing the nine-year-old embargo against Cuba. Belated as it is, this slightly more flexible approach on the part of Washington is certain to get a favorable response from many O.A.S. governments long ago convinced that the attempt to isolate Fidel Castro's regime in the hemisphere was futile and counterproductive.

MOSCOW-The newspaper campaign [in the Soviet Union] with respect to my recent interviews employs as its fundamental argument the accusation that I am supposedly speaking against the relaxation of international tension, almost in favor of war. This is an unscrupulous play on the antiwar feelings of the nation which suffered the most from the Second World War, which lost millions of its sons and daughters. This is a deliberate distortion of my position.

The Justice Department moved today to facilitate the confirmation of Henry A. Kissinger as Secretary of State by bowing to Senate pressure and .allowing two Senators to read a secret Federal Bureau of Investigation report on 17 wiretaps carried out from 1969 to 1971 on officials and newsmen.
Coach Joe Morrison, for 14 years a New York Giant, said he "felt itchy" Saturday as his football team, the University of Tennessee at Chatranooga, lost to Eastern Kentucky, 10-6.
The Haitian Embassy in the Dominican 'Republic said tonight that the armed forces of Haiti had broken up a guerrilla landing earlier in the day on Haiti's northwest coast in an intense He gun battle.

The nation's corn crop, a key to consumer food supplies in 1974, will set a record of 5.77 billion hushels this year, up 4 per cent from last year and 2 per cent more than forecast in August, the Agriculture Department said today.
Senator John C. Stennis, who has been around long enough to acquire the proper perspective, said that what went on in the United States District Courthouse here today was bound to be historic; but,.
Jackie Gleason, the comedian, said today he has signed a two-year contract with the National Broadcasting Company for a minimum of three television shows a year.

The nine members of Community School Board 17 in the Crown Heights-Flatbush section of Brooklyn were ousted from office yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice, who said that there were irregularities in the local board elections last May.
A Public Service Commission examiner today recommended that the panel reject a proposed merger of the Sylvan Lake Telephone Company into a subsidiary of the Rochester Telephone Corporation.
A Federal court today ordered New Jersey to repossess by Oct. 31 more than $3-million in school equipment distributed to 700 nonpublic schools under
Yale University announced today the appointment of Hanna Holborn Gray as provost, making her the first woman to serve at the top level of the school's administration.

One of the more provocative jazz events of last winter was a week-long series of rehearsals by the Jazz Composers Orchestra of Don Cherry's "Relativity Suite," conducted by the composer in December at New York University's Loeb Student Center.

The Marriott Corporation, which has 570 units in operation, realized a 22 per cent increase in earnings for the fiscal year ended July 27 on a sales gain of 27.3 per cent, the company's report disclosed yes. terday.
A prize fund of $275,000 was announced today for the United States Grand Prix auto race here Oct. 7.

Amid grumbling from black Republicans, the party reform committee set up to attract more women, young people, minorities and ethnic group members began its work today. At a meeting in the Mayflower Hotel, the committee members agreed to poll local Republican organizations on what they were doing to broaden the party's base.

The controversy over grand jury access to secret White House tape recordings was very nearly submerged in legal confusion today as the case was argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Five African Presidents and a representative of a sixth met here today to consider recommendations for projects to alleviate the ravages of five years of drought.
Gov. Francis W. Sargent named a new Commissioner of Corrections today to fill the vacancy left by the dismissal of John O. Boone.

Any military coup is a tragedy, representing a breakdown of civilian authority and usually the collapse of government by consent. It is especially tragic for Chile, where sturdy democratic machinery had functioned for many years and the armed forces had a strong tradition of keeping to their barracks. The Chilean tragedy will be compounded if the report of President Salvador Allende Gossens' suicide proves to be true.
Charles S. Whitehouse arrived here today to take up his duties as the new American Ambassador to Laos.

The Environmental Protection Agency notified three Indiana oil refineries today that they must reduce the sulphur dioxide emissions coming from their plants in Whiting and East Chicago. The notices were sent to American Oil in Whiting and Atlantic Richfield and Mobil Oil ni East Chicago.
Chrysler International South America, a subsidiary of Chrysler Corporation, and Mitsubishi Motor Sales today signed an agreement aimed at broadening Chrysler sales in Japan.

The United States sought today to spur efforts of the major Western nations to work out oil-sharing arrangements as insurance against any threatened cutback in petroleum supplies from the Arab nations.
The Otis Elevator Company indicated its confidence in the future of downtown Yonkers today by announcing a $12-million expansion and modernization of its original factory here.

The trial of two formerly prominent New jersey political figures on charges of violation of Federal banking regulations and mail fraud opened in Federal District Court here this morning before fudge Lawrence A. Whipple.
An underworld 'banker" helped finance the betting syndicate that allegedly fixed superfecta races at New York harness tracks, a source close to the investigation disclosed yesterday.
One way for a manufacturer to beat price controls is to bring out a new product that had no previous price.
Delmer (Del) Baker, who led the Detroit Tigers to an American League pennant in 1940, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.
A dramatic last-minute postponement was granted yesterday for the scheduled trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.
Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys named Roger Staubach his No. 1 quarterback today and Craig Morton promptly asked to be traded.
The Senate Watergate Committee is scheduled to meet tomorrow morning to set the scope and format of the rest of its investigation.

Hisham Nazer, president of the Central Planning Organization of Saudi Arabia, said here yesterday that increased oil production would depend to a large degree on the extent of industrialization of the Saudi economy.
Norway's Labor party and its leader, Trygve Bratteli, will form the next government in the wake of the nation's closefought general elections.

Negotiators for the United Paperworkers International Union and the strikebound Canadian International Paper Company are scheduled to resume negotiations on Friday in an attempt to end the six-weekold strike, according to the union.
Mrs. Billie Jean King's $100,000, winner - take -all match with Bobby Riggs was placed in jeopardy yesterday by her husband, even though she competed in a television tournament at Hilton 'Head, S.C.
Jim Bouton, the controversial sportscaster and former New York Yankee pitcher, told local television viewers last night of his dismissal from Channel 7's Eyewitness news team.
President Pompidou of France arrived here yesterday on the first trip to China by a West European head of state.
A letter of intent for a $100million loan commitment from Howard Hughes, the industrialist, has been approved by the board of directors of the Lockheed Corporation to enable financing of an extended

A severe winter or protracted cold spell could force New Jersey utilities to curtail naturalgas deliveries to low-priority industrial and commercial customers so as to continue service to homeowners, Arthur Schoenwald, executive director of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, said today.

The New York State Banking Board will hold a series of three meetings next week to determine whether the interestrate ceiling on home mortgages should be lifted to 8 1/2 per cent, Harry W. Albright Jr., superintendent of banks, announced yesterday.

When Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens was elected President of Chile, the first freely elected Marxist President in the Western Hemisphere, senators and deputies in the joint session of the Chilean Congress serenaded his choice by raising their voices in the national anthem.
Prices of seasoned corporate bonds eased again yesterday as one of the larger new financings in recent days came to market.
Lucien Laurin and Fred Hooper were extremely happy over developments at Belmont Park yesterday.
Hannah Stein, executive director since 1959 of the National Council of Jewish Women, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 53 years old.

Majorie Merriweather Post, the businesswoman and philanthropist whose great wealth allowed her to entertain lavishly and live regally, died today at her Hillwood estate here after a long Illness. She was 86 years old.

The White House offered today in Federal Court to permit private judicial review of a series of confidential Administration memorandums in connection with the controversial 1971 increase in Federal milk price supports.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he "would not be surprised" if the President proposed a tax increase to improve the nation's budget situation and thus help reduce interest rates. Dr. Burns conferred with Mr. Nixon yesterday.
Bache Co., the nation's second largest brokerage firm, had a loss of $4,257,000- on revenues of $35,344,000 during the quarter ended July 31, 1973, John E. Leslie, chairman, announced yesterday.
Disputes over school lunches and the movement of pupils from one municipality to another continued yesterday as schools across New Jersey began the second week of the new Year.

A 64-year-old grandfather today won almost $1.4-million on the British football pools and said he hoped to live long enough to spend his fortune.

Senior United States officials said tonight that they had received advance warnings of the military coup in Chile. The last warning--that the coup would take place on Tuesday--was conveyed to the highest levels in Washington on Monday.
By definition a circus is a public entertainment composed of a variety of performances by acrobats, clowns and trained animals.
City Parks Commissioner Richard M. Clurman warned yesterday that he might close Bryant Park to the public as a last resort to keep undesirables from using it.
Premier Golda Meir's governing Labor party lost about 4 percentage points in yesterday's elections for the General Federation of Labor, but its leadership remained unchallenged.
Negotiators for the Laotian Government in Vientiane and for the proCommunist Pathet Lao initialed an agreement yesterday to bring about the first coalition;
President Pompidou and Chairman Mao Tse-tung held a two-hour meeting tonight, a French spokesman said. The meeting took place at Chairman Mao's residence in the Chungnanhai area of Peking.

When the Nixon Administration first decided several years ago that commercial lending institutions ought to take over the lion's share of the responsibility for student loans, the banks responded enthusiastically to this apparent reaffirmation of free enterprise in academic lending. At the time money was relatively plentiful and the Government-guaranteed loans seemed a good business opportunity.

Children tuning in "Sesame Street" yesterday saw the Cookie Monster flicker off their television screens to be replaced by a parade of naked women. Seconds later National Cablevision Limited was flooded with calls from angry mothers.
Democratic leaders in Conggress, still pushing for an October adjournment, said today that they expected Congress to pass about 50 "significant" bills in the final weeks of the 1973 session.

The Senate Watergate committee has acted in the public interest by resisting political pressure to call off its hearings, or to close them to coverage by press and television. The panel's bipartisan agreement to resume its investigations on Sept. 24 means that the Senators will adhere to their mandate to seek full disclosure of the abuse of governmental power.

Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, accused the Nixon Administration today of neglecting Mexican-Americans, Puerto Ricans and Cubans.

A scandal is shaking France's haughty and ancient aristocracy of wine merchants over the purity of their product and is even threatening the presidential ambitions of a former Premier.
The House gave President Nixon an important, although narrow, legislative victory today by sustaining his veto of a bill to provide the nation with improved emergencymedical services.

The United Paperworkers International Union reported yesterday that six of its 17 locals at plants of the Abitibi Paper Company in Canada had ratified a new contract providing for pay increases of 8.5 per cent in each year of a twoyear agreement.

Unlike his coach, who spoke with respect that bordered on reverence, Dan Pastorini is not awed by the New York Giant defense and their fancy preseason statistics. "I think they have a good defense," the Houston quarterback said today by phone before the Oilers' morning meetings.

Ray Garrett Jr, the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that approval of higher commission rates for. stock brokerage firms was justified by the dismal financial condition of The industry.

The Exxon Corporation today brought suit against the State of Connecticut in Federal Court here, contending that the state law that gave Connecticut's Petroleum Products Control Commission authority to control prices was unconstitutional.
Members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade began a sweeping two-year effort here today to cut tariffs, reduce other trade barriers and generally liberalize world trade.
United States diplomats sounded out West Germany. Spain, Italy and Greece during the summer about a boycott of Libyan oil, informed sources reported today.
The subject of prices was on every executive's mind and on many executives' lips at the annual convention here of the American Apparel Manufacturers Association.

President Nixon has emerged from seclusion in the last few days and is once again a public President, meeting daily with a wide range of visitors, negotiating with Congress and making public appearances. On Saturday, the President conducted a conference on energy and appeared personally in the press room to explain what had happened.

WASHINGTON -- The Watergate scandal and the climate it has created will have political repercussions-perhaps far-reaching in future elections, but I seriously doubt if they will be confined to the Republican party. Rather, the reverberations of scandal and corruption will shoot through both major parties and create real trouble for incumbents,

Given the ingredients of first-rate psychological mystery, "Jealousy," a Japanese film that opened yesterday at the Bijou Theater, manages to deliver no more than soap opera - and unexceptional soap opera at that.

Delegates to the California Bar Association convention have commended an inquiry by the association into possible disciplinary action against President Nixon and other California lawyers in connection with the Watergate affair.

Americans fared poorly today in Greco-Roman competition at the world wrestling championships. Only Phil Frey of Salem, Ore., was a winner, pinning his opponent, Andrezej Soupral of Poland, in a 1491/2-pound division.
The stock market behaved yesterday like a boat in heavy seas. It opened at its high point with the Dow-Jones industrial average at 885.61, down only 0.15 point.

More than 700 independent heating oil dealers from the Northeast asked the Federal Government today to compel major oil companies to sell heating oil to retailers. It appeared likely that the issue would lead to a confrontation between the Democraticcontrolled Congress and President Nixon.

The "death ray," prominent in science fiction, may not be around the corner, but the Navy is considering laser defense against guided missiles, the Air Force is researching laser defenses against antiaircraft artillery and the Army is investigating the laser's capabilities against air attack.
The Chicagoan, a new monthly magazine devoted to the hapopenings and affairs of the country's second city, published its first issue today.
The New York Stock Exchange urged Federal regulators yesterday to bar the Chase Manhattan Bank and other banks from selling stock to small investors through monthly deductions from checking accounts.

Angry holdouts in a long fight against eviction in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn were dragged from the stoop of a condemned building by sheriff's deputies yesterday, and bulldozers immediately moved in to begin demolition making way for an expanded industrial plant.

Tonight Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson open in Jean Anouilh's "The Waltz of the Toreadors" at the Circle in the Square - Joseph E. Levine Theater, and after the premiere their friends will join them in a gala benefit party celebrating the Wallachs' 25th anniversary.
An estimated 800,000 children are either being dropped from or are dropping out of the federally subsidized school lunch program because of rising food prices, Senate investigators disclosed today.

The House gave President Nixon an important, ,although narrow, legislative victory today by sustaining his veto of a bill to provide the nation with improved emergency medical: services. The House voted 273 to 144 to override the veto, with one member presernt but not voting.

George Foreman, the heavyweight boxing champion, was offered $1.5-million today to defend his title against Jerry Quarry in Seattle.

Reversing a lower court decision, the United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the city had not necessarily violated the constitutional rights of blacks and Puerto Ricans by giving preference to Jews for a public housing project on the Lower East Side.

When the Court on the Judiciary convenes today in Albany to hear arguments concerning the possible removal from the bench of State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst, it will be the sixth case the Court has considered in its 25-year history.

Chile's new military rulers announced that a private funeral had been held for President Salvador Allende Gossens and warned that any of his supporters found armed would "be shot on the spot if taken prisoners." The announcement came as snipers barricaded in office buildings exchanged fire with military patrols on streets empty of civilians because of a curfew.

The National Endowment for the Humanities has offered a $1-million "challenge" grant to the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Tht library must raise twice what it receives from the Na tional Endowment and thus could generate up to $3-million.

If all the customers who kicked and clawed their way into the grand ballroom of the Plaza the other day buy a fur coat, it will be a smashing year for Ben Kahn, the furrier who sponsored the fashion show.

Despite its newly won approval for higher' brokerage fees - "a shot in-the arm," as one investment man put it yesterday-Wall Street still faces a wave of mergers and consolidations.

The last two service stations had displayed hand-lettered signs saying, "Sorry, No Gas Today," but the one ahead apparently had a supply, since the line of cars waiting for it stretched half a block, creating a traffic situation.

The Pittsburgh Pirates took over first place yesterday in the National League East with a 4-2 victory over the Cubs at Chicago while the St. Louis Cardinals lost to the Montreal Expos, 2-1, last night. Pittsburgh leads by half a game.
The Federal Communications Commission today authorized five industrial groups to begin construction of domestic communications satellite facilities worth $292-million.
Assault charges against an American Indian Movement leader, Carter Camp, in connection with the shooting of a fellow A.I.M. official have been dropped, a United States Magistrate said today.

The Campoen Soup Company Had the largest sales and earnwings in its history in the quarter and fiscal year ended July 29, it was reported yesterday by the nation's largest producer of Manned soups and a major fac.or in other foods.

Manufacturers expect sales to decline by one-tenth of 1 per cent in the fourth quarter following a 1.7 per cent increase in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said today. It also said that manufacturers expect to increase their inventories by $2.6-billion in the third quarter and $1.8-billion in the fourth quarter.
A group of bandits killed a Brinks armored car guard and wounded another today as they were picking up money at a bank. The police said as much as $100,000 might have been stolen.

The arraignment of Robert Lange Sr., the uncle of this year's disqualified All-American Soapbox Derby winner, was postponed today until Oct. 2 to allow a judge to consider motions filed in the case. Mr.

The American Civil Liberties Union protested yesterday a Federal district judge's order barring two Watergate defendants, Jeb Stuart Magruder and James W. McCord Jr., from giving public lectures or granting press interviews, United Press International reported.
The Senate Watergate committee decided today on a schedule of hearings that will sharply curtail its public inquiry into 1972 Presidential campaign sabotage and financing.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday released the contents of two letters it wrote on Sept. 7 to the Controller of the Currency and the Securities and Exchange Commission complaining about investment plans offered by some banks.

A threatened shutdown of the Radio City Music Hall last midnight was averted when progress was made in negotiations for a new contract to cover the theater's orchestra musicians.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, surmounting political, geographical and musical obstacles, arrivedd here today at the outset of a 10-day, five-concert tour as the first American orchestra ever to appear in China.
The Senate passed today a major consumer protection bill requiring that sellers state specifically what warranties mean.
The Federal Trade Commission has started an investigation into the possibility that some bubble-bath products may cause infections and other discomforts among users.

The Senate Watergate committee decided today on a schedule of hearings that will sharply curtail its public inquiry into 1972 Presidential campaign sabotage and financing. The Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities agreed, at a 75-minute closed meeting, to delay resumption of its Watergate hearings until Sept. 24, to limit the sessions to three days a week and to aim at Nov. 1 for completion of the investigation.
Five surprises by Carl Yastremzski helped Roger Moret gain his 11th victory in an unbeaten season last night as the Red Sox toppled the Yankees, 7-1, at Yankee Stadium.

Voter identification with the Republican party has eroded to its lowest percentage in at least 33 years, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday. Only 24 per cent of those interviewed indicated a preference for the Republican party, a drop of four points since the 1972 Presidential campaign.

A series of sweeping charges regarding the influence of the Governor of American Samoa over the political life and the information media of this tiny American territory marked the opening of hearings similar to impeachment proceedings against Gov. John M. Haydon.

Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state's consummer health physician who has closed kitchens in several state institutions in recent weeks for unsanitary coneditions, ordered four more closed today and ran into a confrontation with Dr. Maurice Kott, Acting State Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.
Thomas E. O'Hara worries about whether the small investor who has only $500 or $600 at a time to invest is going to be permanently squeezed out of the market.

Government troops yesterday fought Communist forces in a six-hour battle for control of crucial Route 1 on the Central Coast, the South Vietnamese command said today. A land mine exploded less than eight miles west of Saigon last night, killing two Government soldiers and wounding three.

Six African nations today ended 14 days of meetings on ways to get help for their drought-stricken region just below the Sahara. Many delegates expressed cautious optimism that the world community would help the six nations - Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Upper Volta,
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that a"limited-stop" service would begin Monday during the morning and evening rush periods on three main north-south bus a routes in Manhattan.

Unofficial figures yesterdayindicated that a consumer advocate, Mrs. Alpha Smaby, may have won a seat on the board of directors of the Northern States Power Company, the largest power utility serving Minnesota, Wisconsin, North Dakota and South Dakota.

A State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn has issued an order approving a change in voter registration dates next month by the Board of Elections.
Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special prosecutor, accused President Nixon's lawyers today of raising a "bogus fear" to block delivery of the Watergate tape recordings to a grand jury.
Tran Thi Nga is waiting. She is Vietnamese, and although she has lived most of her 23 years in Laos, where her family took refuge in 1960, she yearns to go home to Vietnam.
Prices broke sharply in the grain and soybean pits on the big Midwest exchanges yesterday, with daily permissible declines posted in almost every wheat, corn, oats and soybean product delivery.
The father of a man killed during the police assault on the Attica state prison during the 1971 riot is suing state officials for $1,001,000, charging that his son's civil rights were violated.
London's third and fourth bomb blasts in three days exploded today in a crowded shopping area and in the Chelsea district. Eight persons were reported injured.

To the Editor: Stories which have been filling our newspapers, magazines and television screens in recent days have fostered a dangerously distorted view of relations between business and government in this country.

The province of Brie in France is famous for its cheese, Among dog fanciers, however, it is also known for a squarely built, powerful animal-the Briard. The breed still is comparatively rare in this country.

WASHINGTON--In this week's hearings to confirm a new Secretary of State, Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman J. William Fulbright was tempted to stretch his arm across the committee table and witness table, take the ample jowl of Henry Kissinger between thumb and forefinger and give him an affectionate pinch.
The Commerce Department closed the door today on export of small orders of scrap metal.

Yesterday was a big day for gorillas here. The Bronx Zoo announced the birth of another baby gorilla and Patty Cake, the popular baby gorilla at the Central Park Zoo, celebrated her first birthday for the second time this month.
Prices dropped again yesterday in slightly heavier trading on the American Stock Exchange. Stocks also declined in the over-the-counter market. The Amex market value index closed down 0.36 at 100.14

Martin Wolfson, a character actor best remember as Captain George (Iron Belly) Brackett, U.S.N., in "South Pacific" died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 555 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.
President Nixon's proposal to give states the major role in disaster relief "could lead to 50 different levels of disaster assistance," the Red Cross told Congress today.

Roseland probably hasn't been so full since big bands came back in a big way-the Pointer Sisters attracted about 3,500 rock fans, glitter people and the curious to the venerable Roseland Ballroom on West 52d Street for their official city debut on Monday.
Prime Minister John Vorster today defended the police action last night in quelling a riot at the Western Deep Levels Gold Mine hire in which 11 black workers were shot to death.

Thomas A. O'Boyle, a senior partner in Shearman Sterling, New York law firm, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his office at 53 Wall Street. He was 56 years old and lived in Spring Lake, N. J.

Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the number of active duty officers working in Government outside the milltary services was actually twice the number the Defense Department reported to the Senate' Armed Services Committee.
The Rev. Howard O. Hough, founder and pastor emeritus of the First Radio Parish Church of America, died here today in the Maine Medical Center. He was 75 years old.

Gerald E. Frug, first deputy administrator and counsel to the Health Service Administration, was named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to head the agency. He succeeds Gordon Chase, who announced several weeks ago that he would resign effective Oct. 1 to write a book on urban health services. Mr. Frug's salary as agency head will be $43,255.

The life and work of George A. Wiley, the founder of the National Welfare Rights Organization who drowned last month, were commemorated and celebrated yesterday in a memorial service and a march across Manhattan.
The carrier they call "old shake, rattle and roll," the Ticonderoga, is destined for the scrap heap and is fighting what appears to be a losing battle.

John Furlong had his own grand opening yesterday. He opened 250 hot dog rolls at his sidewalk pushcart, feeding hungry shoppers who surged around the new Abraham Straus and Ohrbach's stores on Queens Boulevard, looking for a place to eat.
Joseph A. Boccia, who retired in 1960 after having served 10 years as a Municipal Court justice, died Tuesday at his home, 331 East 116th Street. His age was 84.
Two black elected officials expressed strong opposition yesterday to the use of community-planning-board boundaries as a basis for new councilmanic district lines.

Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate; charged today that the abuses committed by the giant corporations were concealed by secrecy. He urged a United Nations panel inquiring into the impact df multinational companies to try to get at the "priceless information" now being withheld.

The Miami Dolphins will go through the season; which starts Sunday, undefeated and untied once more. Green Bay will win 13 games and tie its other game, while Washington's final won-losttied record will be 13-1-0.

The RCA Corporation expects to spend "at least $110-million" in the five years ending in 1976 on expansion and modernization of Alaska's communications system, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman, said in a speech prepared for delivery last evening at Anchorage.
The Soviet Government set off another powerful underground nuclear explosion on the' Arctic island of Novaya Zemlya today, the Uppsala seismological institute reported.
A party of 80 representatives of development and industrial site selection organizations toured this city today with officials of manufacturing and transportation companies.

The final returns are in, and the stage is now set for a clear-cut confrontation of opposites in Detroit mayoral politics. As had been projected on the basis of returns from selected "indicator" precincts last night Police Commissioner John F. Nichols and State Senator Coleman Young emerged as the two top vote-getters among five major candidates in the city's nonpartisan mayoral primary yesterday.

The Illinois Court of Appeals refused today to overturn two injunctions issued by a circuit court judge last year against a delegation to the Democratic National Convention that succeeded in challenging and ousting Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago and his elected delegation.

A six-foot, 200-pound teenager lifted a 3,000-pound tractor today to free a trapped farm worker. Kennebec County investigator, Leo Bazinet, said that Arthur Hinkley, 18 years old, had raised the vehicle enough so Lloyd Bachelder, 18, could wriggle out.

Arthur' Andersen Co., one of the country's eight major accounting firms, has filed a complaint against the Securities and Exchange Commission, charging the regulatory agency with failing to follow Federal rule-making procedure in setting out accounting principles.

Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today that a Federal Bureau of Investigation summary "completely supports" Henry A. Kissinger's statements that beyond the furnishings of names he had no involvement in wiretapping of his staff as President Nixon's national security adviser.

An Italian military source said today that two missiles that were apparently to have been fired in a guerrilla attack on an Israeli airliner near here last week were believed to have been among arms supplied to an Arab country by the Soviet Union.
Rosemary Casals of San Francisco breezed to a 6-3, 6-1 victory over Barbara Downs of Alamo, Calif., in the first round of the $30,000 St. Louis women's international tennis tournament tonight.

Senator John V. Tunney disclosed today that attorney General Elliot L. Richardson had rejected his demand for a reopening of the controversial out-of-court settlement of antitrust cases against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

The Mayors of four municipalities met with officials of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority in an unusual session today to press for modifications in, the alignment of the proposed Driscoll Expressway from the turnpike in South Brunswick to Toms River.
Mrs. Mabel I. McMahon Sargent, widow of Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, who was rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, died Tuesday at her home, 200 East 66th Street. She was 92 years old.
John Baum and Bob Lackey of the Nets don't know Charles 0. Finley, the owner of the Memphis Tams of the American Basketball Association.

It is always a pleasure to see the Royal Danish Ballet in its home theater here. With its long, unbroken history, and its homogenous style, the Royal Danish Ballet has a very well-defined profile that combines classicism with a considerable degree of adventurousness.
State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday promised New Yorkers that they were "going to see a slugging John Marchi from now to election day."

A state audit of Auburn Community College released today said Auburn illegally charged its half of the cost of building a new campus bookstore to a student activity fund.

The stockholders of Doubleday Co., Inc., overwhelmingly defeated at their annual meeting yesterday, a move by Mrs. Neltje Doubleday Kings, to have the huge publishing combine file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in order to have a public offering of the stock.

The Ladies Pavilion in Central Park, a century-old structure of lacy ironwork that was knocked down by vandals two years ago, has been restored and is being rebuiilt at its old site on the Lake near Central Park West and 77th Street.

The body of a 59-year-old man who had been on parole on an unspecified charge in Westchester County for the last four years was found in a field here early this morning. He had been shot five times with a .38-caliber weapon.

President Nixon's soybean knowledge went up a nickel's worth today. Representative Jerry Litton, Democrat of Missouri sent Mr. Nixon a small bag of soybeans to let him know firsthand what the oilseed looked like.

United States officials reported today that they had strong indications that the Soviet Union had stopped jamming broadcasts from the Voice of America, the British Broadcasting Corporation and the West German radio.

The Japanese Government today appealed against a court decision last week that the country's 260,000-man SelfDefense Forces were unconstitutional.

An abrupt increase in heroin addiction among Burmese youth has spurred the military Government. to. take its first major steps against the huge opium-trafficking trade. In recent months, the Burmese Government, reluctant for many years to suppress opium smuggling, has shaped new drug regulations, ordered stiffer army action along the Thai border to curb the flow of opium, and started to cooperate, somewhat hesitantly, with United Nations narcotics teams.

Mrs. Margaret Cheney Dawson, former editor of Child Study magazine and earlier of Junior League magazine, died yesterday at her home in Salisbury, Conn. She was 71 years old, and the widow of James A. Dawson, who coordinated the construction of the United Nations headquarters.
Following is the 273-144 roll call vote by which the House yesterday sustained President Nixon's veto of a medical services bill.

The smartest move Bert Bell made during his historic reign as commissioner of the National Football League was to instigate television blackouts of home games. It was to be the salvation of pro football. League members ceased to live a day-by-day existence and gained financial stability by selling tickets in advance.
European officials are congratulating themselves at having managed the first hurdle toward working out a new definition of relations with the United States.

Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson has promised the Senate Foreign Relations Committee he will attempt to ensure that "a genuine national security interest" is involved before he orders wiretaps without court warrants.

Newark International Airport formally dedicated the second of its three glass-and-concrete passenger terminals today amid predictions that the expansion would generate huge economic M benefits and a reminder that it :Idisrupted people living nearby.
A convicted heroin dealer was sentenced to life imprisonment and fined $300,000 in Federal District Court here yesterday after he bitterly demounced the judge and the prosecution.

The bloodiest prison uprising in all American history ended with a police charge on inmates at Attica two years ago. An inventory of changes since then reveals that some conditions at this upstate New York maximumsecurity facility have improved while others have not. Attica still remains a symbol of misguided correctional policies.
A Government spokesman reported today that enemy forces had been cleared from the embattled provincial capital of Kompong Cham and that the Phnom Penh Government had won a clear-cut victory.

The British Government said today that it had decided to go ahead with the construction of a tunnel under the English Channel to France. The historic decision to breach Britain's symbolic waterbound isolation-what Shakespeare and generations of Englishmen since have thought of as a wall "against the envy of less happier lands"-was set forth in a white paper.

A 26-year old police officer was shot to death here by a sniper last night after he had responded to a complaint of a double-parked car, the police reported. Three men were seized and charged with murder.

Although it is difficult to contemplate on these sultry, late summer days, New York State's waterfowl hunting season will open Oct. 1 upstate, Oct. 6 in the Lake Champlain area and Nov. 19 on Long Island.

Willie Mays continued his mystifying behavior tonight by rejoining the Mets when he wasn't expected to. But it was other Mets, including John Milner and Tug McGraw, who helped spark the team to a 3-2 victory over Philadelphia, and kept the pennant hopes alive.

Loaded With athletic nostalgia, the American Sports Card Collectors Association will shuffle into town again tomorrow for its second three-day show of the season. "Those old cards in the attic may be worth thousands of dollars," the promoters said. "Cards, buttons, pennants, yearbooks, autographs, photographs-you name it, if it has to do with sports, it will be there."

An assistant accountant of' The New York Times and two other men charged with seconddegree grand larceny in the theft of more than $25,000 from The rimes through bogus expense account vouchers pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court here.
Senator Barry Gold, water said last night that. he believed Vice President Agnew had the inside track on tile 1976 Republican Presidential nomination and he said he supported the Vice President.

Erik Van Dillen was the only one of eight seeded players to survive second round play in the $37,500 national hard-court tennis championships today. The 22year-old member of the Davis Cup team beat Ray Moore of South Africa, 6-2, 76.

John E. Harrington Jr., a founder and retired president of Harrington, Righter Parsons, Inc., television representatives, died Tuesday in New York Hospital after having undergone cardiovascular surgery. He was 62 years old and lived at 120 Whitehall Boulevard in Garden City, L. I.

Frank E. Fitzsimmons, general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said today that the had discussed union business with his predecessor, James R. Hoffa, when Hoffa was here in April, 1971, to visit his ailing wife, Josephine.

A 40-room mansion formerly occupied by the showman Billy Rose will open later this month as the Smithers Alcoholism Center and Rehabilitation Unit of Roosevelt- Hospital.

The House voted 396 to 4 today to place a special design on all silver dollars, half dollars and quarters 'to commemorate the nation's 200th birthday.

Abraham Straus, the giant Brooklyn department store, and Ohrbach's, the Manhattanbased fashion-at-a price store, yesterday ended thier long holdout against competing in the city's other boroughs. At 9:45 A.M., they opened their first urban branch stores in New York in the new Queens Center Mall.
The Nixon Administration's policy of conciliation toward China is causing serious political unrest in Albania, Peking's East European ally, according to information reaching the United States.

District Attorney Jim Garrison, defendant in a pinball bribery case in United States District Court here, took over his own defense today because of "irreconcilable differences" be. tween him and his attorneys.

The countries of Eastern Europe are in the market for textiles manufactured in this country, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute said yesterday.

Betty Stove of the Netherlands edged Pam Austin of Rolling Hills, Calif., 7-6, 6-4, today and led the favorites into the second round of the $30,000 St. Louis women's international tennis tournament.
