The Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of,New York, Inc, announced yesterday it has renegotiated an ageement in principle to acquire the Franzia Brothers Winerg for stock valued at about $49.3-million.

Egypt announced the resumption of diplomatic relations with Jordan today. The announcement, which ends a long period of isolation for King Hussein, was issued a few hours after the Jordanian King had completed three days of talks here with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.
Bob Allard, a tour rookie, held off Jim Simons with a one-underpar 70 today and won the Sea Pines open golf tournament, a satellite event.

The long fight between residents of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and the city government came to an end yesterday as two buildings were demolished and angry residents were dragged from the stoop of a condemned building where the last families had been holding out against eviction.

Meat prices should start downward sometime between next month and the end of the year with increased shipments of cattle to market and seasonal rises in pork supplies, according to a Federal Agriculture Department survey released yesterday.

Twelve years after it was first proposed, years in which it was nearly overwhelmed by bureaucratic, political and financial obstacles, the ambitious and dramatic Waterside housing development over the East River was formally opened yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and former Mayor Robert F. Wagner.
Margaret Linn, a stage, film and television actress, died of a brain hemorrhage today in Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital. She was 39 years old and lived at 110 West 86th Street, New York.

Russell E. Train, the new head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that he thought the nation was entering a period of "testing the public commitment to environmental progress" and that he was confident that the commitment would be fulfilled.

President Nixon has emerged from seclusion in the last few days and is once again a public President, meeting daily with a wide range of visitors, negotiating with Congress and making public appearances.
Several government officials and representatives of a number of conservation groups expressed opposition last night to a United States Navy plan to dump dredging spoil in Long Island Sound.

A state district court judge here listened to five hours of testimony today concerning a request by citizens to have criminal charges filed against five F.B.I. agents, then recessed to allow the agents to rebut the allegations, which include assault with a dangerous weapon, malicious destruction of property and larceny.

The State Department of Environmental Protection has assigned top priority to the financing of sewer projects for the New Jersey shore, the nontidal reaches of the Passaic River watershed and the Raritan River basin. The department set the priorities in seeking funds from the United States Environmental Protection Agency. The Federal Government is providing $171-million during the current fiscal year for the sewage facilities.

A 38-year-old man offered a $5,000 reward yesterday for information leading to the arrest of the person or persons who killed his children's pet calf. Robert Debeck, who owns a used truck concern here, offered the reward after the calf, Bambi, was found dead Saturday.

Irving Anker, chancellor of the city school system, said last night that "an agreement in principle" had been reached with the directors of Harlem Prep on its entrance into the city school system "perhaps by next spring."
An unidentified holdup man was shot and seriously wounded in a shootout with two policemen last night as he fled the B B Food Store at 366 Second Avenue,, near 22d Street, in the Gramercy Park area.

A Jesuit historian said today that an Italian writer who specialized in fabricating Vatican information between 1939 and 1948 duped American news organizations and secret agencies, and probably Hitler and the Soviet Union as well.
An estimated 800,000 children are either being dropped from or dropping out of the federally subsidized school lunch program because of rising food prices, Senate investigators disclosed today.
The Ellsworth Kelly exhibition, which opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, is an event bound to baffle--and probably exasperate--almost as many people as it Will delight.

Canada in August recorded her largest monthly rise in living costs in more than 22 years, an increase of 1.3 per cent, which was likely to bring criticism of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's proposals to combat inflation.

President Nixon said yesterday that he was a member of the sneezing minority those Americans afflicted this time of year with hay fever. Mr. Nixon disclosed his irritation as he was having his picture taken before a meeting with members of the House Ways and Means Committee.

Sidney I. Cohen, a film, theater and television service consultant, died of cancer yesterday in a hospital here. He was 64 years old.

Frederick H. Dutcher, who retired as associate professor of mechanical engineering at Columbia University in 1958, died in Norwalk Hospital on Monday. He was 81 years old and lived here.

Extradition proceedings are under way to return a 19-year-old youth now serving in the Israeli Army to New York to face a murder charge in connection with the fire-bombing of the offices of Sol Hurok, the impresario, early last year.

Corporate bond prices were mixed yesterday in quiet trading. News from Washington that Melvin Laird, President Nixon's chief domestic adviser, reported the President was considering, a 10 per cent income-tax surcharge generated an upturn in the bond market, dealers said.
The presiding judge of the Court on the Judiciary said today that it would be "a shocking situation" to have a judge presiding at a trial who had been convicted of a crime and was facing a jail term.

Mayor Paul T. Jordan said today that there was no planned connection between the sniper murder or a Jersey City policemen late Wednesday night and a street-corner altercation over a traffic violation that preceded the shooting.
The National Football League repealed yesterday its television blackout of all sold-out home games in the wake of Congressional action prohibiting continuance of the 22-year-old blackout policy.

An attorney for 13 black members of last season's Jackson Parkside High School basketball team filed a $100,000 suit against school officials today in United States District Court.

Theodore Lightner, one of the world's greatest players, celebrates his 80th birthday here today. Nathaniel Penistone Davis, former Ambassador to Costa Rica and former Minister to Hungary who retired from, the Foreign Service in 1951, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 78 and he formerly lived in Glens Falls. N.Y.

The American Natural Gas Company announced yesterdays that its subsidiary the Michigan Wisconsin Pipe Line, has entered into agreements involving expenditures of about $80-million with the Cities Service Corporation, the Gelty Oil Company and the Skelly Oil Company to explore for and develop natural gas reserves in the Gulf of Mexico.
Elfie Beck, a bar waitress who spends 10 hours a day on her feet mixing drinks, comes in for an electric massage twice a week to help keep unsightly cellulitis from disfiguring her sightly thighs.

A police officer who disappeared from his Queens home with his wife and two children about a month ago was indicted yesterday by a Queens grand jury on charges involving $29,800 in alleged bad-check transactions. The officer, Robert Cameric, 34 years old, was charged with three counts of grand larceny and four counts of issuing bad checks, which are punishable by up to 21 years in prison upon conviction.

The G. I. bill, which now provides armed forces veterans with $220 a month to further their education, should be expanded to pay 80 per cent of veterans' tuition and fees, a report sponsored by the National League of Cities and the United States Conference of Mayors recommended today.

The South Vietnamese command reported a battle today in the central coastal province of Binh Dinh. A spokesman said that 37 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers were killed when they attacked two Government infantry posts near the district of Bong Son.

Homero Blancas's brilliant putting gave him a five-under-par 66 and a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the $150,000 Heritage Golf Classic.

The passenger ship terminal being constructed on the Hudson River between 48th and 52d Streets will offer enclosed selff-propelled gangways for passengers and baggage handling similar to those used at modern airports,

A slowdown in the economy, without recession and with a distinct lessening of inflation was the forecast for 1974 yesterday of more than 400 business economists.

Mayor Lindsay told a House committee today that elected judges in New York State had become too insulated from the public and too lacking in accountability.
With their monuments and plaques, remembrances of another era, in center field for the last time, the Yankees squeezed out a 2-1, 12-inning victory last night over the Boston Red Sox.

Health Minister Luigi Gui said today that 239 cases of cholera have been verified in Italy since the disease was first identified two and a half weeks ago, and that there have been 24 deaths from cholera.

A leading Chilean economist declared here today that the "Chilean drama" demonstrated why poorer countries feared the industrialized powers and their influential corporations.

Faced with its worst financial crisis since 1932, the Metropolitan Opera has canceled the new production of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" planned for March 28 as well as future summer presentations of free opera concerts in the city's parks.

Senatorial inquiry into Henry Kissinger's responsibility for seventeen wiretaps of dubious legality ought to be pushed to the limit. That inquiry has tended, nevertheless, to obscure Mr. Kissinger's views on the deeply troubling question of what, if anything, the United States ought to do about the treatment of political dissidents in the Soviet Union.
The exhibition, "American Impressionist Painting," which opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, is something of a mixed blessing.

Following is the text of a memorandum issued today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, addressed to President Nixon, United States District Judge John J. Sirica, and Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Watergate case:

Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz said today that Melvin R. Laird should "keep his cotton-picking hands off economic policy." Mr. Shultz was replying at a news conference here to a question about a Washington statement by Mr. Laird,

The Pittsburgh Pirates, who took first place in the National League's Eastern Division Wednesday for the first time since May 8, increased their lead to one game yesterday with a 6-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The victory at Wrigley Field in Chicago gave the Pirates a 72-71 won-lost record, the only team in the division over the .500 mark.

There are men like him everywhere, executives and laborers discarded or ignored by their employers because they are considered "too old" for the job. Few ever get the opportunity to disprove the theory. But when the National Football League season begins Sunday, one of them will have the chance. Johnny Unitas will be at quarterback for the San Diego Chargers, and he will be symbolic to the men he represents.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 193.6 from 196.6 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 122.3 on Sept. 12, 1972,

Boston University ended its 1973 fiscal year with its first surplus in three years, the university's president, John R. Silber, said yesterday. The university reported that it had a surplus of $611,000 June 30.
Israeli and Syrian jets clashed over the Mediterranean today in their biggest air battle since the 1967 war, and a military spokesman here said 13 Syrian planes and one Israeli were shot down.

In Cambodia it is still civil war. In South Vietnam there is indecision. Only in Laos, third of the Indochina states, has a widely heralded cease-fire turned into formal peace-signed and sealed yesterday. The accord establishes a coalition government between a disciplined national Communist movement, the Pathet Lao, and a diffuse body of neutralist politicians led by the durable 72-year-old Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma.

To the Editor: Recently Dr. I. D. J. Bross in a letter suggested that in association with a proposed nuclear power plant at York, Pa., and "other affected areas" a health-surveillance system should be set up "so we could at least get an early warning of any serious hazards," presumably arising from the radiation emitted by the proposed and other operational power plants.

" They want me to be a bad guy so they make me a bad guy even when I am not a bad guy." That was Ilie Nastase talking yesterday about his run-ins with tennis linesmen, associations and writers. The run-ins have led to fines and possible suspensions for the Rumanian player.
A predawn fire raced through a nursing home today, and 11 elderly persons were killed, in part because of what authorities called a "delayed alarm" and "confusion" among the residents.

Russell E. Train has celebrated his confirmation as head of the Environmental Protection Agency in a highly appropriate way. He has taken issue with the Administration that appointed him on the important question of. relaxing the country's clean air standards in order to meet the expected shortage of heating oil in the coming winter.

Westfield High School, a winning football team is not just a tradition, it's a habit. Since Gary Kehler took over as head coach in 1961, Westfield has posted a 94-9-5 won-lost-tied mark and has not lost in its last 42 starts, a New Jersey scholastic record. The only blot on the record was a tie with Rahway in 1970. n 1970.
In an attempt to involve the entire community in the future of the public schools here, the district has hired the Roper Organization of New York to take a detailed look at the district.

The Memorex Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of magnetic recording and computer equipment, has filed an amendment to its form 1O-Q report with the Securities Exchange Commission on its operations for the six months ended June 30, it was announced last night.

Dr. Oscar Sussman, the State Consumer Health Director, who has closed kitchens in a number of state institutions because of unsanitary conditions, said tonight that the State Health Commissioner had threatened to dismiss him.
Typographical Union 6 announced yesterday that it had "decided to recess" for an indefinite period its contract negotiations with The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post.

Israel and Syria fought their biggest aerial battle since the 1967 war as Israeli and Syrian jet fighters clashed off the Syrian coast. Israel claimed 13 planes shot down, with one Israeli loss, while Syria said that "five enemy planes were shot down, and eight of ours were hit." [Page 1, Column 8.]

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to rezone the Northside section of Williamsburg to permit construction of housing for the Brooklyn families who were displaced to make way for the expansion of a factory.

When Doc Medich walked Orlando Cepeda in the fourth inning last night, it marked the first base on balls yielded by a Yankee since Monday--a span of 27 innings. . . . Fifty years will be condensed into 32 minutes on an original record called "Yankee Stadium-The Sounds of 50 Years."
The National Football League repealed yesterday its television blackout of all sold-out home games in the wake of Congressional action prohibiting continuance of the 22-year-old blackout policy.

" It seems like a long time ago," said Jack Dempsey this week as he rolled time backward a half-century to the evening of Sept. 14, 1923, and his frenzied fistic battle with Luis Angel Firpo of Argentina at the Polo Grounds.

The Skylab 2 crew hunted today for sources of water in west Texas and helped map remote areas of the Rocky Mountains. The astronauts Capt. Alan L. Bean, Owen K. Garriott, a civilian scientist, and Maj. Jack R. Lousma photographed 12,600 miles of the earth in two long sweeps.

George Stone, whose 10-3 won-lost record gives him the best Met winning percentage, opposes Ferguson Jenkins as a three-game series with the Chicago Cubs opens at Shea Stadium tonight.... Tug McGraw, already in the jewelry business, is diversifying even further. He's getting into the leather business with his older brother, Hank, a former minor league player.
An attorney for 13 black members of last season's Jackson Parkside High School' basketball team filed a $100,000 suit against school officials today in United States District Court.

A brokerage firm is not automatically liable for the negligent conduct of an employee, Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. ruled here yesterday.
Volvo, the Swedish automobile manufacturer, formally announced here yesterday that it would build a car assembly plant in the United States at a cost of more than $100-million.
Arthur Ashe of Miami, topseeded but a late arrival, beat Gary Groslimond, 6-2, 7-5, today to advance to the second round of the $37,500 Seattle international tennis tournament.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Two hundred members of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Workers Union, on strike against Columbia University since Monday, occupied the university's personnel offices yesterday afternoon.

An attempt to burn a 4-foot by 5-foot cardboard model of the Bronx in front of City Hall, to dramatize the "deterioration of housing" in that borough, went up in smoke yesterday as the police intervened.
" Let's Go Get Stoned," sang Ray Charles back in 1965, and people in this pop life instantly knew this funky drinking song was destined to become a pop-music classic.

Trading dipped slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as prices reversed the downhill slide of three previous sessions and closed mixed. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market. .
A grand jury investigating Maryland political corruption met for about three hours today under unusual security precautions.

Business sales outstripped inventory accumulation in July for the first time in four months, the Commerce Department reported today. Manufacturing and trade inventories gained only $1.502-billion, or 0.7 per cent, to $206.754-billion.

George Meany, urgently appealing to Congress to override President Nixon's veto of the minimum wage bill, charged today that the President, in his veto message, had "deliberately perpetuated many myths about the poor."
City and county investigators arrested 13 persons on drug-sale charges today, with two of them accused under the new state laws that could lead to life imprisonment upon conviction.
CINCINNATI-It would serve this country's whining, complaining pennywise and pound-foolish housewives right if all the farmers started selling everything they produce to foreign countries.

With a verbal swipe at "liberal do-gooders," Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican gubernatorial candidate, told a legislative committee today that he supported pending legislation to restore the death penalty in New Jersey.

An American student in Heidelberg has been ordered to leave West Germany in three weeks for working on a newspaper opposed to the United State Army, called Fight Back, according to state government officials in Stuttgart.

THE WALTZ OF THE TOREADORS, a Play by Jean Anoullh, translated by Lucienne Hill. Directed by Brian Murray; setting by Clarke Dunham; lighting by Thomas Skelton; costumes by Joseph F. Bella; production stage manager, Gerald Nobles. Presented by Circle In the Square, Inc., Theodore Mann, artistic director; Paul Libin, managing director; Claire Nichtern, associate director. At the Circle In the Square-Joseph E. Levine Theater, West 51st Street. t.

An out-of-court compromise solution to the dispute between President Nixon and the Watergate grand jury over the White House tape recordings was proposed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

A Fairy Tale of New York, by J. P. Donleavy (Delacorte Press, $7.95). The misadventures of a misfit. A Perfectly Natural Act, by Dennis Litrell (Putnam, $6.95). The pressures that push a man into Insanity.

The Nixon Administration announced today that it was considering asking Congress to make two. radical changes in the tax laws, both of which would be aimed at maintaining a prosperous economy with lessened inflation.

Preparing to resign as president of the Off Track Betting Corporation to run for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination Howard J. Samuels has recommended that a Suffolk County Republican replace him in the $45,000 post.
Marion Lady Chesham, the former Marion Donoghue of Philadelphia and a former member of the Tanzanian Parliament, died Sept. 6 in Guildford, Surrey.

Mickey's Dodge Bar is an industrial oasis, a cool corner of friendliness just a short dash across Joseph Campau Street from the clatter and noise and heat of the Chrysler Corporation's big Hamtramck assembly plant. "Dodge Main," the plant is called, after the cars produced there.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

Six players were named to the taxi squad yesterday: Phil Wise, safety; Steve Thompson, defensive tackle, and Margene Adkins, wide receiver, all taken off the designated injured list. The others are Dennis Cambal, tight end; Rocky Turner, wide receiver-safety, and Rick Harrell, rookie center.... Another player will be deactivated before Monday to fill out the squad and make room for Riggins. .
Arthur. W. MacPherson, a former New York investment broker who was also a tennis player, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 78 years old and lived at 435 East 52d Street.

Taiwan's newly-organized National Chinese Opera Theater, which left today for a three. month tour of the United States, may have caused the collapse of the country's only opera company giving regular public performances.

Dr. Joseph W. E. Harrisson, a chemist and pharmacologist who had been president and director of LaWall and Harrisson Laboratories, died at the hospital of the University of Pennsylvania on Monday. He was 77 years old.

A system of variable-rate home mortgages should be considered to allow savings and loan associations more flexibility, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Thomas Bomar, told the House Banking Committee today. Mr. Bomar was testifying on the present situation of high interest rates and credit shortages along with the Controller of the Currency, James Smith,

Students marched on the American Embassy here three times today, charging the United States with supporting the military take-over in Chile, but each time they were kept back by helmeted policemen carrying machine guns.
A Democratic drive for quick enactment of a mandatory oil-supplies allocation bill bogged down unexpectedly in the House Commerce Committee today.
Dr. Paul Hoxworth, widely known for his work with blood banks, died yesterday at the age of 66. He leaves his wife, Nancy; three children, and two grandchildren.
Richard Goode, a native New Yorker, won the fifth Clara Haskil international competition for young pianists here last night. The victory carries a cash prize of 10,000 francs ($3.300).
A break in a century-old water main under Central Park South has closed the street to traffic between the Avenue of the Americas and Fifth Avenue.

The Addressograph Multigraph Corporation suffered a deficit in the fourth fiscal quarter ended July 31 and sharply lower profits in the full fiscal year, according to yesterday's report by the manufacturer of duplicating, data writing and copy system equipment.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.5 billion ton-miles, 8.1 per cent above the corresponding week last year.
Chile's new military junta named an army general as President today, formed a cabinet and broke diplomatic relations with Cuba in a sharp reversal of the country's foreign policy.
The police questioned drivers and visited neighbors today in a quest for clues in the death of a 12-year-old girl whose body was found yesterday in a wooded lot near here.
Administration officials said today that President Nixon had received numerous reports in the last year of an impending military coup in Chile, and

Representative Mario Biaggi, the Conservative party's candidate for Mayor and a much-decorated retired police lieutenant, won the applause sweepstakes-but by a slim margin-when he and two other mayoral aspirants addressed the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association here today.
Space-age technology is helping to salvage some of the millions of records damaged in a fourday fire at the Military Personnel Records Center in suburban Overland last July.
A 10-year, $1.961-billion transportation program for Nassau and Suffolk Counties was out lined today by State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler.

Sharp criticism of the Soviet Union's continuing harassment of dissident elements was voiced yesterday in the United States by a civil rights organization, an authors' league and a publishers' association.
Lawyers for John N. Mitchell have issued a subpoena for any White House tape recordings that might be related to the obstruction-of-Justice case involving the former Attorney General.

A state District Court judge denied today a request by citizens here that criminal charges be filed against five agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for assault with a dangerous weapon, malicious destruction of property and larceny.

President pompidou conferred with Premier Chou En-lai today, for three hours. A French spokesman reported that the discussions, on the .third day of President Pompidou's state visit to China, covered Southeast Asia, East West relations and the Common Market.

Bundling was a fine tradition-a form of coping with the energy crisis--back in Pilgrim times. It is defined by Webster's International Dictionary thusly: "The custom of unmarried couples' occupying the same bed without undressing, practiced chiefly in earlier days especially during courtship in some British and American communities."

The Soviet Union announced today the start of construction of a huge new port on the Black Sea as a direct outgrowth of a multibillion dollar chemical deal concluded earlier this year with an American company.

Signal Companies, Inc., was denied on Wednesday a preliminary injunction in its suit to block a tender offer of Cemp Investments, Ltd., for up to 1.5-million shares of Signal stock, it was disclosed yesterday.
Copper-futures prices on the Commodity Exchange rose sharply here yesterday, still influenced by the confused conditions in Chile since the overthrow of the Allende Government by a military coup.

The Communist-led Pathet Lao and the Laotian Government in Vientiane today formally signed an agreement to create a coalition government charged with mending the wounds of 20 years of intermittent civil war.

The Long Lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for permission to add 19 more cities to its planned digital data system to create an interim 24-city network for the transmission of data communications.

Eddie Palmieri, a major force in New York's Latin music scene, was given short-shrift in the "First Conquest," a commendable attempt at a Latin variety show that failed at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday.
Bowing to the will of the White House, the Senate took steps today toward enacting two major bills without provisions that had prompted their earlier vetoes.
About 20 inmates of the Jefferson County Jail staged what prison officials described as "a brief protest" today against food preparation and the lack of recreational facilities.
A spreading rank-and-file revolt is threatening the no-strike labor contract signed earlier this year by the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America.

Benjamin J. Malcolm, the city's Corrections Commissioner, predicted yesterday that under Governor Rockefeller's stringent new drug-abuse laws, which took effect Sept. 1, the city's present prison population, now 9,216, would increase by up to 3,600 in a year.
Joseph Mercadante, former president of the Green Star Shipping Company, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived here.
A 10-year, $1.961-billion transportation program for Nassau and Suffolk Counties was outlined today by State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler.

Students at eight colleges around the state report heightended fears among users of drugs, and many campus dealers say that they have gone out of business as a result of the state's stringent new drug laws, which took effect Sept. 1.
WILLIMANTIC, Conn. Warren Kimbro, the man who murdered a suspected Black Panther turncoat in a Middlefield, Conn., swamp in 1969, is back doing the things he always wanted to do.
The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it had obtained exclusive United States television rights for coverage of the 1976 Winter Olympic Games in Innsbruck, Austria.
Food Fair-Pantry Pride Supermarkets, a leading supermarket chain, announced yesterday that it was reducing meat and poultry prices "significantly" below those of the last 30 days.

St. Jean Baptiste's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here yesterday for the marriage of Miss Suzanne Butler Hooker, a junior at Barnard College, to Ames Braga, who graduated with the class of '73 from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Rene Fontaine.
A 5 per cent drop in the nation's meat consumption was forecast yesterday by Federal Agriculture Department experts.

The White House is formally refusing to say whether President Nixon paid any Federal income taxes in 1970 or 1971 on his $200,000 annual salary plus whatever other income he had, holding that this is a personal matter--although an anonymous White House official says he did pay such a tax. Whether he did or not,

The Nixon Administration is making a strong effort to end its deadlock with Congress over Federal aid to education and has let it be known that if a compromise can be worked out on the way the money is distributed, the Administration's budget request for next year will call for more spending on schools.

The three previous speakers had succeeded only in putting the audience at the Association of Swedish Industries to sleep. The 35-year-old president of Scandinavia's largest insurance company was the fourth speaker.

More than 25 affluent businessmen will be arrested within the next three weeks when the city's Department of Investigation completes a yearlong inquiry into the bribing of city officials, cording to sources close to the investigation.

A secretary's message that Jesse Moss was "busy with a lot of clients right now" helped confirm a report yesterday that 22 harness-racing drivers would begin appearing today before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.
A new controversy involving pupils from East Harlem was apparently resolved yesterday, but in Brooklyn, protesting parents maintained their boycott of two schools.

The Alabama Legislature, in the closing hours of its 1973 session tonight, passed and sent to Gov. George C. Wallace a strong ethics bill that requires newsmen as well as public officials to make financial disclosures.
OLE AL FRESCO Midtown will be jumping with Mexicans at midday today, all by Way of tooling up for the southern amigos' Independence Day celebration over the weekend.
Ministers from nearly 100 nations approved today a declaration paving the way for the world's most ambitious attempt to remove obstacles to international trade.
A $9.1-million low-interest loan and a $900,000 Federal grant were awarded today to St. Joseph's Hospital here for expansion and modernization work.
With a strike deadline a day away, negotiators for the United Auto Workers and the Chrysler Corporation intensified their efforts today to reach a contract settlement.

Two former officials of the Arkansas division of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., a cooperative of dairymen, were charged today with conspiring to make illegal campaign contributions to the 1968 Democratic Presidential campaign.
Greg Larson offered Dick Enderle some friendly advice today on how to prepare for John Matuszak, Houston's 6-foot-8-inch, 290 - pound rookie.

First off, let's make a couple of things perfectly clear. Mason Reese is neither a midget nor a girl. He is the precocious 7-year-old boy who ate his way to fame and fortune in television commercials for Tasty Cake, Underwood Chicken Spread and Post Raisin Bran. You know, the pudgy red-haired kid with the round face and freckles.

Evidence of the financial pressure on Wall Street continued to mount yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange announced new layoffs and Lehman Brothers, a major investment banking firm, disclosed that it was in the midst of a major belttightening program.

The question of whether the Administration is planning to seek higher taxes helped keep the stock market from showing even a modest gain yesterday. At the opening bell on the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow-Jones industrial average stood at 882.68, up 1.36 over Wednesday's close.

Miss Eileen Marguerite Brettler, assistant director of the neighborhood decentralization project in the office of Deputy Mayor Edward A. Morrison, was married here last evening to John Andrew Berenyi, banker, author and former aide to Mayor Lindsay.
The Acting Governor of Kompong Cham Province today denied a report that 12 army officers were executed here last week for ordering their men to retreat.
Chile's new military junta named an army general as President today, formed a cabinet and broke diplomatic relations with Cuba in a sharp reversal of the country's foreign policy.

With the advent of television following World War II, pro football was one of many sports whose games were televised live over local stations. Then dwindling attendance, especially in Los Angeles for Rams' home games, led to the concept of foregoing television at home.

In response to continuing pressure from the House Armed Services Committee, the Department of Defense has forbidden civilan employes to take courses at colleges and universities that have eliminated Reserve Officer Training Corps programs on their campuses.

The president of Phoenix House, a drug-treatment program, conceded to the Board of Estimate yesterday that his staff might have recruited "a limited" number of addicts from out of state into the treatment program.
Egil Krogh Jr., contending that he "did not commit a crime," has established a legal defense fund like that of Daniel Ellsberg, the man he held a White House mandate to investigate.
Prince Littler, the British impresario and theater owner, died today at his home in Sussex. He was 72 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

Dr. Oscar Sussman, the State Consumer Health Director, who has closed kitchens in a number of state institutions because of unsanitary conditions, said tonight that the State Health Commissioner had threatened to dismiss him.
Typographical Union 6 announced yesterday that it had "decided to recess" for an indefinite period its contract negotiations with The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post.

The body of David Post Rumbough, the 23-year-old son on Dina Merrill, the actress, was Found yesterday, five days after Mr. Rumbough was reported missing in a boating accident in waters off eastern Long Island.
The British Broadcasting Corporation announced plans today to turn one of its radio channels over to women for an entire day.
Israeli and Syrian jets clashed over the Mediterranean today in their biggest air battle since the 1967 war, and a military spokesman here said 13 Syrian planes and one Israeli were shot down.

Sun Fo, the only child ,of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Republic of China, died here today of a heart attack. He was 81 years old. His Widow, the former Kwai Jun-chun, two sons and two daughters survive.

Two things concern the South Vietnamese these days, a prominent political figure said recently: the unending war and the cost of living. "But the most important thing," he went on, "is the cost' of living."

A once-a-year birth-control device developed by an American pharmaceutical company is being tested on women in China. The tests are believed to be the first permitted by the authorities in that country on a foreign-made drug since the Communists took power nearly a quarter of a century ago.
Incumbents raised more than twice as much money as their challengers in the Congressional election campaign last year, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

Hilliard W. Paige, president of the General Dynamics Corporation, who has had a long career in aerospace, missile and computer development, has been named chairman and chief executive of the CML Satellite Corporation of Washington.

Two 12-year-old boys who had gone fishing on the banks of the Hudson River at 121st Street rather than go to school were found floating on a section of collapsed pier in a swift current in the middle of the river.

Open warfare within a number of big Republican county organizations and charges that Governor Cahill is deliberately piloting the defeat of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. were reported today to be undermining the conservative Republican's campaign for Governor.

Vice President Agnew and his family have for years received gifts of food from a friend here who is a wealthy, politically active supermarket executive, according to a Maryland political figure with contacts in the Vice President's staff.

The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it had authorized the nation's railroads to increase their freight rates and charges by 1.9 per cent on Oct. 1 and by an additional 0.7 per cent on Jan. 1.

Even with the new television season's strategy of "staggered" premieres, spread over several weeks due to script delays caused by the writers' strike, it is impossible to avoid "roundup" reviews, those collections of titles strung together precariously with observations bordering on the cryptic. The mere quantity of TV material is numbing, in more ways than one. .
Following their latest game of Willie or won't he, the Mets went out and kept pace with first-place Pittsburgh tonight by trimming the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-2, in 12 innings.
Harry MacArthur, drama, film and nightclub critic for The Washington Star-News for nearly 30 years, died yesterday at Holy Cross Hospital after a long illness.

Some members of Premier Golda Meir's Labor party who favor annexation of the occupied Arab territories joined today in an opposition attempt to offer an alternative to the present Government in the Oct. 30 elections.

Two Democratic Senators, Stuart Symington of Missouri and George McGovern of South Dakota, argued today that cuts must be made in the defense budget to protect the economic strength of the nation.

Representatives of 21 Western European nations opened a month-long conference in Munich this week to adopt a new, unified European patent system.

President Nixon and Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special prosecutor, made no visible progress today toward the proposed out-of-court compromise of their dispute over the Watergate tape recordings.

President Pompidou of France said today that there were still "stumbling blocks" to Chinese - French relations, though there were many areas in which both countries were in harmony, including the need to build independent nuclear arsenals.

Bernie Boland, who pitched for the Detroit Tigers from 1915 to 1920, died Wednesday in Mount Carmel Hospital after a threeweek illness. He was 81 years old.

Dwight E. Dobbs said today that he had had "just the biggest thrill of my life" when he picked up the telephone and the caller identified himself as President Nixon.

Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Democratic National Committee chairman, refused the job after he looked beyond the $110,000 salary. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz was scratched as being too controversial and too old at 62 even before he could make up his mind.
Capt. Robert E. Christopher, a freelance coast-wise pilot for deep-sea vessels, died yesterday of cancer in Cooper Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 110 Buttonwood Lane, Riverton.

A Good Day to Die by Jim Harrison (Simon Schuster, $5.95). Three youths on a mission to save the Grand Canyon. Fight of the Grey Gdose by Victor Canning (Morrow, $5.95). A teen-ager's adventure in the Scottish Highlands.

Maurice Clements, president and director of the publishing firms of Caldwell-Clements, Inc., and the Manuals Corporation of New York City until his retirement in 1957, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 79 years old and had lived in NewYork.

Chiang Ching, wife of Chairman Mao Tse-tung, attended a concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra tonight. Accompanied by a group of high-ranking party officials, she sat through the entire concert and later joined Eugene Ormandy in a backstage ceremony.

With their co-tenants of Three Rivers Stadium, the Pirates, in the final two weeks of their bid for a fourth consecutive division baseball title, the Pittsburgh Steelers staged a successful start today toward a second straight football title after 39 years of failure.

Rehearsals are scheduled to begin Wednesday.

Brig. Gen. Robert W. Smart, formerly vice president of the North American Rockwell Corporation and chief counsel of the House Armed Services Committee, died yesterday of cancer in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 66 years old.

Miss Margret Fine, a doctoral candidate in social psychology at Trinity College of the University of Dublin in Ireland, was married here yesterday evening, to Dr. Earl Edward Davis, a research professor of psychology at the Economic and Social Research Institute in Dublin.

Sweden's Social Democratic party, in power for 41 years, appeared early this morning to have just barely staved off the challenge of a non-Socialist coalition in the closest election in modern Swedish history. With nearly 90 per cent of the votes counted, the Social Democrats and their tacit allies, the Communist party, held a two-seat margin in a seesaw battle over the 350 seats in Parliament. The acceptance clears the way for rehearsals to begin tomorrow for the fall season.

NORMAL OPERATION The New York Philharmonic, ending a summer of playing in the parks, in the neighborhoods and to people sitting on rugs, starts a new regular season tonight, playing to an audience that comes in and sits on seats in Philharmonic Hall, 63d Street and Broadway (874-2424).

The International Business Machines Corporation was found guilty today of violations of the Sherman Antitrust Act and ordered to pay triple damages of $352.5-million to the Telex Corporation, a manufacturer of peripheral equipment for computers.

Governor Rockefeller declared here tonight that the Watergate scandal ultimately could become a "very significant turning point for America" by reversing a sense of moral decay that he said had tragically permeated "

Unprepared and uninspired, the New York Jets were the epitome of inefficiency tonight in a 23-7 loss to the Green Bay Packers in the opener of the Monday night TV series in the National Football League season.

A group representing about 100 large and small companies agreed here yesterday to fight efforts of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to eliminate by the end of 1974 its wide area telephone service (WATS).

The Treasury Department, invoking executive privilege, refused today to tell Senator Joseph M. Montoya whether President Nixon had instructed the Secret Service to wiretap the telephone of his brother F. Donald Nixon.

A bipartisan group of 33 Senators and Western gasoline station owners appealed separately to the Cost of Living Council today to revise Phase 4 oil industry regulations. Under the regulations, retailers have been required to roll back prices while other sectors of the oil industry have been allowed to raise prices.
It took only one batter to make the Yankees' Wayne Granger, purchased from the St. Louis Cardinals last month, a losing pitcher tonight.
A 20-year-old mother who fought in the courts to regain the daughter she gave up at birth, dropped the fight today "because the baby was getting too old to be moved around like a pawn."

A police officer who has been suspended for allegedly selling $35 worth of marijuana was denied yesterday a request that he be restored to duty and be given rehabilitation in the same way that the Police Department tries to help alcoholics.
Representatives of organizasions that are trying to finance self-help activities in poor communitiess said today new Federall legislation was needed f they are ever to get the necessary funds.
The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee voted in June to temporarily grant the New York Federal Reserve Bank great flexibility in carrying out monetary policy in July.
For Sundays at 7:30 P.M., the Columbia Broadcasting System has taxed its imagination and come forth with a series called "The New Perry Mason," starring Monte Markham. Not surprisingly, ...
C. R. Smith, the 74-year-old Texan who left American Airlines five years ago after building it into a colossus, is expected to be called back tomorrow as chairman of the financially sagging company.
Dr. Frank H. Krusen, an international authority on physical medicine and rehabilitation, died Sunday night at his home in Orleans, Mass. He was 75 years old.

The nation's food-retailing industry as a whole was described as "in a very poor financial position" by the National Association of Food Chains yesterday. But It still foresaw food prices stabilizing and even some declines by the first of the year.

Posing in the brisk breeze and bright sunshine on Columbus Avenue, in front of a shuttered restaurant, Controller Abraham D. Beame suggested yesterday that such vacant stores could be used as "police outposts"-small sub-units that could give "reassurance" to neighborhoods far from regular station houses.

The director of Houston's Museum of Fine Arts and the former director of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts will join the staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the museum's president, Douglas Dillon, has announced.

Rocky Thompson, who felt good enough to go dancing after the New York Giants' opening-game victory last Sunday, learned yesterday that he would be sidelined for at least four weeks with a neck injury.

Sweden faced a period of, political uncertainty today after near-final election results showed the governing Social Democrats and their non-Socialist challengers in an absolute deadlock in the fight for Parliament.

As five St. Louis players let Ron Wood's pop fly to the mound with two out in the ninth inning drop for a single, Felipe Alou scored the winning run from second base tonight and the Montreal Expos downed the Cardinals, 5-4, in the first game of a double-header.
Two more 'bombs exploded' in Britain today, one of them wounding an explosives expert as he was on his way to defuse the device, planted outside an office building in Birmingham.
A representative American family will be paying about $250 a year-1.8 per cent of $13,500 income-for pollution controls by 1976, the Council on Environmental Quality said today.
A senior official in Santiago, Chile, said that 5,200 civilians detained during the military take-over of the country would be tried by court-martial under wartime military laws.

The love affairs of poets tend to be more fervent than those of other mortals, more fervent and occasionally more confused. The love affair of the impetuous but unworldly Robert Browning for the sweetly determined but invalided Elizabeth Barrett has become one of the most famous of poetic history.

Federal District Judge Marvinin Frankel ruled yesterday that 30 American and British insurance companies must pay Pan American World Airways $24.3 million for a Boeing 747 jetliner destroyed by members of an Arab terrorist group in Cairo three years ago.

Santiago is still in a state of shock from the abrupt political surgery of last Tuesday. The visible symbols of the Government of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens and its allies further to the left are being obliterated as quickly as possible.
The move to a 10 per cent prime rate broadened a bit yesterday as several more major banks followed the lead of the Wells Fargo Bank, which moved up from the 93/4 per cent level last Thursday.
Skill in card play is to some extent measurable. Most players firmly believe that they are "above average" in this department, but how much above?
With just eight days left in the mission of Skylab 2, preparations have started on the ground and in space for the return of the astronauts, who have broken the record for time in space.
A 34-year-old woman who had received injections of a fertility hormone gave birth to sextuplets here late last night.

Navy had little trouble beating Virginia Military, 37-8, in the Middies' opener Saturday as Cleveland Cooper ran for 172 yards in 25 carries. Also, Navy and its new coach, George Welsh, came up with a bonus in Steve Dykes, a plebe (freshman) place-kicker.

An assistant district attorney said today that the death of an alleged mass slayer, Dan A. Corll, was justifiable homicide and that no charges would be filed against Elmer Wayne HenIey, 17 years old, already under indictment for six of 27 known murders of teen-aged boys.
When the President talks about getting on with the great tasks confronting America, it seems to be only foreign policy and war-making readiness that he has in mind. These are big tasks, all right.

The demolition of Lewisohn Stadium began yesterday morning when the wreckers' ball struck one of the concrete walls of what used to be a cultural center on the City College campus, and is now an unused and decaying arena.

A panel of Federal appeals judges decided yesterday to take no action against Judge Mark A. Costantino, who sits in Federal Court in Brooklyn and who had been the subject of complaints by Government lawyers and others.

The striking United Automobile Workers reached a tentative settlement today with the Chrysler Corporation that was described by Leonard Woodcock, the union president, as "a breakthrough" in giving the industrial worker more say over how long he will work and under what conditions.
Cuba today accused President Nixon of having instigated the coup in Chile last week in which the Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens was overthrown.

Despite all temptations to belong to other professions, John Kenneth Galbraith remains an economist, and in his new book, "Economics and the Public Purpose," .he boldly sets out to move his profession -and the literate public-beyond Keynes.

The British Government announced a plan today to outlaw unfair discrimination against women in employment and to promote equal opportunities in all fields of life.

The Ogden Corporation's Avondale shipyards subsidiary has signed contracts totalling $322.5-million to build three more large liquified natural gas carriers for the El Paso Natural Gas Company, bringing its total to six.
Changes have been so rapid in this burgeoning community that the barber shop down the road now advertises, "Two barbers-no waiting."

Activity on the American Stock Exchange continued Friday's erratic behavior. Prices were mixed, but the number of advances led declines and the Amex market value index was off, although only 3 of its 16 components showed a decrease.

Several large brokerage firms said yesterday that they would not raise commission rates on orders in excess of $5,000 until the New York Stock Exchange membership approved increases on smaller orders as well. That action is expected Sept. 24.

In calling on President Nixon yesterday to give voice to American concern over Moscow's latest assaults on individual liberties, the Senate emphasized that progress toward detente with the Soviet Union need not and should not involve sacrifice of this country's right to speak out in behalf of human freedom.

With the beginning of the fall planting season--the best time to put in a new lawn or repair an old one-homeowners are facing a shortage of grass seed and a skyrocketing increase in its price. Since spring, the cost has more than doubled.

Pope Paul VI today gave a long address to participants in an international congress on canon law, but passed over in silence a recommendation for a significant change in the Roman Catholic Church's rules on matrimony.

Tenants from the Northside community in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, who are being relocated to permit expansion of a factory, will be in new, permanent homes by next summer, city officials said yesterday.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., announced today that it would withdraw from motion picture distribution and dramatically cut back the production of films.

Liza Minnelli is patrial to his homemade hand-dipped chocolate wafers, Richard Avedon keeps his ground almond log by his bedside and Elizabeth Taylor survived her separation from Richard Burton with a supply of his chocolate-covered strawberries.
Kevin Loughery's preseason coaching debut was a success tonight as his New York Nets of the American Basketball Association defeated the Philadelphia 76eres, 94-88, at Veterans Memorial Arena.
John S. Lawson, board chairman and president of the Marine Midland Bank of New York, today opened the institution's first branch office in Asia.

France today walked out of the annual meeting of the South Pacific Conference, a regional aid body, when representatives of island territories strongly condemned the recent French nuclear tests over Mururoa.
A band of six to nine ment, apparently leftist guerrillas tried to kidnap one of Mexico's wealthiest industrialists today and he and four other persons were killed in a gun battle, the police said.

Sweden faced a period of political uncertainty today after near-final election results showed the governing, Social Democrats and their non-Socialist challengers in an absolute deadlock in the fight for Parliament.

The merger proposal of the Fruehauf Corporation and the Kelsey-Hayes Company involving an exchange of stock valued at about $92-million, announced a month ago, will include a tender offer for KelseyHayes stockholders.

Donald H. Segretti, who was hired to play tricks on the Democrats in the 1972 Presidential campaign, has agreed to plead guilty to an expanded fourcount indictment charging campaign law violations and to cooperate with the Watergate special prosecutor.

The chief reason multinational companies are disturbing to many governments and their citizens is that they represent "today's visible agents of change," Walter B. Wriston, chairman of the First National City Corporation, told the annual session of the International Industrial Conference here today.

The dollar weakened in relation to key European currencies yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here. Dealers said that the easing was the result of dollar liquidation, in reaction to the 5 per cent upward revaluation of the Dutch guilder during the weekend.

Norman H. Wilson, former director of the Asian Center in Tokyo of the American Friends Service Committee, and until recently director of the Antioch-Putney Graduate School of Education, died here Saturday of cancer. He was 47 years old and had recently been named director of school services for the School for International Training in Brattleboro.

IL TROVATORE, opera with music by Giuseppe Verdi, libretto by Salvatore Cammarano. Metropolitan Opera production staged by Nathaniel Merrill with sets and costumes by Attilio Colonnello; associate designer, David Reppa. Conductor, James Levine. At the Metropolitan Opera House.

Mrs. Billie Jean King swept two matches tonight in the $30,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.
World Team Tennis served another ace in its bid for recognition yesterday when the Pittsburgh Triangles announced the signing of Evonne Goolagong to a "generous" multiyear contract.

The United States and Panama have abandoned their original intention to build the final link of the Pan-American Highway by 1976, and it remains unclear how much longer the $150-million project will take.

If a women's version of the Harlem Globetrotters is ever established, Dottie McCrea of Matawan will qualify for the team with her ability and experience. Miss McCrea has played basketball in many cities in the United States, in Peru and now is starting a 10-month stay in Monaco.

Hank Aaron moved a step closer to Babe Ruth's record of 714 home runs tonight, hitting his 711th career homer.
Cushman Wakefield, the real estate and insurance corn pany, filed a $2-million suit yesterday against a competitor who allegedly lured away a Cushman vice president and his confidential information.

Lam is an epileptic and mentally retarded, but he was drafted into the South Vietnamese Army anyway because his family could not afford the bribe demanded by Government officials to certify him as unfit. Now, a year later, Lam has finally been discharged after his father went into debt to raise the million piasters ($2,000) the officials wanted.

Two union officials accused of embezzling $170,000 from union funds pleaded not guilty yesterday. The officials, Peter Ottley, 64 years old, president of local 144 of the Service Employees International Union, and Peter Byrne, 66, its secretary-treasurer were arraigned in Federal Court in Manhattan.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan suffered a minor stroke on Aug. 10 and was taken to St. Luke's Hospital, where he underwent surgery for a lung tumor on Sept. 7, Joseph C. Hogan, his brother, said late yesterday.

The head of a supply company that did almost $279,000 worth of business with the Passaic County Technical and Vocational High School, testified today that he paid about 5 per cent of that amount in "commissions" to Alex Smollok, the school's business manager.

The time may come when hatchery-reared Atlantic salmon stocked in certain small rivers, which are not now major salmon-producing streams, will provide substantial harvests of the species, says Lee Wulff, director of the International' Atlantic Salmon Foundation.

A secondary offering of 400,000 common shares of Citizens Southern National Bank of Georgia at 225/8 per share was made by Salomon Brothers. The company's stock, traded over-the-counter, closed at 221/4 bid, 223/4 asked, down 3/8.

A strange, mutant species of literary man has been romping here among the cool green hills of central Pennsylvania for four days now. The swarms of alien wordmen were first observed on Friday, and their eerie ways have proved deceptive.

The Los Angeles Lakers planned yesterday for the time when Wilt Chamberlain would no longer be with them. They obtained Elmore Smith, a young, proven 7-foot-1-inch center, from the Buffalo Braves for high-scoring Jim McMillian.
The steel industry rebounded in the week ended Sept. 15 to score the largest percentage gain in production for any single week to date this year.

A special Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee reported today that Henry A. Kissinger's role in the wiretapping of 17 officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971 "was not such as to bar him from confirmation" as Secretary of State.
East Flatbush parents lost an attempt yesterday to have a court overturn the recent appointment of Norman Desser as principal of Public School 208 in Brooklyn.

Few episodes in recent labor history have been more repulsive than the undisguised partnership between the scandal-ridden Teamsters Union and large-scale agricultural interests in California to smash the tiny United Farm Workers, headed by Cesar Chavez.
Thousands of persons, attracted by a sale of beef at prices as much as $1 a pound below regular prices, converged today on a downtown market.

At 8:25 last night, anyone who had bought a ticket for the Metropolitan Opera's 89th opening night, or anyone who had been invited, was inside the opera house watching the curtain come up on Verdi's "Il Trovatore."

Richard Lewisohn, the Republican party candidate for City Controller, yesterday issued a five-point program to improve the operation of the office and to establish a system of continuous monitoring of municipal agencies.

Negotiations between New York City and its uniformed services began to warm up with John J. DeLury, sanitationmen's leader, meeting Mayor Lindsay and proposing a nine-month agreement with no wage rise other than a retro-active cost of living increase.

Despite advances in birth control techniques that have sharply lowered the nation's birth rate, more than a third of the women in a national study of couples practicing birth control over a five-year period became pregnant anyway, according to a report made public yesterday.

Everyone has talked about museum decentralization, but the Whitney Museum--miracle of miracles!--has actually done something about it. It has now established a branch museum in an area of the city that, despite its celebrated concentration of corporate wealth and power, may justly be described as culturally deprived.
Maurice F. Granville, chairman and chief executive officer of Texaco, Inc., yesterday called upon the American public to "pause and examine" the nation's policy in the Middle East.

The General Motors Corporation said here yesterday that it had made a proposal to the Government of Saudi Arabia to build a plant in that nation for assembling cars and trucks. A spokesman said that arrangements had not been completed and declined to estimate the size of the undertaking. .
Stanton Griffis, the financier and former Ambassador to Poland, Egypt, Argentina and Spain, wed Mrs. Elizabeth Blakemore last Thursday in Palm Beach.
Japan has proposed to invest in, the construction of a huge petrochemical complex on Korea's south coast in a joint venture with South Korean companies.

Sidney P. Marland Jr., the Federal Government's chief education official, has submitted his resignation, authoritative sources said yesterday. They said an announcement would be made by the White House today.

Japan's Premier Kakuel Tanaka will fly next week to France, West Germany and Great Britain, bearing gifts. The Kyodo news agency in Tokyo reported that Mr. Tanaka would offer $1-million in each of the three countries to assist universities with Japanese studies programs.

Some high White House officials have been saying in private conversations in the last few days that it might be best for Vice President Agnew to resign and allow President Nixon to choose a new Vice President.

King Hussein of Jordan declared an amnesty today for political prisoners, including Palestinian guerrillas jailed since 1970, in a move toward Arab reconciliation.
Six Nassau County patrolmen, battling six-foot waves and 35 mile-an-hour winds, tonight completed a two-way relay swim of the English Channel but failed to set a record.

During Maurice H. Nadjari's first year as the special state prosecutor in charge of investigating corruption here, he has obtained indictments against 35 persons-including a District Attorney, a judge, the president of the City Tax Commis.

The White House acknowledged today the probable existence of a tape recording of a 1974 meeting between President Nixon and leaders of the dairy industry that occurred just be. fore the Administration announced a major milk price support increase.

Cemp Investments, Ltd., owned by the Bronfman family of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., in Canada. and other investors in the group announced yesterday the acquisition of 1.5-million shares of Signal Companies. Inc., stock.
The cliche about Sweden is that she has the world's highest standard of living, income levels almost as high as the United States, an unparalleled system of social-welfare benefits and pretty girls.

Co-op City in the Bronx was hit last night by a series of incidents of vandalism including flooding in seven high-rise buildings when fire hoses on top floors were turned on by unknown persons.

Jim Bouton, the controversial former New York Yankee pitcher, has joined WCBS-TV as sportscaster, it was announced yesterday by Ed Joyce, director of news for Channel 2.

The New York Philharmonic, living dangerously, opened its season last night with a gala Pension Fund Benefit Concert, and with an unresolved musicians' contract dispute hanging over Philharmonic Hall like a sword.
The president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, Edward B. Rust, said yesterday that the consumer-advocate Ralph Nader was miscast as an "enemy" of the American business system.

A State Supreme Court jury today convicted Carlos Feliciano, a Puerto Rican nationalist, on four of six charges that stemmed from the discovery of a bomb that failed to go off at the General Electric Building at 51st Street and Lexington Avenue.

The tentative pact agreed to yesterday between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation contains a provision that is expected to spur demands by labor for enactment of national health insurance, which has been stalled in Congress for three years.

Theo Lefevre, a forceful Social-Christian political who was Premier from 1961 to 1965, died of cancer here this morning. His age was 59.
East and West Germany were admitted as members of the-United Nations today: at the opening of the 28th annual General Assembly.

A senior official of the Seoul district prosecutor's office announced today that South Korean investigators had been unable to find any clues as to who kidnapped Kim Dae Jung, a Korean opposition leader, in Tokyo and brought him to Seoul early last month.

Geotek Resources, at the opening of hearings on whether a temporary receiver should be appointed to supervise the affairs of the Geotek complex of companies, denied today an assertion by the Securities and Exchange. Commission that the companies are "insolvent."

Services today 1:30 P.M., at "The Riverside," 1250 Central Ave., Far Rockaway, L. I. In lieu of flowers Contributions may be made to the National Leukemia Foundation.

Eleven years after Ne Win seized power In Burma, he remains one of the most remote and enigmatic leaders in Asia. He disappears from public view for months, his name Is rarely mentioned in the Government-controlled press and he shuns almost all diplomats.

The Environmental Protection Agency released figures today on mileage performance of 1974 automobiles, placing the 2,000 pound Honda Civic at the top of the list and the 4,000-pound Ferrari-365 GTB-4 at the bottom.

Tens of thousands of Swedes, many weeping, bade farewell to King Gustaf VI Adolf today as a motorcade bearing his coffin journeyed from southern Sweden to the royal palace here.

Frederick E. Meyer, actor, stage manager and director of the Timbers Playhouse in Mount Gretna, Pa., died Sunday in an automobile accident here. His age was 63, and he lived at 333 West 18th Street in New York.

A spokesman for the Chilean junta, giving official figures for the first time, said today that 95 people had been killed and 300 wounded since last Tuesday when the three-year-old Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens was overthrown in a military coup.

The State Commission of Investigation, opening hearings today into alleged corruption in the Albany Police Department, heard witnesses testify that policemen had carried out burglaries, had covered up the crimes with official sanction and then had sought to intimidate citizens who complained.
The Soviet Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced plans here yesterday to build a $110-million International Trade Center in the center of Moscow.

Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state consumer health services director Who was stripped of his power to close kitchens at state institutions because of unsanitary conditions, urged Governor Cahill today to investigate the administration of the institutions.

One of the Stanek sextuplets died tonight, but the five other babies remained in fair to satisfactory condition.

A public relations and advertising concern in Woodmere, L.I., agreed not to use the Nassau County seal on its stationery after two political opponents of Ralph G. Caso, the Republican County Executive, charged that such use created the impression of official endorsement.
A coalition of antiwar and church groups opened the International Days of Concern for South Vietnamese Political Prisoners here today.
Columbia University returned to normal activity yesterday after members of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union completed their first full day on the job.

Despite his familiar smile and the warm reception he received last night, Governor Rockefeller saw that something was wrong the moment he arrived in Cherry Hill to deliver the principal speech at the dinner starting Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.' s Republican campaign for Governor.
The Senate cleared the way today for early passage, possibly tomorrow, of a bill to establish Federal standards for the improvement of private pension systems.
Sixty years ago 'a Scarsdale resident, Emily Butler, donated most of the 39 acres she owned along the Bronx River to encourage construction of a landscaped parkway.

A Federal judge in Newark yesterday upheld an Air Force decision to switch a potential $75-million jet-engine repair contract from the Curtiss-Wright Company of Wood-Ridge to a concern in Texas. The decision, by Judge James A. Coolahah, could result in a layoff of more than 1,200 workers at the Jersey plant of Curtiss-Wright, which has had the contract since 1967. The Air Force contract is for overhaul and maintenance of engines on KC-135 jet tankers.

Prime Minister Heath issued a warning last night-which he apparently retracted tonight that Northern Ireland might have to be fully integrated into Britain if the current efforts for a political solution failed.
With the Giants bound for the Yale Bowl in New Haven for their final five games, someone asked if they were going to play in button-down shirts.
The Communications Satellite Corporation awarded a $65.9-million contract today to the Hughes Aircraft Company to build four highcapacity domestic satellites.
Baroness Charles P. Wrangell-Rokassowsky of Phoenix, Ariz., and formerly of New York, died here Monday at the Peninsula Hospital. Her age was 84.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 16 to 1 today to recommend the confirmation of Henry A. Kissinger as Secretary of State. The full Senate will probably approve the nomination on Thursday or Friday.

Everyone has talked about museum decentralization, but the Whitney Museum--miracle of miracles!--has actually done something about it. It has now established a branch museum in an area of the city that, despite its celebrated concentration of corporate wealth and power, may justly be described as culturally deprived.
Stan Smith opened the defense of his Pacific Southwest tennis championship today with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Mike Machette, a young player he helped to develop.

The high-intensity sodium street lights that have been installed here to help reduce crime may be killing trees, according to research by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The RCA Corporation demonstrated yesterday what it described as "the largest solid state image sensor" in the industry.

Ron Johnson received several shocks in Sunday's New York Giant 34-14 victory over the Houston Oilers. The most frightening, of course, was the bruised ribs he suffered in the fourth quarter while throwing a block for his running mate, Vin Clements.
Prices closed up slightly yesterday on the -American Stock Exchange. They opened higher, then slipped but rebounded before the close in stepped-up trading.

T. F. Willers, chairman and chief executive of the Champion International Corporation, announced yesterday that the company had committed $1.25-billion in capital expenditures over the next five years to strengthen its three major businesses.
An Icelandic official declared today that United States troops must leave the Atlantic alliance's air base at Keflavik and ruled out any possibility of negotiation on the subject.

Homers proved the life of the party tonight but singles spiked the punch as the Boston Red Sox feasted on their Yankee "cousins" for the 13th time this season and seven of eight at Fenway Park by a score of 4-2. Boston leads the year's series, 13-4.

Sunshine in Chicago after days of rain in the Midwest was enough to depress prices yesterday for soybeans, wheat and corn. on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Both sides were reported far apart last night in efforts to end the 18-day strike by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians that has forced the New York City Opera Company to cancel all performances since Sept. 1.

Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, received a generally favorable reception from a key Congressional subcommittee today for his proposed new system for measuring the performance of television stations.
Chevrolet announced yesterday that it would drop two engine types and limit sales of three others in 1975 to meet interim Federal exhaust emission standards.
The unpredictable St. Louis Cardinals kept alive their hopes for the National League Eastern Division title yesterday, and' at the same time dealt a blow to those of the Montreal Expos.

Curt Blefary has two mementos of the eight years he played major league baseball. One is a World Series ring he earned as a member of the 1966 Baltimore Orioles and the other is a lifetime pass, engraved with his name, to major league games. Blefary, only 30 years old, lives in New Shrewsbury and is selling cars in Toms River. He wonders why he is no longer playing ball for a living.

Sometimes politics seems to be as much a staple in Maryland as crab cakes. The Federal grand jury investigation into alleged kickbacks to officials from consulting firms has given devotees something to nibble on well in advance of the 1974 political season.
Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan today received a warm welcome from President Nixon and promises of generosity toward Pakistan's aid and credit needs.
The Food and Drug Administration said today it had tested more than 36,000 cans of evaporated milk and concluded there was no danger of high lead content.
Edward Warfield, who was in a company of black soldiers accused of carrying out the "Brownsville Raid" at the turn of the century, died today of an apparent heart attack at the age of 89.
Owens-Illinois, Inc., announced yesterday that it had increased prices of its glass containers by "somewhat less than 5 per cent," effective immediately.

A collection of more than 400 antique ivories and 600 from the Orient, as well as 1,000 other items including jades, bronze sculptures, snuff bottles and Art Deco ivories is being auctioned off at Kennedy Air. port's International Hotel.

A suspected major importer of cocaine and two alleged accomplices were arrested by a team of undercover policemen last night and charged with selling two and a quarter pounds of cocaine to one of the officers in a bar and grill in Brooklyn, the police reported.

Delegates of 35 countries opened the second, down-to-business phase of the European security conference here today amid debate in both Western Europe and the United States on just how fast and how far the move toward warmer relations with the Soviet bloc should proceed.

The settlement of the brief strike of Chrysler workers may mark as much of a turning point in labor history as the memorable General Motors contract of 1948. That agreement represented a long step toward bringing an element of science into the determination of what constituted a fair wage increase.
Herbert W. Mullin, 26 years old, who was convicted of slaying 10 persons early this year, was sentenced today to Life imprisonment of each of two counts of first-degree murder,

The local law-making body of New York City-the City Council-is too largely a non-representative, nonfunctioning, non-investigative, non-legislating, non-meeting collection of anonymous people who spend too little time at City Hall and respond too often to private political pressures. We suspect that any poll of New Yorkers would turn up pathetically few who could even name their City Councilman.
The Whitney Museum of American Art, launching a satellite from Madison Avenue and 75th Street, will make a landing in lower Manhattan today when it opens a branch at 55 Water Street.

The State Commission of Investigation ended today its hearing on charges of waste, laxity and corruption in the management of state surplus property and said that findings of improprieties or criminal activities would be turned over to "the propel law enforcement authorities."
Dr. Donald L. Hutchinson, chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Pittsburgh, died of cancer yesterday in his home in suburban Fox Chapel.

Beginning today, the State Division for Youth will provide separate facilities for children who need supervision for behavior problems and for children convicted of serious crimes such as murder and robbery. ry.

Volunteering lavish praise of Abraham D. Beame, his mayoral running mate, State Senator Harrison J. Goldin spoke expansively yesterday of his plans to infuse new "creativity" into the City Controller's office as Mr. Beame's heir.
While the United States Ryder Cup team participated in its first formal practice session today, Christy O'Connor of Dublin buoyed the hopes of Britain and Ireland's squad with a round of 61.
The State Court of Appeals yesterday gave the City Council until Oct. 15 to come up with a third redistricting plan. The court issued the deadline in an order that did not include an opinion.

The International Wheat Council said today that the world wheat shortage had apparently been reduced. In a revised market report, the council said that the wheat shortage - the difference between demand and supply would range between three million and six million tons during the council's 1973-74 year.

The United States should abandon all covert operations in foreign countries except the gathering of intelligence. That proposal is made by Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, the former Attorney General and Under Secretary of State, in an article just published in Foreign Affairs.
President Nixon plans to concentrate on domestic problems until Congress recesses. Aides say the date of any European trip is now uncertain.
