The deficit in the nation's "basic" balance of international payments--generally considered the most meaningful of the four definitions used--declined further in the second quarter to the lowest level in almost three years, the Commerce Department reported today.

Directors of American Airlines returned C. R. Smith-at 74, almost 10 years older than any other major airline chief in the nation-as chairman and chief executive officer yesterday in the hope that he can pull the troubled airline out of its financial dilemma.

The Nixon Administration moved today to enlist the support of consumer groups for its proposals to restructure the nation's financial system. One of the main proposals would allow saving institutions to offer interest-bearing checking accounts.

The Giants will play their last football game in the Yankee Stadium on Sunday. Or will it really be the last? It certainly is supposed to be, because the construction crews are about to begin the face-lifting and modernizetion of the ancient ball park, shunting the Giants off to the Yale Bowl for the remainder of this season and all of next.

Seeing Bizet's "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night was particularly interesting in that a production experienced a year ago as new and arresting was now being put on view as a standard repertory item.
Distillers Corporation Seagrams, Ltd., reported yesterday the highest quarterly sales and earnings and record results for the fiscal year ended July 31.
Howard P. Jones, who served as Ambassador to Indonesia from 1958 to 1965, one of the longest such terms of continuous service in recent times, died yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old.
Walter Schirra Sr., father of Walter Schirra Jr., retired Navy captain and astronaut, died in Veterans Hospital yesterday. He was 79 years old.

McDonald's Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a secondary offering of 952,312 -common shares, 100,000 of which are being sold by chairman, Ray A. Kroc. After the sale, Mr. Kroc will own 7,016,402 shares. The company's stock was up 3/4 at 68 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Two Long Island teen-agers with dreams of sailing to Europe in a $110,000 ketch they allegedly stole were seized on Long Island Sound yesterday after an air-and-sea search directed partly by the boat's owner from a rented airplane.
Stan Smith struggled to beat 20 - year - old Dick Bohrnstedt of Redlands, 5-7, 6-2, 6-3, in the second round of the $75,000 Pacific Southwestopen tennis tournament today.

A four-level garage on West 28th Street collapsed early yesterday afternoon, burying dozens of automobiles, heavily damaging scores more and leaving several dangling precariously in the remains of the building. There was no one in the building at the time.
A graphic-arts company and its president have been acquitted of charges that they paid kickbacks to an executive of American Airlines to obtain business contracts with the airline.

The efforts of 1,300 workers at a watch company in France to keep on making watches after management decided to close down the factory has caused some fundamental questioning here about the relation of labor and capital and the rights of workers to participate in the decisions of management.

Richard S. Robie, a financier and leader in the automobileand truck-rental industry, died yesterday in Peter Ben Brigham Hospital, He was 70 years old and had homes in Marblehead and in Mirror Lake, N. H.

The Health Department has named 17 more restaurants and food establishments as second offenders against the health code. If a third inspection later this month finds the violations still uncorrected, closing orders could result.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference voted yesterday to conduct a 16-team postseason basketball tournament starting in 1975 to help raise more operating revenue for the conference.

A Federal judge yesterday refused a request by Fire Island property owners to order a halt to all commercial development on the island.

The Jean Cocteau Theater, one of a number of off-OffBroadway houses clustered around the Bowery, is embarked, in Its third year, on its first season of repertory.

The Brooklyn Museum, which is the proud possessor of a renowned collection of ancient Egyptian art, has mounted an extraordinary loan show of objects from the Amarna period (13781362 B.C.) which has rarely before served as the subject of a special exhibition.
The Senate passed tonight a bill for Federal standards to protect the rights of workers covered by private pension plans. The vote was unanimous, 93 to 0.
The Nixon Administration has been stung by the growing criticism in the United States and in Soviet dissident circles of its effort to move from confrontation to cooperation with the Soviet Union.
Aldred Udell, former head or Udell Travel Service, died yesterday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 415 East 52d Street and in East Hampton, L.I.

The Federal Government has approved the controversial alignment of Interstate Route 895 across Burlington County to link Route 295 in New Jersey with Route 95 in Pennsylvania, the State Transportation Department announced today.

When Mrs. Mary Stephenson moved from the East to Phoenix, Ariz., several months ago, she chose a house Just a 15-minute drive to the airport. And with good reason. She now is doing so much judging, she's in a plane almost every weekend.

Chile's new military Government has wisely ended censorship of outgoing news dispatches and allowed a planeload of foreign reporters to fly in from Argentina. The outside world will thus have its first chance to judge the junta's claim that the situation in Chile has largely returned to normal after the violent overthrow of the Popular Unity Government and the tragic death of President Salvador Allende.
Out of the enmities loosed in 19th-century Japan by Western Insistence on an end to its isolation, the director Masahiro Shinoda has fashioned another of his vexing samurai dramas.

Should Vice President Agnew resign? Will he resign? The White House has undoubtedly considered the question. Mr. Agnew must have asked it of himself. He apparently has discussed it with at least one political friend.

MATANE, Quebec--There was a time when Raoul Roux, the ebullient proprietor of Hotel Belle Plage on the northwest corner of the Gaspe Peninsula, had to have help from a black bear to attract business, but that no longer applies.

Gov. Meldrim Thomson, Jr., who accused Senate Watergate investigators of "Gestapo-like tactics" in the state, says he will continue to urge New Hampshire citizens "to cooperate fully with committee members."
The Central Intelligence Agency is planning to abolish the 15year-old system of turning out what it calls national intelligence estimates, sometimes as many as 50 a year.
A White House meeting of Administration officials and state Governors today appeared to move the Government closer to management of heating oil supplies.

Nolan Ryan broke the American League oneseason strike-out record and pitched a five-hitter in leading the California Angels to a 6-2 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight in the first game of a double-header.

The failure of the House of Representatives to override President Nixon's veto of the minimum wage bill condemns millions of workers at the bottom of the income scale to intolerable exploitation in a period of skyrocketing living costs.
Talking Picture almost was upset in the $111,250 Matron at Belmont Park yesterday, but the star of the Elmendorf stable rallied at the right time under Ron Turcotte to register the triumph by a head.
The energy difficulties of the United States are not the result of any "Arab oil squeeze," at least up to now, John Lichtblau, head of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said yesterday.

State and local housing officials here expressed hope yesterday that the housing policies announced by President Nixon yesterday would permit construction of certain projects whose fate had been in doubt since last January.
In major changes in the top management of the Knight Newspapers, Inc., of Miami, the directors yesterday elected Lee Hills as the chairman and chief executive officer.
The Skylab 2 astronauts photographed the Swiss Alps today searching for clues to avalanches. Over Israel they collected data on geology, water resources and crops.

The Assembly Committee on Governmental Employes will hold public hearings next month to determine whether teachers and other public employes in nonessential services should be excluded from the nostrike provisions of the Taylor Law.

Consumer groups rallied to the support of Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state's embattled consumer health director who has been stripped of his powers to close kitchens at state institutions because of unsanitary coneditions.
A homemade scrapbook full. of hard-to-read mirror handwriting is slated to go into publication this winter at a price of $10,000, which makes it perhaps the world's .most. expensive new set of books.

President Nixon, in a message to Congress, proposed today that the Government provide housing allowances for poor and moderate-income families rather than continue what he described as a wasteful, inequitable system of subsidizing buildings for the needy.
Five counselors were injured Tuesday night in a disturbance involving 12 youths in detention at the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx, the police said.
A lawsuit filed last year to shut off telephone service to the Democratic National Committee because it had not paid a large bill was dismissed today in United States District Court.
Charles W. Colson refused today to answer questions put to him by the Senate Watergate committee, claiming his constitutional right against self-in-crimination.
The 35-nation European security conference decided today to allow delegates of Israel and five Arab countries to appear before it and present their views on the continent's security.
A former policeman told the State Commission of Investigation today that he had committed 16 burglaries with 11 fellow policemen, including a lieutenant and two sergeants still on the force.
Willie Mays has finally decided to end his 22-year career in baseball, and his retirement will be announced today by the New York Mets.

Sweden's new King, Carl XVI Gustaf, was formally installed today but not crowned. His reign began a few hours before final unofficial returns confirmed that the governing Social Democrats would have the backing of only half the members of Parliament elected last Sunday.
Carman R. Runyon Jr., a pioneer in the development of FM radio, died yesterday. He was 80 years old and lived at 130 East End Avenue.
The South Vietnamese Government today charged Hanoi with making "intensive warlike preparations to reopen hostilities" in South Vietnam.

A survey released yesterday by Gallup International reports that 45 per cent of leading figures in 70 non-Communist nations say their attitude toward the United Nations has become less favorable. No change in view was reported by 37 per cent.

To, the Editor: With tax credits now ruled out by the Supreme Court, the cost of parochial education ever more burdensome and the fiscal requirements of public education ever more demanding, it's time for parents sending their children to parochial and private schools to join a new majority in order to obtain tax relief.

Sagging prices marked trading in many commodity futures yesterday. For consumers the most significantt declines have come recently in live cattle contracts, reflecting heavier-than-expected offerings at terminals by farmers and stiff consumer resistance at the meat counters.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company had its best quarter ever in the three months ended Aug. 31, according to figures released here yesterday. Both revenues and earnings reached new highs for the quarter and for the 12 months ended Aug. 31.
Prices and trading volume Spurted sharply upward yesterdary on the American Stock Exchange as the number of large blocks traded climbed to 18 from 12 in each of the previous two sessions.
City and state education officials reported yesterday that : city pupils had scored gains on recent reading tests.
A Georgetown University research team reported today that pregnancy appears to partly disable a woman's defense mechanism against severe viral infections.

The stock market staged a broad and spirited rally yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrials rose 19.11 points to 910.37. A recovery in I.B.M. shares, climbing 11 3/4 to 270 3/4 after recent sharp weakness. sparked the rally.

Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives have reportedly made plans to insist, if Vice President Agnew leaves office before his term expires, that his successor pledge not to seek election as President in 1976.

When Douglas Fraser, a vice president of the United Automobile Workers union, made visits to the plants recently some workers came to him and said: "Doug, you've got to do something. Things have got to change."

The Central Intelligence Agency has told the American Civil Liberties Union that it will oppose the publication of about 100 pages of allegedly classified material contained in an account by a former C.I.A.' official of the agency's internal workings.

The Memphis Tams have selected forwards John Baum and Jim Ard, from the New York Nets as compensation for signing a rookie, Larry Kenon, the Nets announced today. The Nets were permitted to freeze six veteran players from their active roster-excluding rookies-after the American Basketball Association commissioner, Mike Storen, ruled earlier this week that the Tams Were to be compensated. Kenon, the Tams' No. 1 draft choice,

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective jodgment of quality in relation t the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.
Ben Webster, the American jazz tenor saxophonist who played in the Fletcher Henderson, Duke Ellington, and Count Basie orchestras, died today of cerebral thrombosis. He was 64 years old.

The Philadelphia Orchestra tonight played the last concert but one on its trip to China. The program was familiar-- Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony, Respighi's "Pines of Rome," Barber's Adagio for Strings and the "Yellow River" concerto with Yin Chengchung as soloist.

Crucial negotiations in Washington between the Federal prosecutor here and Vice President Agnew's lawyers brought the Federal grand jury investigation of bribery and kickback allegations against Mr. Agnew to a halt today.

A' hero of the Chilean left known as "Comandente Pepe" has been captured with 17 of his men while attempting to organize resistance in the south against the military junta, it was officially announced here today.
Another New York brewery has ceased production, leaving only two operating here. As late as 1953, there were five and after Repeal, more than a dozen breweries in New York.
The Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community called today for a study of the possibility of establishing contacts with the Soviet bloc's trading organization.

Elliot Roosevelt has been invited to appear before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations "next week or as soon as possible thereafter" to answer charges that he was involved in a plot to kill the Governor of The Bahamas at the time.
Gamblers Anonymous, a self-help group with no promotion department, appears to be making quiet progress in the widely promoted shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

Indian Head, Inc., which has become a diversified industrial company through acquisition and internal development, yesterday reached an agreement in principle to sell about 15 per cent of its common shares to a privatelyheld Netherlands-based industrial company.

A majority of Governor Rockefeller's closest advisers are recommending that he not seek a fifth term and instead concentrate all his efforts on a bid for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1976.
You could ride a bus almost anywhere in and around New Haven, Hartford or Stamford today for a 5-cent fare. And if you didn't have nickelwell, they were being given away free on the street corners.

Dr. William R. R. Granger Jr., who had been a physician in Brooklyn for 52 years at his retirement in 1970, died Sunday of Parkinson's disease in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 82 years old and lived in Smithtown, L.I.
Socrate Barozzi, a New York Philharmonic violinist from 1934 to 1959 who had often been soloist at stadium, park and promenade concerts here, died Saturday in San Antonio, Tex., at the age of 79.

A Government informant, Pershing O. Gervais, testified in United States District Court here today that an attorney allegedly supplied to him by District Attorney Jim Garrison, a defendant in a bribery case here, had talked with Mr. Garrison's lawyers about letting them "write the script" for the trial in exchange for $50,000.

The unanimous vote in the Senate for comprehensive reform of private pension plans is not only a significant contribution to improved old-age protection for American workers but also a reassuring sign of vitality in the legislative process. Last year a wrecking operation by the Senate Finance Committee killed an excellent reform measure sponsored by the Labor Committee.

Philharmonic Hall, which opened 11 years ago this month, yesterday was renamed Avery Fisher Hall in appreciation of a "major gift" of undisclosed size by a pioneer manufacturer of high-fidelity phonograph and radio equipment. Informed sources in musical and financial circles here immediately estimated the over-all gift at $8-million to $10-million.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that "very little, if any, justification, was presented in most instances" for the White House-sanctioned wiretapping of the phones of 13 officials and four newsmen from 1969 to 1971.
The Bank of France today raised its basic lending rate from 9.5 per cent to 11 per centa postwar high and the second increase in two months.
The women at Ms. magazine are very happy indeed these days, for they are managing, with a boldness not always seen in their male counterparts, what has become a miniconglomerate.
Jordan today released the last of the 747 Palestinian guerrillas pardoned by King Hussein as part of a gesture of reconciliation toward the Palestinians as well as toward Egypt and Syria.
Terrorists exploded a large bomb inside an army barracks in London's Chelsea section early today. Two soldiers and three civilians were injured.

Safeguards to protect human rights in the sterilization of persons under 21 years of age, or who are legally incapable of consenting to the operation, will be issued tomorrow by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

The chairman of the State Assembly Committee on the Election Law yesterday said that even if Republican campaign officials did aid Liberal candidates in 1972 in order to deny victory to Democrats, he could see nothing illegal in that.

President Nixon's lawyers and Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Watergate case, informed the United States Court of Appeals here today that they had failed to reach a compromise on access to Presidential tape recordings bearing on the Watergate crimes.

The State Department de. scribed as "absurd" today any suggestion that the United States had financed the truck drivers' strike in Chile that preceded the military overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens last week.

A $564-million schoolconstruction program for 1974-75, which would provide 52,700 more seats for pupils and make possible improvements to many existing schools, was proposed yesterday by School Chancellor Irving Anker.

Four teen-age boys died when their car crashed into a brick pillar in Little Falls in Passaic County. The victims were Richard Seel, 17 years old, of Cedar Grove, the driver; Vernon Holscald, 16, of North Caldwell and John Haszonich and Sean Fitzpatrick, both 16, of Cedar Grove.
A two-alarm fire on the 15th floor of an 18-story apartment house in Rego Park, Queens, caused injuries to 14 firemen yesterday, fire officials reDorted. Officials said the blaze,

About 500 persons connected with harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway crowded into three courtrooms in the County Court Building here today in response to subpoenas issued by Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn in his investigation of irregularities in races at the WestburY track.

The Avery Fisher endownment, while it will alleviate the financial burden of one constituent of Lincoln Center, serves to throw into sharp relief the extraordinary dimensions of the fiscal crises of all the Center's cultural components.

Dr. Fordyce Barker St. John, an eminent surgeon, teacher and clinical investigator, died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, which he helped plan and to which he devoted his professional life and energies. He was 89 years old and lived at 520 East 86th Street.
The pragmatic moderate and conservative Arab leaders who control most of the area between the Nile and the Persian Gulf are fashioning a new solidarity.

Earl Clifton Reno, a leader in major labor demonstrations in the Depression years, died Sunday at his home here of a heart ailment complicated by emphysema. He was 68 years old.
" The People Show" has been called England's "most original" show. I don't know about "original," but it is certainly one of the most Curious shows that I have seen.

The Senate Democratic whip, Robert C. Byrd, said today that he was "sufficiently impressed" by the doubts of some scientists to question whether nuclear power plants were a major risk to the safety of the United States.
On stage the Moody Blues rock group, takes, it calculates, one hour and 45 minutes to go through its act. The British group arrives in New York next month on a 10 country tour.
Mrs. Jacqueline Jackson smiled at the hordes of schoolchildren moving through the exhibit she had conceived and said: "What's so beautiful about it is they're bringing pencils and papers along."

James H. Quello, a retired broadcasting executive from Detroit, will be nominated for membership on the Federal Communications Commission, the White House announced today. Mr. Quello, 69 years old, is a former vice president of the Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation.

A study presented last night at a meeting of Community Board 2 in Greenwich Village said that the proposed reconstruction of the West Side Highway would do 'little to solve the problem of traffic congestion along Manhattan's West Side, and could possibly even become an alternate route for trucks that now use New Jersey highways.

Prices rose again in continued good volume on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-cournter.market yesterday. The, Amex market-value index rose 1.01 to 102.29 with 3,883,210 shares being traded, compared with 3,947,000 the day before.

Melvin's Woe driven by Joe O'Brien, won the one-mile Little Brown Jug pace for 3-year-olds today. Melvin's Woe, owned by Thurman Downing of Cleveland, won the first division in the split 17-horse field in 1:57 3-5, and turned in a 1:59 2-5 clocking in taking the eight-horse raceoff.

Norman Blankman, Independent party candidate for Nassau County Executive, said today that a Republican committeeman had been denied a promotion in a county job after refusing to give the Republican party $100.

The special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, today challenged five of the original bugging conspirators to substantiate their charges that they were lured into crime by "high government officials."

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped by 1,115,359 shares to 16,844,252 shares in the month ended Sept. 14. It was the lowest short position on the Big Board since January, 1972, the exchange said.

All five of the surviving Stanek sextuplets rallied today. Doctors conceded that they were still worried, but said they had no reason to hope for more improvement.

If a partnership has a strong six-card suit in one major opposite a singleton, and a similar holding in the other, the other way round, it might seem a matter of indifference which suit became trumps. But if one suit split three-three and the other four-two, the former would no doubt seem more desirable.

The slayer of a 19-year-old Seton Hall coed being sought by the police may bear the marks of a brutal struggle with his karate-trained victim in a secluded tree-fringed lot of a quiet residential section here.

AREA A - Small-to-medium-sized striped bass are being caught from the beach at Surf City, N.J., with regularity. An occasional large blue or fluke is also being taken. Fluke are in Barnegat Bay at Beach Haven and Barnegat Inlets.

A special offering of 129,300 common shares of the Zale Corporation at 20 3/8 was completed yesterday by Shields and Company. The company's stock was up 1/4 at 20 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

An Albany policeman told the State Commission of Investigation today that he had carried out "many" burglaries and larcenies with fellow policemen and said that "to remain in good standing" with his colleagues he had felt compelled to pretend that he was stealing even more than he was.

One of every five welfare cases investigated in the state has been closed in the first two months of face-to-face interviews with welfare families, the State Department of Social Services announced yesterday.

The Senate began today what is expected to be a protracted debate on the Nixon Administration's defense policies, with the issues of military spending enmeshed in a confrontation between two senior and proud Scnators-Stuart Symington of Missouri and Henry M. Jackson of Washington.
Governor Cahill announced today that the state would move quickly to provide up to $100million in emergency home mortgage funds to ease New Jersey's growing housing crisis.

The Minnesota Twins signed Manager Frank Quilici today to manage again in 1974 with an increase in salary despite a losing session. "I feel Frank has come a long way as a manager," said Calvin Griffin, the Twins' president.

The slayer of a 19-year-old Seton Hall coed being sought by the police may bear the marks of a brutal struggle with his karate-trained victim in a secluded tree-fringed lot of a quiet residential section here.
Hank Aaron of the Atlanta 23 Braves says he knows the secret of Dave Johnson's home-run success and it has nothing to do with playing in Atlanta Stadium.
Major copper companies said yesterday they had not communicated with the new Chilean military Government about the possible reopening of mines there.

President Nixon and the head of Chile's military junta, Gen Augusto Pinochet Ugartce, were attacked in a poem published here today and reportedly written by Pablo Neruda, the Chilean poet who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1971.
House Speaker Carl Albert indicated today his support for some form of public financing of Federal election campaigns. Without specifying details of election law reforms he preferred,

Russell L. Hoyt's Destination, a Cuthbertson and Cassian 43-foot sloop that flies the New York Yacht Club burgee, was first to finish and also the winner on corrected time in the International Offshore Rule Division I today.

South Africa's police ignited both an internal crisis and an international incident when they killed eleven black miners and wounded more than twenty others during a riot at the country's largest gold mine last week. The shootings inevitably rekindled painful memories for South Africans-black, white and colored--of the slaying of 69 Africans at Sharpeville in 1960 for protesting the Nationalist Government's harsh racial laws.

City Buildings Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff said yesterday that cars were parked without legal authorization on the roof of the Travelers Garage on West 28th Street when the building collapsed Wednesday.

Two leading Democrats are now on record as saying that if Vice President Agnew resigns or is shoved, President Nixon should have no trouble in choosing Mr. Agnew's successor and getting the Democratic-controlled Congress to approve the President's personal choice.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Philip R. Mather, board chairman ot the American Social Health Association, died, apparently of a heart attack, last evening. He was 79 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill.

The United States leads the world in advanced communication's research but lags, in some important respects, in applying that technology for the nation's benefit, according to a report released today by the National Academy of Engineering.
Maurice E. Olen, once considered a retailing "boy wonder" who headed the H. L. Green variety store chain and was indicted and fined in 1961 for allegedly violating laws of

An Albany policeman told the State Commission of Investigation today that he had carried out "many" burglaries and larcenies with fellow policemen and said that "to remain in good standing" with his colleagues he had felt compelled to pretend that he was stealing even more than he was.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that "very little, if any, justification, was presented in most instances" for the White House-sanctioned wiretapping of the phones of 13 officials and four newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

Malcolm F. Forbes, the 54year-old magazine publisher who collects art and real estate, had his first balloon ride 15 months ago. Yesterday he announced plans to start a cross-country flight on Oct. 3 from the Oregon coast

At the prompting of Representative Bella S. Abzug, the House Public Works Committee placed an obstacle yesterday in the path toward Federal approval of the city's plan to build a $200-million convention center over the Hudson River.

Enemy shelling of this provincial capital has subsided to the point at which one person was killed and 14 were wounded today - relatively inconsequential casualties in a town that has seen 8,000 killed or wounded in the last three weeks.

Postmaster General E. T. Klassen said tonight that he would seek authority next week to raise first-class and airmail postage rates by 2 cents each to pay for recent wage increases and capital improvements.

Edward W. Duffy, 47, president of the Marine Midland Banks, Inc., of Buffalo, will become chief executive officer of the $12-billion bank holding company on Oct. 1. He will succeed Charles A. Wilding, 65, who continues as chairman.

For several weeks, speculation and rumors concerning possible criminal charges have swirled around Vice President Agnew. He has held one full-scale press conference, and also issued a brief supplementary statement, denying these charges. The Justice Department now seems to be moving toward decisive action in the investigation.
The Zenith Radio Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices on eight of its 48 models in its current "E" color television line, effective Oct. 1.
Desperate buyers bid all but the most distant cotton delivseries up the daily permissible limit of 2 cents a pound yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

ARIOSO The Amato Opera Theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street (228-8300), is off to another season in its 103-seat house, where it will be doing six productions starting tonight with a new one of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," in Italian.

Dozens of elderly people yesterday described to state officials how, after a lifetime of work, they had applied for their pensions in private industry only to find that they were not eligible, that the funds had been dissipated or that their benefits were lower than they had been led to believe.

Prime Minister Heath's suggestion, later qualified, that Northern Ireland might have to be integrated into Britain continued to send off political sparks today, but there were signs that the three-day controversy was beginning to fade.
Profits of United States corporations during the second quarter of the year were 34 per cent above a year earlier, the Commerce Department said today.
The pragmatic moderate and conservative Arab leaders who control most of the area between the Nile and the Persian Gulf are fashioning a new solidarity.

Israel expects a renewed American effort to get the Middle East stalemate off dead center later this year. Although the Israelis harbor mixed feelings about any renewal of political activity that could bring pressure on them, the expected United States move has stimulated sentiment within the top leadership that--at least for the sake of her image abroad -- Israel should be prepared to adopt a flexible approach toward any American-sponsored initiative.

A majority of Governor Rockefeller's closest advisers are- recommending that the not seek a fifth term and instead concentrate all his efforts on a bid for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1976.

Three vice presidents of Eastern Airlines have left the company, and three others have been demoted in an executive shake-up that seems at least partly intended as a response to recent criticism that its management was top-heavy.
Richard J. Sullivan, StateCommissioner of Environmental Protection, said today he would have a plan to relax New Jersey's tough air-quality standards "in two to three weeks."
In 10 years, the proportion of laymen and women teaching in the Roman Catholic high schools operated by the Diocese of Brooklyn has shot up from 20 to 65 per cent.
Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany today defended the European Economic Community's response to the United States' call for a ',new Atlantic charter."
The stock-market rally, powered by the heaviest trading of 1973, moved forward yesterday along a broad front.

The Nixon Administration, as a' derisive saying goes, is "all heart." It was willing to let Ernest Fitzgerald "bleed for a while." It was willing to let the pathetically loyal Pat Gray "twist slowly slowly in the wind."
Algeria has suspended immigration of her workers to France until the current wave of anti-Algerian acts is brought under control.

The Sloan House Y.M.C.A. on 34th Street just east of Ninth Avenue will become the residence next month for 40 male and 20 female inmates serving the last three months of their city prison sentences, Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm said yesterday.
year-old Protestant from Northern Ireland was cleared here today of a double murder charge.
Without golf's leading players to contend with, and shooting a blistering 29 on the back nine, Bob E. Smith led the first round today of the $100,000 Broome County open with a six-under-par 65.
Governor Cahill announced today that the state would move quickly to provide up to $100million in emergency home mortgage funds to ease New Jersey's growing housing crisis.

To the Editor: The surtax plan revealed by Melvin Laird merits support. The fast rise of inflation can no longer be stated in exact figures. How far the tremendous rise of international commodity prices and the devaluation and shaky position of the dollar will carry our price level, no one can predict.
Jack Hawkins, whose movies included "The Bridge on the River Kwai," left nothing after payment of liabilities and death duties, his will disclosed today. His wife, Dorreen, said:

Philharmonic Hall, which opened 11 years ago this month, yesterday was renamed Avery Fisher Hall in appreciation of a "major gift" of undisclosed size by a pioneer manufacturer of high-fidelity phonograph and radio equipment.
Government issues rose yesterday in active trading as corporate bonds remained firm. Dealers reported nearly across-the-board gains in prices of Treasury bills, Government and agency bonds and notes.
Using new statistical evidence, Mayor Lindsay reiterated yesterday that heroin addiction in the city was "declining markedly."

Mike Miranda, an elder statesman of the Genovese Mafia family, died of natural causes in Miami on Sunday. He was 82 years old. Miranda, who had an elaborate home said to have cost $75,000 in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, had been arrested a number of times, twice for murder, but served very little time in prison.
Nathan W. Goldstein, circulation director of The New York Times for 25 years, was cited by Mayor Lindsay last night for "distinguished and exceptional service" to New York City.

Paul Dickopf, former president of Interpol, died yesterday at the age of 63. The Federal Criminal Office, which Mr. Dickopf helped organize after World War II, said he succumbed to a sudden illness at the Bonn University clinic.
Tentam, a 4-year-old colt who holds the record for 11/8 miles on the grass, was purchased for $2-million by E. P. Taylor, a spokesman for. the Canadian owner and breeder said today.
A 78-year-old clothing manufacturer was stabbed to death just before 1 P.M. yesterday in the elevator of his office building in the garment district.

President Nixon's lawyers and Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Watergate case, informed the United States Court of Appeals here today that they had failed to reach a compromise on access to Presidential tape recordings bearing on the Watergate crimes.
Rick Monday collected three hits and scored three runs today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 5-4 victory over Montreal.

She flung her racquet high toward the girded roof of the Astrodome and then collapsed, tears in her eyes, in her husband's arms. Mrs. .Billie Jean King had just beaten the lady-killer of wo. men's tennis and all of a sudden, she was a champion, a woman and a little girl at the same time.

Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National Chairman, appealed today for compromise between factions within the party as a, party reform commission prepared to map plans for rewriting controversial 1972 delegate serection guidelines.
Tinney Cavenaugh Figgatt, a former independent floor cotton broker, who was elected president of the New York Cotton Exchange in 1960, died here yesterday at the age of 90. He lived in Pawling, N. Y.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday the formation of what was described as a nonpartisan and broadly representative citizens panel to support passage of the $3.15billion state bond issue, which will be in the ballot on Election Day as a referendum.
" Put the city up; tear the city down; put it up again; let us find a city," wrote Carl Sandburg, the poet laureate of Chicago, in his poem "The Windy City."

The Rev. Dr. Eric Wilfred Baker, honorary president of the World Methodist Council and for 19 years secretary of the British Methodist Conference, died in London on Wednesday. He was 74 years old and lived in Eastbourne, Sussex, England.
The Government announced today that it had decided to release from prison Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh, a leading critic of the war and the Government, and three dissident labor leaders.

In the first visit of a supersonic airliner to the United States, a French-British Concorde flew here today from Caracas, Venezuela, to provide an extra dimension to Saturday's dedication of the world's largest jetport.
Bloomingale's cooked up its usual tasty pudding of fashion, culture and good works Wednesday night after the store was closed, using its time-tested recipe.

The Ethiopian Embassy in Paris today denounced as "imaginary" reports from Beirut, Lebanon, that a member of the royal family tried to hijack the plane carrying Emperor Haile Selassie from West Germany to Addis Ababa last Friday.

" The World at War," produced by Jeremy Isaacs for Britain's Thames Television, is an unusually ambitious project devoting 26 hour-long episodes to a factual documentation and analysis of World War II. It is also unusual-in other ways.

A new city consumer protection ordinance is being violated by many Times Square merchants catering primarily to tourists. They continue to charge more than list prices without conspicuously posting or labeling items with the manufacturer's suggested selling price.

The rest of the Philadelphia Orchestra's concerts in China will be played by a slightly punctured group. So far, six of the players and one member of the stage crew have had acupuncture treatments, and after their glowing reports, more are sure to follow.

A woman and four men were' presented Harmon International Aviation Awards yesterday in the Oval Office of President Nixon. The 1972 Aviatrix Trophy went to Geraldine Cobb, who was cited for humanitarian flights into jungle airstrips and clearings in the Amazon River basin in 1971.

The battle between Gary Smolyn and John Piccirillo for No. 1 quarterback at Rutgers has been decided in favor of neither. Steve Havran, a southpaw all-everything at Bridgewater East High School, will start at Lehigh Saturday in the opening game. "We made up our minds last night," Jim Taigia, the Scarlet offensive line coach, told the New Jersey college football writers here today.
Inflation is a prime topic among delegates to the International Industrial Conference here this week.

Arthur T. Roth, who built the Franklin National Bank from a small single-office bank to a $3-billion institution and then retired in 1970 under less than friendly circumstances, is on the move again on Long Island.
Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan told the General Assembly today that the greatest impediment to peace in the world was the"injustice imposed on the weak by the strong."

Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves says he knows the secret of Dave Johnson's home-run success and it has nothing to do with playing in Atlanta Stadium. "I've seen him hit 'em a long way anywhere," said Aaron. "He always hits the ball in the air and that's the secret of hitting home runs."
Rumors of a possible devaluation of the French franc set off a wave of speculation on world money markets today, dragging down the dollar and putting pressure on the French currency.

Mrs. Billie Jean King struck a proud blow for herself and women around the world with a crushing 6-4, 6-3, 6-3 rout of Bobby Riggs tonight in their $100,000 winnertake-all tennis match at the Astrodome.

Four former Nixon Administration aides, indicted for the break-in at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, will argue that their activities were lawful and within the "scope of authority" of the President, their lawyers said here today.

Samuel Aronowitz, a lawyer and a founder of radio station WTRY in Troy, died today of injuries following an auto accident. He was 83 years old. Mr. Aronowitz was senior partner in the Albany law firm of O'Connell Aronowitz.
The Soviet Union today announced the long-awaited formation of a state copyright agency to act as a clearing house for publishing Soviet works abroad or foregin works in the Soviet Union.
Israel expects a renewed American effort to get the Middle East stalemate off dead center later this year.
A section of a building under renovation on the Lower East Side fell to the sidewalk yesterday about noontime, injuring a workman.

Negotiators representing management and musicians of the New York Philharmonic orchestra were reported "quite far apart" early today. A strike deadline passed at midnight, but the musicians' union said it would continue to perform at concerts until further notice.
Robyn Smith would like to ride against Bobby Riggs in a horse race, but she doubts the male chauvinist of the sports world would accept the challenge.

Israeli officials, noting President Nixon's recent statements about the "priority" he attaches to the Middle East, expect the United States to begin a major new effort to get negotiations started between Israel and the Arab states.
Willie Mays - conceding that "maybe I'll cry tomorrow"-announced yesterday that he would end his baseball career at the close of this season, his 22d as one of the superstars of the major leagues.

Far from suppressing dissident sentiment in the Soviet Union, the recent intensive Soviet press campaign against Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and civil rights advocate, seems to have provided domestic critics of the regime with a new rallying point.
The defending champion, Jim Wright of Inwood, L. I., took a threestroke lead after the second round today in the New York State Professional Golfers' Association open.
Thomas F. Fitzpatrick, the "Fitz" of "Fitz and Hitz," who have operated the Artist and Writers Restaurant, formerly Jack Bleeck's, at 213 West 40th Street, for the last 20 years, died Wednesday.

Gram Parsons, the rock musician and former member of the Byrds, died Wednesday in Joshua Tree, Calif. He was 27 years old. The cause of his death was not immediately determined. The San Bernardino coroner is awaiting results of autopsy tests.

Los Angeles-based Continental Air Lines, with a total advertising and promotion budget of some $10-million, announced yesterday that Benton Bowles and Ogilvy Mather had been selected as finalists for its account, but did not rule out the possibility that it might stay with Needham, Harper Steers.
The Securities and Exchange Commission, backtracking to a significant degree on a decision it made last January, proposed new rules today to tighten the
The two United States Senators from New York have agreed to recommend a Suffolk County lawyer for a Federal judgeship in the Eastern District.

" Salome," for all its secure foothold in the operatic repertory, presents a continuing dilemma: any soprano possessed of a voice hefty enough to sing the part is likely to be too hefty of figure to-manage the Dance of the Seven Veils without straining the imagination as well as the stage boards. And vice versa, of course.
Wide-open production for the 19th consecutive month has been ordered by the Texas Railroad Commission, as demand for Texas oil continues to increase.

The bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company ran further into the red in August with a loss for the month totaling $18.1-million, according to the trustees' report issued yesterday. In August, 1972, the railroad subsidiary of the Penn Central Company lost $10.3-million.

In the first visit of a supersonic airliner to the United States, a French-British Concorde flew here today from Caracas, Venezuela, to provide an extra dimension to Saturday's dedication of the world's largest jetport.

Philharmonic Hall got a new name Thursday, Avery Fisher Hall, and what may be thought of as the baptismal concert that evening was a spectacular event. It was the first subscription concert of the season by the New York Philharmonic.

An Assistant Attorney General who said he was speaking for both the Justice Department and the Nixon Administration said today that the public financing of' Federal election campaigns was "not a subject for hasty legislative action."

There is a commune here that went straight and thereby went wrong. It entered commerce and became the owner or operator of seven thriving businesses. It started 'the town's first Chamber of Commerce and its first Optimist Club.
Hubert Green shot a course record six-under-par 65 today and tied for the second-round lead at 134 with Bob E. Smith and Dwight Nevil in the $100,000 Broome County open golf tournament.

After a four-month observation of thoroughbred racing in this country, 23-year-old Dean Latimer will return to his native city of Bulawayo in Rhodesia "most impressed with just about everything" he has seen, he said yesterday while watching the races from the stewards' stand at Belmont Park.

Fifty undercover agents of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor are searching here and in New Jersey dock areas for clues to the mysterious disappearance of the head of a Jersey City longshoremen's union.

Mrs. Margaret Beck McCallum, the widow of James Dow McCallum, Winkley Professor of the Anglo-Saxon Language and Literature Emeritus at Dartmouth College, died Saturday while visiting friends in Wales She was 75 years old and lived here.

Mediators in the two-week-old Harrison teachers' strike decided today to force the issue into the open by calling a public meeting Monday night in the town. A spokesman for the Public Employment Relations Board in Albany said that the open session would take place at 8 o'clock in the Harrison fire house if the impasse continued through the weekend.

Driven by a devotion to treating presumably hopeless patients, a New York brain surgeon has developed another in a series of techniques to reverse the incapacitating symptoms of severe neurological disorders.
The American flag was lowered at the Nam Phong Airbase in northeastern Thailand today in a ceremony to mark its official closing to United States forces.

Robert S. Calvert, the state's 81-year-old Comtroller of Public Accounts, has turned allegations of racism and sexism in his office into an overnight cause celebre by referring to his accuser as a "nigger woman."

The Detroit Edison Company has filed with the Michigan Public Service Commission for authority to issue and sell up to 4,000,000 shares of common stock. The company's common closed at 19 1/8, up 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The passing of D. C. Nobles and the running of Leonard Parker carried 16th-ranked Houston to a 27-19 victory over South Carolina tonight in the Astrodome.

When Tom Cahill was the plebe (freshman) football coach at West Point, the Army assigned young lieutenants to assist him. They were either former football players just out of college with an R.O.T.C. commission or newly commissioned West Point graduates.
Sir Stanford Cade, an authority on the use of radiation in the treatment of cancer, died Wednesday at Portsmouth. He was 78 years old and had been ill with bronchial pneumonia.

The license issued by the Department of Consumer Affairs to the garage that collapsed last Wednesday permitted parking on the roof, but the city's Buildings Department said yesterday that the license it had issued did not.

The last chance to revive a pennant race in National League West was afforded the Los Angeles Dodgers as they opened a three-game series with the Cincinnati Reds tonight. The Dodgers had to win all three to make the challenge believable, and their chances were improved by the fact that Johnny Bench of the Reds would be suspended for the first two games.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates a nationwide chain of department stores, continued to operate in the red in the second fiscal quarter ended July 31, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday. Sales were up for both periods but only nominally.
Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., who has been one of the New York Stock Exchange's severest critics, paid a visit yesterday to the exchange's trading floor, his first in many years.
The Commerce Department announced today it was lifting the remaining controls on exports of agricultural products, including soybeans, cotton seeds and livestock feed, effective Oct. 1
Pressure abated in the European currency markets today following a series of defensive actions that included an order by the Bank of France imposing new controls over franc outflows.

Walter Terry, who has served since February as director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass., has submitted his resignation to the board of directors of the 40-year-old institution founded by the late Ted Shawn.
Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets past the prostrate Pittsburgh Pirates into first place last night before a cheering, chanting crowd of 51,381, the largest of the season in Shea Stadium.
Addressing the Philippine people on the first anniversary of his proclamation of martial law, President Ferdinand E. Marcos said tonight that the nation had weathered "a crisis of survival."

No doubt some women will be unsettled by the new laissez-faire direction of fashion. No hassling over hemlines. No insistence on slim skirts over the wide ones, high waistlines over low ones or, in fact, the necessity of marking the waistline at all.
Frank S. Hogan, the Manhattan District Attorney and candidate for re-election, ended his six-week stay in St. Luke's Hospital by slipping out on Thursday afternoon without any announcement.

Maurice E. Olen, financial adviser to a company that has been buying troubled New England department stores, is currently under probation from a Federal court as a result of a three-year-old sentence for mail fraud and securities violations.

In a surprise move, a former vice president of the bankrupt Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., pleaded no contest here yesterday to one count of fraud. and agreed to testify against the remaining four defendants in a Federal stock-fraud case.
An international conference of economists proposed today creation of a world grain reserve to guard against periodic shortages and help stabilize prices.

Although a substitute played a dramatic role and scored a hole-in-one today for the Ryder Cup team of Britain, the United States squad drew even in the series. The two-day standing in the competition for professional golfers was 8-8.

Dr. Roy Strong, 38-year-old director of the National Portrait Gallery, has been appointed the new director of the Victoria and Albert Museum.

The Army's senior black general will become commander of the Military District of Washington in November, it was announced today. Maj. Gen. Frederic E. Davison, now commanding general of the Eighth Infantry Division in West Germany, will begin his new assignment Nov. 12.

It happened nearly a decade ago. A prosaic sulphur company, which had been exploring for ore near Timmins, Ontario, suddenly tapped one of the most extensive copper fields to be discovered in modern times.

Referring to the announcement yesterday that a Soviet copyright agency had been established, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident novelist, today challenged the Government to protect his work from unauihorized publication in the West.

The largest single monthly increase in consumer prices in the metropolitan area in 25 years-1.9 per cent-was reported for August by the regional office of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics yesterday.

Friends of Pyotr G. Grigorenko, a dissident and a former general, say he has been released from a psychiatric prison, but officials at the hospital where he was reported to be transferred said they had no patient of that name.
The Agriculture Department formed an, advisory committee today to study the possible formation of a cancer-causing agent in ham, bacon and other cured meats.

The Teleprompter Corporation, the country's largest operator of cable-television systems, announced yesterday that it had recently discharged some 600 of the 3,000 employes in its cable division as one of several major steps taken to cut costs and tighten its business operations.
Mary Gordon Thompson, a former president of the Boston Women's Trade League, died in a hospital here Wednesday. She was 88 years old.

The city, in a settlement reached toward the end of a three-week trial, has agreed to pay a total of $8,000 to three former Inmates of the Queens House of Detention who charged they had received "savage and unlawful beatings" after the riots there in October, 1970.

Mayor Roman S. Gribbs dismissed Police Commissioner John Nichols today in a dispute over mixing police work and politics. The commissioner, a career policeman, is running for mayor. He had refused to resign,

A 34-year-old member of the Tactical Patrol Force who vanished with his family Aug. 15 from their apartment in College Point, Queens, was returned here yesterday from Ohio, where he was arrested on charges of passing $29,800 in bad checks. .

Mrs. Justine Cushing, after establishing an early lead, coasted to a 5-and-4 victory over Mrs. Vincent Larkin of Nassau today in the Women's Long Island match-play championship final at Meadow Brook Club.

Federal District Judge Edward T. Gignoux ruled here today that a New Hampshire newspaper reporter might disclose to Watergate investigators his sources for an article linking a former Presidential aide, Murray Chotiner, to acts of political espionage, including the Watergate break-in.

Weeks of unctuous Administration preconditioning do not lessen the shock of yesterday's official announcement that consumer prices in August took their biggest one-month jump since the inflationary explosion that followed the removal of World War II economic controls a quarter-century ago.

With the opening of the new school year has come an expansion of the idea that young people can learn in places besides classrooms. Programs enabling high school students to advance their education through jobs and participation in community activities during normal school hours are spreading and increasing in popularity.

Lev Polugayevsky of the Soviet Union defeated Efim Geller by half a point today in a special three-man chess tournament, becoming the eighth and final competitor for the right to challenge Bobby Fischer, the world champion.
A player who selects the ace of his .partner's suit as the opening lead has usually made a sensible move.
Bobby Riggs lost more than a tennis match last night to Mrs. Billie Jean King: he hustled himself out of $10,000 and perhaps out of businesses a salesman for male chauvinism.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, shattering the usual calm of a State Board of Regents meeting, today publicly attacked the State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyququist, for what he charged was "capitulating" to racism by failing to compel New York City to desegregate schools in Canarsie and elsewhere.

Everyone knows that Seton Hall's football team will not be No. 1 this year, a feat the 'Pirates accomplished last year when they won the national championship in club football. This year, the school has switched to the varsity level and its first test comes tomorrow against Hofstra.

The stock market overcame some early profit taking yesterday to post its third impressive advance in a row on tremendous trading volume. Steels and automotive issues-relative laggards in the week's dramatic upswingcame to life and joined other blue-chip and glamour stocks that kept forging higher.

The United Farm Workers Union is facing "a life or death struggle" for survival, Cesar Chavez, its president, said today. The union, generally credited with the first successful effort to organize agricultural workers in this country, is "back where we were in 1965 to 1970,"

Whatever substance there may be in the speculation that Vice President Agnew may soon resign, Democratic leaders in Congress and out are preparing positions for that contingency. On the face of it, the 25th Amendment seems plain as to the mechanics: President Nixon would appoint a new Vice President, subject to approval by a majority in each house of Congress. But the usual gap between simple theory and complex reality is widening by the day.
George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, discounted hopes tonight that the upcoming international Monetary Fund meeting would produce major progress toward world monetary reform.

Mrs. Justine Cushing, after establishing an early lead, coasted to a 5-and-4 victory over Mrs. Vincent Larkin of Nassau today in the Women's Long Island match-play championship final at Meadow Brook Club.

Beverly Sills, leading soprano with the New York City Opera, warned yesterday that if a musicians' strike was not settled within 48 hours, there would be no more performances this fall or next spring.

Chile's new military junta said that it had banned Marxist political parties and would soon announce a new constitution giving the armed forces a role in future legislative bodies. "We have placed the Marxist parties outside the law," said Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, the junta's president, at a news conference. [Page 1. Column 6.]

Dr. Herbert Hammond Pride, who retired as professor of mathematics at New York University in 1956, after 42 years on the faculty, died Thursday of cancer in Hendersonville, N.C., where he lived. His age was 82.

A simple funeral service was held this morning for Ann Logan, the 19-year-old Seton Hall coed murdered in a sexual assault earlier this week. More than 500 people, including scores of her college classmates and several plainclothes detectives, crowded into St. Genevieve's Roman Catholic

A tenth-inning three-run homer by Tony Perez, his fifth hit of the game, carried the Cincinnati Reds a giant step closer to another National League West Championship tonight as it provided a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers and reduced the pennant-clinching number to three.

Before the match, Billie Jean King's strategy sounded basic. "My coach, Frank Brennan," she said into a TV microphone, "told me just to go out and play my game." But there was more to it than that. Not all the great professors of our world lecture in classrooms. Some are football coaches or golf pros. Others train boxers. Frank Brennan teaches tennis.

Like many freshmen at Princeton University, Maria Imelda Marcos is distrustful of the university food, unsure of the campus geography and slightly baffled by the variety of possible academic and extracurricular pursuits.
Japan and North Vietnam established diplomatic relations today, giving the North Vietnamese the political prestige of recognition by Asia's strongest non-Communist power.

Nearby delivery cotton-the October contract-jumped to 95 cents a pound yesterday, up the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit and the highest price in the 103-year history of the New York Cotton Exchange. Thus, cotton has not been so highpriced since the Civil War era.
Fordham scored a first-quarter touchdown on a deflected pass and added a safety to down St. Peter's, 9-0, in a Metropolitan Conference contest tonight.

Dead City, by Shane Stevens (Holt, Rinehart Winston, $6.95). Life among the lower echelon of organized crime. Headless Beings, by Margaret Malcolm (Doubleday, $4.95). A Crime Club novel of suspense. The Hunting Valley, by Richard. Flanagan (Putnam, $5.95). A horror story.
Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that through her defeat of Bobby Riggs, in tennis, Mrs. Billie Jean King "ratified the 26th Amendment."

Federal Judge Charles E. Stewart.Jr. disclosed here yesterday that he would grant the Securities and Exchange Commission a preliminary injunction to prevent Robert L. Vesco, the 37-year-old fugitive financier, from further violation of Federal securities laws.
Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets past the prostrate Pittsburgh Pirates into first place last night before a cheering, chanting crowd of 51,381, the largest of the season in Shea Stadium.

Only four months since the Knicks won the National. Basketball Association championship from the Los Angeles Lakers in a five-game series, professional basketball returns to New York tonight with a preseason double-header at Madison Square Garden.
At daybreak the golden pagodas shimmer. Hundreds of families trudge past them to wait in line for Government stores to open.
The condition of one of the five surviving sextuplets born to Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Stanek slipped today from good to satisfactory because he rejected his mother's milk.

George A. Eddy's Windance, a 39-foot sloop of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club fleet at Greenwich, was the corrected time winner in Division I today on the second leg of Indian Harbor Y.C.'s cruise on Long Island Sound. Richard N. Jayson's Pride, a 44-footer out of Noroton, Conn., which was first to finish the 14.4-mile passage, took the series lead, finishing second on corrected time for the second straight race.

Susan Davenny Wyner, a soprano who needs no introduction to alert followers of the vocal scene in New York, appeared at Tully Hall on Wednesday evening as winner 'of the 1973 Joy in Singing Award Recital.

State Supreme Court Justice Vincent A. Massi reserved decision yesterday on whether The New York Times still has a labor contract with Typographical Union No. 6 forbidding strikes or interference with

The Bronx Borough President, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday that he would conduct a series of neighborhood hearings to receive community proposals for local improvements to be included in the 1974-75 capital and expense budgets.

Two blocks south of Eastern Parkway in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, an unusual and once controversial city housing project that was designed to be temporary has become an apparently permanent fixture amid rows of burned-out buildings.

WASHINGTON--To the relief, delight and doubts of Washington and the world diplomatic community, appearance and reality are finally joined in holy patrimony: Henry Kissinger is the new Secretary of State as well as Assistant to the President.

David Rockefeller, chairman of the board of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has joined a group of business, labor and civic leaders as a committee member for the National Urban League's annual Equal Opportunity Day Dinner, scheduled for Nov. 14 in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel.

To the Financial Editor: I read with great interest and some chagrin your article entitled "The Hospitality Crusade" (Aug. 26). Although the chart with the article appears to be a list of the top 17 such chains (in terms of rooms), it leaves out Quality Inns (with 32,000 rooms and about 350 motor inns).

I am a Bligh man unashamed, utterly unimpressed by the attacks on the record of that great seaman and early Governor of Australia. If this lengthy effort by Richard Hough had never been written there would be no loss.

Whenever a vacancy occurs on the board of trustees of the Brooklyn or the Queens library systems, there are at least 20 applicants for the job. Yet the position pays nothing, brings little publicity and is of very little use in advancing professional careers. In fact,

WASHINGTON-Early this year, the Air Force put into service for President Nixon's personal use a new four-engine jet, "The Spirit of '76," to supplement a fleet of four-engine jets that are maintained for the use of the White House. The plane cost $7.4-million and the Government spent $1.7-million more equipping it with a plush interior.

Amtrak, the national rail passenger service, has proposed saving historic Union Station here from demolition by the city's Redevelopment Agency. In a letter to Mayor Daniel D. Schwartz, Amtrak said it would be willing to contribute financially to restoration of the station, which was designed in 1885 by the noted architect Henry Hobson Richardson.

Hans Joseph Wolflisberg, former president and board chairman of the Nestle Corporation, died Tuesday in Waterbury Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived here. Mr. Wolflisberg retired about five years ago after 27 years with the company.
Denis Potvin, the New York Islanders' prize rookie hasn't been himself on the ice this week and he doesn't expect to be himself until some time in November.
TRENTON-Parents all over the state are expected to visit public schools during Open House observances of American Education Week, Oct. 21 to 27.
Leroy Moss scored twice and John Cherry passed for 199 yards and one touchdown today as Missouri rolled over Virginia 31-7.
Dogs, bats and pigeons, plus occasional wild skunks and snakes, have kept Dr. Samuel Hutt on his medical toes for 34 years.
Kermit Bloomgarden has won the bidding for the American rights to Peter Shaffer's "Equus," a hit in the repertory of the British National Theater at the Old Vic in London.
An East German physician hid with his wife and daughter this week In a westbound truck, adding to the growing number of people who have fled to the West in the last few months.

Miss Sandy Ellen Hunter was married here this evening to Second Lieut. Martin-Guden Chilek of the Army Medical Service Corps. The Rev. H. Dana Fearon performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church.
Jimmy Connors defeated Raul Ramirez and Tom Okker upset Ilie Nastase in today's semifinals of the $75,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.

Louisana Negro Normal and Industrial Institute defeated Centenary Biblical Institute in football yesterday, and 64,243 persons came to Yankee Stadium to watch. It would be more credible, using the colleges' newer names to say that Grambling beat Morgan State, 31-14.

Ruby Newman, highsociety band leader, diedThursday at the age of 70 in Pittsfield General Hospital. Mr. Newman's death ended a romantic era of music that saw his band entertain at gala debutante parties, Harvard class reunions, weddings and society balls across the country.

The schooner was queen here today. And it was a sight to gladden the hearts of old saltsand young salts, too, as 29 of them slanted off in a blustery, rail-burying southeaster in the Mystic Marine Historical Association's sixth annual race exclusively for the gallant graceful two and three-masted vessels.

When Ted Harris, a composer, received a letter from the New York Bicentennial Corporation last month stating it was interested in the opera that he had collaborated on with the late American poet William Carlos Williams, he was not overly excited.

MINEOLA, L.I. - Long Island's reputation as having been "the cradle of aviation" will be permanently memorialized in a building in a new $44-million Nassau County park at Mitchel Field, the former Air Force base.

The purchasing power of an average factory production worker's salary in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area continued to decline during July, as sharp increases in prices cut into earnings, the United Statles Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

They stood last on July 8, a dozen games out for first place in the mad world known as the National League's Eastern Divisionlast in the pack and last in the hearts of their countrymen, who were still feverish over the "revival" of the Yankees.
The New York Rangers opened their exhibition season with a 10-3 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Flyers before 16,381 fans at the Spectrum.

Bob Langan, a halfback, scored three touchdowns to lead Bucknell to a 24-16 victory over Boston University today. Langan scored on runs of 1 and 2 yards in the first quarter, then sprinted' 22 yards around left end on the first play of the fourth quarter for his third touchdown.

THIS is the second installment of our inquiry begun last week into the hotel guest-innkeeper relationship based on the recently published textbook "The Laws of Innkeepers" by Prof. John H. Sherry (Cornell University Press), and we come now to the question of who is a guest and must he sign the hotel register.

Trying to measure the impact of Maurice H. Nadjari, the state prosecutor appointed just one year ago to root out corruption in New York City's criminal justice system is like trying to determine the winner of a football game played at night without lights, on a field of shifting length, where all the players are wearing the same color of uniform.

On this bleak afternoon under overcast skies, the United States professional golfers retained the Ryder Cup by defeating the squad from Britain, 19 to 13. The teams had started the day deadlocked 8 to 8.

Any resemblance between the Baltimore Colts of last year and the Colts the Jets play tomorrow isn't coincidental; it's accidental. It's probably an accident that Joe Thomas, the Mad Trader, overlooked a handful of players in his wholesale dealings the past eight months.
Baylor unleashed a devastating ground attack bolstered by Gary Lacy's 167 yards rushing on 39 carries and survived a fourth-period Pittsburgh rally to defeat the Panthers 20 to 14 today.

IT is Polanski weather: gray, threatening, with patches of fog, the weather of "Knife in the Water" and "Cui-dc-Sac," of "Repulsion" and "Macbeth." The director is staying in a distinctly Raymond Chandlerish rented house in the hills above the Sunset Strip:

John H. Glenn, the former astronaut, shattered the harmony of Ohio Democrats this week by accusing party leaders of bossismsm" and "blackmail" in attempting to arrange a United States Senate endorsement for his archrival, Howard M.Metzenbaum, a Cleveland millionaire.

Kaufman and Broad, Inc., one of the country's largest producers of low-priced and moderate-priced housing, has announced its entry into the high-rise condominium business. Its first project, a 21story tower in Cliffside Park, N.J., is scheduled for completion early in 1975.

WASHINGTON-The Court of Appeals, with nothing to lose and a great deal to gain, had tried a long shot: To avoid a drastic collision between the judicial and executive branches of government, it had urged President Nixon and Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox to find a way to resolve the Watergate tapes issue out of court.
NUTLEY--From now until June, about 40 movie buffs will be sampling their favorite silent and early talkie fare in a little backyard theater that once served as a fruit-jelly factory.

Miss Suzanne deClairmont Warner, daughter of Rawleigh Warner Jr., board chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation, and Mrs, Warner, was married here this afternoon to Robert White Parsons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris B. Parsons of Barrington, R. I., and Fishers Island, N. Y.

WASHINGTON-The bizarre has become commonplace here since those bumbling burglars broke into Democratic headquarters more than a year ago, but not commonplace enough to forestall a mild uproar over the latest episode in the life and difficult times of Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.
The Philadelphia Eagles, who lost to the New York Giants in 95-degree weather earlier this month, will challenge the New Yorkers' hot eight-game winning streak today at Yankee Stadium.

Mr. and Mrs. Chalmers Handy have announced the engagement of Mrs. Handy's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Roberts Elkinton, to Charles Carrington Barr, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Barr 3d of Louisville, Ky. A wedding in December is planned.

" At some time in the distant future," said the Council on Environmental Quality, "it may be possible to aggregate all aspects of environmental quality, and issue a definitive pronouncement that, for example, the quality of the environment improved 3.68 per cent during the past year."
