One of the tax changes recently suggested by the Nixon Administration was a refundable tax surcharge. The idea was to reduce purchasing power (with a tax increase) during a time of inflation and to stimulate it (with a tax refund) when the economy was sluggish.

The state's coral reef formations are in danger of. extinction, according to marine biologists. Citing damage inflicted by water pollution, boat anchors, souvenir hunters and developers, scientists stress that urgent measures must be taken if the coral reefs are to survive.

WHILE television thrives on unimportance, some of it less trivial than the rest, movie goers have become increasingly stern about the unimportant film, not the bad film but the good, entertaining-for-as-long-as-it-takes-to-watch movie that, afterwards, disappears from the memory with the completeness of rain sinking into a desert.
A lap prize fund of $34,000 has been added to the purse for the Oct. 7 National 500 stock car race at Charlotte Motor Speedway.

I.B.M. WAS FOUND GUILTY of having violated the Sherman Antitrust Act and was ordered to pay Telex, a computer equipment manufacturer, triple damages amounting to $352.5-million. I.B.M. says it will appeal .... The nation's deficit in the balance of international payments was $782-million In the second quarter, narrowed from $947-million in the first quarter and sharply less than the average quarterly deficit of $2.5 billion during 1972.
Stan Mikita, the hockey allstar who grew up here but never finished high school, will receive an honorary doctor of laws degree at Brock University Oct. 15.

Striking workers at a Chrysler Motors plant in Britain agreed today to return to work for a week and to allow talks to resume. The agreement came after a day of secret meetings between union leaders and company representatives over the two-week strike.

A fable may dramatize the, true source of the nation's present discontent with our public schools: Suppose that, 50 or 75 years ago, the U.S. had adopted the same institutional arrangements for the distribution of food as it did adopt for elementary and secondary schools. Suppose, that is, that the retail provision of groceries had been nationalized, that food was paid for by taxes and distributed by Government-run stores.
Until a rew weeKs ago, Nlathan Allen worked as a community specialist for the Community Relations Service, a Federal agency responsible for mediating racial conflicts.

Any time a suit bid is given an artificial meaning the deal may be played "upside-down," with the trump length in the dummy. This is seldom material if the artificial bid is in a minor suit, as most of them are, since most contracts are played in major suits or no-trump.
Elliott Roosevelt, son of President Franklin 1). Roosevelt, said today that he would probably return to the United States the first week in October to face a Senate rackets investigation.

State Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson has decided to call his fellow Republicans to Albany next month to take the unusual step of formulating a preliminary legislative program before the regular session, where the Governor traditionally takes, the lead in setting the agenda.

Ferdinand A. Heinige, the Republican Mayor here from 1961 to 1969, was convicted yesterday of misconduct and extortion. After the verdict was returned in Superior Court in neighboring Hackensack, a grand jury handed up a presentment criticizing the administration of the present Mayor, Malcolm Hill, a Democrat.

Miss Margaret Woodnutt Emory, daughter of Mrs. John Martin Groome Emery of Westbury, L.I., and the late Mr. Emory, and Dr. Christopher Wayne Stackpole, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stackoole of Williamstown,

Miss Susan Parker Handy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Douglas Handy, was married here this afternoon to James Campbell Stover, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Stover of Princeton, N. J., by the Rev. Stanley Lyon Houston in the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

The marriage of Miss Joan Morgan to Peter Lincoln Folsom took place here this afternoon at the Eaton's Neck home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Morgan, grandparents of the bride. The Rev. Howard M. Lowell of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church performed the ceremony.

BOTH "Gordon's War" and "Cleopatra Jones" are important films. They are remarkably accurate in reflecting the mood, the ambience, the sensibility of the seventies in black communities across the nation.

The marriage of Miss Susan R. Schmid, daughter of Mrs. Frances Schmid of Flushing, Queens, to Robert J. Mullaney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Mullaney of Flushing and Sag Harbor, L. I., took place in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

Dr. Robert S. Hartman, research professor of philosophy at the National University of Mexico and the University of Tennessee, died Friday in Mexas City. He was 63 years old and lived in Cuernavaca, Mexico.
A Soviet space scientist, in an unusual break with traditional secrecy, disclosed today some of the scientific goals and experiments of the caravan of four Soviet spaceships on their way to Mars.

TRENTON-The New Jersey Lottery Commission, which took a successful gamble with a special bonus drawing to spur lagging ticket sales, is now giving serious consideration to changing the structure of the weekly and daily drawings.

Puerto Rico's Migration Division, set up in 1948 to aid adjustment of Puerto Ricans on the mainland, has deteriorated and become "ineffectual" in the last four or five years, according to key leaders who have submitted their views to Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon.

CUTCHOGUE, L. I.- Suffolk County's once-abundant farmland is rapidly giving way to developers and the county's efforts to save what remains of this land for posterity is endangered by the attractive profits offered to the farmers and by local disputes.

Richard A. Brown, formerly the city's chief legislative representative in Albany, will be sworn in tomorrow by Mayor Lindsay as a Criminal Court judge. Mr. Brown, who is 40 years old, was appointed to the $36,451-a-year post by the Mayor for a term to expire at the end of 1982.

Fattened beef cattle and hogswere brought to Middle Westerr markets in large numbers this week, sending wholesale prices down and offering the hope that the reductions will be passed on' to supermarket counters within a few days.

Loomis scored two firsthalf touchdowns today and then used a strong defense to defeat Hopkins Grammar, 14-12. Bill Majewicz led the Loomis defense with three interceptions at his defensive halfback spot.

In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Lorraine Wrightson Besch and Ens. Paul Bainbridge Sanwick Jr., U.S.N.R., graduates of the University of Colorado, were married by the Rev. George W. R. MacCray.
Jose Cardenal tripled home two runs in the 10th inning and scored on a throwing error as the Chicago Cubs took a 5-2 decision from the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

ABEL--Lester D., on Sept. 21, 1973, beloved husband of Elizabeth (nee Slane) devoted father of Alice E. Abel, brother of Helen Hatfield, and Doris Hultin. Reposing 2.5 and 7-9 P.M. at Henry McCaddin Son, 24 7th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of the Ressurrection Church of St. Augustine's Monday 9:45 A.M.

For the past five years American demographers have been congratulating themselves on the success of contraceptive practices in this country. They point out that the population growth rate for the nation has declined rapidly-from 1.5 per cent a year in 1962 to 0.8 per cent last year.
TRENTON - An exhibition of works by Everett Shinn, a New Jersey member of the controversial turnof-the-century group, "The Eight," is on view at the New Jersey State Museum until Nov. 25.

NEWARK - Jersey Central commuters living west of Plainfield, who are fear-, ful of losing service when PATH trains replace the Central between Newark and Plainfield, may wind up with an improved express train schedule.

In the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Susan Marie Lesch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lesch of Scarsdale and Highland Lakes, N. J., was married to James Peter Carr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carr of Bloomfield, N. J., and Highland Lakes.

Miss Elizabeth Jane'Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Kelly of Tenafly, N. J., was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Dennis George Huskins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Huskins of Hempstead,
Miss Margaret Vance Vose, daughter of Mr. and Mr. Charles Baldwin Vose, was married here this evening to Robert Francis Amnao, soa of Mrs. Michael Charles Armao of New York and the late D'. Armao.

Fighting in the highlands north of Saigon and the Mekong Delta to the south has caused the deaths of 151 Communists and 23 Government soldiers between dawn yesterday and noon today, the Government command said.

The American Independent party, winding up a three-day convention here, has elected William K. Shearer of Lemon Grove, Calif., as its national chairman. Mr. Shearer, 42 years old, was among 17 new officers elected to lead the party. Andrew Watson, 60, of Harrisburg, Pa., was elected vice chairman.
The running and pass receiving of Steve Sokolich, a sophomore halfback, led Holy Cross to a 13-5 victory over Flushing Friday night before 3,500.

Roger Furstenburg of Hunterdon Central, New Jersey's scoring champion with 164 points in 1972, got off to a good start today. The 6-foot-1-inch, 175-pound running back paced his team to a 34-6 victory over Belvidere. rushing 41 limes for 193 yards.
The world welterweight champion, Jose Napoles, retained his title today with a unanimous 15-round decision over Clyde Gray of Canada at the Maple Leaf Gardens.
BERNARDS TOWNSHIP Almost one-third of the households surveyed in a recent religious census have no church preference, a typical ratio for a predominantly Christian community in New Jersey.

The short story is alive and well in Canada, where most of these 15 tales originate like fresh winds from the North. Alice Munro ("Lives of Girls and Women") creates a solid habitat for her fiction-southwestern Ontario, a generation or more in the past-and is in sympathetic vibration with the farmers and townspeople who live there.
A 16-year-old Columbia boy was sentenced yesterday to 30 years in prison for voluntary manslaughter in the strangulation of a 7-year-old girl.
COUNTRY music is booming as never before.The form-and the in dustry - has transcended its rural roots, spread to the suburbs and the cities and the middle class and has been discovered by the press.

This highceilinged apartment in a mid-nineteenth-century, Greenwich Village brownstone was seven years in the making, despite the fact that both the occupants work in the fields of design and art. Buzz Miller of Melvin Dwork Associates and Alan Groh were not concerned with the latest fashion in design.

Hank Aaron blasted home run No. 712 tonight and pulled within two of equaling Babe Ruth's record of 714. Aaron's four-bagger proved to be the difference as the Braves defeated the. Astros, 4-2.

Diana Sands, the actress who won overnight critical acclaim for her stage portrayal in 1959 of Sidney Poitier's young sister in "A Raisin in the Sun," died Friday night at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 39 years old.
In the second of three related fall elections, voters of the Denver area will decide on Tuesday whether to take another step toward metropolitan government.

One of the biggest upsets in American chess is in the making. John Grefe, a young California master, is showing his heels to a 12-man field, including five grandmasters, in the United States Chess Championship going on in El Paso.

Herricks, unheralded among the teams that comprise the Nassau County North Shore Division I, threw a mild scare into Farmingdale before losing yesterday, 36-8.

Tom Sloan set a Temple single-game rushing record tonight and the Owls amassed their highest game yardage total ever in defeating Akron, 47-33.
A second-half drive led by Eric Torkelson gave Connecticut a 26-14 victory over Vermont today. Torkelson carried the ball 33 times for 150 yards and scored two touchdowns.

The home run, which has become a big thing in the local scene because of the shortened fences at Municipal Stadium, erupted tonight as the Cleveland Indians produced four of them to triumph over the New York Yankees. 5-1.

Two specially equipped ambulances that, in effect, bring the resources of a hospital emergency room to a heartattack victim, are being operated by New York Hospital and the Empire State Ambulance Service.

Charlie Scott, one of New York's many fine basketball products, spoiled the Knicks' preseason opener at Madison Square Garden last night by scoring 32 points and leading the Phoenix Suns to a 93-89 victory before a sellout crowd of 19,694.

Fifth-rfanked Michigan scored the first five times it had the ball and Mike Lantry kicked two recordsetting field goals as the Wolverines crushed Stanford, 47-10, in a nonconference football game today.

To the Editor: Jimmy Breslin's recent Guest Word (which predicted an unfavorable reaction, by Manhattan-based reviewers, to his new novel "World Without End, Amen") gives the impression that he is a spokesman for the working-class semiliterates who heavily populate the borough of Queens.
Government forces routed insurgents from a pagoda on the northern fringes at Kompong Cham today after 17 hours of fighting, the military command reported.

SAIGON, South VietnamIn the nineteen-sixties the small program seemed like a humane counterpoint to the fury of the war. Levittown Memorial, last year's champion in Division III and among the favorites in Division II this season, was only minutes away from watching its season go down the drain yesterday when it rallied for 22 points in the final period to defeat Mepham, 22-20.

Miss Carol Carter Straton and Robert LeBrecht, senior vice president of the investment firm of R. W. Pressprich Co., Inc., were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. John Charles Straton.

Woods-King Mr. and Mrs. Philip King announce the marriage of their daughter, Carol Marjorie, to Robert Mark Woods, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron L. Woods, at Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, L.I. on September 15, .1973.

Americans do not like to think of themselves as extremists, but we are not a patient people. The demand for instant answers to instantly (and usually belatedly) recognized problems is part of the American way.
By GORDON S. WHITE Jr.

The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today the start of an investigation that could overhaul the trans-Atlantic air transportation system and connect 16 new United States metropolitan airports with Europe by direct flights.
Denis Potvin, the Islanders' No. amateur choice last spring, assisted on New York's first two goals in his first exhibition game tonight in a 4-4 tie with the Atlanta Flames.

In St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here this morning, Miss Lorraine Lavin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lavin of North Andover, was married to Stephen Dillon Reed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond S. Reed of New York. Msgr. William J. Keneally performed the ceremony.

CLASSES at Harvard open tomorrow morning. And if you find yourself fascinated by the nation's oldest college - Harvard, founded in 1636, is 140 years older than the United States-you can go-to Cambridge, Mass., and get an education of sorts without being enrolled as a student.

The Italians have a number of hearty vegetable stews in their cooking heritage that are good main dishesespecially when meat and poultry prices are out of sight as they were this summer when a three-pound chicken cost more than $4 in our local market at Cortona in southern Tuscany.

The Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy last night ended its visit to China with a concert in the Auditorium of the Revolutionary Committee. Afterward there was a banquet attended Chinese dignitaries.

Yorkville residents and city politicians yesterday celebrated the opening of the first grasscovered football field in their area, one month before the Board of Estimate is scheduled to consider a proposal to build two high-rise apartment buildings and a school on the site.

Nolan Ryan, supported by Frank Robinson's five runs batted in, became a 20-game winner for the first time and moved closer to the major league season strikeout record today as the California Angels routed the Minnesota Twins, 15-7.

Miss Cynthia Munro Pyle, a doctoral candidate in Italian Renaissance literature at Columbia University, and Dr. Richard Stanley Kayne, professor of linguistics at the University of Paris in Vincennes, were married here yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.
The executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority said today that tolls on the turnpike might have to be raised to meet' increased maintenance and building costs.

A dozen post offices in the northern half of New Jersey have distributed to 50,000 residents franked envelopes with instructions printed on them so that patrons can order "stamps by mail." It is the first test in the metropolitan area of a new national postal service program.

Yoga devotees stood on their heads on stage in the Central Park Sheep Meadow yesterday. Nearby, Althea Gibson gave beginners a first tennis lesson. Members of the Hare Krisna sect distributed sticky fruit-and-nut "luglus," and bare feet predominated as hundreds of people held hands to dance in a "human energy chain."

A fire on the third deck of the giant aircraft carrier Saratoga was extinguished early today after burning for nine hours. A spokesman for the Navy's Atlantic Fleet said an investigation had begun into all aspects of the fire, including the possibility of arson.
For its fourth performance and first "L'Elisir d'Amore" of the current season Thursday night, the Metropolitan Opera offered a cast of the sort normally encountered in the dreary days of April.

Long before the Watergate crimes brought Mr. Nixon's White House into disrepute, there had been widespread concern that the office of the Presidency had somehow become bloated, unresponsive, unduly secretive, out of touch with the people and perhaps even with reality. Each President to some extent shapes the office to his own personality and needs, but the unhealthy trends derive from sources deeper than the personalities
Mayor Lindsay intervened personally yesterday in an effort to avert a threatened cancellation today of the New York City Opera season because of a strike by union musicians.

To the Editor: I take issue with your assessment [editorial Sept. 9] of Controller Beame's career in public life and his potential to be an outstanding Mayor of New York. I have worked at very close range with Abe Beame over the past three and one half years on the Board of Estimate.

A spokesman said today that the Vatican had not taken any "formal position" 'on the military Government in Chile. The statement followed reports that the Vatican had recognized the junta of Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, which overthrew President Salvadore Allende Gossens Sept. 11.
The body of a West Hartford, Conn., pilot was found today in the wreckage of his single-engine private plane in dense woods off U.S. 20 near Sherwood Forest, the state police reported.
Juan Z. Peron tonight won his third term as President of Argentina after his chief rival, Ricardo Balbin of the Radical party, conceded victory with nearly 90 per cent of the votes counted.

Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, urged Congress today not to revive the military draft for at least two more years until the all-volunteer armed forces concept has been given a "full test and fair trial."
The former head of the Maryland Committee for the Re-election of the President has been elected chairman of the divided Republican State Central Committee.

This busy Bergen County community seems destined to have a transplanted Oklahoman by way of Texas move into town next year. He's Lindy McDaniel, the New York Yankee pitcher, who is about to purchase a two-story colonial home on the east end of the township.

Pennant fever soared in the city yesterday as shrieking Met fans stampeded down the elevated ramp to Shea Stadium, used ladders to scale fences, perched in trees and stood in mammoth lines outside ticket windows.
Foreign Minister Nguyen Phu Duc of South Vietnam defended his Government yesterday against reports that it was corrupt and repressive.
Now that it is certain that Mayor Lindsay will not run for re-election, the new guessing game at City Hall is: Will he endorse any of the candidates seeking his job-and if so, when?
It was with some embarrassment that Victor G. Bloede, toward the end of last week, gave a speech that was amazingly similar in thrust to one given three days earlier by David B. McCall.

A small group of sports fans in Arlington, Va., plans to buy the tickets for 500 obstructed seats in Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium to thwart the blackout plans of Leonard Tose, the owner of the Eagles. The group, called Beat the TV Blackout, ran an ad in the Philadelphia Inquirer today requesting $2 contributions to purchase the unsold seats for the Eagles-Redskins game next Sunday. The tickets, a spokesman for the group said,

Evidence gathered in a civil suit against the General Services Administration suggests to persons close to the case a pattern of irregularities in the award of a multi-miilion-dollar Federal contract to a Philadelphia developer.
Boris Spassky, who lost the world chess championship to Bobby Fischer in the summer of 1972, will face Robert Byrne of the United States in the first round of the Candidates Matches next year.

Civil-liberties groups and criminal-defense organizations are preparing a full-scale legal attack on new state mandatory minimum sentences for a variety of crimes, including rape, armed robbery and burglary.

Pina Antonelli, the pianist who gave a recital Saturday night at Tully Hall, has the kind of keyboard facility that enables her to skitter through Dohnanyi's Rhapsody in C, Khachaturian's Toccata and Liszt's "Mephisto" Waltz at high speed, and she did precisely that with a certain charm.

Under strong prodding from Mayor Lindsay, representatives of the New York City Opera and its unionized musicians have begun a last-ditch effort to save that deficit-ridden institution, now threatened with extinction by a three-week-old strike. The chief point at issue is the opera's desire to scale down its present guarantee of 11 weeks of extra pay for work outside the regular season.

Rosemary's wedding didn't take place in the safe deposit vault after all. This somewhat disappointed a few hundred friends and acquaintances who trooped to the old bank at 110 Hudson Street in the nighttime wasteland between Greenwich Village and Wall Street Saturday expecting to witness the ceremony.

On the flight director's console at Mission Control here is a glass tank containing a small female spider named Arachne, for the woman in Greek mythology who tried to outweave Minerva and was turned into a spider.

Peter Revson, an American driver for the British McLaren racing team, won the Grand Prix of Canada today after a raindelayed and confusing 200mile Formula I race. His victory was good for at least $25,000 prize money.

BOSTON-This city has a sleeping giant. The new wing of the Boston Public Library on Copley Square by Philip Johnson and John Burgee has opened without fanfare, watched only by architects and librarians
After phase 4, what Even as they prepare for the expected flood of autumn price increases. Administration policy planners have been thinking about how to deal with inflation in 1974 and beyond.

Hotels often provide a brochure that lists their services, but according to some Brooklyn residents, the best place to read about the Pierrepont Hotel in Brooklyn Heights may be the police blotter of the 84th Precinct.

Kathy Whitworth shot a par 73 in a steady drizzle today to win the $30,000 Portland golf tournament, her third straight pro victory. It was the second consecutive Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament to be shortened by rain. Yesterday's round was rained out.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak in general debate-Brazil, United States, Peru, Ecuador, Singapore, Cameroon (tentative), Norway, Nicaragua, Ireland and Paraguay.
Mrs. Joan Ruth Abrams Windell of Teaneck was married here this noon to Mort Rubenstein, a widower and creative consultant to Viacom International, the television and cable company.

As the Ervin committee resumes its hearings today with its focus now on abuses in the 1972 election campaign, no one-and least of all the committee members themselves-should view its business as a mere tidying up of leftovers. The public interest demands that the hearings continue with all the thoroughness necessary to unfold the entire pattern of corrupt and unlawful practices for which Watergate has become the label.

Taking advantage of Montreal errors committed under the pressure of the tightest of pennant races, the Pittsburgh Pirates today captured a double-header and moved to within a half-game of the New York Mets.

New York Typographical Union 6 voted to end its 17-month strike against the defunct Morning Telegraph and to remove its picket lines from The Daily Racing Form, a sister newspaper published by Triangle Publications in Hightstown.
Braniff International Airways and the Air Line Pilots Association reached a contract agreement early today, ending a strike by flight attendants five minutes after it began.

Joe Namath will be lost to the New York Jets for at least six weeks and perhaps for the rest of the season. The injury-prone quarterback suffered a separation of his right shoulder yesterday as the Jets were defeating the Colts, 34 to 10, before a crowd of 55,942 in Baltimore.

The Chilean military junta has notified foreign embassies in Santiago that Chilean nationals will no longer receive safe-conduct passes for political asylum abroad, foreign diplomatic sources in Santiago disclosed. The Mexican Government is expected to send a plane to Santiago today for Chilean and foreign political refugees being sheltered in its embassy.

Joe Namath went to Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday on the return of the Jets from Baltimore. The injured quarterback will remain there until Dr. James Nicholas, the team's orthopedist, decides whether an operation is necessary on his right shoulder.

JAZZ The Downbeat, on the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 42d Street (972-1082), was once a Longchamps restaurant, and it still looks pretty much like one, sleek and a bit formal. For five years it has been the Downbeat, with live jazz on the menu.

Around the halls of Congress, it's known as "playing the money game"--authorizing vast amounts of money for various programs, but appropriating much smaller sums. Last week, the "money game" found itself under heavy attack in two quarters.

This city of ruins is where the Burmese empire flouished, where an 11th-century King brought Buddhist monks to the arid plain to convert the spirit worshipers and animists. It is the city where craftsmen, buoyed by religious fervor, built brick and stucco temples and pagodas and monasteries covering 16 square e miles.

For many middle-class working Americans, buying a house is rapidly becoming beyond reach. They cannot get a mortgage, or if they qualify for one, they cannot afford it. Officials of savings and loan institutions say mortgage money is almost nonexistent.
The team that Casey Stengel used to call "my amazing Mets" amazed 54,701 fans in Shea Stadium yesterday by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-2, and storming to their sixth straight victory.
Joe Coleman pitched a onehitter and Jim Northrup drove in two runs with his 11th and 12th homers, leading the Detroit Tigers to a 3-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

Gregory Brown, 2 years old, sat spellbound atop a police barricade on Seventh Avenue in Harlem yesterday, and when he spotted a colorful float of musicians--complete with a towering man in scarlet robes and headdress-he almost fell off his perch.

THE MARRIED LOVERS. By Julius Horwitz. 202 pages. Dial. $6.95. Suicide is the only alternative to a failed marriage, because we have nothing else to take its place. This is David, the hero of "The Married Lovers" speaking. Like almost everything else he says, this is both an over-generalization and an
Art authorities here we??comed as a coup for Australia the purchase of Jackson Pollock's "Blue Poles" for $2-million ($1.49-million Australian).

One of the subjects the Senate Watergate committee might "take into consideration would be the future of the F.B.I.," according to Fred Thompson, the chief minority counsel to the committee. His remarks were made in a news conference prior to a speech to students at the State University Center here.
Israel's dominant Labor party chose Premier Golda Meir unanimously today to lead its list of candidates in the general elections Oct. 30, virtually assuring her of another four years in office.

In this agrarian center, the military coup d'etat of 12 days ago started early in the morning, when local army troops took control of the radio stations and ordered all leftist leaders to turn themselves in to the police.
Even before they start negotiating on a declaration about their special relations, Western Europe and the United States have found themselves in apparent disagreement on the purpose of the exercise.
Steve Garvey and Tom Paciorek slugged two-run homers and the Los Angeles Dodgers whipped Cincinnati, 6-4, today and prevented the Reds from clinching the National League's Western Division title.

Johni Newcombe stormed past Dick Stockton today to win the singles final, then teamed with Owen Davidson to take the doubles in the $20,000 Palmetto tennis tournament. Newcombe, the Australian playing out of Houston, defeated Stockton, 6-4, 6-3.

Charles Previn, an Academy Award-winning musical director, who led George Gershwin's first Broadway show, "La La Lucille," died here yesterday. He was 86 years old. Mr. Previn won an Oscar in 1937 for the musical scoring of "100 Men and a Girl."

If you have purchased a new house, registered a new car, subscribed to a magazine, ordered a catalogue or in any way given your name and address to a profit-making organization, chances are very strong that your mailbox will be filled shortly thereafter with a wide variety of junk mail.
AUSTIN, Tex.--The American farmer's parity ratio (prices received relative to prices paid) fell from 107 in 1951 to 70 in 1971. It was 78 by December 1972, and 102 by August 1973.

Left-hander Jimmy Connors defeated Tom Okker, 7-5, 7-6; to capture the Pacific Southwest tennis championship today. Neither player took the net, preferring to stand back and fire long shots at each other.

Miss Alyce Jo-Anne Gluer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eloy Gluer of Lakehurst, N. J., was married here this afternoon to Dr. Roger Miles Rose, a New York otolaryngologist and the son of Mrs. Ben-Henry Rose of New York and the late Dr. Rose.
A merchants group here issued a protest today against any delay in hearings on a proposed fare increase on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson rail line.

The Senate's Watergate hearings, which resume tomorrow, are only one of many investigations and legal proceedings now under way concerning potential scandals that directly or tangentially involve President Nixon or his associates. What follows is a report on the status of these inquiries.

In the first joint appearance of the four major candidates during the mayoral campaign, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal sought to counter State Senator John J. Marchi's safetyin-the-streets campaign by linking his Republican rival with the Watergate scandal and the investigation of Vice President Agnew.
A visit by President Kennedy and his family to the America's Cup yacht races in Newport, R. I., in 1962 cost the Government $600,000, a General Services Administration official said today.

Henry A. Kissinger flew to New York yesterday for three days of intensive diplomatic discussions that will mark his entry into what Dean Rusk, one of his predecessors as Secretary of State used to call "the club of foreign ministers."

Melvin R. Laird, President Nixon's chief adviser on domestic affairs, insisted today that "there will be no tax increase this year." Mr. Laird announced 10 days ago that the Administration was considering asking Congress for radical changes in the tax laws to help maintain a prosperous economy with lessened inflation.

Following is the text of a proposal by the European Economic Community for a joint declaration on relations between the Common Market and the United States: The United States of America on the one hand and the European Community and its member states on the other hand.

Juan D. Peron was elected president of Argentina again today, 18 years after he was ousted from power by a military coup d'etat. His running mate and wife, Isabel, will become the first woman vice president in LatinAmerican history. The Perons are to take office Oct. 12.
The police are searching for the strangler of a woman whose body was found in the back seat of her car 200 feet from a Methodist church here this afternoon.

The Mediterranean coast of Spain is still dotted with the rough stone ruins of Roman watchtowers and Moorish castles but they do not stand alone. Crowding the playgrounds of the Costa Brava, the Costa Blanca and the Costa del Sol are the modern high-rise hotels and apart ment houses that have turned Spain's once placid shores into a concrete desert.
McCall's, the century-old women's magazine with a circulation of 7.5 million a month, will be sold by Norton Simon, Inc., to Chicago interests for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes next week.
Hubert Green carded a 67 on the final round today for a total of 266, and won the $100,000 Broome County open golf tournament and pocketed $20,000. His score for 72 holes was 18 under par.

It's no Mount Ararat, that wooded swell of land cleared this summer by the Rev. Jack S. Miller and his team of amateur construction workers. Yet the house they erected on its crest "comes close to being an ark," insisted Mr. Miller, flashing a broad, mutton - chops - tramed smile, "When we're finished we'll have a gangplank or a bridge going from the railroad tiefront steps to the front door."

In the confusion, at least the New York Giants showed a sense of history. On their last play at Yankee Stadium, a 14-yard field goal by Pete Gogolak salvaged a 23-23 tie with the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday. The tie was like kissing your nearest season ticket-holder good-by-a reminder of the glory years when the chant in the upper deck was "Dee-fense, Dee-fense" and a reminder of the disaster years when the chant was "Good-by, Allie."
The United Farm Workers Union is in trouble, but the delegates to the union's first constitutional convention are busy building their labor organization, not burying it.

Dr. Thomas C. Cha?mers, the director of the Bethesda, Md., Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health, hopes to put some new approaches to medical education into practice when he becomes dean of the Mount Sinai School of MedIcine of the City University of New York next week.
BOSTON-This city has a sleeping giant. The new wing of the Boston Public Library on Copley Square by Philip Johnson and John Burgee ha opened without fanfare,
A criminal case against three men accused of defrauding the city's Municipal Loan Program has been dropped for lack of proof that city officials tried hard enough to avoid being duped.

When Sidney P. Marland Jr. became United States Commissioner of Education in 1970, his qualifications as an administrator of proved talents seemed appropriate to deal with the serious internal problems in the sprawling Office of Education. Before long, however, it became evident that the Nixon Administration viewed the job of the chief education official--Dr. Marland was later elevated to Assistant Secretary for Education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare--as primarily one of image-building.

Once or twice a year, the duty to deal with children's Programing on commercial television becomes inescapable. As the bulk of that Programing is confined to Saturday mornings, dominated by cartoons and commercials, the prospect is inevitably dreary.

Greece today entered a week of goveniment-making that will test the military-backed regime's avowed plans to restore parliamentary democracy. Spyros 'Markezinis, a 64year-old historian and respected politician who has agreed to serve as Premier under President George Papadopoulos, is due to start formal consultations tomorrow for a new allcivilian cabinet.
A new wave of purges is under way in Yugoslavia's League of Communists to make the party "ideologically pure" before its crucial 10th Congress early next year.
Ken Brett's two-run single capped a five-run eighth-inning counter rally today that carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 9-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
The military junta here has notified foreign embassies that Chilean citizens will no longer be given safe-conduct passes for political asylum abroad, foreign diplomatic sources here disclosed today.

Miss Susanne Joan Lyons, a student at Trinity College in Washington, and Frederic Henry Kass 3d, who is in his fourth year at the George Washington University School of Medicine, were married here this evening at Mayfair Farms.

Edward Lynch, president of the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians, said yesterday that union leaders were "not worried" about rank-and-file acceptance of the tentative agreement reached with the National Broadcasting Company Saturday night.

Mrs. Louise Place Caven, widow of former Mayor Alexander Caven and a former member of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association, died yesterday in Vassar Hospital. She was 80 years old.

The Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan civic group, said yesterday that the City University of New York could save from $26-million to $34million a year by increasing the faculty workload without diminishing the quality of education.

Evidence gathered in a civil suit against the General Services Administration suggests to persons close to the case a pattern of irregularities in the award of a multi-million-dollar Federal contract to a Philadelphia developer.

Susan Starr, an American pianist, has challenged Van Cliburn to a musical battle of the sexes. Following the Bobby RiggsBilly Jean King tennis match, the 30-year-old Miss Starr said in an interview pub lished today that if Mr. Cliburn would accept her challenge, she would play "with gloves on-to give him an added advantage.

With the 10 per cent primeinterest-rate level a reality and tax-increase talk from Washington stilled, credit-market analysts have turned their attention to the question of whether interest rates have indeed peaked.
Left-hander Jimmy Connors defeated Tom Okker, 7-5, 7-6, to capture the Pacific Southwest tennis championship today. The 21-year-old Connors earned $11,000 as he won in 90 minutes.
Having won only four of their last 13 games, the hapless New York Yankees stirred themselves sufficiently today to take a double-header from the lastplace. Cleveland Indians, 9-1 and 2-1.
The opening of a Palestinian guerrilla mission in East Berlin and other undercover Arab activities have stirred a furor in West Berlin, particularly among the Jewish population.
The first death in the present outbreak of terror bombings in England occurred tonight when an army officer died who had tried to defuse a bomb in Birmingham last Monday.

Dane N. Bath, graphics editor of The Chicago Tribune, has been named picture editor of The New York Times, A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The Times, announced yesterday. Mr. Bath, who is 33 years old, began his journalism career in 1963 as a sports writer for The Oshkosh Daily Northwestern in Neenah, Wis., after attending the University of Maryland and the University of Wisconsin.
The country's top narcotics treatment official predicted today that New York City would receive a greater share of new Federal narcotics - treatment funds, and promised to cut red tape.

Histradrut, Israel's labor federation, will undertake a four-year, $60-million program of vocational training, health services and cultural work among new immigrants, including the heavy influx of Russian Jews. Yehoshua Levy, treasurer of Histadrut, reported on details of the program yesterday before the board of directors of the National Committee for Labor Israel at the committee's headquarters, 33 East 67th Street.

Vice President Agnew has reportedly made a decision to "confront head-on," as a friend has put it, the possibility, that he may be indicted by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore for alleged bribery and extortion.
Iraq has awarded a $117 million contract for construction of crude oil exporting facilities in the Persian Gulf to Brown Root, Inc., an American company, the Iraq news agency announced today.

The American woman is the most cherished, the luckiest, the best loved, the richest woman in the world. She has the most things, the best men, the happiest children, the biggest houses. Why then are American women worrying about the problems of American women? If we are so damned lucky, what is all the fuss and fury about?
A solid defense, timely passing, better ball control and fewer mistakes are the ingredients that Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, said it took to win championships.

The New Jersey Assoclation for Mental Health has joined consumer groups in the state that are backing Dr. Oscar Sussman, the controversial consumer-health director, who has been stripped of his powers to close kitchens at state institutions
The 19th season of Chicago's Lyric Opera has opened at the Civic Opera House here with a production of Gaetano Donizetti's 139-year-old, three-act bel canto work, "Maria Stuarda."
