A Dream Play, by August Strindberg, adapted by Ingmar Bergman, introduced and translated by Michael Meyer (Dial Press, $6). A Hard Man to Kill, by Ritchie Perry (Houghton Mifflin, $5.95). Intrigues involving secret agents.
After prolonged controversy, frustrating delays and ever-mounting expense, the spectacular architectural creation known as the Sydney Opera House is at last about to open its first season on Friday.

More than 3,000 people from outside Kenya have descended upon this first African capital to be host to the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, and so far matters have gone smoothly.

Mrs. Lilly Peckham Pickett, widow of Clarence E. Pickett, who was executive secretary of the American Friends Service Committee from 1929 to 1950, died yesterday in the Medford Leas Retirement Community. She was 91 years old.

Two physicists have proposed that the event that leveled forests in a wide region of because of tl Siberia on June 30, 1908, was health." the passage of a "black hole" that plunged completely through the earth.

The Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan civic group, said yesterday that the City University of New York could save from $26-million to $34million a year by increasing the faculty workload without diminishing the quality of education.

The marriage of Miss Sue Gardner Burgess to Paul Kenneth Goldsmith, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Goldsmith of Rockville, Md., took place here this afternoon. State Supreme Court Justice Charles Tierney performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Carter L. Burgess, parents of the bride.

After three months of extreme ferocity, the war in Cambodia seems to have bled both sides to the point of exhaustion, and although the fighting is far from over, major crises in the next few months seem unlikely.
The Oakland A's clinched their third straight American League Western, Division championship today by deeating the Chicago White' Sox, 10-5, for Vida Blue's 20th victory.

Twenty-eight men, traditionally capped and gowned, if untraditionally attentive and disciplined, received degrees in arts and sciences this afternoon from Dr. Richard K. Greenfield, president of' Mercer County Community College, at an unusual commencement exercise in the college auditorium.

New Jersey's Public Broadcasting Authority will begin its instructional television schedule tomorrow, broadcasting to an expanded student audience, offering a larger variety of courses and, for the first time, producing one of its own shows.

William Warwick Cowgill, vice president in charge of the warproducts division of the United States Rubber Company (now Uniroyal) in World War II, died yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

A $55,000 cargo of gold wire, destined for shipment to Singa pore, was stolen from an airfreight terminal near Kennedy International Airport. The police reported yesterday that between 9 P.M. on Saturday, when Randy International Forwarders closed its warehouse at 147-95 Farmers

If the Metroplitan Opera has as good luck with all the American singers it takes into the company this year as it did with those who made their debuts in the Saturday matinee performance of Mozart's "Die Zauberflote." it will have much o rejoice in.

Vice President Agnew has reportedly made a decision to "confront head-on," as a friend has put it, the possibility, that he may be indicted by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore for alleged bribery and extortion.
Hubert Green carded a 67 on the final round today for a total of 266, and won the $100,000 Broome County open golf tournament and pocketed $20,000. His score for 72 holes was 18 under par.
Chrysler workers have ratified the contract negotiated last week between the No. 3 United States auto maker arid the United Automobile Workers, clearing the way for production to resume tomorrow.

The Oakland Raiders, who had not contributed to it while it lasted, ended the 18-game winning streak of the Miami Dolphins today with a deceptively decisive 12-7 victory fashioned by George Blanda's four field goals and a stifling defense.
Gen George Grivas, the Cyprus underground leader, has denounced what he said was a plot to catch or kill him to eliminate his opposition to a GreekTurkish settlement in Cyprus.

Former Gov. Fuller Warren died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old. Mr. Warren, who was Governor from 1949 to 1953, was stricken at his suite in the Dupont Plaza, according to his brother, Julian, a Jacksoniville lawyer.
An International Council to Combat Lethal Yellowing, a disease that is deadly to the coconut palm tree, has been formed by a group of scientists from around the world who met here last week.

Civil-liberties groups and criminal-defense organizations are preparing a full-scale legal attack on new state mandatory minimum sentences for a variety of crimes, including rape, armed robbery and burglary.

In granting trade advantages to the Soviet Union, Should the United States require concessions to human rights? As Congress grapples with that profound question, it is important to remember the human realities involved. Hence a story.
A 25-year-old Brooklyn taxi?ab driver who got his chaufeur's license only last month .vas shot and seriously wounded last night by a holdup man in he Bedford-Stuyvesant section.

Lord Olivier was attacked by an intruder yesterday in his home in Brighton, 50 miles south of London. He was hit on the face and his glasses were broken but he was not seriously hurt, the National Theater reported today.

On the flight director's console at Mission Control here is a glass tank containing a small female spider named Arachne, for the woman in Greek mythology who tried to outweave Minerva and was turned into a spider.
More than 600 Bengalis and Pakistanis were repatriated today by United Nationschartered aircraft in two flights between Lahore and Dacca and Karachi and Chittagong, official sources said.

Finance ministers from 20 nations who have been made responsible for developing an improved world monetary system decided today not to negotiate any further here but instead to set themselves a deadline of next July 31 for agreement on all the main issues involved.

Opponents of a massive recreational property development in the Catskills say they will keep fighting the project even though the two towns involved and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation have given the necessary approval for its completion.
Most of the fans here call the game "le baseball" and their team "les Expos," but they yield nothing in enthusiasm to their English-speaking rivals south of the border.
Despite a iower court ruling that Japan's military forces are unconstitutional, Parliament approved two bills today increasing the size and scope of those forces.

A few years ago, when H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire, first sought entree to the huge, potentially lucrative world of New York welfare administration, his sales staff members reported they had no good contacts in state government to pursue. Mr. Perot remembers passing through an airport a few days later, spotting an interesting prospect and getting a friend to make an introduction.

Sixty-five per cent of the mothers screened in a new city medical testing program were found to have severe disabilities, according to city officials and representatives of the medical laboratories administering the tests.

The Jets had at least three reasons to be pleased today, but they had one reason to be unhappy and that had to overshadow everything else. For the third time in the last four seasons, Joe Namath suffered a season-shattering injury, this time a separated right shoulder.

Peter Revson of New York, driving a McLaren, came from behind today and won the Canadian Grand Prix, which was marked by confusion and controversy over the actual winner. After four hours of deliberations, race officials named Revson the winner of the 80lap, 200-mile, contest.
Machine tool orders and shipments in August showed gains over July and over August, 1972, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported over the weekend.

A few years ago, when H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire, first sought entree to the huge, potentially lucrative world of New York welfare administration, his sales staff members reported they had no good contacts in state government to pursue.
Three guitarists who don't appear very often in New York combined Friday evening in Carnegie Hall to present a panoply of possibilities for their instrument.

Angela and Philip Bloom have arranged Wood'n' Straw East, their shop at 1727 Second Avenue between 89th and 90th Streets, to look as much like a Haitian market as possible. The walls are covered with carved wooden masks and plaques as well as rather lurid paintings, which Mrs. Bloom characterizes as "primitive art."
The military junta here has notified foreign embassies that Chilean citizens will no longer be given safe-conduct passes for political asylum abroad, foreign diplomatic sources here disclosed today.

WASHINGTON -- Eight times as many couples are living together today without being married as cohabited ten years ago. That judgment-it's really my guess--is based on a new study being made by Dr. Paul C. Glick, the Census Bureau population division's senior demographer. (Census Bureau people are either Democrats or Republicans.)

One day last week a woman on city welfare who identified herself as Maureen Jameson walked into a nondescript building on the Lower East Side, clutching a piece of paper. On it was written the date and time for a medical examination and the words: "You must come for this appointment and have this medical examination if you are to be considered for an increase in your grant."

Notre Dame borrowed the University of Delaware offense last year, using it about half of the time. The Irish have apparently decided to move from that wing-T with motion exclusively this year. It was the pattern of attack all game long as Notre Dame opened its season Saturday by trouncing Northwestern, 440.

Pete Gogolak's 14-yard field goal on the final play saved a controversial 23-23 tie for the New York Giants yesterday against the aroused Philadelphia Eagles. The deadlock, in their final Yankee Stadium appearance, spoiled the Giants' perfect record after six preseason victories and last week's 34-14 opening-game rout of Houston.

The Institute for the Future has issued a sweeping and somewhat pessimistic forecast on the next decade. A report on its "Project Aware," commissioned by four private companies, said sex discrimination would decline, hospital costs would double and cable television would have a daily impact on local schools.
Charges of political favoritism have heightened a controversy over expanding efforts by Maryland state health officials to curb sewage flow through limitations on construction.
Bridge is a difficult game of chance, as one might conclude from a study of the most freakish deal in Saturday's play at the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Championships here.

David Roaman, chairman since 1966 of Roaman's, Inc., a chain of women's apparel shops, died Saturday at his home, 25 Central Park West. He was 67 years old. Mr. Roaman, president of the concern from 1931 to 1966, built the chain from a retail store his father, the late Harry Roaman, had owned.
The world's top financial experts have gathered in Nairobi, Kenya, to try to speed up the slow pace of international monetary reform. Even with a push, the job will not be a quick one.

The Chilean military junta has notified foreign embassies in Santiago that Chilean nationals will no longer receive safe-conduct passes for political asylum abroad, foreign diplomatic sources in Santiago disclosed. The Mexican Government is expected to send a plane to Santiago today for Chilean and foreign political refugees being sheltered in its embassy.

In a stirring game marked by consecutive 97-yard kickoff returns in a 34-point fourth quarter, the St. Louis Cardinals upset the Washington Redskins, 34-27, today. The Cardinals, who have an attackminded new coach in Don Coryell, went right at the Redskins' strength, pass defense, and shattered it.

The Suffolk County police said yesterday that four Long Island youths had been charged with tampering with telephone equipment to make calls worth an estimated total of $100,000 to such places as Shanghai, the United States Embassy in Moscow and a guard shack at Buckingham Palace.

"Under the collective title "Inside Women" or "Portrait of the Artist as a Young Woman," a program of six short films ranging from the surreal to the documentary ushered in the fourth season of the Film Forum last weekend.
The United States Postal Service announced today the inauguration of certified delivery service for large volume users of Mailgram, the postal letter that goes by wire.

Pennant fever soared in the city yesterday as shrieking Met fans stampeded down the elevated ramp to Shea Stadium, used ladders to scale fences, perched in trees and stood in mammoth lines outside ticket windows.
Joe Namath will be lost to the New York Jets for at least six weeks and perhaps for the rest of the season.
Chile's ruling military junta has begun to dismantle some of the institutions that drew attention to this country as a laboratory for the establishment of socialism through democratic consent.
The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today he hoped that close to $6-billion could be cut out of the $21.9-billion military procurement bill now on the Senate floor.
Pablo Neruda, a Nobel Prize winner who was regarded as one of Latin America's greatest poets, died tonight in the Santa Maria Clinic. He was 69 years old.

The Cubiculo has in the last few years taken a very special place in American modern dance. With its simple, spartan stage-more of a place than a stage-it has proved hospitable to any number of dancers, some established, some virtually unknown.

Finance ministers from 20 nations who have been made responsible for developing an improved world monetary system decided today not to negotiate any further here but instead to set themselves a deadline of next July 31 for agreement on all the main issues involved.

Soviet authorities arrested a Latvian Jew today for demonstrating outside the Communist party's Central Committee building and detained an American correspondent covering the event, seizing his film forcibly.

Any attempts by Western oil companies to boycott Libyan oil during the current nationalization dispute will be met by a general shutdown in the fields of the major exporting nations, Libya's Oil Minister, Ezzedin A. Mabruk, has said in an interview.
A 2-year-old bargain trotter named Rising Wind took a positive step toward the 1974 Hambletonian tonight at Roosevelt Raceway by winning the $82,695 Westbury Futurity.

A high school football player remained in a coma in the intensive care unit of a Morristown Hospital tonight. A blood vessel in his head ruptured following a game last Saturday. A spokesman at Morristown Memorial Hospital said Robert Fernandez, 17 years old, was in critical condition after a three-hour operation to remove a blood clot that had formed in his brain. Fernandez,
The case against Vice President Agnew, if there is one, will depend on the testimony of men he has considered to be among his closest friends.
Hearings on a proposal to raise fares on the PATH commuter line to 50 cents from 30 cents were abruptly ended yesterday amid growing reports that the proposal was dead.

Chris Legree could be an all-American. He is the starting quarterback for the South Shore football team, he plays varsity baseball at the Brooklyn school and is a, member of the basketball team. But Chris doesn't come from an all-American house or even an all-city apartment. He is from Osborne Street in Brownsville. The ghetto.

Dr. Margaret Stahr, a lawyer, who retired as professor of political science at Hunter College in 1959, died Sunday at a nursing home in Lewiston, Me. Her age was 80. She formerly lived here and in Northampton, Mass.

The State Welfare Inspector General's office yesterday challenged figures released by the city that showed that nearly 65 per cent of the mothers on welfare screened in a new medical testing program were suffering from severe disabilities.
A Gary-based Black Muslim Constellation plane, used for air freight operations between Chicago and California. Crashed on landing and burned early today at the Gary Municipal Airport .

Ernest J. Aries, a partner in Aries Associates, a real estate concern with offices in Yonkers, Hartsdale and Bedford, N. Y., died Sunday in Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Yonkers.
For 16-year-old Francis Folan, yesterday, the sixth day of the strike by teachers ir. eight Roman Catholic schools in Brooklyn and Queens, was the first day he voluntarily stayed home.
The Moslem rebellion on Mindanao Island in the Philippines has been blunted, two Moslem leaders and two defense officials said today.

Mrs. Emelia Maria Canthal Engelhard, widow of Charles Engelhard who founded Engelhard Industries and mother of the late Charles W. Engelhard who expanded it to form Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, died yesterday at Craigmore, her home here. She was 96 years old.

Smarting from a 140-100 defeat here on Saturday night at tile hands of the Buffalo Braves, the Boston Celtics played their National Basketball Association preseason exhibition last night against the New York Knicks at Madison Square Garden as if it were a vital playoff game.

Dr. Richard O. Cummings, professor of history at Brooklyn College, who wrote on the development of food processing and refrigeration, died Friday at his home in the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn. His age was 64.
Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States would never be satisfied "with a world of uneasy truces, of offsetting blocs, of accommodations of conventence."

Almost everyone is inclined to take a parochial view of the United Nations, equating its "success" or "effectiveness" with whether or not it seems to serve their own national interests, charging it with "failure" or "impotence" when it pays more attention to other people's interests.

Wall Street, beset with profit problems, yesterday formally initiated a move to higher commission rates on securities transactions. The rate increases, amounting to 10 per cent on most small trades and 15 percent on orders from $5,001 to $300,000, become effective today.

Despite reports on Friday that 50 persons had been let go by Teleprompter Manhattan Cable TV, employes confirmed yesterday denials by its president, Joseph C. Groth Jr., that anyone had been discharged from the New York outlet, which serves subscribers in the upper half of Manhattan.

The annual New York Elton John concert had the artist appear onstage dressed in whitefeathered trousers and vest, inlaid with silver lame, alternately resembling a gay cabellero and a rock'n' roll rooster.

It all begins with a classified advertisement in The New York Times. A man-so experienced that he has held down 17 jobs in 10 yearsgoes to a Second Avenue bar. He has to meet the boss, for an unspecified job. He is nervous. The bar is closed.

Superman is middle aged. He has every right to be, after all those decades of chasing bullets and flying cross-country without even a windshield to keep his face from chapping. Still, middle age is something you hadn't expected to happen to Superman, and when you first meet him

For the second time in two months, Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein yesterday directed the United States Attorney in Brooklyn to seize a Colombian jetliner in which narcotics had been smuggled from South America.

State Senator John J. Marchi and Representative Mario Biaggi debated yesterday who was first to emphasize the crime issue, while their two rivals for the mayoralty let their mimeograph machines do their talking.
Quintuplets, three girls and two boys, were born to a Cameron, Tex., housewife tonight, but all five died within an hour. Doctors said the babies were about four months premature.

Dr. James R. Cowan, the State Health Commissioner, and Dr. Maurice Kott, Acting State Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies, met with Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. yesterday to plan inspection procedures for kitchens in state institutions. The meeting followed the controversial closings of kitchens and bakeries in nine state institutions or day-care centers by Dr. Oscar Sussman, State Director of Comumnity Health Services.

Production or steel in the week ended Saturday totaled Full 2,848,000 tons, a decline of 1.3 lace, per cent from the 2,886,000 part tons poured in the preceding acquire week, the American Iron and by the Steel Institute reported yesterday.
October delivery cotton jumped the 4 cents a pound daily limit yesterday reaching 99 cents a pound, the highest level in the 103-year-history of the New York Cotton Exchange.
The copy by Eastman Johnson of Emanuel Leutze's famed painting, "Washington Crossing the Delaware," will be auctioned on Oct. 25 at Sotheby Parke Bernet.

When the more than 5,000 delegates, advisers, wives, guests and assorted hangers-on arrived for the opening of the International Monetary Fund conference this morning, they were greeted by great waves of rhythm-thumping of tribal drums, chanting of singers, stamping of feet, jangling of bells, but all jumbled together.

E. Howard Hunt Jr. told the Senate Watergate committee as it resumed public hearings today that Charles W. Colson, the former White House special counsel, had been aware early last year of the "large-scale" intelligence scheme that led to the Watergate break-in.

For six games on Sunday, there were 15,326 no-shows, meaning those who had tickets to the local pro game, but decided not to bother attending, possibly because the game could be seen at home on television. That was quite a drop from 50,072 the week before who stayed away from 10 games teleAbout vised locally.

At 5:35 this morning, Eastern Air Lines Flight 653 took off for Wilmington, Del. The uneventful, on-time departure was the first from the still-in-complete Terminal B at Newark's new and expanding airport.

Short-term interest rates plummeted again yesterday in continued professional response to clues left by the Federal Reserve late last week that its increasingly tight monetary policy might have come to an end.
If elected Mayor, John J. Marchi said yesterday, he would be a LaGuardia type who would "ride herd" on judges and, if they did not measure up, demand their impeachment.

The Federal Home Loan Bank board announced today that the outflow of deposits in savings and loan associations in August had been the third largest in history-a net of $1.2-billion more in withdrawals than in deposits.
Barring last- minute court intervention, this is the last week that Americans will be able to buy high-concentration doses of vitamin A or vitamin D without a prescription.
In an atmosphere of hail and farewell, the "miracle du Parc Jarry" apparently ended tonight, but not before the Expos inadvertently helped the New York Mets in the National League East race.

An 80-year-old inventor and former research engineer for the International Business Machines Corporation has filed suit in Federal Court in Washington, charging both I.B.M. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation with restraint of trade in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

Eight correction officers and their union announced yesterday that they would sue the city and the Legal Aid Society for $1-million because, they said, both had conspired to induce guilty pleas from the officers in departmental hearings.

As Vice President Agnew's at torneys prepared to go into court by Wednesday to try to head off an investigation and possible indictment of their cli ent, Mr. Agnew's office an nounced today that he still planned to make a speaking trip to California this week. In contrast to the Vice Presi dent's business-as-usual an

The American Stock Exchange market-value index rose sharply yesterday, with its retail, high-technology and part of its natural-resources components showing considerable strength. Prices also rose in the over-the-counter market.

The Federal Government is concentrating too much on suppressing the heroin traffic and paying too little attention to the spread of other illicit narcotics into the suburbs and schools, a Congressional report said today.

The City University of New York yesterday attacked as "fiawed both in method and in substance" a report by the Citizens Budget Commission that recommended a heavier workload for the City University faculty as a way of reducing expenses.

Same faces. new placesthat's the outlook for rock in the coming months in New York. The rock industry (and it is an industry) is forever poised and ready, awaiting the arrival of the New Elvis or the New Beatles to take us all into a new era of excitement and affluence.

Postmaster General Elmer T. Klassen said today that the United States Postal Service would seek an across-the-board increase in postal rates to take effect next January, including raising first class mail from eight to 10 cents.

Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge, a niece of John D. Rockefeller, left the bulk of an $85-million estate to a foundation in her name devoted to "charitable, scientific, literary or other educational purposes, or for the
Judge John J. Kitchen of the United States District Court in Camden died Friday, apparently' of a heart attack, in Underwood Memorial Hospital. His age was 61. He lived in Bridgeport.
Everette Howard Hunt Jr., today's lead-off witness at the Senate Watergate hearings, left the Central Intelligence Agency in 1970 after 21 years of clandestine operations.

A Cambodian Government official, saying "we are short of many things," appealed to the United States today to increase its military aid by the amount Washington used to spend on the bombing here, which the Cambodians estimated at $1-million a day.
A campaign of denunciation of the fallen Lin Piao is being made an occasion for reaffirming the values of the Cultural Revolution that he was once supposed to personify.

Angry parents in Lincoln Park, Mich., a suburb of Detroit, surrounded the Board of Education building yesterday and pledged to blockade negotiators until an agreement was worked out to end a teachers' strike.

The New York City Opera and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians reached agreement early yesterday on a new contract, erasing the threat that the opera might shut down for the fall and spring seasons and paving the way for a resumption of performances Saturday night.
Mrs. Pauline Conant Bacon, widow of Charles E. Bacon, a former chairman of Allyn Bacon Inc., textbook publishers, died yesterday at her home here.

The new managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today that the experience of the last six months had shown that floating currency-exchange rates "offer no panacea for the problems confrontin us."
Franqoise Durr, displaying innings, accuracy. upset Rosemary Casals, 6-4. 1-6, 6-4, today to capture the $30,000 Virginia Slims singles championship.

A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan issued a temporary restraining order yesterday barring the . City Commission for Human Rights from holding public hearings on charges that The New York Times accepted discriminatory advertisements for jobs in South Africa.

A new deal for an old island was formalized yesterday as Welfare Island was renamed and dedicated in honor of President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the presence of four of his five children and scores of Roosevelt-era Democratic celebrities.
School teachers in Greenburgh's Central 7 District voted overwhelmingly today to end a two-week-old strike and return to classes tomorrow.

A citizens coalition of regular and reform Democrats, labor leaders, lawyers and representatives of civic groups has been formed to support Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic nominee for chief judge of the Court of Appeals.

Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in PhilaJelphia yesterday set Oct. 12 For a hearing to which he has asked all interested parties in the Penn Central Railroad's bankruptcyy to advise the court under what conditions the railroad can continue train service.
On June 25, 1876, Gen. George Custer made his last stand at the battle of the Little Big Horn. Also on that day, Martha Nelson completed her first year in a, mental institution. She is still there.

Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr., Democrat of Texas, and two witnesses before his Senate Finance Subcommittee said today reforms are necessary to prevent banks and other major institutions from dominating the United States economy.

Prison officials say they have learned of an alleged plot to kill Richard F. Speck, the convicted mass murderer, in prison. Allyn R. Sielaff, director of the Illinois Department of Corrections, said yesterday that a prisoner at Old State Prison at Joliet said he had been offered money to kill Speck.
Mrs. June Cowley Eliot, widow of George Fielding Eliot, the military writer and broadcaster, died Friday in a Torrington hospital. She was 71 years old.
One of the youngest teams in the event captured the Swiss Team Championship Sunday. The event concluded the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Championships here.

Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, announced a $22-billion lending program for poor countries today, particularly stressing help for nearly 800 million rural people who have been bypassed by economic growth.
The National Park Service has decided that surrender is the most honorable conclusion of its fight to prevent beach erosion at the Cape Hatteras National Seashore, officials of the agency said today.
MUSQUARO LAKE, Quebec.-For perhaps 10 minutes we raised no fish, then trout hanging g from two to three pounds hit our flies savagely on nearly every cast.
Mrs. Frances McCullough of Harper Row demurs about the remark here that "hot" foods come from poor countries: "To judge from two where I've eaten under the supervision of first-rate cooks,

The RCA Corporation is holding discussions on the possibility of acquiring Oriel Foods, Ltd., London, it was disclosed yesterday following activity in Oriel stock on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
Years ago, dowagers had their chauffeurs drive them down to 14th Street, where Ohrbach's was then located, so they could save a dollar on a pair of gloves or a handbag.
While Hank Aaron and Nolan Ryan struggle for wellpublicized baseball records, New York's hottest jockey gallops quiety toward the first $4-million season in the history of horseback riding.

WASHINGTON - Only in America could President Nixon cling to power as his Administration is rockedd by scandal. In any other self-governing nation, the parliament would months ago have called the head of government to account.
The Thalia will end its 31-year reign as the Upper West Side's oldest repertory movie theater Friday when a new manager takes over and begins showing secondrun films.
Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan said yesterday that his country would like to discuss a mutual reduction of arms with India in the near future.

E. Howard Hunt Jr. said today that he had fabricated State Department cables to show a link between President Kennedy and the assassination of the President of South Vietnam, Ngo Dinh Diem, a Roman Catholic, to estrange Catholic voters from the Democratic party.

In an apparent effort to avert further protest shutdowns of filling stations, the White House said today that President Nixon had told the Cost of Living Council to act this week to allow an increase in retail gasoline prices.

AS television halves Into "adult," i.e., primarily sexu-al, themes in an attempt-to attract audiences of young marrieds, i.e., more conspicuous consumers, it may, be facing some surprising competition from an older and relatively neglected brother.

Fuel oil dealers in the city now have only about one-fourth of the home heating oil they can store instead of the 70 per cent supply they should have as of Oct. 1, the city's energy coordinator said yesterday.

E. Howard Hunt Jr. told the Senate Watergate committee as it resumed public hearings today that Charles W. Colson, the former White House special counsel, had been aware early last year of the "large-scale" intelligence scheme that led to the Watergate break-in.
The Cerro Corporation announced yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to sell to the Peruvian Government its mining and smelting business in Peru.
Two of the nation's most important blood-banking organizations announced today plans so form an American Blood Institute to help reorganize the country's entire blood distributing enterprise.
A Manhattan grand jury is scheduled to begin hearing testimony next Tuesday on- an alleged Republican party scheme to drain votes from Democratic candidates in the
A prominent South Korean opposition legislator demanded today that the Cabinet resign if the Government fails to arrest the kidnappers of Kim Dae Jung within a set time.
A hamburger cook was charged last night with the murder of Elizabeth Ann Anderson, a McGuire Air Force Base civilian employee who was found strangled yesterday morning in the back seat of her car.

In the 1930's, the lights of free scholarship were being extinguished in the great universities of Germany and Italy, and within a decade the darkness enveloped most of the European continent. It was in response to this intellectual blackout that the late Alvin Johnson, as president of The New School, mobilized a rescue operation of Europe's persecuted scholars.
Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak are Mauritania, Canada, the Soviet Union, Greece, Guyana, Japan, Ethiopia, Lebanon and Iran.

North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troops attacked at least three Government positions in the first reported Communist violation of the Laotian peace accords signed on Sept. 14, the Defense Ministry said today.

As Vice President Agnew's attorneys prepared to go into court by Wednesday to try to head off an investigation and possible indictment of their client, Mr. Agnew's office announced today that he still planned to make a speaking trip to California this week.
BLOCK BUSTER In New York, when a building or so begins to go, so does the rest of the block. That means going good and going bad. Take the north side of

While the Pittsburgh Pirates were playing their critical double-header in Montreal, the Mets rested their six-game winning streak yesterday and braced for the six games that could settle the championship of the National League's chaotic Eastern Division.
Until recently, the professional relationship between dancers and sculptors has been a conventional one. The dancer was merely a model, interchangeable with any other subject.

Thanks to the peace efforts of Mayor Lindsay's special mediator, Harold Israelson, the New York City Opera and its unionized musicians have settled the strike that threatened to kill that invaluable cultural institution. It would have been suicidal as well as socially irresponsible for the musicians to have pressed their demand for assured year-round income to a point that would have brought only total unemployment.

A few minutes after secretary of State Kissinger began to speak in the General Assembly, the last of 500 copies of his text was grabbed up by delegate, prompting an Amercan official to say, "That's unny--last year I couldn't get ?id of three."
A Presidential panel urged today that the lumber industry be allowed to cut down "substantial" portions of the national forests, and President Nixon immediately endorsed the recommendation.

New orders for durable goods from the nation's manufacturers declined in August for the second straight month, the Commerce Department reported today. The pace of orders for durable goods is one of the key business indicators relied on by the Government in forecasting future performance of the economy.
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell sharply in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.
W. A. Boyle, 71-yearold former president of the United Mine Workers, was admitted to George Washington University Hospital tonight after suffering a possible stroke, hospital officials said.
The widow of the former Chilean President, Salvador Allende Gossens, flew to Cuba today for a visit. She was accompanied by the Cuban Ambassador to Mexico, Fernando L6pez Muino.
Dr. Josue de Castro, a Brazilian diplomat and scholar who was known for his work in favor of third-world countries, died here today at the age of 65.

Ornate air-conditioned hotel dominate the once entirely green landscape curving around sapphire-hued Tumon Bay, th lively center of the booming tourist industry on this tiny American island in the western Pacific.
MUSQUARO LAKE, Quebec.-For perhaps 10 minutes we raised no fish, then trout ranging from two to three pounds hit our flies savagely on nearly every cast.

The United States Government signed an agreement today with nine West European countries enabling the Europeans to participate in international space research by constructing a large space laboratory by 1980.

To the Editor: A recent British independent study provides substantial evidence that the arms race is not slowing down but continuing to escalate. Behind President Nixon's rhetoric of a "generation of peace" is a massive arms build-up, including a crash project to deploy multiple nuclear warheads on our land-based and submarine missiles.
Mayor Lindsay went into City Hall with "some strength" and "some gumption" and "he did some exciting good things initially," particularly with respect to rearrangement of the city's tax structure.
The United States has offered to sell Lebanon a squadron of 18 A-4 Skyhawks, a light attack bomber, Administration officials reported today.
The military authorities made dozens of new arrests in downtown Santiago today as the house-to-house search for supporters of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens continued.
A number of Onodago County resident have been illegally receiving both welfare and unemployment compensation at the same time. it was reported today.

The Cordura Corporation announced its directors had authorized purchase of up to one million Cordura common shares outstanding from time to time for use in possible future acquisitions, employ benefit programs and stock option plans. The company's stock was up 5/8 at 4 1/2 on the New York Stock Exchange.
A labor dispute that threatened to halt thoroughbred racing at Belmont Park was ended last night when Pinkerton guards at the track ratified a new twoyear contract with the security company.

Leonic I. Brezhnev said today that the Soviet Union offered China a nonaggression pact in midJune but that the Chinese leaders in their "frenzied anti-Sovietism" did not reply.
Hearings on a proposal to raise fares on the PATH commuter line to 50 cents from 30 cents were abruptly ended yesterday amid growing reports that the proposal was dead.

The military junta paid homage today to the Nobel Prize-winning poet Pablo Neruda, who died here last night of cancer, as a figure "of national pride." But it said there would not be a state funeral because the country was under a state of siege.
Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States would never be satisfied "with a world of uneasy truces, of offsetting blocs, of accommodations of convenience."

When it was originally decided to honor Willie Mays at Shea Stadium tonight, the planners thought it would not only be a nice send off for Willie but would also be a welcome interlude at the tag end of a disappointing season. Little did they suspect that they'd find themselves engulfed by Metsomania, a form of lunacy caused by pennant fever.

The Massachusetts Aeronautics Commission has attributed the crash of a Delta DC-9 airliner last July 31 at Boston's Logan Airport to failure of the crew to utilize all navigational information available to them.
John J. Meehan, a correspondent for United Press International and Fox-Movietone News for 26 years died at his home today. He was 52 years old.

There was no surprise in the publishing community over the announcement of the impending sale of McCall's magazine. Everyone in the field knew that David J. Mahoney, chairman and president of Norton Simon, Inc., wanted to sell it.

At 5:35 A.M., Eastern Airlines Flight 653 left fo Wilmington, Del., an uneventful departure-but the firs from the still uncompleted Terminal B of Newark's net and expanding airport. Between 8 and 9 A.M., 400 passengers boarded Eastern's shuttle fights to Washingto and Boston, and by mid-morning, Terminal B was operate ing without major problems.

The stock market's strong rally, appearing to catch its second wind over the weekend, extended recent gains yesterday as activity continued brisk. Automobile and steel issues, relative laggards of late, moved ahead after showing signs of life on Friday, Oils, a standout

A strike by lay teachers against eight Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens started its second week yesterday with representatives of both sides saying that there were no signs of a break in the dispute over salaries.

SOUTH SALEM, N. Y.-By 6:27 A.M., which was when the sun rose on the first day of school here, the meat loaf in Betty Treyz's brick and beamed kitchen looked brown and juicy through the oven window. It was baking away in there with nine potatoes.

Brooke Hindle, a New York University faculty member since 1950, has been appointed director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of History and Technology here, the institution announced today.
Five persons were rescued on aerial ladders and 30 famiies had to be evacuated yes:erday in a three-alarm fire that burned through six frame Dwellings in the South Bronx.
Governor Cahill said today he would ask the Legislature to strengthen state control over the burgeoning cable television industry.
Ira F. Warner, a New York insurance broker and for 40 yeas a director of what is now Warnaco, Inc., a diversified apparel company of which his father was a founder, died today in Bridgeport Hospital.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation may have to seek an extension of the maturity date or an alteration in the payment schedule on its $250-million Government guaranteed loan, Edward Schmults, treasury general counsel, said today.

The Treasury Department announced today it has started an investigation into whether imported hand tools from Japan are being sold in the United States at less than fair value in violation of United States antidumping laws.
Dallas methodically trounced the New Orleans Saints, 40-3, on the power running of Calvin Hill and Robert Newhouse tonight to hand Cowboy Coach Tom Landry his 100th National Football League victory.

Juan Domingo Per6n has now completed an astonishing political comeback by winning the Presidency of Argentina with more than 60 per cent of the vote in a free election. Mr. Peron overcame major handicaps: eighteen years of exile, his age (he will be 78 four days before taking office Oct. 12), and the insistence that his wife, Isabel, be nominated Vice President despite strong opposition from some left-wing supporters.

An organization of black women announced yesterday the formation of a national commission on the arts and letters that will "research, identify and secure the creative talents of black people," with particular emphasis on black women.

With but three rounds to go in the United States Chess Championship, the unheralded California master John Grefe continued to set the pace. His 8-2 score put him a point ahead of Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek of Washington and far ahead of the rest of the 13-man field in the tournament being played in El Paso.

A 34-year-old New York City police officer who disappeared with his family from his Queens home more than a month ago was arraigned in Queens Supreme Court yesterday on charges of having passed $29,800 worth of had checks.
The Buffalo police have charged two teen-aged youths in connection with fatal shootings and accused a third of robbing a bank.
A Presidential panel urged today that the lumber industry be allowed to cut down "substantial" portions of the national forests, and President Nixon immediately endorsed the recommendation.
Henry A. Kissinger raised more questions than he offered to solve today, but that was apparently his intention in his first speech as Secretary of State.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that it had negotiatled a $67-million contract with the McDonnell Douglas Coriporation for procurement of 20 Delta launch vehicles.

The New York City Opera and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians reached agreement early yesterday on a new contract, erasing the threat that the opera might shut down for the fall and spring seasons and paving the way for a resumption of performances Saturday night.
Latvian Jew who staged a demonstration in Moscow yesterday has been sent by train to his hometown of Riga with an armed escort, Jewish sources reported today.

Argentines by the hundreds of thousands paraded shouting through the streets of Buenos Aires early today, acclaiming the overwhelming victory won by Juan D. Peron in the Presidential elections yesterday.

Chancellor Willy Brandt, who, in the phrase used here, may do fine on foreign policy but knows a good deal less about domestic policy, is making a priority effort this fall to mark his second term, with "domestic reform."

Peter Revson had the $25,000 first prize after much confusion at yesterday's 200-mile Canadian Grand Prix auto race. Delayed an hour because of rain, the race ended with Brazil's Emerson Fittipaldi contending that he had won. After four hours of deliberation and re-checking of lap times, officials finally confirmed Revson as the winner with a time of 1 hour 59 minutes 04.085 seconds.

The United States Steel Corportion announced yesterday that it had received formal approval from the Cost of Living Council to raise prices by 2.4 per cent for flat rolled sheet and strip products, beginning Monday.
A hamburger cook was charged last night with the murder of Elizabeth Ann Anderson, a McGuire Air Force Base civilian employee who was found strangled yesterday morning in the back seat of her car.
Tony Perez and Andy Kosko hit home runs tonight as the Cincinnati Reds clinched the National League Western Division championship by defeating the San Diego Padres, 2-1.

Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, announced a $22-billion lending program for poor countries today, particularly stressing help for nearly 800 million rural people who have been bypassed by economic growth.

As the dreaded Sunday drivers put newly acquired cars through their paces on these chilly autumn weekends, a Soviet traffic safety group is warning that only one-third of them have received proper driver training.
The Skylab 2 astronauts were set tonight to bring their record 59-day mission to an end with a splashdown in the Pacific Ocean at 6:20 P.M., Eastern daylight time tomorrow.

Carmine Persico went on trial yesterday on a charge of plotting to harbor a fugitive murder suspect, with a judge again trying to black out his underworld record. A similar attempt in another case was ruled out of order on appeal.

A. S. Neill, founder of the revolutionary and controversial Summerhill School, in which children were allowed to develop in their own way, died today at Aldeburgh, Suffolk. He was 89 years old.

The President Nixon's lawyers asked the United States District Court here today to reject the request for a summary judgment that would force Mr. Nixon to turn over to the Senate Watergate committee tape recordings made in his office.

It was an auspicious coincidence of timing that led Henry Kissinger to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday for his first official act as Secretary of State. The opening words of his formal address only heightened the sense of anticipation for what this respected scholardiplomat could present before the world forum.

A former narcotics and prostitution chief and two of his former prostitutes testified here today that for years they systematically paid several hundred dollars a week in bribes to Albany policemen to stay in business.
A suit intended to force the Nixon Administration to release $126million in impounded funds for mental health and alcoholism programs was filed today by 21 organizations, 10 persons and two states.

While a "meditative, realistic" Joe Namath rested painfully in a $170 private room at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday. the Jets pondered the optimistic possibility that their quarterback could avoid an operation and return for the final five games of the season.
Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that the Soviet Union offered China a nonaggression pact in midJune but that the Chinese leaders in their "frenzied anti-Sovietism" did not reply.

Gov. George C. Wallace has vetoed a bill passed during the recent session of the Alabama Legislature that would have provided a pension for Governors disabled in office.

Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union arrived today for a week's visit to strengthen long-range economic cooperation, to sort out some problems and to discuss international issues in the context of improved East-West relations.

The United States Export-Import Bank today approved a $5.6-million loan for Taiwan's Telecommunications Directorate and promised to support, if required, two private loans for another $5.6-million.

Politics and politicians now stand at the lowest point in public respect during this century, George Gallup, the pollster, said today. Speaking to members of the Indiana Restaurant Association a day after his national poll showed that 35 per cent of the public believed President Nixon was doing a good job while 55 per cent thought he was not, Mr. Gallup said, "The mood of America is one of disillusionment."

Did the New York Giants lose a certain touchdown because an official couldn't see Bob Grim catch the ball in the end zone? This opinion began to emerge privately among Giant coaches and players today after they saw films of Sunday's controversial 23-23 tie with the Philadelphia Eagles at Yankee Stadium.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., who has written more than 40 spy novels, added a new twist to the Watergate plot today, proposing a theory that the burglars were exposed by a double agent.

Vice President Agnew's sudden and dramatic late-afternoon appearance at the House of Representatives today ended weeks of speculation about how he would fight allegations that have emerged against him from a Federal investigation into corruption in Maryland.

Secretary of State Kissinger told a group of Arab diplomats yesterday that the United States recognized their unhappiness with the Middle East stalemate and was ready to assist in finding a solution, but warned against expecting Washington "to bring forth miracles."

Astronauts' Return That was a triumphant return of the Skylab 2 astronauts yesterday. The word "triumphant" is entirely appropriate because even at this early point it is evident that their 59-day stay in orbit was not only the longest manned space flight in history but also the most productive.

Ada Louise Huxtable, architecture critic of The New York Times, has been named a member of the editorial board of The Times, it was announced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page. Mrs. Huxtable will divide her time between the editorial board and expanded duties as architecture columnist for the Sunday paper.
The State Commerce Department trade office in Tokyo will be reopened about Oct. 1, it was announced today by Commerce Commissioner Neal L. Moylan.

In a riotously noisy evening before 53,603 fans in Shea Stadium, the New York Mets said good-by to Willie Mays last night and then gained their seventh straight victory by defeating the Montreal Expos, 2-1.

Robert V. Breen, executive vice president of Carl Byoir Associates, Inc., international public relations counseling firm, died of cancer yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here.
The stock market, displaying remarkable resilience, weathered a midsession wave of profit taking yesterday to post its fifth straight advance accompanied by heavy trading volume.
Henry Aaron missed his 713th home run by about 15 feet tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 5-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves before 10,211 customers.

Argentina's principal labor leader, a strong supporter of President-elect Juan D. Peron, was assassinated by urban guerrillas today less than 24 hours after a Marxist guerrilla organization was outlawed by the Government.

Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, will begin at sundown today with solemn synagogue services. The holiday marks the beginning of a 10-day period of introspection and prayer that culminates with Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, at sundown Friday, Oct. 5.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept. - Bob Seddon's problem, as some of his friends put it, is that he is soccer-sick. Seddon says he has had the disease for 15 years now, but it has just started to infect others. Seddon, soccer coach at the University of Pennsylvania, got the disease at Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood. He took it with him to Springfield College.

Once, in discussing whether the National Football League should create new rules to protect the quarterback, Joe Namath shook his head. "I hope they don't put in any rules like that," he said. Today is the 75th anniversary of the birth of George Gershwin at 242 Snediker Avenue in Brooklyn. Three new books about him and new editions of two old books release today, among other activities, commemorate the occasion.

Despite their tradition of noninvolvement in politics, Chile's armed forces are apparently following the dismally familiar pattern of other military dictatorships since their violent overthrow of President Allende. They have even added a few distinct-and distinctly unsavory -trappings of their own. While the reports of largescale executions of alleged leftists may not be true, the junta's avowed aim to return Chile to peaceful, constitutional government sounds more hollow with every passing day.

This was fan appreciation night for Willie Mays, an occasion supercharged with emotion.
Higher prices for automotive and other cyclical issues helped to send stock prices ahead yesterday for the sixth straight session of a dynamic rally.

Dr. Samuel Graff, a biochemist and cancer researcher, died here yesterday while visiting his son, Dr. Charles Graff. He was 68 years old and lived at 2500 Johnson Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, New York.
Second-seeded Chris Evert had little trouble today in defeating Janet Haas of Miami Beach, 6-1, 6-0, and advancing to the second round of the $30,000 Columbuswomen's pro tennis tournament.

New York City consumers could go out yesterday and get good buys in chicken at 39 to 49 cents a pound for fryers and broilers in supermarkets-down from early August highs of 85 to 92 cents in most stores, some then even over $1.

Milton Musicus, the city's coordinator for energy, charged yesterday that 80 per cent of the No. 2 heating oil used by the Consolidated Edison Company to generate electricity with gas turbines was being wasted.
The public's concern about high prices and inflation is paramount over other problems in the country, according to the latest Gallup Poll, released yesterday.

By chance the legislative and diplomatic calendars have coincided to set this week as the opening both of a new round of Strategic Arms Limitations Talks with the Russians, and of the long-prepared Senate debate on defense spending. SALT is the Administration's forum for negotiating mutual ceilings on superpower weaponry, while the Senate debate gives opportunity to the Administration's critics to curb the Pentagon's ambitions for more glittering and deadly hardware.

The winners in last night's Democratic primary elections in Connecticut were for the most part, the incumbents and the more colorful candidates.

Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany and other Western representatives warned today that individual human rights were a fundamental factor in seeking an accord between East and West.

The INA Corporation, which last month refused to comply with a Government plea to cut its dividend, decided yesterday to conform after all.

WASHINGTON-There are more political prisoners in South Vietnam today than in any nation in the world. Amnesty International estimates that there are 100,000. This is three times its 31,000 estimate for the Soviet Union, Brazil, Turkey, Spain, Ceylon, Portugal, Angola, Mozambique, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and South Africa combined.

Protagonist and Lord Rebeau may never run in the Kentucky Derby, much less win it, but remember the names. Both 2-year-old colts stamped themselves as potential future champions at Belmont Park by racing to impressive victories in the divided 51st running of the Cowdin Stakes.

An agreement announced late last month for an out-ofcourt settlement of an antitrust suit against five producers of antibiotics has been confirmed by Judge Miles M. Lord of the United States District Court in Minneapolis.

Wall Street's stock brokerage firms, which earlier this month won approval of an estimated $300-million rate increase from the Government, apparently were moving into a profitable stance even as the increase was being granted, according to industry officials.
Pat Dobson scattered nine hits and the New York Yankees clinched a fourthplace tie in the American League's Eastern Division by defeating the Milwaukee Brewers, 2-0. tonight.

William Fellner, President Nixon's nominee for membership on the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the goal of reducing unemployment to 4 per cent ought to be abandoned and a 5 per cent target substituted.
The Senate, in a foreign policy setback to the Administration, voted today, 48 to 36, to require a 110,000-man reduction in overseas troops by the end of 1975.
Spokesmen for Governor Cahill of New Jersey accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of leading Jersey officials into an embarrassing political trap over fares on the PATH commuter line.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, in a competitive move apparently aimed at New York race tracks, has cut proposed admission prices at the thoroughbred and harness plant it plans to build in the Hackensack meadows.
Rudiger von Wechmar, the chief spokesman fo rthe Westmar, the chief spokesman for the West German Government, says that it is "absurd to charge the Brandt Government with neutralist tendencies."
A long and tumultuous session of Japan's Parliament ended today when' the speaker of the house stood up and intoned wearily: 'Icre I adjourn the session."

The three major television network have not renewed their agreement to provide rotating coverage of the Senate Select Watergate Committee hearings and henceforth will carry them as news events warrant. The reason, according to a spokesman for the American Broadcasting Company, is that "the character of the hearings has changed and the story has run down."

Gasoline retailers say they will raise prices one to three cents a gallon if the price freeze oN motor fuel is lifted. "I'll raise one cent to get back to the pre-freeze level, then I'll kick it up another penny to cover the wholesale increase," said H. G. Thompson, the owner of a Gulf station in Atlanta.
Despite Administration objections, Congress may be moving toward the creation of a national commission to protect the rights of human subjects of all federally supported medical research.
The archives of Ezra Pound, among the most controversial literary figures of this century and a bulwark of modern Anglo-American poetry, have been sold to Yale University for an undisclosed sum.

President Nixon asked Congress today to enact major changes in the patent laws that would alter the basic procedures for granting patents and require publication of detailed information about patent applications before the patents are actually granted.

" Jonathan Livingston Seagull," the film of the book, will have its premiere next month and in among all the bird doings is a soundtrack written by Neil Diamond, a singer and writer whose credits wind back to the early nineteen - sixties, stretching from the Monkees to his own remarkably successful solo career.
John Sanders pleaded guilty yesterday to a conspiracy to obtain bribes in 1971 when he was acting director of the Harlem Model Cities Program.
Jules Podell, owner of the Copacabana, the last of the big New York nightclubs, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 900 Fifth Avenue, He was 74 years old.

Vice Presidents count for little in the American scheme of things. They are likely to spend their careers-if not like Alexander Throttlebottom, taking tours through the White House -- in relative obscurity.

The Soviet Union announced that it had ratified two international covenants on human rights, including one affirming that "everyone shall be free to leave any country, including his own." The announcement appeared to be an effort to influence the United States Congress, where approval of trade arrangements with the Soviet Union has been linked to the right of Soviet Jews to emigrate. Eduardo Zuleta Angel, former foreign minister of Colombia and the diplomat who presided at the first United Nations Assembly in London, died yesterday in Miami, relatives here reported today.

Endless argument could be generated by an attempt to establish any one player as the best ever. The strongest American candidate for this title is probably Howard Schenken of New York, who celebrates his 70th birthday at his home here today.

The impact of rising costs with no corresponding price relief under Government controls reduced net income of the General Tire and Rubber Company in the third fiscal quarter and nine months ended Aug. 31, it was reported yesterday. Sales, however, rose 18.5 per cent for the quarter and 28.6 per cent for the nine months.
Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak are: Gabon, Turkey, Albania (tentative), Morocco (tentative), Senegal, Oman, Tanzania, Spain, Sierra Leone, Cambodia, and Saudi Arabia.
Larry Wise, Dwight Nevil and Dave Stockton equaled the course record with 64's today and shared the first-round lead in the $100,000 Quad Cities golf tournament.
District Attorney Jim Garrison was acquitted by a Federal jury today of charges of taking bribes to protect gambling interests.

In an economy marked by shortages, not the least these days is a shortage of personnel. Unemployment still hangs heavy over many occupations and industries. The national unemployment level last month was 4.8 per cent.

A Civil Aeronautics Board member, Robert Murphy, resigned today effective Oct. 15. Mr. Murphy's term expired at the end of 1972 but he remained in office pending Senate confirmation of Judge Lee West of Oklahoma,
A long-term contract was signed yesterday in Teheran, Iran, for the importation of large quantities of Iranian natural gas products to help alleviate growing fuel shortages on the East Coast.

Allison R. Maxwell Jr., with nearly four decades of service with the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, yesterday announced his retirement as chairman at age 59. Mr. Maxwell served as chief executive of the company for 17 years,

A member of the Atomic Energy Commission and a leading member of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy agreed at a public hearing today that dividing the A.E.C. into a research and a regulatory agency, as President Nixon proposed earlier this year, is necessary to bolster public confidence in the safety of nuclear power.

Assemblyman Chester Hardt, an Erie Republican, has resigned as chairman of the temporary state commission to evaluate the drug laws. He will be succeeded by Assemblyman Emeel S. Betros. a Republican from Poughkeepsie.
The Soviet Union, in its first manned space mission in more than two years, today launched an improved Soyuz spacecraft with two astronauts aboard, placing it in earth orbit.

The Senate Watergate committee, its Democratic Senfators embarrassed by the outcome of yesterday's interrogation of Patrick J. Buchanan, is planning to speed up its investigation of political "dirty tricks."
The Bowater Paper Corporalion said in Montreal yesterday that it intended to apply to the Cost of Living Council for permission to increase newsprint prices.

Six of Alabama's largest and most influential lobby groups have been indicted on charges of violating the state's Corrupt Practices Act by secretly financing a front group in order to avoid disclosure of campaign financing.
Henry Friedricks, founder and president of Heniry Fredricks Co., a coat and suit manufacturer in New York, died Tuesday at the Heart Institute here. He was 77 years old.

To the Editor: In his Aug. 29 letter, Richard De Combray deplores the situation regarding so-called hard drugs. In that letter, and in statements by public officials, it is implied that addicts are responsible for the violence plaguing New York City.
Frederick L. Johanns Jr., president of Johanns and Keegan Company, Inc., a marine- and industrial-supply company founded by his father, died of cancer yesterday in the New York Hospital.

President Nixon is reportedly prepared to appoint a new chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights to replace the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, who was forced off the commission last November.

A Federal District Court judge here ordered the city's Board of Elections to run a bilingual election on Nov. 6, with all amendments, propositions and voting instructions printed in Spanish as well as English.

The chances that a person arrested for carrying a loaded pistol on the streets of New York City will escape conviction and imprisonment have increased in the last two years; a Police Department study has found.
William H. Leck, founder and chairman emeritus of Leck Industries Ltd., in Long Island City, Queens, New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

Samuel Flagg Bemis, twice a Pulitzer Prize winner and a leading authority on the diplomatic history of the United States, died here yesterday at the age of 81. He had lived here since his retirement in 1960 as Sterling Professor of Diplomatic History and InterAmerican Relations at Yale University.

Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee sought today to put pressure on Speaker Carl Albert to reverse his decision rejecting for the time being Vice President Agnew's request that' the House investigate charges against him.

This year's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Nairobi was to have marked the end of the first stage in the creation of a new world monetary system. But instead of agreeing on basic principles, the conference has disclosed a fundamental deadlock between the United States, on one side, and the Europeans, Japanese and most other nations, on the other.
John B. Peck, senior editor at Farrar, Straus Giroux, Inc., the book-publishing house, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 354 West 21st Street.

A faux pas and a miscue in the 13th inning tonight made the Pittsburgh Pirates 3-2 losers to the Philadelphia Phillies and cost them a chance to tie the idle New York Mets for first place in the National League's...

Byron De La Beckwith, who was tried twice but never convicted in the 1963 murder of Medgar Evers, the civil rights leader, was arrested today as he drove into New Orleans with a bomb and several rifles.
William J. Goddard, assistant editor of The Long Island Catholic, died Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip. He was 49 years old and lived here.

Percy B. Menagh, retired executive secretary of the Savings Banks Association of New Jersey, died yesterday in a nursing home in New Providence. He was 84 years old and lived here.
The National Farmers Organization faces possible loss of its tax exemption, and several of its home office aides have been subjected to personal incometax review by the Internal Revenue Service.
The Precision Valve Corporation of Robert H. Abplanalp announced yesterday that it was withdrawing a proposal to take over the operation of the dormant Sullivan County International Airport.

Maybe the people here are too close to it to appreciate the significance. Maybe they just don't understand. Or maybe they don't want to understand. Whatever the reason, the panorama of Atlanta Stadium is dominated by empty blue seats as Henry Aaron approaches Babe Ruth's record of 714 home runs. In a modern ball park with 52,870 seats, there were 47,299 empty seats last night, 42,659 empty seats the night before.

Late selling pressure sent prices on the American Stock Exchange down yesterday after they had drifted higher during much of the session with the net result that they closed mixed in slightly lower trading. However, prices rose in the over-the-counter market.
Ernie Terrell, who won the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship in 1965, was retired from boxing in New York yesterday by a unanimous decision of the three-man State Athletic Commission.

John Wilson of Union County announced yesterday that he was dropping out of the race for the State Assembly. Mr. Wilson, who was indicted by a Union County grand jury last week on charges of misconduct in office when he was business administrator of Clark, said he found it "impossible to continue as a viable candidate."
Ranking officials from a number of countries addressed the General Assembly today, generally expressing gratification at the improvement in relations among the major powers of the East and the West.

Bobby Tolan was suspended by the Cincinnati Reds today for the rest of the regular season for what Bob Howsam, the club president, said was "a continued refusal to take and participate in regular batting and fielding practice and for a lack of interest." Tolan, an outfielder, left the team for a few days last month after an argument with a club official, but returned under an ultimatum. Howsam did not say whether

Wilt Chamberlain is gone and Jerry West says he is almost certain to quitwhich would leave the Los Angeles Lakers with only two-fifths of the starting team that made a shambles of the National Basketball Association two years ago.

The National Broadcasting Company's "Wednesday Mystery Movie," which consists of several series presented in weekly rotation, introduced its new "Faraday and Company" this week. In the wholly familiar tradition of private investigators on TV, it is slickly produced, riddled with action sequences and skimpy on credibility.
The Senate, in a foreign policy setback to the Administration, voted today, 48 to 36 to require a 110,000-man reduction in overseas troops by the end of 1975.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it has given the go-ahead for a resumption of trading in stock and other securities of the Coastal States Gas Corporation of Houston.

Exxon Corporation said today it was prepared to take action against unauthorized buyers of crude oil and other hydrocarbons from its Libyan concessions that were 51 per cent nationalized earlier this month. The company's position was contained in a statement scheduled for publication as a paid announcement in newspapers in major non-Communist countries. It is issued in the names of Esso Standard Libya, Inc., and Esso Sirte, Inc.. two unites of Exxon with Libyan operations.

A small St. Louis bank yesterday afternoon lowered its prime rate on corporate loans to 93/4 per cent. Major money-center banks quickly indicated they believed the reduction was not likely to spread quickly.
A brawl today between black and white students forced the closing of Dorchester High School for two days. Officials attributed the violence to "reciprocal fear."
A long-term contract was signed yesterday in Teheran, Iran, for the importation of large quantities of Iranian natural gas products to help alleviate growing fuel shortages on the East Coast.
Jimmy Wright of Glen Cove, L.I., toured the St. Andrews course in a five under par today to take the third-round lead in the international Four-Ball golf tournament.

George Karger, a retired photographer whose fashion and theater pictures often appeared in Vogue and Life magazines some years ago, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 252 East 61st Street.
Larry Wise, Dwight Nevil and Dave Stockton equaled the course record with 64's today and shared the first-round lead in the $100,000 Quad Cities golf tournament.
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have received from Peking "a communication regarding the membership of China," a spokesman disclosed today.

A comet that could outshine Halley's Comet of 1910 moved into telescopic view this week, following a predicted course that should give the Skylab 3 astronauts an unprecedented opportunity to gather data on such brilliant objects in the sky.

Joe Namath and New York Jets fans got some good news yesterday as Dr. James Nicholas, the team physician, confirmed that there was little likelihood he would have to operate on the quarterback's separated right shoulder.

President Pompidou discoursed for almost two hours at his semiannual news conference in the Elysee Palace today, making no major pronouncements but proving that he can still give a lively one-man show.

The Chicago plane crash that killed a Congressman and the wife of E. Howard Hunt, the convicted Watergate defendant, was caused by pilot error, not by sabotage, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.
Cambodians celebrated their most important festival today in a demonstration of the continuity of life in this country amid war.

WASHINGTON - For sixty years Walter Lippmann (who turned 84 last Sunday) has been a lodestone not only for American journalists but also for journalists around the world. It is an extraordinary career reaching into a past that must seem dim and. remote. He has rarely if ever wavered in his pursuit of the truth in the nation and the world.

For the first time since the inauguration in January, President and Mrs. Nixon danced in public tonight. At a dinner party for Prime Minister Norman Kirk of New eZaland, the Nixons and Vice President and Mrs. Agnew were in a jovial mood.
One of the roughest days in British Isles golf history was finally halted today after six hours of rain, wind and cold had numbed the 36 professional contestants in the $145,000 John Player Classic.

Bacon d Field Chow, a professor of biochemistry at the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, who in 1936 was cred, ited with helping to isolate for the first time in pure form one of the substances known as antibodies, died today at the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 63 years old.

Grosset Dunlap, the pubfishing house, has offered to sell the mass-market paperback rights to "Marilyn," Norman Mailer's best-selling book about Marilyn Monroe, for a minimum guarantee of $500,000 against royalties, paperback publishing executives reported yesterday, but no paperback firms have met the terms.

The Authors League of America, representing 6,000 writers, and Grove Press, the publishing house, sent separate cablegrams to Chile yesterday decrying what were described as acts by the ruling junta against writers in Chile and their works.

The chances that a person arrested for carrying a loaded pistol on the streets of New York City will escape conviction and imprisonment have increased in the last two years, a Police Department study has found.

Two opponents of the military take-over in Chile were executed today on the order of military tribunals. The former governor of Talca Province, German Castro Rojas, was executed at Talca, 150 miles south of here.

The Soviet Union disclosed today a new system of high tax rates on authors' income from foreign royalties, suggesting that the Government's need for foreign exchange had been a major consideration for its joining the Universal Copyright Convention earlier this year.

The Reynolds Leasing Corporation, a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase from Pacific Far East Lines, Inc., two containerships at a price of approximately $32-million.
Iceland notified Britain today that she would break off diplomatic relations if British warships were not withdrawn from the disputed 50-mile fishing limit here within a week.
Yogi Berra flew into Chicago tonight with a small head cold and several large headaches as the New York Mets arrived at the site of their final four games in the battle for first place.

The Federal grand jury investigateing political corruption in Maryland began today to hear evidence against Vice President Agnew after weeks of legal maneuvering by the Justice Department and Mr. Agnew's attorneys.
