Sir Har old G. Christie, one of the largest landowners in the Ba hamas, died Tuesday during a business trip to Frankfurt West Germany. He was 77 years old.

E. Howard Hunt Jr. has testified before the Senate Watergate committee in great detail about his secret mission to the Denver hospital bedside of Dita D. Beard, the lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. According to his testimony, the White House plumber went on this extraordinary errand in a disguise furnished by the Central Intelligence Agency and with an "aide memoire" containing a specific line of interrogation, drawn up inside the White House.
Guards at the Leesburg State Prison tonight tentatively agreed to return to work at 6 A.M. tomorrow, ending their two-day "sick-out" in protest against prison security policy.

When Avery Fisher, the electronics manufacturer, gave several million dollars to Lincoln Center last week to help underwrite the operating and maintenance deficit of the New York Philharmonic, he could hardly have expected that the first fruit of his benefaction would be a strike by the orchestra.
John Grefe, a newcomer, and Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek tied at 9 1/2 points each today to share the title of 1973 United States Chess Champion.
Ernie Terrell, who won the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship in 1965, was retired from boxing in New York yesterday by a unanimous decision of the three-man State Athletic Commission.

After nearly two centuries of sheltered operation, the traditional mechanism for trading shares of ownership in public corporations is coming up for major overhaul. If fully implemented, the recent decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission to abolish fixed brokerage commissions for stock exchange transactions should spark a profound revolution in the securities industry.
The gubernatorial campaign got off the ground briefly today, thanks to a helicopter.

Recent statements by Soviet party leader Brezhnev indicate the Kremlin's growing concern over Peking's rapidly changing status in the world community. Speaking in Tashkent this week, Mr. Brezhnev openly chided those independent nations who are intent on seeking friendly relations with both Peking and Moscow.

Charles Longstreet Weltner hitched a leg over the arm of a chair in his law office the other day and couldn't help laughing as he savored the rich ironies that run through his campaign for Mayor of this Southern capital.
In what one broker called "chaotic" trading, copper futures on the Commodity Exchange ranged widely in price yesterday.
William Scanlon became the new varsity basketball coach at Union College today, succeeding Gary Walters, who returned to his alma mater, Princeton, to become an assistant coach.
The Soviet Union is reported to be quietly trying to calM discord between Yugoslavia and Bulgaria over the Macedonians, a Slavic-speaking people living in Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Greece.

The Senate Commerce communications subcommittee was asked today to delay consideration of James H. Quello to be a member of the Federal Communications Commission. Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, who made the request, said that because of Mr. Quello's "affiliation with the broadcast industry, close scrutiny must be made of .his sensitivity to the public-interest responsibilities of broadcast licensees." Mr. Quello is a retired Detroit broadcast executive.

Ralph Earnhardt, stockcar racer, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 45 years old.

President Nixon urged Congress today to modify the antiSoviet restrictions voted by the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday and permit the Soviet Union to enjoy improved trade treatment in the United States without linking it to the emigration of Soviet Jews.

Deputy Premier Nikolaos Makarezos announced his resignation today. Alfred Capaldo, a shop teacher in Public School 106 in Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, who had helped in the rehabilitation of many young children and adolescents, died Thursday at his home, 3082 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. His age was 54.

A scientific discovery that promises a powerful new weapon against starvation and malnutrition among millions of people in the poorest nations of the world was announced today by the State Department and Purdue University.

PALERMO, Siclly--Inflation is one thing; spaghetti, ice cream, good wine and the good life another. We Italians become poorer every day but spend as if we were richer. Italy and Italiansperhaps Europe and Europeans--are living in the'center of a troubled paradox. We have learned to be consumers in recent years but now we are admonished to be austere.

At the request of the United States Attorney, a Federal District Court judge today dismissed a 33-count bribery and extortion indictment against former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton on the ground that the Government's only remaining witness was too ill to testify at a trial.

The six banks of the Michigan National Corporation, a $2.88-billion holding company, reduced yesterday their prime interest rates on corporate loans to 9 1/2 per cent in a move that resulted from high rates pinching smaller and medium-sized companies.
Dr. Bryan J. Gallagher, a general practitioner for 37 years and a member of the staff of Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, died Thursday of a heart attack at Brooklyn Hospital.

Manager Red Schoendienst, whose St. Louis Cardinals are still in the running for the championship of the National League East Division with only two days left on the regular schedule, yesterday signed a contract to return for the 1974 season.

The White House denied today reports that Alexander Butterfield, who disclosed the existence of President Nixons Watergate tapes, was being eased out of his job as head of the Federal Aviation Administration.
Attorneys for Vice President Agnew filed a suit in Federal. District Court here today seeking to halt a grand jury investigation of Mr. Agnew's possible role in political corruption in Maryland.
Delta Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that it arranged to borrow $300 million under a new credit agreement with a group of 32 banks.

" Wide World News With Ben Grauer and Angus Corley" will be shown on cable television from 9:30 to 10:15 P.M. starting Monday. The program will be produced live and in color by Teleprompter Manhattan CATV Corporation.
John Schroeder broke the course record with an eight-under-par 63 today and tied Kermit Zarley for the lead at 132 in the $100,000 Quad Cities golf tournament.
There was a bit of confusion at last night's opening of the city's 11th annual Film Festival over who was being honored, Francois Truffaut or Max Arons.
Responding to a Federal court order, President Nixon's 1972 campaign finance aides disclosed today that the President's fund-raisers had collected re-election, including nearly $1.5-million in cash.

Jozser Cardinal Minaszenty, the 81-year-old exiled Primate of Hungary, was reunited at Kennedy International Airport last night with 200 Hungarians who fled to the United States in 1956 following the Hungarian uprising.

The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation announced yesterday it had filed an application with the Federal Trade Commission to reacquire control of Atlantic Department Stores, Inc., which operates 68 discount stores.
Fifteen undergraduates at Union College in Schenectady think they have found a way to cut their expenses, in these days of rising prices.

Prominent political figures in the city have played major roles, in the management and development of two banks in the city, and the relationships have aroused the attention of Federal and state investigators.
Stock prices retreated in orderly profit taking yesterday after seven straight sessions of advance on huge volume. Wall Street observers tended to regard the pullback as a normal procedure.

President Nixon, in his housing message to Congress last week, was blunt and to the point: Nearly 40 years of Federal housing programs for the poor had failed, the President said in essence, and the time had come for a fundamental new approach.

The tide has turned in the battle to eliminate pollution in the Hudson River, with almost all fishermen, marine biologists, environmentalists and government officials agreeing that the river is cleaner now than it has been in recent years.
Norma Crane, stage, film and television actress, died today of cancer at Beverly Glen Hospital. She was 42 years old.

Lawyers for the Senate Watergate committee argued today that there was "sufficient-evidence to establish a prima facie case that the President was engaged in criminal conduct." Thus, they contended, he has damaged his claim to executive privilege in withholding tape recordings of converstations made in his office.

Fifty-two Chinese restauant operators yesterday began the fourth mandatory good-protection training class given by the City Departnent of Health.

After a bewildering display of indecision, the Senate finally hammered out a reasonable interim position this week between the contradictory pressures affecting the United States military presence overseas. It put on record an impressive show of support for cutting back a bloated military establishment, but wisely backed away from specific cuts in European troop strength which could have weakened American negotiators just as they began delicate talks. with the Soviet Union.

Saudi Arabia cautioned the General Assembly today not to be "carried away" by "the euphoria of detente" among major powers while critical problems, such as the Midde East situation, remained unsolved.

Farm prices dropped 8 per cent in the month ended Sept. 15, the Department of Agriculture said today, and a top official at the Cost of Living Council predicted that sharp declines in meat animals would be reflected soon at retail counters.

The Soviet Union has now ratified two international covenants on human rights adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1966. Since the United States has not ratified these covenants, the groundwork has now been laid for Moscow to claim it is even more virtuous on civil rights than the United States.
Attorneys for Vice President Agnew filed a suit in Federal District Court here today seeking to halt a grand jury investigation of Mr. Agnew's possible role in political corruption in Maryland.

Chile's new Foreign Minister, Vice Adm. Ismael Huerta, said today that "the door is open" for a resumption of negotiations on compensation for United States copper holdings nationalized by the former Marxist coalition Government.
Japan's balance of payments recorded a deficit of $872million in August, compared with a $657-million deficit in July and a $557-million surplus a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.

A scientific discovery that promises a powerful new weapon against starvation and malnutrition among millions of people in the poorest nations of the world was announced today by the State Department and Purdue University.
Dr. Frank D. Kern, first dean of the Graduate School of Pennsylvania State University for whom its new building is named, died today at a nursing home here. His age was 90.
The 3rd United States Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed today a petition by the PBW Stock Exchange challenging a new Securities and Exchange Commission "Institutional Investors' rule.

Ed Tutwiler, a former Walker Cup player from Indianapolis, paced 16 golfers qualifying for the 49th George Arthur Crump Memorial Cup with a four-over-par 36, 38-74 today on the Pine Valley Golf Club course.

Two Soviet astronauts, in an unusual orbital change, today flew their modified Soyuz spacecraft higher above the earth than previous Russian manned missions.

Eckhard Dagge, the West German middleweight champion, knocked out Matt Donovan of Trinidad tonight in the second round of a nontitle bout. Dagge also floored Donovan in the first round.

The Soviet Union, which made history's biggest purchase of food grains last year because of shortages, is lending two million tons of grain to India, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government announced today.

The heavy outflow of deposits from New York State savings banks has sharply reduced commitments to make mortgage loans, and expansion of actual mortgage loans has slowed down. According to data released this week by the Savings Banks Association of New York State, commitments declined by $361-million -- their largest monthly drop since 1969 -- and now total $4.2-billion.

John B. Connally took his traveling political road show before the National Federation of Republican Women today and received a mixed response from this organization of grass-roots party loyalists.

Rain fell on the New York Mets' dash to some sort of destiny today, postponing their game against the Chicago Cubs and forcing the battle for first place to be waged in consecutive double-headers tomorrow and Sunday.

The board of directors of the Fairmount Foods Company of Omaha, Neb., agreed to a nonrecurring charge of $1.77-million against the concerns third quarter, ending Nov. 30, 1973.

However, when we examine the probability that a person will be struck by a falling watermelon, we must conclude that this environmental danger is not worth worrying about.

Elliott Roosevelt met privately with his lawyers today in preparation for a Senate subcommittee appearance Wednesday to rebut charges that he had tried to arrange the assassination of Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling of the Bahamas.

Since the primary election, State Senator Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday, he has taken in $37,678.34 in contributions to his campaign as Democratic nominee for City Controller.

The Boston Red Sox, frustrated by another bridesmaid finish in the American League East, dismissed Eddie Kasko as manager today and promoted Darrell Johnson to field boss for the 1974 season. Kasko will be an executive scout for the Red Sox for the one year remaining on his contract. Johnson, 46,years old, was a Boston coach under Dick Williams, who was replaced by Kasko in 1969.

In the sunshine of the first inning, Henry Aaron stepped up out of the Atlanta Braves' dugout onto his stage. At last, needing one home run to equal Babe Ruth's record of 714, he had attracted 40,517 spectators to Atlanta Stadium today for his final game of the season. The atmosphere had changed.

Confetti was thrown from the windows of Wall Street buildings, cab drivers shouted joyfully at each other in Times Square, and a Seventh Avenue shoeshine man won $50 in what he called "a sociable bet" yesterday after the New York Mets won the Eastern Division championship of the National League.

" Hawkins," which will be rotated. Tuesday with two other series on the Columbia Broadcasting System, stars James Stewart as Billy Jim Hawkins, a criminal lawyer with a pronounced down-home country manner.
Premier Golda Meir of Israel will fly to Vienna tomorrow to confer with Chancellor Bruno Kreisky on a possible comprovise arrangement for the continued transit of Soviet Jews throughh Austria.

The Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu, which has been talking of a Communist offensive next year, today put on trial the brigadier general charged with fleeing be. fore last year's North Vietnamese drive in Quang Tri Province.

P-RATED The films shown Tuesdays at the Donnell Library Center, on West 53d Street, and on Wednesdays across the street at the Museum of Modern Art are political, polemical, often socially perverse. Which is what they're intended to be.
Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union last night approved a contract with the city's three major daily newspapers by more than a 4-to-I margin.

Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci" returned to the New York City Opera repertory Sunday night in Frank Corsaro's double-bill production, which continues to succeed in pinching these two weary warhorses into a semblance of youth.

Fog rolls in from the East River, lightning crackles high above the Empire State Building, the old Third Avenue El rumbles downtown. Moments later firecrackers explode, Fourth of July music whips to a frenzy and the Statue of Liberty is dedicated.
E. H. Werner, who retired in 1954 as president of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, died yesterday at the Bethesda Memorial Hosiptal. His age was 83.

The President's Council on Environmental quality will hold hearings this week in Mineola, L.I., to assess local response to the idea of drilling for oil and gas off the coast of Long Island. John Busterud, acting chairman of the council, explained that the drilling, if approved by the Government, would be about 60 miles off shore. He said he anticipated the discussion would focus on the secondary effects of drilling.
Warming up for his expected bid for a fourth term next year, Senato Jacob K. Javits attacked the Nixon Administration last night charging it had failed to slow inflation and prevent energy shortages.

In a move of major political as well as economic significance, Egypt has accepted an offer by Bechtel Inc., based in San Francisco, to build a $400-million oil pipe. line from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean. The line will bypass the Suez Canal which has been closed since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.
Tom Gorman of Seattle and top-seeded Ken Rosewall of Australia scored first-round victories today in the $25,000 Osaka tennis tournament, the first of seven events on the Asian circuit.

Cambodian insurgents today forced Government troops off the south bank of the Prek Thnot River, leaving rebel forces in control of the river bank 11 miles south of Phnom Penh, reports from the field said.

Never, since systematic observations of the remarkable behavior of monarch butterflies began, has there been such a profusion of those insects as those in the hordes now migrating south, according to a leading specialist in their population trends.

The most immediately urgent point now, in the negotiations between Israel and the Austrian Government over the emigration process for Soviet Jews, is to insure that the line of exodus through Austria remains open. This is the prime issue to be resolved when Chancellor Kreisky and Premier Golda Meir confer in Vienna today.
The Nigerian Bank of Commerce and Industry opens here tomorrow to provide loans to Nigerians wanting to take over, or buy into, a number of commercial establishments here now owned by foreigners.
The Senate approved today a $20.9billion military procurement bill after rejecting a last-minute proposal for an across-the-board $500-million cut in the defense budget.
Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson assured President Nixon this morning that Henry E. Petersen was not the source of a disputed news broadcast about Vice President Agnew.
Promises of gourmet dining on the New Jersey Turnpike - complete with chafing dishes and Viennese pastriesproved to be pie in the sky today.
The military Government today announced that nine more people had been executed over the weekend.
A Federal judge adopted the recommendation of a prosecutor yesterday and imposed a suspended sentence on a New York City detective who last May 21 pleaded guilty to splitting a $4,000 payoff.

Two health food organizations announced today that they would go to court to try to stop the Food and Drug Administration from banning the sales of large doses of Vitamins A and D without a prescription.

Tchi Chang Yun, Minister to Britain from South Korea from 1949 to 1951 and its Ambassador to Turkey in 1961, died yesterday in New York, where he lived. His age was 74. He studied at Ohio State University and the University of Chicago.
William B. King, a former Associated Press foreign correspondent who retired here last year after more than two decades with the United States Information Agency, died today. He was 62 years old.
Dr. Ruth Rabinovitch Cohen of Glen Cove, L. I., a specialist in child psychiatry, died Saturday in Memorial Hospital. Her age was 57.
An unidentified gunman killed himself yesterday in the basement of a Brooklyn apartment house after attempting to hold a woman hostage.

Elston Howard, who was the first black player with the New York Yankees in 1955 and became the first black coach in the American League in 1969, now would like to become the first black to manage a major league team--preferably the Yankees.

The Gulf Oil Corporation, the world's third largest producer of crude oil, said late yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the CNA Financial Corporation, a large holding company with interests in insurance, real estate and other financial services.

In a move of major political as well as economic significance, Egypt has accepted an offer by Bechtel Inc., based in San Francisco, to build a $400-million oil pipeline from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean. The line will bypass the Suez Canal which has been closed since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.

A court - ordered desegregation plan for this city's public elementary schools that requires busing to achieve racial balance has provoked strong opposition here, including a move by a local judge to impeach the Federal judge who imposed the plan.

For the first time in nearly two centuries, the United States mail was carried by stagecoach today between New York City and historic Nassau Inn here, which, in the mid-seventeen-hundreds, was the halfway station on the dirt and cobblestone roads to Philadelphia.

A special unit in the Department of Correction, consisting of private investigators who were brought in last February, has been investigating the record number of escape attempts-at least 50 in the last 12 months-from the city's detention facilities.
The largest airsea search in the New England area this year for a missing boat has ended in the location of a lobster boat off a Maine island, the Coast Guard said.

Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway and Defense Minister Georg Leber of West Germany officially welcomed American troops arriving at the air base here in southern West Germany to take part in a vast reinrorcement exercise code-named Reforger V.

Harriet Michel had just bought some paint at Macy's and the salesman was filling out the delivery form when she noticed that he had written down her old address - 5900 Arlington Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. "My new address is 616 West 147th Street," she said, still beaming over being a homeowner.
On arrival in Geneva yesterday, the reception for the Dalai Lama of Tibet was about as cold as the bitter north wind that swept across the airport runways.

The men appeared to be train robbers, but Moshe Litvak soon found out otherwise. He and two other Soviet Jews held hostage by two Palestinian terrorists arrived here by air from Vienna today and told their stories.
The West Side Highway Story-a road show with horrible advance reviews-failed to live up to all the dire predictions when major repair work started yesterday.
The Senate Finance Committee resumed hearings today on the confirmation of Helmut Sonnenfeldt as Under Secretary of the Treasury. Now,

For all the loose talk about crime to which New Yorkers are being subjected during this mayoralty campaign, President Johnson's Commission on Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice stated the issue most succinctly several years ago when it termed the criminal court "the central, crucial institution in the criminal justice system."
Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, was attacked by two youths as he walked home from work tonight, the District of Columbia police reported.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel decided to fly to Vienna to confer with Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria on a possible compromise arrangement for the continued transit of Soviet Jews through Austria to Israel. In Strasbourg, France, where Mrs. Meir addressed the Council of Europe, an aide said that the Premier "has reason to believe her trip will be worth the effort." [Page 1, Column 6.]

Peking officials are negotiating to buy large additional quantities of North American grain despite prospects of a record harvest in China this year, according to knowledgeable Midwest grain trade sources.
The United States said today that it did not agree with Austria's decision to close down transit facilities to Soviet Jews going to Israel and had expressed its concern to the Austrian Government.

The public water supply serving most of this city's homes, offices and hospitals is contaminated with high levels of manganese and may pose a threat to health, the Health Department's director warned today.
A $250,000 learning center at Abbott House, a children's home in Irvington, N. Y., was destroyed yesterday in a blaze apparently set by an arsonist.

Prices closed higher on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as stepped-up trading at the closing bell pushed them up after being lackadaisical during most of the session. Prices closed lower in the overthe-counter market, however.
The Senate approved today a $20.9billion military procurement bill after rejecting a last-minute proposal for an across-the-board $500-million cut in the defense budget.
The faculty union at Rutgers University has protested a decision by the administration to extend the semester by two weeks, calling it a change in working conditions without negotiation.

The Soviet Union today opened a natural-gas transmission line to West Germany that is part of a continuing effort to expand markets in Western Europe and ultimately in the United States for vast Soviet natural-gas resources.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger has approved Navy plans to purchase 50 Grumman F-14 fighters each fiscal year through 1977 but says a cheaper plane must be bought after that, military sources said today.

Senator Adlai E. Stevensen 3d introduced today a far-reaching oil and natural gas proposal that shaped up as the principal Democratic alternative to the Nixon Administraion's plan to end Federal regulation on natural gas prices.
President Nixon provided the first indication tonight of when he might make his planned visit to Western Europe, saying it could come "in about two or three months."
A shopkeeper, a cabby and an off-duty patrolman joined forces yesterday to capture an armed suspect as he allegedly fled with $120 in cash and $6,000 in jewelry taken from a Brooklyn store.

The lawyer for four of the Watergate burglars said today that his clients "weren't ordered to kill anybody" but yet were being treated discourteously by the office of the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox.

The stock market returned to its winning ways yesterday, following last Friday's interruption of a seven-day upsurge. After a continuation during the morning hours of the profit taking that marked the previous session, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange firmed slightly to close at their best levels of the day.
The capital of Tanzania is to be moved from Dar es Salaam on the Indian Ocean to the arid heartland of-the country at Dodoma.

Lieut. James Pelosi, who drew national attention when it was disclosed that he endured more than a year of "silencing" as a cadet at West Point, was hissed by classmates today as he received his infantry officer's basic course diploma.
" Ye are the salt of the earth: but if the salt have lost its savor, wherewith shall it be salted?" Matthew V, 13.
Despite a new state law permitting them to spend up to $1.5-million each, the Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor reported today that they would actually spend far less.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today asked a Federal District Court in Philadelphia not to permit the Penn Central Railroad's trustees to proceed with their plans for shutting down the 20,000-mile system at the end of the month.

The European Championships, which ended in Ostend, Belgium, last week, resulted in a not-expected double victory for Italy. The astonishing partnership of Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo demonstrated once again that they are virtually unbeatable.

On a pleasant midsummer evening Gabe Paul, administrative assistant of the Yankees and the power behind the throne, dropped in for a social call on a next-door neighbor, Bob Scheffing the general manager of the Mets. At that time the Yankees were riding along in first place behind the fantastic relief pitching of Sparky Lyle, while the Mets were dragging dreadfully because Tug McGraw, their relief artist, had lost his touch.
The United Paperworkers International Union reported yesterday that tentative agreements had been reached with the Eastern Newsprint Group and the Consolidated-Bathurst Group at their Canadian mills.
The Memorex Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached a basic agreement with the Bank of America and 13 other lenders to restructure its debt credit.

The crowd waiting the victorious Mets to arrive from Chicago at La Guardia Airport's Marine Air Terminal last night began forming around 7 o'clock. Among the crowd were Al Gordon, who drove 26 miles from Plainview, L.I., and Paul Tannenbaum, a friend, from Queens.

The World Series will open in an American League city, either Baltimore or Oakland, on October 13, the baseball commissioner's office said yesterday. If the A's take the American League pennant, the 'game is scheduled for 4 P.M. Should the Orioles be champion, the game begins in Baltimore at 2 P.M.

As China celebrated the 24th anniversary of her Communist government today, Chairman Mao Tse-tung's familiar countenance could be seen in huge portraits in public squares and on the front pages of the official newspapers; his revolutionary exhortations stretched virtually across the land in outsized Chinese characters.

Despite more profitable operating conditions on Wall Street, the consolidation trend continued yesterday with the announcement that two brokerage houses had merged to form First Regional Securities, Inc.
Following is a list of the capital construction projects for Queens and Staten Island submitted to the City Planning Commission by the community planning boards.
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

The Soviet Union announced today that an exhibition on Soviet youth, including a mock-up of an American Apollo and Soviet Soyuz spacecraft docking, would begin a 10-month tour of the United States in Washington on Oct. 12.

Larry Walton, a wide receiver, shocked Atlanta by going 57 yards for a touchdown on a reverse the second time Detroit had the ball tonight to set the tone for the Lions' 31-6 rout of the Falcons in a National Football League game.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it would discontinue operation of its block automation system Dec. 31 in an economy move. The move reflects revenue losses and continued operating problems of the system, the exchange said. Anticipated losses this year are estimated at $3-million.

California election officials confirmed today that for several months they had been trying to get Herbert W. Kalmbach, a Newport Beach, Calif., lawyer who has represented President Nixon, to account for the use that was made of a large part of $1,668,000 in surplus funds from the 1968 Nixon Presidential campaign.

In 1928, three years after "The Great Gatsby" had secured his literary reputation, F. Scott Fitzgerald turned to his early youth for the subject of a series of stories.
Vladimir Viardo, 23year-old pianist from Moscow, won the fourth quadrennial Van Cliburn International Piano Competition here Saturday night.
Three astonishing flyrod striped bass catches have been made this summer, and leading the list is the 64 1/2-pound fish taken on Oregon's Smith River July 10 by Beryl Bliss of Nevada.
Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak are Costa Rica, the Philippines, India, Nepal, China, Guinea, Trinidad and Tobago, Liberia, Lesotho and Burundi.

Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson assured President Nixon this morning that Henry E. Petersen was not the source of a disputed news broadcast about Vice President Agnew.
Assemblyman Calvin Williams charged yesterday that his arrest on bribery charges was an attempt to put the "gypsy" cab industry, of which he is a leader, out of business.

The Parliamentary leader of the governing Social Democratic party, Herbert Wehner, has stirred a political storm with his reported remarks during a trip to the Soviet Union that Bonn had "pushed too hard" for concessions from the East on West Berlin.
Secretariat's handlers apparently have changed their minds about not running the Triple Crown winner against Riva Ridge again.

Joseph J. Perrini, the Conservative party candidate for City Controller, yesterday accused his Democratic opponent, State Senator Harrison J. Goldin, of running an unethical, heavily financed campaign that has made him beholden to Wall Street tycoons.

To the Editor: Several of the Nixon Administration proposals for the energy crisis may involve serious health hazards. These range from short-term effects due to inadequate heating or air pollution to long-term effects such as increased leukemia.

The president of Eastern Air Lines, Samuel L. Higginbottom. resigned yesterday as a result of a long slump In business and basic differences with the company's chairman on the best way to turn the airline's fortunes around.
Such is the speed of institutional change in Washington that an election reform proposed by President Roosevelt-Theodore, not Franklin-is now getting serious attention in both houses of Congress.
PEKING - A journalist is fated to follow the advice given by A Shanghai friend to Teilhard de Chardin: "Write about China before you have been there too long; later you would break your Pen."

The House completed today Congressional action on legislation instructing the Federal bank-regulatory agencies to put an unspecified ceiling on the amount of interest banks can pay on time deposits of less than $100,000.
The Iranian Government said today that it had uncovered a plot to assassinate the Shah of Iran during presentation ceremonies later this month to the makers of the best movies for children.

When the 25th Amendment was ratified on Feb. 10, 1967, few would have guessed that within a decade the nation would be wondering how to apply it.

Costello's, the Third Avenue bar that catered to James Thurber, Ernest Hemingway, John O'Hara, A. J. Liebling and others seeking shelter from life's cares, is about to be closed.
Volkswagen of America yesterday instituted a round of price increases for foreign cars sold in the United States, announcing a 14 per cent rise in list prices of 1974 models.

The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company: Announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of 2,000,000 shares of common stock.
The Senate approved a $1.2-billion foreign assistance bill today by a vote of 54 to 42 after resisting two attempts to trim the authorization sharply.
The House agreed today to continue operations of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, despite protests that American-financed propaganda stations have outlived their usefulness.

Members of the City Council clashed yesterday with Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams as Mr. Abrams attacked the third and latest version of council district reapportionment during a public hearing.

An off-duty Sanitation Department policeman was shot and seriously wounded last night in a gun battle with three men who attempted to rob a bar in Brooklyn.
The test version of a new rocket for planetary exploration, including the first American robot landings on Mars in 1976, was rolled out last week to its launching pad at Cape Kennedy. Fla.
House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a 25 per cent increase in Federal aid to the school lunch program, with a promise of more money if food costs continue to rise.

WXTV (Channel 41) a Spanish-language television station here, said yesterday it was considering a suit to force the Port Authority to "live up to" its 1967 contract to place the antennas of the city's 10 TV stations atop the World Trade Center.
The stock market closed strong yesterday and reached its highest closing since April 19. Electronic, oils and specialty issues featured the day's trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Paul Cavalier, who has toiled before thousands of sports spectators during a long career, will face the crowd again. Cavalier, the top boxing referee in New Jersey for more than 30 years, will be honored with a testimonial dinner here on Friday when highlights of his career as a boxer, referee, school attendance officer in Paterson and boxing instructor will be recounted.
By sheer pluck the New York Islanders fought the New York Rangers to a 6-6 tie in a National Hockey League exhibition game tonight.
A Cook County Judge awarded $1.6-million today to Jerome Lisiecki, 18 years old; who suffered brain damage and paralysis in the crash of an Illinois Central Gulf Railroad train in
A 25 story, $160-million concrete and glass building, scheduled to open next month;: will bring the ancient rambling complex known as Bellevue into the age of modern hospitals.

The Los Angeles Lakers are breathing easier today. Though he said he still wasn't happy about some rookies getting more pay this year than he received, Jerry West has ended his holdout with the National Basketball Association team.
Valentin Oehen is leader of the parliamentary group of the movement he founded and heads, the Nationale Aktion gegen die. Uberfremdung von Volk und Heimat.

Columbia University announced yesterday the receipt of a $6.5-million grant from the Fairchild Foundation that will permit beginning construction next spring of a $12-million, seven-story life sciences building.
The Government military spokesman announced yesterday in Saigon that a regiment of Communist troops, supported by a Vietcong battalion, had attacked two Government battalions just northeast of here.

When someone climbs the rather steep flight of steps bordered by flowers and shrubs and rings the doorbell at a certain house in Flushing, a light embedded in a wall here, a ceiling there, or perhaps in an archway, flashes on, no matter how bright the day. For this is the home of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hlibok (pronounced LIEbock) and they and their four children are deaf.
In an atmosphere more reminiscent of a playoff game than an exhibition, the Nets defeated the Knicks, 97-87, last night at Madison Square Garden.

The Arab commando raid that impelled the Austrian Government to announce a suspension of special transit arrangements for groups of Soviet Jews going to Israel has won the official approval of the Egyptian Government.
The two sides in the long Laotian civil war today named powerful men as cochairmen of a committee to oversee the cease-fire and political settlement signed last month.
After months of indecision, the White House committed itself today to Federal supply-management of heating oil for the coming winter, the first such peacetime regulation in the country's history.
Officials disclosed today the murders of three more whites on this racially tense Caribbean island, bringing to 18 the number of whites slain here in little more than a year.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company set a sales record in its second quarter, reporting $1,659,000 in revenues, but the troubled supermarket chain lapsed into red ink following a profitable first quarter, the company reported yesterday.
The Jet pass defense, the worst in the National Football League last season and questionable at best at the start of this year, has distinguished itself in the first three games.

The New York Mets, again amazing after three years of third place, took the day off yesterday to savor their farfetched victory in baseball's most intricate race.

The body of a 20-year-old woman, wrapped in aluminum foil and painted with varnish, was found last night in a Brooklyn Heights apartment. A man who shared the one-room apartment was arrested and charged with stabbing and strangling her to death 10 days ago.

Mrs. Margaret French Cresson, daughter of the sculptor Daniel Chester French and herself a sculptor, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack. She was 84 years old and lived at Chesterwood, the family estate here.

The Senate Watergate committee resumes its hearings tomorrow with testimony from Donald H. Segretti, who was hired by White House aides to disrupt the campaigns of candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Rankin Smith, owner of the Atlanta Falcons, expressed bitter disappointment at his team's showing against the Detroit Lions last night, but said today he wasn't "ready to fire" Coach Norm Van Brocklin just yet.

Samuel Baron, a former vice president of the Textile Workers Union of America and a high official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters until an incident with the then president, James R. Hoffa, in 1962, died yesterday in Miami, where he had been living. He was 70 years old.
Two of the oldest unions in the printing industry merged today to form the International Printing and Graphic Communications Union. with a combined membership of 132,000.

Three research biologistsRenato Dulbecco, Harry Eagle and Theodore Puck-have been named recipients of Columbia University's 1973 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize for outstanding contributions to tissue culture research.

Six persons, including a minister and his two teenaged children, were shot to death and two other persons were wounded early today, and the police said that two escapees from a Federal court jail had been arrested in connection with the slaying.

The City Health Department has released the names of 20 more restaurants and other foodhandling outlets in the city accaused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that had persisted after two inspections.

A Federal Judge ordered the Detroit Edison Company today to pay $4million in punitive damages to blacks who, according to the judge's finding, have been victims of "deliberate" and "invidious" racial discrimination by the utility.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday said that it was moving forward on a "top priority basis" with its plan to initiate trading in stock options and hoped to begin its pilot project by Dec. 10.

Nelson W. McCombs, who retired in 1955 after 31 years as head librarian at the Washington Square branch of New York University and two years at the University's Gould Memorial Library, died today of pneumonia at Foulkeways, a Quaker retirement home here.

Federal Judge John R. Bartels yesterday dismissed an indictment charging Carmine Persico and three other alleged Mafia figures with conspiring to help Joseph Russo, one of the defendants, to escape prosecution for murder.
Twentyone Soviet psychiatrists and neuropathologists today denounced charges that Soviet mental hospitals were being used to punish political dissenters.
Dr. Beatrice G. Konheim dean of the Institute of Health Sciences at Hunter College and a faculty member for 43 years, died Monday at New York Hospital.
Yields on both Government-backed and conventional mortgages fell sharply at this week's Federal National Mortgage Asociation auction.
Stephen D. Raimo, president of the Ray Contracting Company of Syosset and past president of the Masonry Contractor's Association of America, died today at the North Shore Hospital, Manhasset.

The Women's Tri-County Golf Association defeated the Garden State Women's Golf Association, 21 1/2 to 8 1/2, today in their annual betterball team match played on the 5,451-yard, par 37, 3673 course at Ridgeway Country Club.

Andy Granatelli, one of the sports world's dominant and successful personalities, has had his contract with STP terminated because of "differences" with his board of directors, Studebaker-Worthington, Inc. controls 55 per cent of STP.

The Vice Mayor of Atlanta, Maynard Jackson, rolled to victory yesterday over a field of 10 opponents in the first step in his effort to become the first black Mayor in this Southern capital.
The British Government yielded today to an ultimatum from Iceland and agreed to withdraw its naval frigates from disputed fishing waters.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria conferred for nearly two hours today, but were unable to reach any agreement on facilities for the continued transit of Soviet Jews through Austria.

In sharply stepped-up trading, prices rose markedly along a broad front on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as well as in the over-the-counter market.
State Environmental officials disclosed tonight that they were attempting to learn if New Jersey inland waters near Atlantic City were dangerously contaminated by mercury.
Senator John C. Stennis told a Federal District Court jury today how he was shot and robbed last Jan. 30.
Two men sought in connection with the mass slaying here last January of seven Hanafi Moslems were arrested today in Jacksonville, Fla., the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

The city's 4,569 local election boards will be open today and tomorrow from 5:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. and on Saturday, Oct. 13, from 7A.M. to 10:30 P.M. to register voters. To register, a person must be 18 years old on or before the Nov. 6 general election, have lived in this city or in his county outside the city for 30 days by Election Day and be a citizen.

Paavo Nurmi, the celebrated long distance runner of the nineteen-twenties, died here today. He was 76 years old and had been in declining health for several years.

Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today that the prices of corn, wheat and other commodities can be manipulated almost without fear of discovery or penalty to the detriment of farmers and consumers.
Just how fantastic a performance Hank Aaron turned in during 1973 is only now beginning to sink in as statisticians dig through his accomplishments.
The Conservative mayoral candidate, Representative Mario Biaggi, shook hands at the ferry terminal on Staten Island and then visited the Willowbrook State School.

C. Arnholt Smith, the financier, won two rounds against the Government yesterday. A Federal judge ordered suspension of grand jury proceedings against him and quashed attempts to collect immediately on a $22.8-million tax lien.

A Staten Island widow yesterday, received the highest cash settlement ever awarded by the medical malpractice mediation panel of the State Supreme Court - $350,000 for the amputation of her left leg by a orthopedic surgeon.

Top Soviet and American officials and corporate executives made a deliberate show today of ignoring Congressional obstacles to press ahead with new programs for promoting expansion of Soviet- American trade.

In a break with precedent, the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church announced today that It had named the Bishops of Ohio, California, Arkansas, Rochester and Mississippi as nominees for Presiding Bishop.

The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Caspar W. Weinberger, has named Dr. Roger 0. Egeberg, former dean of the University of Southern California Medical School, as interim head of the newly created Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration.

Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, said today that he would seek a vote of the full House of Representatives if necessary to force an inquiry into "whether the Vice President has committed impeachable offenses."

More local teen-aged girls than boys experiment with drugs, according to a survey in this suburban Morris County community. The survey was made by Dr. Marvin Lavenhar, associate professor of preventive medicine at the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.
Volkswagen of America yesterday instituted a round of price increases for foreign cars sold in the United States, announcing a 14 per cent rise in list prices of 1974 models.

Will they or won't they? That was the question at Belmont Park yesterday as the focus continued on Meadow Stable's two crack colts, Secretariat and Riva Ridge. Both are eligible for next Monday's $100,000 added Man o' War. Will both compete?
The state's Fair Trade Act came under renewed attack yesterday at a hearing sponscored jointly by the Assembly Commerce Committee and the Senate Select Committee on Consumer Protection.

Six of the 16 new Court of Claims appointees who will be sitting in the new narcotics courts as acting Supreme Court Justices did not receive the highest rating of "qualified" from Governor Rockefeller's new State Judicial Screening Committee, but instead were listed as "qualified with reservations."
" There are a lot of people these days wondering why the Secretary of Agriculture has not been canned," said Dr. Earl L. Butz, speaking of himself.

A total of 10,000 youngsters will receive free tickets to 20 Madison Square Garden games of the New York Golden Blades of the World Hockey Association under a program announced yesterday. The announcement was made by Louis Roddis Jr., vice chairman of Consolidated Edison Company, and Ralph Brent, president of the Golden Blades, formerly the New York Raiders.
Roy Halston Frowick, widely acclaimed as this country's most influential designer, has been acquired by Norton Simon Inc., one of the country's largest diversified companies.
State Environmental officials disclosed tonight that they were attempting to learn if New Jersey inland waters near Atlantic City were dangerously contaminated by mercury.

The House Appropriations Committee approved a $2.203-billion measure to maintain United States contributions to several international institutions as a result of February's 10 per cent devaluation of the dollar.

Mrs. Mary Ellen Peck Churchill, a geneticist, and the wife of S. Garton Churchill, a retired New York lawyer and championship bridge player, died yesterday at her home here.

Coach Bud Grant and several of his players went duck shooting yesterday morning. Grant, an outdoorsman all his life in his native Minnesota, arranges the Viking practice schedule so mornings can be spent in duck blinds.

A deputy chief of the Albany Police Department, investigating a report that policemen had broken into and looted a tire store, assured his men that "we would try to cover this up," according to the chief's internal police report released today by the State Commission of Investigation.
The teachers who struck the Greenburgh schools in West chester last month and returned Sept. 25 have learned that they will lose an average of $1,200 in fines.
Authorities said today they were working on the assumption that a fire that killed at least 10 persons in a five-story tenement was started in a mattress discarded on the second floor landing.
A Prayer for Katerina Horovitzova, by Arnost Lustig, translated from the Czech by Jeanne Nemcova (Harper Row, $5.95). What happened to a group of wealthy American Jews-in the hands of the Nazis.

Rubin of Queens was unqualified for the bench.
Traffic was light and the track was fast yesterday morning on the West Side Highway, where major repairs are under way.

Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that if elected Mayor, he would name Representative Herman Badillo to head a cabinet-level committee that would seek to ease tensions among ethnic, economic and social groups within the city.

The Soviet Union in recent weeks has sent about a dozen TU-22 supersonic bombers to Iraq in what American officials interpret primarily as a psychological move to enhance Soviet credibility in the Arab world.

Corporate bond prices were lower yesterday and Government issues were mixed. In the corporate sector, the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company's $300-million of 7 5/8 per cent debentures was offered publicly at 991/2 to yield 7.665 per cent in 40 years.

The Bechtel Corporation, which Egypt has picked to build a $400-million oil pipeline across its desert, is hardly a household name. Yet it is known to virtually all the industrialists and governments around the world, and its operations have touched the lives of Americans and other peoples as much as, say, the Ford Motor Company.

Hundreds of Liberals and Democrats will come to the aid of the Liberal party tonight at its annual fund-raising event just a month before a mayoral election that will mark a crucial point in the party's 29year history and its long and often stormy relationship with the Democratic party.
Major oil consuming nations are pressing negotiations for an agreement under which they would pool their petroleum supplies in order to deal with any emergencies in case of production disturbances.

The Orange County board of supervisors voted today to ask the State Board of Equalization to appraise the value of President Nixon's property at the Western White House in San Clemente.

Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst testified in a hearing here today that the United States Attorney for South Texas, Anthony J. P. Farris, did not follow instructions in granting immunity to the central figure in a Texas stock scandal that rocked the state government in 1971.

A sociologist said here today that much of what is called school vandalism is the product less of malice among children than of failure among adults to design schools properly and understand how young people use them.
Peter Gennaro's method of teaching dancing is to catch his students unawares. He has them take a few light steps, bouncing up and down in place in time to the music and glide around in a circle.

The New Jersey Lottery Commission, which has proposed changing the prize structure of the weekly lottery, is also studying a possible change in the daily lottery's prize setup.
Glen R. Schubert, a former Nationwide Insurance Company claims adjuster, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of trying to extort $280,000 from the company by threatening to blow up its facilities.

Most of the leaders of political reform in this city appear to have decided that the mayoral election can be dispensed with this year. The multiplicity of hitherto undetected virtues they are discovering in Controller Abraham D. Beame reflects their conviction that he nas the mayoralty won a full month before anyone goes to the polls and that the course of wisdom for them is to scramble aboard his bandwagon now.

President Nxon's proposal to replace most housing programs for the poor with an experimental program of cash subsidies met strong opposition today from Senate Democrats in its first Congressional hearing.

John W. Core, lawyer and speial agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who retired from Government service in 1962, died Saturday of a heart attack on his farm near Sadie ville, Scott County. His age was 61.

The Arab commando raid that impelled the Austrian Government to announce a suspension of special transit arrangements for groups of Soviet Jews going to Israel has won the official approval of the Egyptian Government.
The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, its liquor permits imperiled by its racially exclusive membership laws, has voted to accept persons of all races.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria conferred for nearly two hours today, but were unable to reach any agreement on facilities for the continued transit of Soviet Jews through Austria.
Nearly three years after their $20-million extravaganza for the world heavyweight title, Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali will meet in a 12-round rematch at Madison Square Garden on Monday, Feb. 4.
About 200 blue-shirted gasoline station dealers in Monroe County staged a demonstration outside the. Federal Building yesterday to protest against Federal price-control guidelines.
Prices of newsprint, homeheating oil, milk, sheets and pillowcases and copper were raised yesterday in a series of actions announced here and in Canada.

Vice President Agnew has repeatedly charged that his constitutional rights have been violated by leaks of allegations made against him in the course of the Federal investigation into possible bribery, extortion and tax fraud. To the extent that such rumors and allegations have been allowed to breach the secrecy of the judicial process, there can be little doubt-as we have noted before-that Mr. Agnew's complaints are justified.
China--in a speech Sharply critical of the United States, the Soviet Union and, for the first time, the United Nations-today characterized the world situation as one of "great disorder."
The National Anti-Vivisection Society announced yesterday that it would amend an earlier complaint to include the Army in a suit to save 600 beagles from military tests.
The Baltimore Colts announced today they had obtrained Hubert Ginn, a running back, from the Miami Dolphins in exchange for Don Nottingham, a running back, and a sixth-round draft choice.
South Africa does not mind being called a nation of gold bugs as long as it can call its opponents "chrysophobes" - haters of gold.

How slow is the mail? Slower, maybe, than a horse-drawn stagecoach? The answer is no, in at least one case. A letter was dispatched by the regular Postal Service on Wall Street in New York yesterday at the same time that a letter was sent by a stagecoach that left New York with a packet of mail at the same time.
Governor Cahill said today he intended to push for reform of New Jersey's Workmen's Compensation Law when the Legislature returned on Nov. 12.

The projected oil pipeline through Egypt from the Gulf of Suez to the Mediterranean will bypass the blocked Suez Canal geographically, but will not take its place. It will transport only a portion of the tonnage that used to pass through the canal and now goes around the Cape of Good Hope.
The Senate approved a $1.2-billion foreign assistance bill today by a vote of 54 to 42 after resisting two attempts to trim the authorization sharply.

The federally financed project-the Newark Comprehensive Health Services Plan-was approved in September, 1972, by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

In the first six months after the signing of the Paris peace agreement, the United States provided the South Vietnamese Air Force with 142,000 bombs, rockets and flares and 13.8 million rounds of small-arms ammunition, according to American military officials.

Rumors-mainly false, as it turned out-dominated trading in copper futures yesterday, causing prices to push ahead. The first rumor was that a Phelps Dodge subsidiary had received permission to make an important increase in prices of its copper products.
Negotiations aimed at ending the 12-day strike by lay teachers against eight Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens hit a new snag yesterday, this time over the issue of job security.

In two solo sessions with Dick Cavett, presented last night and tonight on the American Boardcasting Company network, Katharine Hepburn discusses herself and her career with enough wit, intelligence, humor and typical Hepburn vitality to leave the average talk-show personality speechless.

Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic candidate for chief judge, was endorsed yesterday by James Roosevelt, the former Congressman from California, who hailed him as "one of the most respected trial lawyers in the country."
John Newcombe, the United States Open champion, won his first-round match in the $50,000 Colonial tennis tournament today by defeating Charlie Owens of Tuscaloosa. Ala.. 6-2. 6-2.

Why Herbert Wehner-of all people-felt moved during a visit to the Soviet Union-of all places-to blast his own West German Government's stand on Berlin is a king-sized enigma. Royce Ryton's "Crown Matrimonial" is a strongly conceived historical drama of variable impact. This London import, which opened last night at the Helen Hayes Theater, is the first major offering of the somewhat sluggardly Broadway season.

The reason, cf course, is that a surrender invites others to attempt similar blackmail.

The Conservative party, badly split over the candidacy of Representative Mario Biaggi, its nominee for Mayor, has invited him to its annual dinner but has not asked him to speak.

A 25 - year-old real - estate agent was fatally stabbed near the Bowery yesterday morning minutes after delivering a set of apartment keys to the superintendent of a building owned by the company he worked for.

Diplomats here say that the drafting of a declaration of military security principles for the "year of Europe" will probably take weeks longer than the Americans had thought it would take.

In order to scout the lateafternoon sun and shadow in Riverfront Stadium, the New York Mets will work out there today at 5 P.M., an hour after tomorrow's opener of their National League playoff with the Cincinnati Reds is scheduled to begin.

On her own after about a decade of hits with the Vandellas, and about to have her first solo album released by her new record company, MCA, is Martha Reeves.

The Republic of Texas Corporation, a bank-holding company recently organized by the Republic National Bank of Dallas, has reached agreement in principle to acquire the Houston National Company, which owns the Houston National Bank.

Federal and city law enforcement officials yesterday announced the indictments of 43 persons in a move that United States Attorney Paul J. Curran said would have a "substantial impact" on heroin distribution in the city.

A group of conservative economists took a long look ahead at the Federal budget today and concluded that a growing economy would produce enough tax receipts to start new programs or permit tax reductions, or both, beginning two or three years hence.

Morris McDonald, like most of the harness racing drivers at Roosevelt Raceway, bitterly resents what he considers the filching of his good name by the Federal investigation into alleged fixing of races.

President Nixon and four aides arrived here this afternoon for a long weekend. Landing at nearby Homestead Air Force Base with Mr. Nixon were his staff chief, Alexander M. Haig Jr., his press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, a speech writer, Patrick Buchanan, and his special counsel, J. Fred Buzhardt.

MS. MESSAGE The second annual Women's Video Festival is in full swing, and even those women chained to household chores with no other company than soap operas or Watergate hearings on the small screen will find this television different.

Orville H. Schell Jr., president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday attacked the Gover nor's method of appointing new Court of Claims judges and said there was a strong likelihood" that the association would join in a law sui challenging the constitutional ity of the appointments.

The producer of the police comedy film "Fuzz" said today he was disturbed by allegations that the film might have contributed to the gasoline burning of Mrs. Evelyn M. Wagler by six youths in Boston Tuesday and said, "I just hope it wasn't so."

Repretentative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican, and Brendan T. Byrne, the Democrat, exchanged ridicule and abuse tonight in a free-swinging campaign debate that was their most bitter confrontation far in their fight for the ernorship of Ncw Jersey.

Burton S. Flagg, former president of the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies and the Mutual Fire Insurance Association of New England, died yesterday at a nursing home in North Andover. He was 99 years old.

In good company, redoubled contracts are very rare. Leaving aside the wild gamblers and those who stubbornly pass when their partners make S/O/S redoubles, one might expect to be involved in a redoubled contract two or three times a year at the most.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved unanimously the construction of a $2.5million aerial tramway across the East River between Roosevelt Island and Manhattan.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.4 billion ton-miles, up 9.3 per cent from the yearearlier level.
The Senate today passed by voice vote a bill to require Federal judges to disqualify themselves in any case in which they have a financial in terest.

Court of Claims Judge Howard A. Jones, former director of the state addiction control program, warned yesterday that provisions of the new narcotics laws mandating strict prison terms for past felony offenders allow no distinctions, even for Jim Crow conviction records in the South dating back many years.
Walter H. Johnson Jr., who had served Maride Midland banks for 42 years at his retirement in 1962, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Cranbury, N.J.
Morris Thompson, a 34year-old Athabascan Indian from Alaska, is reported to be the Administration's choice to become Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

Seven stolen paintings valued at $200,000 were recovered Wednesday night when six persons were arrested on the East Side, the police reported. And yesterday a seventh suspect was picked up in Brooklyn.

Dr. Bernard Bucove, former Health Services Administrator of New York who was appointed director of the School of Hygiene at the University of Toronto in 1970, died of cancer today in Women's College Hospital. He was 60 years old.

POINT ROBERTS, Wash.--This five-square-mile geographical absurdity has traditionally been viewed with some amusement as a harmless accident of history-a separated bit of the United States that should logically be part of Canada.

A Federal judge refused today to subpoena tapes of conversations between President Nixon' and John N. Mitchell that, attorneys contend, could prove that the Government meddled in a Texas stock fraud case to embarrass Democratic politicians and influence the 1972 elections.

A witness in a class action suit against the Douglas Aircraft Company testified yesterday in Federal Court here that the airplane manufacturer had production problems when it issued a prospectus in 1966 for an offering of $75-million of convertible subordinated debentures.

The withdrawal of British warships from disputed fishing grounds off Iceland is a constructive gesture. It ought to facilitate the solution of two unrelated issues which Iceland has managed to link for bargaining advantage-fishing rights and NATO bases. Reykjavik already has agreed to resume talks on British fishing rights within Iceland's newly proclaimed fifty-mile fisheries limit.

Representatives of major American Jewish organizations decided yesterday to intensify economic, political and public relations efforts to persuade Austria to reverse her decision to close the transit camp for Soviet Jews going to Israel.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three, as excellent and four as superb.

Seventy-five young members s of the militant Jewish Defense t League attempted to force open I the entrance gate of the t Former Austrian Mission to the I United Nations last night, inluring a police officer and breaking at least one window.

Three exconvicts seized a bank vice president and a woman teller as hostages during an attempted holdup south of here today and repeatedly threatened to kill them before surrendering to Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and 100 policemen who surrounded the bank.
The Bundesbank announced today measures to absorb 2.5-billion marks of the September currency inflows-put at between 4-billion and 5-billion marks.

Morris MacDonald, like most of the harness racing drivers at Roosevelt Raceway, bitterly resents what he considers the filching of his good name by the Federal investigation into alleged fixing of races.

WASHINGTON-In the fall of 1939, in my native city in Vietnam, the now sadly famous former imperial capital of Hue, a young poet, Luu Trong Lu, published his Tieng Thu (The Sounds of Autumn). Overnight he became our idol.

President Nixon urged Congress today to include better tariff treatment for the Soviet Union in a trade bill that would give the Administraton sweeping new negotiating powers in international trade talks.

Two young men--one apparently contrite, the other unapologetic-told the Senate Watergate committee today of their efforts to disrupt the election campaign of Democratic Presidential candidates last year.

" We've had a history of playing one bad game a year. I hope that [Lafayette] was it." So spoke Harry Gamble, the Penn football coach, as the Quakers prepared to open the Ivy League campaign against Brown in Franklin Field tomorrow.
The new student FM radio station of, Rutgers University, scheduled to go on the air Nov. 1, has already found an audience, but not in the usual manner.
Profit taking in the blue-chip and glamour stocks helped to push the stock market lower yesterday in slower trading.

The State Commission of Investigation, reviewing what it called "the appalling acts of police corruption that have been revealed here," today characterized, the citizens of the state's capital city as "victims of police corruption-tyranny."

A 45-year-old portfolio analyst testified to the New York State Human Rights Division yesterday that Merrill Lynch discriminated against her last year because she was pregnant and then cut her from the payroll last spring. Merrill Lynch denied the charges.

A former deputy purchase commissioner for the city was indicted yesterday for perjury by a special Bronx grand jury investigating a scheme to bribe an unnamed "public- official," according to Maurice H. Nadjari, special state prosecutor.

State Controller Arthur Levitt has accused the state courts of allowing many motorists arrested for drunken driving to plead guilty to lesser offenses and of then delaying for weeks or months the report on every conviction that is supposed to be filed with the Department of Motor Vehicles within 48 hours.

The Times Square electronic billboard of the Bulova Watch Company at 46th Street and Broadway, which tells the time to the tenth of a second, violates the Consumer Protection Law three times every four minutes, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Betty Furness charged yesterday.

The Labor party has been holding its annual conference here this week and its significance was summed up obliquely by a leading British journalist as he made his way last night to a meeting of the "Tribune" group, an association of Laborites who have fought for years to move the party to the left.

Israeli authorities today began considering the practical problems involved in maintaining the flow of Soviet Jews through Vienna if the Austrian Government adheres to its decision to close special transit facilities.
Fire raced through the Hilltop Stables here early this morning and killed 54 horses, including show horses, jumpers and hunters being boarded there.
W. H. Auden regarded as the foremost poet of his generation, was buried today in a village churchyard here, near the summer home he was fond of.
The Chrysler Corporation said today that preliminary figures Indicated that it had a "net loss of up to $26-million, or 50 cents .a share," in the third quarter.

Since they live on advertising, television network executives should stand up and be counted when advertising comes under attack, according to Samuel Thurm of Lever Brothers.

Third-quarter earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., are expected to be 50 per cent higher than the year-earlier level, while sales are expected to show a gain of 23 per cent, the company said yesterday.
Bus riders will be able to buy 75-cent ticket for unlimited rides in midtown Manhattan during nonrush hours beginning Monday.

Mario Andretti, driving an Offy-powered Viceroy Special, set a world closed-course speed record today of 214.158 miles an hour in a qualifying run. He had a previous lap of 213.460. The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community has approved a major purchase of enriched uranium from the Soviet Union by a West German consortium of electricity producers.
Circult Court Judge Thomas J. Foley today found striking Detroit teachers guilty of contempt for ignoring an order to return to their classrooms.

In what is described as its largest and most important recruitment drive since the end of World War II, the New Jersey Army National Guard will try to add 1,000 men and women to its ranks in the two-week period ending Oct. 26.

The thought of that dizzying, breath-stopping, last look downward before stepping off into space from the Golden Gate Bridge has long held a powerful fascination for San Franciscans.

Debbie Willson's Tergonrell won the stake and with it the amateur-owner hunter championship tonight at he Philadelphia horse show. The six-day event at the Spectrum ends Sunday.

United States Attorney James R. Thompson has been selected to represent the Government if hearings are held to investigate news leaks in the Justice Department's case against Vice President Aenew.

If Governor Rockefeller wants. a straightforward answer to his request for a report on why rents are going up so fast in this city and state, he should not have to wait long. Part of the explanation, of course, lies in the general price explosion that has marked the Nixon Administration's slack monitorship of anti-inflation controls.
Edward F. Lambert, assistant to the president of Union Carbide Puerto Rico, Inc., died Tuesday in San Juan, P. R., after an auto accident. He was 45 years old and had lived in Rio Piedras since 1970.

Members of the New York Newspaper Guild on the staff of The Daily News voted 696 to 5 yesterday to empower their union officials to call a strike if negotiations for a new contract were unsuccessful.
Jack Nicklaus, disappointed and embarrassed, scored a 75 today on the course that bears his name and of which he is part owner and co-designer.
Phelps Dodge Industries, Inc., yesterday confirmed rumors by announcing price increases for copper magnet wire, copper water tubing and related items and brass fittings and valves.
A second student demonstration against the government of President Park Chung Hee was staged here today despite official moves to clamp down on the students and universities.

Eastern Air Lines, shaken by heavy economic losses, put before its major lenders yesterday a revised financing plan tied mainly to proposed delays in deliveries of Lockheed widebody jets and to temporary waivers of some mortgage conditions.

Anna Hyatt Huntington, a sculptor noted for heroic statuary, died today at her home here. She was 97 years old. Mrs. Huntington's art is housed in more than 200 museums and galleries here and abroad, and she received high honors from the United States, France and Spain for her work.
Twenty-two striking teachers from Yorktown Heights, seven of them women and one a grandmother, spent most of the day in the Westchester County jail today for defying a court order to return to work.

Mention running, kick returns and pass catching to Phil Zofrea, Sarge's coach at William Paterson, and he smiles. "Sarge is dangerous every time he gets hold of the football," Zofrea said the other day. "Our opponents have realized that and after the first game have been kicking the ball away from Sarge."

The Foreign Minister of Austria, in an interview today, gave some details of the bargaining process last weekend between the Austrian Government and two Palestinian guerrillas who were holding four hostages at -the Vienna airport.

The political talks between the Saigon Government and the Vietcong were indefinitely suspended today after the Vietcong State Minister, Nguyen Van Hieu, walked out of the 28th session without waiting for the other side to speak.

Striking newspaper drivers and truck loaders approved a new contract tonight, ending the longest shutdown of both major newspapers in the city's history.

Henry Lichtig, a real estate lawyer who was counsel to the Bronx Chamber of Commerce in New York for 25 years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old and formerly lived at 737 Park Avenue in New York.

Foreign Minister Einar Agustsson of Iceland began talks here today with United States officials on the future of Keflavik air base. The Icelanders would like the 3,700 American servicemen manning it to be withdrawn by 1975.

Orville H. Schell Jr., president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, yesterday attacked the Governor's method of appointing new Court of Claims judges and said there was a "strong likelihood" that, the association would join in a law suit challenging the constitutionality of the appointments.
Andy Kendall of Portland, Ore., won a 10round split decision over Mike Quarry last night in a light-heavyweight bout.

The New York Mets announced yesterday that mail orders would be accepted for World Series tickets. If the Mets qualify as the National League representative, the games at Shea Stadium will be on the nights of Oct. 16, 17 and 18. Tickets will be sold only in three-game strips, a total of $45 for a box seat, $30 for a reserved seat, $24 for a reserved general-admission seat.

Bus riders will be able to buy a 75 cent ticket to be used for unlimited rides in midtown Manhattan during nonrush hours beginning Oct. 8, according to Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

The City Council and Board of Estimate last night approved a $54-million capital budget amendment to purchase and develop a Staten Island container port to bring the United States Lines back to the Port of New York.
