The Rev. Salvatore Anastasia, brother of Albert and Tony Anastasia, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 54 years old.

With the possible exception of the commissioner-not Bowie Kuhn, any commissioner-the most absurdly overrated figure in sports is the manager of a baseball team. The best can't win games and the worst lose precious few. If a man has enough executive ability to head the housewares department in Macy's and knows when to change pitchers, he can manage as well as his troops can play.
Consumer buying across the nation maintained its strong pace in September and provided a dozen of the country's largest retailers with sales gains of at least 7 per cent over the 1972 level.

The index of wholesale prices led by a large decline in food prices, went down in September, registering the largest decline for a single month since February, 1948. However, prices of industrial products shot up sharply again.
Phil Wrigley, the owner. of the Chicago Cubs, said he was "disgusted" with his team's performance this season, then rehired Whitey Lockman as manager for 1974 yesterday.
The new season, cont'd: "The Police Story." Tuesdays, 10 to 11 P.M., National Broadcasting Company. Of all the police capers on TV, this has the most potential.

The accounting profession, after two and a half years of self-examination, published today a 71-page document designed to tell what financial statements - balance sheets, earnings reports and the like are supposed to disclose.

The Nippon Steel Corporation and the Kawasaki Steel Corporation, both of Japan, have agreed in principle to build and deliver a steel plant, valued at more than $380-million to China by 1975, Kawasaki spokesmen said today.

The city's Corporation Counsel Conf has formally asked the Federal Government to restore nearly $1-million in Federal grants to a Brooklyn school district that refused to take part in what it charged was a discriminatory, dual-standard Government testing project.
The State Department of Health said today that the kitchen at the Bloomfield Home for Aged Men and Women was clear enough to remain in operation.

Connecticut will conduct bilingual elections this fall in districts where the Spanishspeaking voters account for at least 5 per cent of the population, Secretary of the State Gloria Schaffer said yesterday.
Three persons were injured last night when an IRT Lexington Avenue express train was derailed in the subway tunnel under Flatbush Avenue near the Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn.

Richard M. Gerstein, the Florida State's Attorney in Miami, said today that his office had been looking into the possibility that unidentified persons tapped telephones and bugged hotel rooms there during the Democratic National Convention in July, 1972, in Miami Beach.

The growth of consumer credit during August slowed somewhat from the frantic pace set earlier this year, an additional indication of a slowing of economic activity, Federal Reserve Board statistics showed today.

On the eve of Yom Kippur, which begins at sundown today, Jewish spiritual and secular leaders assailed the Austrian Government for deciding to close its transit facilities for Soviet Jews leaving for Israel.

The chips are down this week for Julius Rudel and his New York City Opera, and judging from the success with which they pulled off "Anna Bolena" on Wednesday night they might just end by raking in the pot.
Arthur Weiss, president of the Photographic Manufacturers and Distributors Association, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Lake Success, L.I., on Wednesday. He was 58 years old.

The State Energy Crisis Study Commission said yesterday that it opposed lowering air quality standards this winter to help ease the predicted energy shortages. Assemblyman Albert Merck, Republican of Morris County and a commission member, said, "We have chosen not to accept for the whole winter a lowering of air quality standards."
Some plays just refuse to lie down - and "A Streetcar Named Desire" is one of them. Last season it was wonderfully successful with the Lincoln Center Repertory Company, staged by Ellis Rabb.

The Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company returned to New York last night with one of its finest programs in years - a fitting way to inaugurate the Felt Forum's first ethnic-dance series that is going under the name of "International Festival of Entertainment."
Interest rates should march up to their peaks in the coming weeks and then tiptoe down a sloping plain for a year afterward, according to Willard C. Butcher, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
The Right Rev. John Maury Allin of Mississippi, new Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, was described yesterday by one of his admirers as "a great guy and a charming person."

Dr. Harry H. Epstein, a specialist in internal medicine and pulmonary diseases, died Wednesday in Long Island Jewish-Hillside. Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived at 167-01 Highland Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

Snapping a three-day wining streak, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yesterday in lighter but still moderately-active trading. Prices also closed lower in the over-the-counter market.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today that the Senate Watergate committee would recess its hearings at the end of next week when the Senate begins a two-week break.

State Senator John J. Marchi, Republican candidate for Mayor, promised yesterday to seek additional financial aid for parochial and other nonpublic schools if he is elected.

The Egyptian command announced last night that Egyptian troops had raided the Israeli-occupied Egyptian oilfields at Balayim, on the Gulf of Suez, and set large fires.
The Senate began debate today on a bill that seeks to balance the nation's energy needs with environmental concerns by setting minimum standards for the surface mining of coal.

The Soviet Union has some of the world's most extensive timber resources-and it has a chronic paper shortage. The problem is due to inefficiency all down the line, from timber industry to paper transport and storage, accord ing to the weekly Literary Gazette.
The body of Mrs. Constance Fisher, who had been committedd to a state hospital after allegedly' drowning six of her children, was found in the Kennebec River here.

Mrs. Barbara Borkland Achenbach and Philip A. Uzielli, both of New York, were married yesterday afternoon in Hamilton, Bermuda. The ceremony was performed by Mrs. Valerie Scott of the Registrar General's office.

Three Jewish teen-agers were jumped and beaten by a gang of some 30 youths last night as they emerged from a fried-chicken outlet in an Arab-American neighborhood in Brooklyn Heights, the police reported.

Three $1-million checks, among other large contributions, were handed over to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York yesterday as part of an outpouring of concern over th Arab-Israeli conflict.

Why did war erupt again in the Middle East? Different experts are offering widely different explanations for the conflict, which began during the holy Islamic month of Ramadan and as Jews were celebrating their holiest day, Yom Kippur.
Two major craft unions have toted down tentative contract agreements reached with negotiators for Washington's two daily newspapers.

Senior tennis players, a hardfighting, no-nonsense group, are getting a little upset over Cal MacCracken, who won the New Jersey title in the 45-years-and-over division for the seventh time the other, day. They are hoping that in the future he will pay more attention to his inventions than his court-tactics...
Gone are the days when Wall Street was grinding out new issues so fast the public could not keep track in the roaring bull market of the nineteen-sixties.

Israeli officers began today to refer to the Middle East war in the past tense, personally confident that the short-term outcome was now a foregone conclusion, but there was little of the euphoria and elation that accompanied the six-day war of 1967.

GENEVA, N.Y.-As the bright days and cool nights of fall in the Finger Lakes region ripen the grapes to perfection, Joe Bertino is stemming, crushing, pressing and fermenting them into 500 gallons of experimental wines, any one of which could someday improve the flavor of New York State wines-and possibly the future of the $150million industry.

The police charged a juvenile tonight with pointing a pistol at another person in the same area where the sports editor of The Atlanta Constitution, Jesse Outlar, was shot yesterday as he was leaving the parking lot of Atlanta Stadium.

Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, will propose soon, in a major statement on education policy, that state loans for college education be made available to middle-income families.

The Rev. George G. Beazley Jr., a Disciples of Christ minister and prominent figure in the ecumenical movement, died Sunday in Moscow, apparently of a heart attack. Dr. Beazley, who was 59 years old, had just begun a visit in the Soviet Union at the invitation of the Russian Orthodox Church.
The Knicks' regular-season opener tonight was heartbreak time for some players and a temporary respite for others.

" This is Nassau County," Ralph G. Caso said, pointing out his window. "This is why the people left the city." From his fourth-floor office, the Nassau County Executive could see mostly green tree tops,
Prime Minister Heath announced plans today to ease restraints on wages but tighten curbs on prices in new anti-inflation measures that will have an important bearing on his political future.

The Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov today issued an appeal on behalf of Yuri A. Shikhanovich, a former Moscow State University mathematician who is under arrest and allegedly "in complete isolation."
The State and Federal Labor Departments are trying to locate 150 former employes of Regina Footwear, Inc., of 810 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, who lost their jobs 19 months ago--that is. since 1971.
" Elect the Beame Team in Queens" said thousands of of scorecards in the hands of fans in Shea Stadium at yesterdy's playoff game between the New York Mets and the Cincinnati Reds.

Police arson specialists sifted through debris yesterday to determine the cause of a fire that destroyed a stable in the West Orange area for the second time within a week. A policeman and two off-duty officers led 21 horses to safety Sunday after the fire broke out at 6 P.M. at the stable housing the horses of the Essex Junior Troop, an equestrian group.
The first two days of fighting in the Golan heights consisted of seesaw tank battles with small isolated Israeli units often surrounded by great concentrations of Syrian armor.

Britain's first commercial radio station, London Broadcasting, began operations today. The all-news station is the forerunner of some 60 independent radio networks to be licensed by the Government and that will eventually cover the country's main towns and population areas.

Secretary of State Kissinger warned tonight that there were limits to how far the United States could press Soviet leaders for changes in their system without running the risk of reviving the cold war and increasing international tensions.

The Peoples' Symphony Concerts, which has been offering a high-quality, lowpriced series at Washington Irving High School for many years, has ventured uptown this year for an additional six-concert chamber festival at Town Hall.

Mesmin Arenwald, principal of the Olinville Junior High School, the Bronx, from 1937 to 1952, and of the Henry Hudson Junior High School, the Bronx, from 1952 until his retirement in 1956, died Sunday in a nursing home in Peekskill, N. Y. His age was 87.
Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative-Republican of New York, urged Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. today to plug what he termed the "notoriously leavy" Senate Watergate committee.

By deluding themselves once again into military adventurism as a cure for political frustration, the leaders of Egypt and Syria seem to have succeeded only in placing themselves and their peoples-as well as peoples in many lands - in great peril. PEDRICKTOWN--The Shell Oil Company, barred by Delaware from building across the Delaware River in Delaware, has purchased 1,800 acres and plans to refine 150,000 barrels of oil daily in pastoral Logan Township.

Leaders of American cities today used a symposium marking the opening of President Johnson's papers on urban affairs to con trast the attitudes of Mr. John son and his successor on the crisis of the cities.

Fists, cups, beer cans, assorted debris and even whisky bottles filled the clamorous afternoon air at Shea Stadium yesterday as the Mets and their public fought the Cincinnati Reds in one of baseball's memorably riotous games.
The General Electric Company had its best third quarter ever this year, Reginald H. Jones, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.
More than 1,600 teachers struck two Michigan school systems today, joining thousands 'of Detroit instructors who are staging the nation's largest school walkout.
Administration officials said today that the Soviet Union had indicated that it shared the American desire to limit the conflict in the Middle East.
The head of the Cost of Living Council indicated today that some adjustments might have to be made in Federal wage guidelines next year if living costs continued their rapid advance.
The Museum of Modern Art will be open today despite a strike called last night by its union of professional and administrative workers following a breakdown in state-mediated contract talks.

Carbery O'Shea, a lawyer and tax specialist, died Monday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 69 years old and also lived in Saltaire, Fire Island, L.I. Mr. O'Shea was a senior partner in the law firm of Donovan, Leisure,
The Dow Chemical Company is headed for record sales and earnings in the third quarter and first nine months this year, estimates released yesterday indicated.
Interco, Inc., announced yesterday it liad entered into a memorandum of intent to acquire Devon Apparel, Inc., in an exchange of capital stock.
The things motorists once took for granted at their service stations now cost money in some areas.
The United States asked the Security Council tonight to bring an end to hostilities in the Middle East and to restore the cease-fire line that existed before the new war.
When Dr. Thomas Wakley founded The Lancet, a medical journal, here in 1823, his purpose was to advance medical knowledge and reform British medicine.
The' Neiman-Marcus Company, the Dallas-based fashion specialty store chain, is expected to announce its first inthe-city store in Chicago on tomorrow.

Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, will propose soon, in a major statement on education policy, that state loans for college education be made available to middle-income families.
The police reported today the apparent death of a second young person in Nassau County as a result of having sniffed an aerosol antisticking cooking substance to obtain a euphoric feeling.

Securities and Exchange Commission policies are aimed at helping the investor, not harming the financial analysts, an S.E.C. official told the Financial Analysts Federation's fall conference here today.

The White House has approved a plan for slashing Government peanut subsidies, a program which, has cost taxpayers $650-million since 1955. Administration sources, asking not to be identified, said Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz would announce the White House-endorsed proposal within a few weeks.
Spyros Markezinis, a long-time politic cian and historian, was sworn in today as Premier of Greece's first all-civilian Cabinet since the 1967 army coup.
Retail food prices in 14 world capitals, while remaining high, were generally down last month from midsummer peaks, a Government study shows.

The five-week-old strike of teachers in Harrison ended today. Classes will return to normal tomorrow. More than 200 teachers, meeting in the Harrison firehouse, ratified an agreement that had been initialed by teacher and school board negotiators after an all-night session.

Eighteen people in three families were left homeless last night when a smoky, two-alarm fire destroyed the first three floors of a partly occupied five-story tenement in Harlem.
The Environmental Protection Agency plans to reverse its policy and give no preference in Federal aid to states that have contributed to local water pollution-control projects.
Foreign Minlaster Michel Jobert, commenting on the Middle East war, said today: "Is it necessarily unforeseen aggression to try to go home?"

Why things don't work-I: The three-way light bulb. Actually, I don't know if it is accurate to call it a three-way light bulb, but that is what we call it at our house, usually modified by adjectives of a pejorative nature.

Three Lower East Side settlement houses declared yesterday that the state had refused to reimburse them for $640,330, or nearly half of the $1,373,504 they had spent under matching contracts for mental-health services in their area for the year ended last June 30.
Romance got tangled up with family ties today when Alma North led from start to finish to win the seventh Matchmaker Stakes for fillies and mares at the Atlantic City Race Course.

WASHINGTON - The Democratic party's 1968 convention in Chicago was boss-ridden and unrepresentative. But the 1972 convention in Miami Beach was quota-ridden and therefore just as unrepresentative. So went the two extreme views in a controversy for which a party drafting committee has proposed a compromise.

The newsprint shortage has forced the nation's newspapers to experiment with the kind and amount of news they, offer Some editors cite unexpected benefits in the cutbacks they have had to make.

After letting it languish in the shadows for two and a half years, the City Council's Committee on Standards and Ethics will finally get around today to considering a code of ethics for local lawmakers. Characteristically, this "open government" measure sponsored by Manhattan Councilman Carter Burden is scheduled for discussion in closed session. It merits overdue approval.

The Senate hastily approved a resolution today calling for a ceasefire in the Middle East and a return of Arab and Israeli forces to the positions they occupied before the outbreak of hostilities on Saturday.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka, the first Japanese head of government to visit the Soviet Union since 1956, today joined Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party chief, in calling for a peace treaty between their nations to end World War II formally.
The last building in the state's 429-acre office building campus on the west end of Albany was dedicated recently, marking completion of a $100-million project where 11,000 state employes work.
A bill to make the Youth Conservation Corps a permanent agency and expand its programs was passed by the Senate today by voice vote.
New York's Criminal Courts cannot function unless defendants are allowed to plea bargain, said a presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

Recent reports from three African countries indicate that their governments are not only aware of the great value of their nations' wildlife but serious about preserving it. Aroused by a heavy increase in poaching, Tanzania's Ministry of Natural Resources has prohibited all hunting until further notice, including the capturing of live animals.

Against the backdrop of a new war in the Middle East, major oil exporting nations and the companies that produce the oil today began negotiating the countries' demands for an increase in prices.

The collapse of a concrete tunnel-ceiling in which one subway passenger was killed and 1,000 other Flushing-line riders were forced to wait 80 minutes for rescue in 115-degree heat last Aug. 28 immediately revived questions about the safety and efficiency of New York City's subways.
Gesualdo A. Costanza, who has just returned from Nairobi, Kenya, and the Middle East, has a new job awaiting him at the First National City Bank.

Richard V. Mulligan, who retired in 1971'as a director and corporate vice president of Johnson Johnson, surgical manufacturers here, and as Democratic County Chairman, died today at his home, 22 Dewey Drive.

Plans for a major plant expansion in Romulus, a suburb of Detroit, were announced yes. terday by the General Motors Corporation. It is expected to lead to a significant increase in Diesel engine production.
Two policemen werewounded in a shotgun attack here early today as violence continued to plague this sunny resort island in the Caribbeat.

The underwriters for a $280million bond issue designed to finance a race track and a new stadium for the New York Football Giants in the Hackensack Meadows yesterday put off the purchase of the securities. The postponement was the second in six months.
Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders reported today "considerable progress" in a new round of talks designed to speed the formation of a cabinet, to govern Northern Ireland.

Earnings of Procter Gamble in the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 may be down as much as 7 per cent from the year earlier period although sales may be up as much as 19 per cent, Howard Morgens, chairman, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Cincinnati.

PEKING -- The first Sino-Russian negotiation occurred in the seventeenth century at Nerchinsk. The Russians were represented by a Pole and the Chinese by two Jesuits. The envoys spoke Latin. Today, three centuries later, the two enormous neighbors have yet to discover a common language or policy.

Former Secretary of Defepse Clark M. Clifford today attacked the Nixon Administration's defense policies in general, and the current defense budget in particular, as "all but oblivious to the great changes taking place in the world around us."

Residents of Crocheron Avenue-a tree-lined quiet block of seasoned one-family homes and apartment houses in Flushing, Queens--found policemen patrolling their street yesterday morning.
A bill to repeal the city's tar-and-nicotine tax -- which adds 1 to 4 cents to the price of a package of cigarettes--was introduced yesterday by Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr.

Stuart Perkins president of Volkswagen of America, said today that the company would introduce in January the first of what he calls "a new generation of Volkswagens," a car with a front-wheel drive and water-cooled engine, to be called the Dasher.
An elderly man was stabbed to death on a subway car yesterday afternoon on an A train on the IND subway line in downtown Manhattan after he had engaged in a long argument with another passenger.

City Council President Louis M. Turco pleaded guilty today to Federal income-tax charges that could send him to prison for four years. He then announced that he intended to continue in his Council post.

Two New York policemen were found guilty last night by a Manhattan jury of burglary, attempted grand larceny and attempted criminal possession of dangerous drugs in connection with what the prosecution described as a "ripping off of narcotics peddlers."

Vice President Agnew told 850 building-industry officials here yesterday that the country's low- and middle-income housing programs had been "a costly failure" because only one of every 15 persons eligible for housing assistance had actually been helped.

Mrs. Rosetta Tharpe Morri- c son, who as Sister Rosetta Tharpe was one of the first gospel singers to gain wide recognition outside the Negro churches of the Deep South, died yesterday in Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia, where she made her home. She was 57 years old.
At the New School last night Choreographers Theater presented the first of its seventh season of "ChoreoConcerts" with premieres by Manuel Alum, Beverly Brown, Phyllis Lamhut and Gus Solomons Jr.

A drive to recruit American volunteers to replace Israeli civilians called to battle stepped up here yesterday as New York area residents continued to demonstrate' support for Israel with rallies and outpourings of money. Randy Johnson, apparently tired of being the New York Giants' No. 2 quarterback behind Norm Snead, announced his retirement from pro football yesterday. But he left the door open for a possible return.

Booker T. Gaither, coordinator for the Model Cities program at the City Housing and Development Administration, died of cancer Sunday in Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived at 289 Convent Avenue.

Bernard H. Lawson, a lawyer who became president of Lawson Associates, fund-raising counsel to many philanthropic and religious institutions, died Monday in Phoenixville, Pa. A former resident of Old Westbury, L.I., he had lived in Chester Springs, Pa., since 1966.

The RCA Corporation announced yesterday a "go-slow" policy in the introduction of its SelectaVision magnetic tape video recorder system. William C. Hittinger, executive vice president of consumer and solid state electronics operations, said field tests would begin "in the first quarter of 1974."

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced yesterday that it had raised the price of gasoline at company-owned stations by one cent a gallon, and the wholesale price to dealers by 1.2 cents a gallon.

Can you force the travel agent, the wholesaler who puts together a travel package deal, the carrier or the hotel to make amends?
The race for County Executive in Westchester took an unexpected turn today when Assemblyman J. Edward Meyer, a Republican, endorsed the Democratic candidate, Mayor Alfred B. DelBello of Yonkers.
A silvery full moon rose over the Western Wall this evening at the start of the festival, of Succoth, one of the most joyous in the Jewish year.

W. Roy Pollard, half-brother of Spiro T. Agnew, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 65. Mr. Pollard retired last year as manager of agency administration for the Monumenal Life Insurance Company.

Max Feldman, vice president and founder of the F A Distributing Company, wholesalers of liquor, died at his home here yesterday. His age was 83.
A Family Court judge said last night that he would consider reversing his decision to banish from New York State three youths found guilty of setting a tenement fire on May 8 that killed six persons.

In an effort to solve their critical quarterback shortage, the New York Jets yesterday picked up Tim Van Galder, a free agent and a former St. Louis Cardinals signal-caller. Although the Jets do not have to officially sign Van Galder until after today's workout, he's likely to stay with them.

The Massachusetts Senate gave initial approval yesterday to its version of legislation making the death penalty mandatory in first-degree murder sentences. The vote 20 to 11, came after four hours of debate.
Two television cameramen and a police detective, were severely beaten yesterday morning outside a Brooklyn church at the funeral of Leonard Vario, son of the reputed Mafia leader Paul Vario.

The sudden resignation of Vice President Agnew touched off a sharp burst of selling yesterday in Wall street. Down by 51/2 points at 2:30 P.M., the Dow-Jones industrial average began to weaken noticeably after reports of the Agnew resignation were carried over news tickers about two minutes later.

George McGinnis scored 8 straight points in the closing four minutes tonight to enable the Indiana Pacers to spoil the debuts of Julius Erving as a player and Kevin Loughery as a coach of the New York Nets as the American Basketball Association opened its seventh season.
One can only conclude that Reka Feketekuty's enthusiasm for creating dances is mistaken after seeing her joint concert with Thomas Holt on Tuesday evening at the Cubiculo.

The United Automobile Workers cleared up its last major dispute with the Chrysler Corporation today, then turned its full negotiating attention to the Ford Motor Company. "They are finally down to Ford," a U.A.W. spokesman said.
Citing the uncertainty of oil supplies from the Middle East, President Nixon said today that the nation must become entirely self-sufficient in energy.

Premier In Tam announced today that he had submitted his resignation to President Lon Nol. He gave no reason for his decision. He made the resignation announcement at the end of a five-minute television speech in which he reassured the people of Phnom Penh that there was no rice crisis.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday lower net income for the third quarter and nine months despite higher sales in both periods.

The Senate Watergate committee is investigating the possibility that $100,000 given by Howard R. Hughes was used to help-pay for President Nixon's San Clemente home, a committee source said today.
Senator John J. Marchi urged yesterday that the state's socalled Sullivan-Law be amended to provide mandatory prison for anyone in possession of a firearm in the commission of crime.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested John G. Coughlin, 30 years old, and Peter A. Pepe, 33, of New Haven yesterday on charges of having held up the Empire National Bank in Hyde Park, N.Y., last October.
A year-old report issued the United States Civil Rights Commission says that national, state and local leaders were responsible for continuing racial tension in Cairo, Ill.

A man who was arraigned yesterday was accused of being the "pussycat burglar" who had terrorized residents in the Riverdale section of the Bronx for the last two years.

The United states has agreed to suspend temporarily the withdrawal of American forces from Thailand, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said at a news conference today. The uncertainty of the military and political situation in Indochina is the main reason for the suspension, he said.
Mrs. Julia Mitchell Kunkle, a former missionary in China with her late husband, the Rev. Dr. John Stewart Kunkle, died Monday in Claremont, Calif. She was 95 years old.

Pierre Elliott Trudeau today became the first Canadian Prime Minister to visit China. He began talks with Premier Chou En-lai. Officials said that 3,500 children welcomed Mr. and Mrs. Trudeau at the Peking airport.
Members of the Boston Teachers Union ratified today a new oneyear contract with the Boston School Committee. The proposal will now go before the school committee tomorrow for a formal vote.

Noting increased Wage costs, the State Public Service Commission yesterday authorized an electric and gas rate rise for the Long Island Lighting Company, its second in five months. The company expects to receive $3,758,000 more a year from the higher electric rates and $1,467,000 from the higher gas rates. This would be on top of an $11,766,000 electric rate increase and $3,408,000 gas rate increase allowed in May.

The State Health Department is looking for the cause of a recent outbreak of salmonella responsible for the hospitalization of 16 persons from five Morris County municipalities, the department said yesterday. Spiro T. Agnew resigned as Vice President of the United States today under an agreement with the Department of Justice to admit evasion of Federal income taxes and avoid imprisonment. Dear Mr. President: As you are aware, the accusations against me cannot be resolved without a long, divisive and debilitating struggle in the Congress and in the courts. I have concluded that, painful as it is to me and to my family, it is in the best interests of the nation that I relinquish the Vice Presidency.

The drama of Spiro Agnew has reached its appointed end. For him, the sad denouement in a Baltimore courtroom concluded his sudden, steep descent from occupant of the second highest constitutional office to convicted criminal-a descent that began two months ago with the official warning from a Federal prosecutor that he was under investigation on grave charges.

The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported yesterdays a decline in operating earnings in the third quarter as the spread between the rates it paid for funds and the rates it earned on loans and securities narrowed.

A bill that would create a special police force for the city's parks met with stiff opposition yesterday from the Parks Administrator and the Police Commissioner, both of whom asserted that the Police Department was best equipped and trained to fight crime in the parks.
House and Senate negotiators today dropped a Senateapproved proposal to bring home 110,000 American troops from overseas as they reached agreement on a $21.3-billion defense authorization bill.
A large Israeli armored force pushed out of the Golan heights in the direction of Damascus today, smashing through Syrian defenses and leaving dozens of burning Syrian tanks in its wake.

James J. McFadden, a state mediator, said yesterday that formal talks between striking musicians and the New York Philharmonic Society had broken off.

The Egyptian command reported today that the Israelis had lost 25 tanks and armored vehicles in the southern sector of the Sinai front. The tank battle lasted from noon yesterday throughout the night and until midday today, the command said.

The League or women Voters has opened a nationwide campaign to raise money for the Equal Rights Amendment, which must win approval of eight more states by 1979 if it is to become part of the Constitution.

Rutgers and Lafayette have played each other in football 68 times since 1882, with Rutgers holding a 38-29-1 won-lost-tied record.. Since 1945, Rutgers has won 26 of 29 games and when the two meet again Saturday, Rutgers will count on the running attack. With a runner like Jim Jennings, no one blames the Scarlet.

Imports of primary lead from Canada, valued about $18-million a year, are being sold at les than fair value in the United States, the United States Treasury Department ruled today.

Garrick Ohlsson earned his international reputation as a contestant, winning the 1970 Chopin competition in Warsaw. Since-that time the tall pianist has made a career of astounding audiences with his powerhouse technique and bravura style.

As New York City's chief fiscal officer, the Controller serves as a valuable check on actions and policies of the Mayor, reviewing proposed municipal budgets, examining spending priorities, suggesting modifications and economies. The Controller has an on-going responsibility to investigate agencies and programs and to spur efficiency. He manages the city's vast sinking and trust funds.

Broadway's Palace Theater is obviously finding music profitable - the box office opens Monday for the three-week Bette Midler season (which look's set for sellout status), and this is preceded by four evenings with the singer Vicki Carr, starting Oct. 25.

Representative Shirley Chisholm and Basil A. Paterson, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, yesterday joined the growing ranks of prominent black Democrats supporting Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor.
The Coast Guard resumed its search today for two persons and their 19-foot sailboat, which capsized last night, the Coast Guard said. The identities of the persons were not released.
Donald P. Ross, chairman of Delaware Park race track, died here today at the age of 71. Mr. Ross was co-founder of the thoroughbred track in 1937 and served as its president from 1946 to 1957.

To the Editor: Despite the refusal of United States military spokesmen in Saigon to reveal the quantity of American-supplied munitions the Thieu army is consuming [news story Oct. 3], there is no mystery whatsoever regarding its flagrant violations of the cease-fire agreement or the American Government's total responsibility for paying for the protraction of the Vietnam war.

Credit conditions continued to ease as the demand for bank loans decreased, Federal Reserve Bank of New York figures for the week ended Wednesday indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON-In the course of the consideration by the United States Senate in 1937 of President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the number of justices he could appoint to the United States Supreme Court (the Court-packing plan), an incident arose which may shed some light on the present efforts of Congress and the special prosecutor to obtain the tapes of private conversations held by the President in the White House.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka, returning from a vist to three Western European capitals and the Soviet Union, expressed confidence today that joint Soviet-Japanese projects for developing Siberian natural resources would progress.

An accumulation of overnight buy orders resulted in a strong opening for prices of soybeans on the Chicago Board of Trade. The November contract that had closed at $6.36 1/2 soon jumped the 20-cent-abushel limit to $6.56 1/2 before profit taking cut the gains. At the close the delivery was $6.50.

The accommodation reached between the Justice Deapartment and lawyers for former Vice President Agnew is a unique political act. The settlement can well be defended because Mr. Agnew's position as the nation's standby President made it urgently desirable to get him out of office as soon as possible once all doubt of his unfitness had vanished. He was able to use that leverage to escape the lengthy prison term that his crimes merited.

Citing the hostilities in the Middle East and the energy crisis as compelling reasons, representatives of industry, labor, utilities and state governments called today for an immediate exploration of the Atlantic Continental Shelf for oil and natural gas deposits.
Heating and hot water to 600,000 tenants in city-owned housing would be sharply curtailed under contingency plans adopted by the Housing Authority for periods of severe fuel shortages.

A nation without a Vice President responded yesterday to Spiro T. Agnew's resignation with expressions ranging from glee to regret, and with calls for reforms and a restoration of confidence in government and the political processes.

Generally fair skies and near seasonable temperatures will continue today throughout most of the Northeast. Fair to partly cloudy skies and mild conditions will prevail along the rest of the Eastern Seaboard.

In comparison with the 25 largest cities in the United States, New York City ranks 12th in homicide, 2d in robbery, 17th in rape and 23d in larceny, according to the most recent reported crime statistics compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, attacked today his Republican opponent's opposition to a state income tax.

The city manager here has said that a former Black Panther, Lonnie McLucas, is not a "desirable" volunter youth counselor in the city's Youth Servce Bureau.

Former Representative J. Irving Whalley of Pennsylvania was fined $11,000 and sentenced to-three years' probation today for his guilty plea to charges that he obtained thousands of dollars in kickbacks from his employes.

Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court declared in an opinion today that he had once been told by Lyndon B. Johnson that the late President's telephone had been tapped, and Mr. Douglas voiced his own belief that "the conference room of this Court has been 'bugged."'
Volkswagen of America, Inc., announced yesterday that it had increased prices on its 1974 model Porsche sports cars by an average of 17 per cent. The increases range from $630 to $1,600 a car.

A group of business executives opened today a drive to stop the Federal Trade Commission er from requiring big companies to file with it detailed information, by product line, on corporate operations.

The Saudi Arabian Oil Minister was reported today to have told Western oil executives that if the United States overtly undertook to resupply Israel's fighting forces, Saudi Arabia would cut crude-oil production by 10 per cent at once and by 5 per cent a month thereafter.

Tens of thousands of students and other civilians overwhelmed the last police forces in Bangkok today, leaving the Thai capital under almost complete control of the insurgents.

A culture loop bus serving Brooklyn and lower Manhattan will be instituted by the Transit, Authority on, Saturday morning, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced. yesterday.

In a sharp change of policy, the Board of Education announced yesterday that it planned to concentrate more on rehabilitating old schools than on building new ones, and that it was undertaking a review of construction projects carried over from previous budgets to see if they were still needed.
Immigration of doctors to the United States must be stopped, a Harvard professor, Dr. Richard Warren, says.

One of New York's venerable organizations observes its 150th anniversary today. When the New York Asylum for Lying-In Women was founded in 1823, the city's population was not quite 150,000, and it was acutely perilous to be both poor and pRegnant.

Despite the outcry in influential circles in the United States that the new Soviet- American relationship is rapidly becoming the major casualty of the Middle East war, Moscow is taking a calm, stoical view.
The Knicks defeated Buffalo last night, 117-91, at Madison Square Garden and gave Ernie DiGregorio, the Braves' high-priced rookie, a lesson in defense he never learned at Providence College.
Joseph Ettinger, who pulled out of the Democratic gubernatorial race in 1970,

Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee, asked today to see all the files and records related to the denial of a national bank charter to a group that wanted to establish a second bank on Key Biscayne, Fla.

The Allstate Insurance company announced today that it would give a 30 per cent discount. on medical and no-fault personal injury coverages for any private 1974 model passenger car with a federally approved air bag safety system.

Nine steel concerns, including the United States Steel Corporation, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's three major producers, have pleaded not guilty to Federal conspiracy charges.

President Anwar el-Sadat called today for a cease-fire in the Middle East war coupled with an immediate Israeli withdrawal from territories seized in 1967. He proposed that the truce be followed by an international peace conference at the United Nations.

Baseball's 70th World Series moved into New York last night as the Mets and the Oakland A's took over the stage of Shea Stadium before 55,000 persons, a national television audience and a record peacekeeping force of more than 1,000 guards.

The Nobel Prize Committee today called the two diplomatic opponents who shared the prize "negotiators with talents and will that could remove distrust and create the necessary mutual respect for obtaining an agreement."
Officials said today that autopsies indicated that parasites in the inner ear caused about 35 pilot whales to beach themselves near Harkers Island last week.

Sol M. Linowitz, the National Urban Coalition was the best thing to come out of the rubble of the riots of 1968. Mr. Linowitz believes that the coalition, made up of civil rights, labor and religious groups and conceived to combat the problems that led to the burning of cities, has achieved a status similar to that of other major, urban organizations.

ADES-Edna (nee Slote), of Union City, N.J., beloved wife of the late Max, devoted mother of RutheMarcus and mother-In-law of Herman Marcus, loving sister of Clara Edelstein and Dr. Milton Slote; also survived by 2 grandchildren, Judith Glass and Susan Rashba and one great-grandchild Wendy Glass. Services will be held at Gutterman's Musicant, Kennedy Blvd. corner Union Street, Jersey City, N.J., on Wednesday, October 17th at 12 Noon.
Final agreement on a compromise bill to clear. the way for construction of the transAlaska oil pipeline was delayed today when House and Senate negotiators decided to reconsider a key provision.
Otto E. Sturm, a news features editor for the United Press International, died Monday at Flushing Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 67 and he lived at 149-35 29th Avenue, Flushing, Queens.
The left-of-center Republican People's party won its first national election in 23 years today, but failed to win a parliamentary majority.

State Agriculture Secretary Philip Alampi called yesterday for a two-year delay in the implementation of state regulations restricting the use of pesticides. Mr. Alampi said his department "supports the regulation of the use of pesticides that have a potential danger to the people of this state or to the environment that these people enjoy."

In a sharp change of policy, the Board of Education announced yesterday that it planned to concentrate more on rehabilitating old schools than on building new ones, and that it was undertaking a review of construction projects carried over from previous budgets to see if they were still needed.
In a day-long display of civic pride the city dedicated its police headquarters yesterday and paid tribute to its police officers.

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt called for a cease-fire coupled with Israeli withdrawal from Egyptian territory seized in 1967. Mr. Sadat also proposed that the truce be followed by a peace conference at the United Nations. He warned that Egypt had developed a missile capable of striking at any part of Israel. WASHINGTON-My point is simple: We have stood by and watched while the Soviet Union supplied the means by which this bloody war in the Mideast was initiated and is now being fought.

A black man was elected today as Mayor of Atlanta, the commercial and cultural center of the Old Confederacy that only a decade ago was quarreling over the admission of a handful of black children into the public schools.
Premier Golda Meir told a special session of Israel's Parliament today that the war would end "when we have succeeded in beating the enemy."

Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel was named senior rabbi and spiritual leader of Temple Emanu-EI yesterday. At the age of 37 he is the youngest rabbi in the history of the 128-year-old temple, the world's largest Jewish Reform congregation.

The Federal Railroad Administration told the Penn Central Railroad today that it would not have to meet Federal track safety standards for freight operations immediately but refused a request to exempt passenger operations also.

Fred A. Young, former presiding judge of the State Court of Claims and regarded by his colleagues as the complete politician, died last night of cancer at the Albany Medical Center. He was 69 years old.

At the invitation of the state Attorney General, some 40 local and upstate museums are expected to take part Friday in a conference that grew out of one controversy and will, a number of museum officials predict, stir up a "hectic" one on its own.

About every 26 months, when the planet Mars swings relatively close to the earth, it shines brightly in the eastern sky after sunset, an unmistakable, unflickering reddish beacon second in planetary brilliance only to Venus.
Emil H. Praeger, a civil enginever and innovator of design concepts, died today at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 81 years old and lived at 104 Grosvenor Street inDouglaston, Queens.

The Federal Government today declared this fire-ravaged city of 32,000 a disaster area. At least 300 persons, most of them poor and elderly, are homeless and 600 are jobless in the wake of a blaze that burned for almost seven hours Sunday night over about, 20 per cent of this industrial satellite of Boston.

The Cost of Living Council has granted a 13.8 per cent rate increase to the bankrupt French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center, an increase that John Battaglia, the center's executive vice president, said yesterday would enable the institution to meet its payroll and remain in business.
Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia, suffering from a stomach inflammation, withdrew yesterday from the $110,000 Virginia Slims championship tennis tournament in Boca Raton, Fla.

The independent sub-Sahara nations have condemned Israel for not giving up lands captured during the six-day war in 1967. This appears to be the only common position on the Middlle East conflict.
A month-old boy was kidnapped from the pediatric floor at Unity Hospital in Brooklyn early Yesterday morning within 30 minutes after two nurses had seen him asleep in his crib.

A Congressional subcommittee is investigating the disclosure that Deputy Attorney General William D. Ruckelshaus and his wife imported a young Finnish woman to help out in their household in apparent violation of immigration laws.

Representative John J. Rhodes, a conservative Republican from Arizona, emerged with what appeared to be a commanding lead today to succeed Gerald R. Ford, the Vice President-designate, as the House minority leader.

A temporary restraining ordered preventing the Ohio Industrial Commission from holding hearings to determine whether to close the Columbus Coated Fabrics Company plant for health reasons has been issued by United States district court.

The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said today that the Pacific Gas and Electric Company had agreed to hire and upgrade women and minorities in all of its managerial, physical and technical jobs.
Pledging to be "the toughest law enforcement guy you ever saw," Charles W: Sandman Jr. brought his Republican gubernatorial campaign today to this city's important business community.

A convicted heroin distributor, described as the kingpin of narcotics sales in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to- a prison term of 25 years to life.

Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia, suffering from a stomach inflammation, withdrew yesterday from the $100,000 Virginia Slims championship tennis tournament in Boca Raton, Fla. Mrs. Court, 31 years old, was admitted to Boca Raton Community Hospital with a condition diagnosed as viral gastroenteritis. She was reported uncomfortable, but in satisfactory condition.
Israeli military authorities today barred newsmen from the Sinai Peninsula, where a major battle of the war remains to be fought.
The Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero, Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn, has called, on the four mayoral candidates to pay attention to the needs of Brooklyn and Queens, not just Manhattan.
Wall Street, which has been awash in red ink for most of 1973, showed several new signs yesterday of a return to profitability.

President Nixon unexpectedly flew to his Camp David retreat in the Maryland mountains today for an overnight stay with his family. The Nixon party arrived at 5:39 P.M. Mr. Nixon is due back at the White House tomorrow morning.

With the new season on the commercial networks demanding, but not especially justifying review attention, there's a chance that good old dependable "Masterpiece Theater" on public television might get lost in the publicrelations shuffle. It shouldn't.

There would be greater pathos in the fate of Spiro Agnew if his had been a fall from grace rather than from arrogance. The state of Texas will fight the Environmental Protection Agency in court over the agency's proposed antipollution controls on cars and buses in Texas cities.

Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ruled against Charlie Finley in the Mike Andrews controversy yesterday, and also took the unusual- step of criticizing publicly a club owner's behavior while expressing concern for the player.

Capt. Archibald B. How, commanding officer of the big Coast Guard training center here, mustered all officers and enlisted men at the base today and instructed them not to discuss with outsiders Saturday night's killing at the enlisted men's club.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 16--John W. Hemphill Jr., an assistant news editor in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, died early today at The Johns Hopkins University Hospital. He was 32 years old.
Mrs. Zelda Wolfman, who was active in political and social causes, died yesterday of cancer at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia, She was 45 years old.
A compromise bill increasing the Federal contribution to school lunches was approved by the Senate today.
Stock prices rallied yesterday from sharp morning declines to finish on an even keel as leading averages are measured. Polaroid and selected oil and steel issues were market stars.

Federal District Judge A. Sherman Christensen withdrew today his $352.5-million judgment against the International Business Machines Corporation for violations of anti-trust laws. He indicated that he planned to set a lower figure later.

Joseph N. Monty, the former chief rackets investigator in the Queens District Attorney's office, went on trial in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday on charges of using his position to extort cash and the free use of cars from the Avis Rent-A-Car System.

Amid reports from at least six American states that unidentified flying objecs had been seen and even been visited, Moscow reported last night the detection of radio signals that may have originated with another civilization.

The leaders of Britain and Iceland agreed today to settle the dispute over fishing rights in Iceland's fishing zone, British of-ficials said. The agreement is conditional on the approval of the two governments.

Felix Millan followed with a single and when Bert Campaneris left his post at shortstop to cover second. base on a hit-and-run play, Rusty Staub hit one where Bert wasn't. Millan scampered home on the- wildest of wild pitches and Hunter attacked a tiny bounder off John Milner's bat as though it were a hooded cobra.

To the Editor: For the fourth time since its creation, Israel is engaged in battle with the neighboring Arab world. It is a battle which is uneven in two respects. In the first place, if Israel wins, the Arab world will endure; if the Arabs win, Israel will cease to exist.

The Roundabout Theater last night moved into its eight season with Gene Feist's staging of Strindberg's 'The Father." It was a production of this same play that in 1966 got this theater, tucked under a West 26th Street supermarket, off to its very first start.

Air Force rescue teams, searching through rough, brushy terrain, recovered early today seven bodies from the burned-out hulk of a C-130 cargo transport that crashed into a fog-enshrouded peak last night.

Thailand, which was viewed by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles as the biggest domino on the Southeast Asian mainland, has wobbled a bit in they. last few days, and nearby governments will be watching her anxiously from now on.

The Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's biggest commodities exchange, yesterday elected Warren W. Lebeck as president, ending six months of suspense among officials of the industry and Government.

YENAN, China - Maoism holds a position in contemporary China which is the equivalent of both political doctrine and ideology, almost a religion. The new party constitution specifically defines "Marxism-Leninism-Mao Tse-tung thought as the theoretical basis guiding its thinking."

Talks were resumed yesterday in the strike against the Museum of Modern Art by a union of professional and administrative workers. It was the first meeting between the two sides since the union went on strike Oct. 9.

Criticism was strong in and outside Parliament here today over its Nobel Peace Prize committee's choice of Secretary of State Kissinger of the United States and Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam as joint winners of the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize.

In fine oratorical fettle at the recent conference of the British Labor party, Harold Wilson noted tartly that the newspapers were publishing no opinion polls while it was on. His implication was that the pro-Tory press feared that an up-to-the-minute poll would show Labor with a big lead over the governing Conservatives.

Arab casualties in the Middle East war so far are four times heavier than Israel's, according to United States intelligence estimates.

Saudi Arabia, the Arab world's largest oil-producing nation, announced tonight she was cutting back oil production by 10 per cent immediately in an attempt to put pressure on the United States to reduce its support for Israel.

" I'm Mrs. Raymond Kravis from Tulsa, Oklahoma," said the woman in the sleeveless black coat with the cape back as she stepped up to shake hands with Bill Blass at Lord Taylor. "I see your things in Jackson's at home. I think it's so nice to meet the designer."

The world vinyl shortage is beginning to affect the record industry. At least two major recording companies have been forced to postpone or delay forthcoming releases because of rationing of coal-tar-based vinyl, essential in record manufacture.
The State Department of Employment Security has been ordered to pay unemployment benefits to a woman who had been denied them because she did not drive a car.

Egypt announced tonight that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union had held three long meetings in Cairo with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, presumably to discuss a diplomatic approach to settling the Middle East crisis.
" Stop the car!" the Israeli officer yelled when the first Egyptian artillery shells crashed alongside the road. "Stop it and get out!"
A pilot project to generate cultural activities in lower Manhattan and eventually in other city neighborhoods was announced yesterday by the Carnegie Hall Corporation and Pace University.
Bank loans to corporations have taken a definite downward turn, and companies have stepped up their borrowing in the commercial paper market by a record amount in recent weeks.

Violence went public in New York yesterday. In the morning, a gunman on 34th Street killed two people and wounded two others before someone else killed him, and in the afternoon two pipe bombs went off in a bank on 14th Street and left 10 people torn and bleeding.

Come Nineveh, Come Tyre by Allen Drury (Doubleday, $8.95). A weak man in the White House creates confusion on Capitol Hill. Deal Me Out by J. S. Blazer (Bobbs-Merrill, $5.95). Humorous novel about dishonor among thieves.
Jane Fonda filed a $2.8million damage suit against President Nixon and other top Government officials today, saying they had conspired to deprive her of her constitutional rights.

Merrill Lynch Co., Inc., the holding company that owns Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., has named, as expected, George L Shinn as its new president and chief operating officer. He will take over the position on Jan. 1, 1974, when Ned B. Ball will retire at the age of 65.

Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican gubernatorial candidate, stepped up today his personal attack on his Democratic opponent, Brendan T. Byrne, as pollsters continued to find voters apathetic about the Nov. 6 election.
The Philadelphia Phillies traded Ken Brett, a lefthanded pitcher, yesterday to the Pittsburgh Pirates, but there was no money involved, just Dave Cash.

A monorail, with expert lecturers, will be the style in which visitors to the Bronx Zoo's projected 40 - acre Asiatic wildlife complex will watch kinodo dragons, Siberian tigers, elephants, rhinocerous, giant bats, mouse deer, the largest wild cattle in the world and other exotic creatures from the Arabian Peninsula to Java.
Tony D'Ambrosio, aboard Sympatico, triumphed again tonight at the 28th annual Pennsylvania National Horse Show before a crowd of 4,500.

A group of Vietnam veterans who received less than honorable military discharges said today that the "bad" discharges were a result of their opposition to the Vietnam war and racism! in the armed forces and had; "stigmatized" them for life.
The admirer of the perfectly rendered novel, of Flaubert's "Madame Bovary," will not feel fully satisfied with the novels of Patrick White.
Rod Laver of Australia, the top-seeded player, was upset today by Christopher Mottram of Britain, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2, in the quarterfinals of the international Melia tennis tournament.

The professional association of Roman Catholic ecclesiastical lawyers said today that the marriage courts they administered were incapable of meeting the "realistic needs" of American Catholics and should be replaced.
Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz proposed today that Congress remove the 5 1/2 per cent interest ceiling on United States savings bonds and allow the rate to float upward with market conditions

Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society have performed many a useful service to this city's musical life in the group's quartercentury of existence. But the concert version of Mozart's "Idomeneo" that they put together on Wednesday night at Town Hall fell far short of being useful to anyone.

A woman with a rifle hijacked a French jet on a flight from Paris to Nice today and demanded to be taken to Cairo. Policemen who boarded the plane at Marseilles tried to disarm her but she opened fire and was fatally wounded in the return fire.
The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1,01-billion up 9 per cent from the yearearlier $926-million.

Two pipe bombs exploded without warning in a crowded bank off Union Square yesterday, injuring at least 10 persons, blowing out 10 of the bank's windows and sending lunchtime strollers and shoppers fleeing for cover.
The decapitated bodies of two young men, both believed to have been Black Muslims, were found this morning in a park here.
Rod Laver of Australia, the top-seeded player, was upset today by Christopher Mottram of Britain, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2, in the quarterfinals of the international Melia tennis tournament.
The United States today advanced $5.6-million to the International Commission of Control and Supervision to help the Vietnam peace-monitoring agency out of a crippling deficit.
A large Israeli armored force was locked in battle with Egyptian units tonight on the Egyptian side of the Suez Canal.

To the Editor: Once again, the U.S. is using coldwar rhetoric and nationalistic fervor to make a case for Israel. Both the press and the State Department have contributed to the inconsistencies of recent days.

The Oakland A's have been winners and they have been losers, and they know from experience that win or lose, winning is better. But beyond that they seemed monumentally undisturbed by the fact that they must win the last two games to be played in Oakland to retain the World Series title they've borne so proudly since last year.

The 7-year-old daughter of Ruggiero Boiardo, a patriarch of organized crime in New Jersey, was found dead yesterday at her home on her father's 29-acre compound here, apparently the victim of a freakish accident.
Chilean military authorities ordered the expulsion of Bo Sourander, Latin American correspondent for the leading Swedish Daily, Dagens Nyheter, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that Congress should refuse to confirm Gerald R. Ford as Vice President unless he states that President Nixon should obey court orders to release White House tapes.

Pedro Bissonette, an American Indian Movement leader in the siege of Wounded Knee, was shot and killed last night by policemen seeking him on a fugitive warrant, the authorities said today.

Dr. Aildred A. MacDonald, a pediatrician who served for 27 years as associate professor of pediatrics at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, died yesterday in Sea View Hospital, S.I., after a long illness. Dr. MacDonald, who lived at 220 Cabrini Boulevard, was 76 years old.

Walt Kelly, the cartoonist who created a pen-and-ink menagerie of Okefenokee Swamp characters in the nationally syndicated strip "Pogo," died of diabetes complications early yesterday at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital in Hollywood. He was 60 years old.

Paul Levine, the former Ecoaomic Development Administration official, said yesterday that he would resign his position with the S S Corrugated Paper Machinery Company if the Board of Ethics ruled that he broke the law in taking the job.
The Philadelphia Phillies traded Ken Brett, a lefthanded pitcher, yesterday to the Pittsburgh Pirates, but there was no money involved, just Dave Cash.

California officials demanded total access today to property tax records of President Nixon's estate at San Clemente. "If our hands are tied, we ought to tell the public something is wrong," said George Reilly, a member of the State Board of Equalization.

Brendan T. Byrne urged today the establishment of a special prosecutor's section in the State Attorney General's office to concentrate on the investigation of corruption in government.

Mention the Mets to any New Yorker, especially at World Series time, and his thoughts fly to Shea Stadium. Unless, perhaps, he happens to be a bridge enthusiast, for whom the Mets may suggest the annual Metropolitan championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which begin today at the New Bridge Association, which begin today at the New York Hilton.

Jack Kent Cooke, the wealthy California sportsman and largest shareholder in Teleprompter, Inc., has been named chairman and chief executive of the troubled company, replacing a former Pennsylvania governor, Raymond P. Shafer, it was announced yesterday.

The latest and most perilous war crisis in the Middle East appears to be rushing toward an early climax, with the forces pointing to military and diplomatic solutions running neck and neck. A decisive turning point seems near-if it has not already been reached-in the massive battles that have been raging along the Suez Canal for several days.

The foundation of C. Arnholt Smith's massive financial empire was shaken tonight when the United States National Bank of San Diego was declared insolvent by the United States Controller of the Currency.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire producer, reported yesterday a sharp drop in thirdquarter earnings despite record sales.

Tomorrow the World Series resumes here, where the left fielders and center fielders can't see a fly ball because of the low October sun. For three nights, the World Series was played in the October chill of New York, where a starting pitcher's arm stiffens after six or seven innings. Baseball advertises the World Series as its showcase event.

Mrs. Helen Childs Boyden, instructor of science and mathematics at Deerfield Academy for most of the years from 1905 to 1968, and widow of Frank L. Boyden, principal of the academy from 1902 to 1968, died today, at her home here. She was 90 years old.
If a show can be called a sleeper only three days after opening, that's the word for "Pioneers of American Abstraction" at the Andrew Crispo Gallery, 41 East 57th Street.

The two exhibitions of new work by. the American painter Al Held, currently occupying both of the Andre Emmerich galleries-uptown at 41 East 57th Street, downtown at 420 West Broadway--constitute an event of uncommon interest.

By the same token, the integrity of the nation's highest office requires scrupulous avoidance on the part of the President of even the semblance of any obligation to his friends, especiallywhen they are also his financial benefactors.

A 150-car motorcade assembled by employes of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey crawled in circles around the ramps and roadways of La Guardia Airport late yesterday in a job action that, for more than an hour, clogged traffic in defiance of a court order.

The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday it would pay approximately $96-million in back taxes to settle a longstanding legal battle with the Justice Department over excess profits taxes in question since 1950.
Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. took his appeal for votes today to the rank and file of organized labor, whose leaders are lined up solidly behind his Democratic rival, Brendan T. Byrne.
Ralph Nader again petitioned Federal court today to reopen the case of the controversial merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.
The Rev. William R. Booth, a Maryknoll missionary for 48 years, died here last Monday at the headquarters of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America. He was 74 years old.

The mounting legal troubles of C. Arnholt Smith, who for years basked in the civic accolade of "Mr. San Diego of the Century," were blamed today for the insolvency of his United States National Bank and the overnight acquisition of assets by the Crocker Bank of San Francisco.

Milton Delano was 11 or 12 years old when a retired whaling captain taught him how to etch whales' teeth. The two of them, Mr. Delano recalled recently, would sit in the back of a hearse parked in his father's garage in New Bedford, Mass. once the world's largest whaling port.
Randy Johnson found a new locker, some new plays and a new pass catcher, Brad Van Pelt, upon his return today to the New York Giants.

The Newark City Council, voting along racial lines in a tumultuous meeting, rejected today a motion to have Councilman Louis M. Turco forfeit his seat because of his plea of guilty to Federal income tax charges.

After thirty months under martial law and military domination, Turkey has taken a long stride toward restoration of full-fledged civilian government with an election that produced an upset. The Republican People's party, reorganized and redirected toward Western Europe's Social Democrats, finished well in front of the Justice party of former Premier Suleyman Demirel.
The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest petroleum company, yesterday estimated that its third-quarter earnings soared 80 per cent to $638-million from $353-million a year earlier.

Museum officials representing art and historical institutions throughout the state of New York told Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday that public disclosure of the disposal of art works by museums would seriously impair their ability to better and refine their collections.
Israeli forces drove some 15 miles into Egypt today, knocking out artillery and missile batteries and expanding their bridgehead on the western side of the Suez Canal, a military spokesman reported.
The World Series on the National Broadcasting Company, not unexpectedly, dominated prime-time television this week and wrecked the program strategies of the other networks.
Food prices fell in September for the first time this year, and as a result the Consumer Price Index posted a comparatively small rise, the Government reported today.

Margaret C. Anderson, who introduced works by Joyce, Eliot, Yeats, Pound, Hemingway and other writers in the avante-garde, in The Little Review, which she founded in 1914, died at Le Cannet, France, last night after a long illness. She was 82 years old.
John Schlee ripped five more strokes off par with a brilliant 67 today and moved into the second-round lead of the $150,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today the S.E.C. had decided to try to determine whether bank stock investment plans were illegally infringing on the securities industry.
Harrison L. Reinke headmaster of the Fay Schoo from 1942 until his retirement in 1969, died yesterday at his home here. He was 68 years old.

Richardson only minutes after former Vice President Sipiro T. Agnew made a personal appearance at the Capitol asking for a Congressional inquiry into the charges against him.
John W. Dean 3d, former Presidential counsel was unable to surrender his passport to a Federal judge today after he pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiracy in the Watergate cover-up.
The No. 2 man in the Dallas Police Deapartment, Donald A. Byrd, was appointed today to replace Chief Frank Dyson, who resigned unexpectedly on Wednesday.

The Newark City Council, voting along racial lines in a tumultuous meeting, rejected today a motion to have Councilman Louis M. Turco forfeit his seat because of his plea of guilty to Federal income tax charges.

Top-seeded Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., advanced to the semifinals of the $110,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament today at the Boca Raton Hotel and Club by defeating seventh-seeded Julie Heldman of Houston, Tex., 6-2, 6-4.

Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers ruled out today the possibility of a contract settlement by Monday's artificial deadline, leaving the No. 2 auto maker on notice of a possible strike at 10 A.M. next Friday.

Authorities in Newark disclosed yesterday that Black. Muslim literature had been found in the pockets of two young black men whose decapitated bodies were found. Thursday. They were the apparent victims of an internal struggle within the Muslims, according to police sources. Detectives are also trying to determine the connection between one of the victims, Warren A. Marcello, 30 years old, and Roger Banston, 25, who lived in the same East. Orange building.

To the Editor: Dr. D. B. Louria (letter of Sept. 14) finds no evidence that heroin-addicted criminals are excessively responsible for the upsurge in urban violence. He opposes "regressive and punitive approaches" for this group and criticizes police failure to differentiate between heroin use and dependence.

There is "little evidence" to support the professional football players' complaint that artificial turf causes more serious injuries than natural grass, the Consumer Products Safety Commission said today. It denied the National Football League Players Association's petition to halt further installations pending the establishment of safety standards for artificial turf.
An agreement for the proposed acquisition by Florida National Banks of Florida, Inc., of seven banks owned by the Charter Bankshares Corporation was announced yesterday.
From my vantage point here at the bottom of the Republic, I don't see any Great Changes coming from our Washington leadership.

The siege of the Bank of America branch seized by leftist guerrillas here yesterday ended today with policemen and army commandos fighting their way in to rescue 39 hostages. Before the battle ended, the guerrillas killed an American hostage.
Egyptian officials said tonight that an Israeli tank column that crossed to the west bank of the Suez Canal yesterday. was no longer a serious threat.
The long-awaited cut in the prime lending rate by several of the nation's largest banks helped the stock market to produce a modest gain yesterday after two days of easing prices.

A superintendent of public works and buildings for Mercer County was charged with extortion and with having filed a false income tax for 1968, according to an announcement today by United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern.

The financially ailing Harlem Prep will get a new chance to survive next week when Chancellor Irving Anker sends to the Board of Education a resolution supporting the school's efforts to be absorbed into the regular system as a city high school.
The former Premier of Thailand, ousted by rebellious students, plans to go back to his country when conditions there return to normal, his son-inlaw said today.
The board of directors of Richmond Memorial Hosiptal and Health Center on Staten Island voted last night to suspend operations at the 53-yearold institution.
Dr. Frank T. McClure, inventor of the Navy's satellite navigation system and an authority on combustion, rockets and guided-missile technology, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

Federal District Court Judge A. Sherman Christensen said today.

The head of the city's typographical union told members of its New York Times unit yesterday that he had agreed to join with the management of The Times in asking Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, to assist 'in the union's negotiations with the city's major newspapers..

After 10 consecutive months of price increases, the cost of food for the home went down by 1.2 per cent between August and September in the metropolitan area, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

Former. Justice Morris Eder of the State Supreme Court, First Judicial District, embracing New York and Bronx Counties, died yesterday in his sleep at his home, 24 Fifth Avenue. He was 86 years old.
